description: Adobe Illustrator Creative Cloud is used by both artists and graphic designers to create vector images both in print and digital form. It is typically used to create illustrations, charts, graphs, logos, diagrams, cartoons of real photographs. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: Illustrator CC
subtitle: Graphics Design Application

episodes.title: Introduction to Illustrator
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.065 --> 00:00:11.065
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.471 --> 00:00:16.195
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.195 --> 00:00:17.847
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and

4
00:00:17.847 --> 00:00:20.620
today we're gonna be going
over Adobe Illustrator CC.

5
00:00:20.620 --> 00:00:25.760
One of many programs available Within
the good old Creative Cloud suite.

6
00:00:25.760 --> 00:00:28.920
And here to help us tell us all
about the program, what we can do,

7
00:00:28.920 --> 00:00:32.050
and how to use it, is Ms.
Vonne Smith, how's it going Vonne?

8
00:00:32.050 --> 00:00:36.450
>> Good, I'm so excited to be
here to talk about Illustrator

9
00:00:36.450 --> 00:00:39.050
which is one of my favorite programs.

10
00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:44.010
It actually truly is one of my favorite
programs, I use it constantly.

11
00:00:44.010 --> 00:00:48.610
And, it's awesome so I'm really glad
to be able to share this all with you.

12
00:00:48.610 --> 00:00:50.570
First of all, what is Illustrator?

13
00:00:50.570 --> 00:00:56.800
Illustrator is the vector editing
program within the creative suite.

14
00:00:56.800 --> 00:00:59.255
It is It is used to edit vector artwork,

15
00:00:59.255 --> 00:01:04.295
create vector artwork, everything
vectors is what you use Illustrator for.

16
00:01:04.295 --> 00:01:05.875
So, what is a vector?

17
00:01:05.875 --> 00:01:09.105
>> That was my next question,
Vonne, what the heck is a vector?

18
00:01:09.105 --> 00:01:12.840
>> Exactly, so,
when you hear the word vector,

19
00:01:12.840 --> 00:01:16.700
you actually think of math which
usually starts to scare people.

20
00:01:16.700 --> 00:01:19.220
You know, [LAUGH] I don't wanna
do addition or subtraction or

21
00:01:19.220 --> 00:01:20.270
any of that kind of stuff.

22
00:01:20.270 --> 00:01:22.642
So, it's actually more like geometry.

23
00:01:22.642 --> 00:01:23.776
Do you remember geometry?

24
00:01:23.776 --> 00:01:24.670
>> Way back when.

25
00:01:24.670 --> 00:01:25.278
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

26
00:01:25.278 --> 00:01:26.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're going a little back on that one.

27
00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:31.590
But, that was actually one of my
favorite math classes because it was

28
00:01:31.590 --> 00:01:34.423
more spatial and it was drawing shapes.

29
00:01:34.423 --> 00:01:38.980
Remember drawing the isosceles
triangle is that one right there?

30
00:01:38.980 --> 00:01:41.850
>> That is an equal something triangle.

31
00:01:41.850 --> 00:01:42.763
>> We'll go with that yeah.

32
00:01:42.763 --> 00:01:44.902
[LAUGH] We'll go equilateral.

33
00:01:44.902 --> 00:01:46.123
>> I told you-
>> I think that's what it was.

34
00:01:46.123 --> 00:01:47.710
>> It's been a long time
since I did geometry.

35
00:01:47.710 --> 00:01:49.254
>> Exactly so we'll go with that so

36
00:01:49.254 --> 00:01:52.067
the equal sides I think that's
an equilateral triangle.

37
00:01:52.067 --> 00:01:52.764
All right, wonderful.

38
00:01:52.764 --> 00:01:54.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

39
00:01:54.270 --> 00:01:57.520
that's basically what you're creating
when you're creating Illustrator.

40
00:01:57.520 --> 00:02:02.380
You're creating shapes,
you're creating lines and curves and arcs.

41
00:02:02.380 --> 00:02:07.680
And the word that you always use
with vectors is the word path,

42
00:02:07.680 --> 00:02:12.740
we're creating vector paths in
Illustrator, and those path have points

43
00:02:12.740 --> 00:02:19.110
along the way and you can have open paths,
close paths, all things like that.

44
00:02:19.110 --> 00:02:22.560
When you're working with shapes,
you have insides and outsides.

45
00:02:22.560 --> 00:02:26.520
Like if I'm looking at this triangle,
I would say that it has a blue inside and

46
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:29.010
a darker blue outside.

47
00:02:29.010 --> 00:02:34.307
The technical term is fills and strokes,
you have the insides and the outsides.

48
00:02:34.307 --> 00:02:41.270
So that's what you use when you're talking
about vector graphics within Illustrator.

49
00:02:41.270 --> 00:02:42.130
>> Okay.

50
00:02:42.130 --> 00:02:45.030
>> The cool thing about
vector graphics is that

51
00:02:45.030 --> 00:02:48.920
you don't have any resolution like
you have with raster graphics

52
00:02:48.920 --> 00:02:52.690
which we'll talk a little more in
the next slide about the differences.

53
00:02:52.690 --> 00:02:57.620
So you use vectors to
where you can scale up.

54
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:00.800
Actually, let's move on
to vectors vs raster.

55
00:03:01.970 --> 00:03:06.240
When I say the word raster,
you're thinking of an actual picture.

56
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:09.830
Like a picture of a cat, or a bunny,
or anything to that effect.

57
00:03:09.830 --> 00:03:15.840
It is made up of pixels and when you have
pixels you are resolution dependent.

58
00:03:15.840 --> 00:03:20.575
It depends on the resolution of
whatever space you’re going into.

59
00:03:20.575 --> 00:03:23.800
When I mean space I'm talking about
whether you’re working in web or

60
00:03:23.800 --> 00:03:27.350
your working in print and that depends.

61
00:03:27.350 --> 00:03:31.970
And have you ever taken a picture, like
off the Internet or off your camera and

62
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:35.360
then you put it somewhere else and you
try to make it bigger and it does what?

63
00:03:35.360 --> 00:03:39.280
>> And it gets all grainy and
it just loses detail, it gets horrible.

64
00:03:39.280 --> 00:03:40.780
>> Yeah.
>> If you try to go too big if

65
00:03:40.780 --> 00:03:41.980
it starts out too small.

66
00:03:41.980 --> 00:03:46.010
>> Exactly, yes so that's the whole
thing about raster graphics

67
00:03:46.010 --> 00:03:50.780
is that you have that resolution and
that total number of pixels

68
00:03:50.780 --> 00:03:55.710
that occupy that space
of that photograph file.

69
00:03:55.710 --> 00:03:58.510
That's all you got for the most part, and

70
00:03:58.510 --> 00:04:02.580
we use Photoshop to edit
those raster graphics.

71
00:04:02.580 --> 00:04:05.660
Illustrator is used to edit
the vector graphics, and

72
00:04:05.660 --> 00:04:08.940
I have some of those kind of
common file formats on this slide.

73
00:04:08.940 --> 00:04:11.485
JPG, do these all look
somewhat familiar to you?

74
00:04:11.485 --> 00:04:13.217
>> Mm-hm, yeah.
>> I'm sure JPG is probably one that-

75
00:04:13.217 --> 00:04:13.720
>> JPG, GIF, TIFF, yeah.

76
00:04:13.720 --> 00:04:16.500
>> Everybody probably, now with
their mobile phones and everything,

77
00:04:16.500 --> 00:04:20.230
you've got your jpgs, your gifs,
your tiffs, your pngs and your bmps.

78
00:04:20.230 --> 00:04:23.750
So those are all raster graphic formats.

79
00:04:23.750 --> 00:04:29.650
Illustrator, you have the eps file,
which is an encapsulated postscript file.

80
00:04:29.650 --> 00:04:34.306
That is probably the most famous,
if you want to say,

81
00:04:34.306 --> 00:04:38.870
of the vector-capable,
or vector-compatible.

82
00:04:38.870 --> 00:04:42.410
It can hold vector information,
basically, is the EPS file.

83
00:04:42.410 --> 00:04:46.260
There's another file format when you're
talking about vectors, is the SVG,

84
00:04:46.260 --> 00:04:48.540
it's a scalable vector graphic.

85
00:04:48.540 --> 00:04:52.610
And also pdf, usually when you're
thinking of pdfs, you're thinking, right.

86
00:04:52.610 --> 00:04:55.710
>> It makes sense now though,
because I know that I can take a PDF and

87
00:04:55.710 --> 00:04:58.820
I can scale it up and
I don't lose the detail.

88
00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:01.638
Now I know why,
because it's a raster graphic.

89
00:05:01.638 --> 00:05:02.774
>> Other one.

90
00:05:02.774 --> 00:05:03.866
>> Is it sort of, sorry,
is it a vector graphic.

91
00:05:03.866 --> 00:05:05.278
>> [LAUGH] A vector graphic, yeah.

92
00:05:05.278 --> 00:05:08.460
Yeah, actually a PDF, a lot of times
when people think of PDFs, its like,

93
00:05:08.460 --> 00:05:13.830
I'm sending you a file like a Word file or
a contract or something to that effect.

94
00:05:13.830 --> 00:05:19.360
So I think people usually equate
PDFs with text documents.

95
00:05:19.360 --> 00:05:22.840
But the PDF file format can actually
hold a whole bunch of information and

96
00:05:22.840 --> 00:05:26.160
it can support vector graphics.

97
00:05:26.160 --> 00:05:30.100
So depending on what is actually in
that PDF that you're talking about,

98
00:05:30.100 --> 00:05:35.670
it could scale but that file format
can also hold raster information so

99
00:05:35.670 --> 00:05:39.450
it does have it's kinda
like a both type of thing.

100
00:05:39.450 --> 00:05:41.540
But on the other side, like a JPEG file,

101
00:05:41.540 --> 00:05:45.600
that doesn't support vectors like you
can not have any vector information

102
00:05:45.600 --> 00:05:49.980
in that file format, as along with any
of those other raster file formats.

103
00:05:49.980 --> 00:05:53.430
The vector files formats
can support vectors.

104
00:05:53.430 --> 00:05:54.510
>> Good.
>> That's how it works.

105
00:05:54.510 --> 00:05:55.520
>> Nice.
>> All right.

106
00:05:55.520 --> 00:05:56.420
Wonderful.

107
00:05:56.420 --> 00:06:00.440
So, I wanted to talk a little bit about
some of the other products that are in

108
00:06:00.440 --> 00:06:04.580
the Adobe Suite,
because these three products

109
00:06:04.580 --> 00:06:09.820
to me are the trifecta of everything for
graphic design.

110
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:11.365
There's others in the creative suite.

111
00:06:11.365 --> 00:06:16.680
But these to me are like the big guys
when you're talking about actual

112
00:06:16.680 --> 00:06:19.510
graphic design,
I think I just said that twice.

113
00:06:19.510 --> 00:06:23.444
Okay, so you have Photoshop right,
I think we had mentioned that before.

114
00:06:23.444 --> 00:06:26.797
That is your raster editing program,
you take your files or

115
00:06:26.797 --> 00:06:30.953
you take your photographs, you edit,
you put the mustache on your cat and

116
00:06:30.953 --> 00:06:32.310
everything like that.

117
00:06:32.310 --> 00:06:36.690
You put the bunny ears on your friends and
you swap faces or whatever you're doing.

118
00:06:36.690 --> 00:06:38.650
And so you edit those in Photoshop.

119
00:06:39.920 --> 00:06:44.290
Then you can take any type of
raster images that you create

120
00:06:44.290 --> 00:06:49.070
in Photoshop and you can use them as

121
00:06:49.070 --> 00:06:53.250
those images within your different
publications that you might create.

122
00:06:53.250 --> 00:06:56.200
Okay so then on the other side we
have InDesign versus Illustrator.

123
00:06:57.630 --> 00:07:03.230
Well, you can see in this kinda list down
there that I have flyers and business

124
00:07:03.230 --> 00:07:08.300
cards under Illustrator, but I also have
flyers and business cards under InDesign.

125
00:07:08.300 --> 00:07:12.870
So, this is kinda the age old, well,
which one do I use when I'm doing that?

126
00:07:12.870 --> 00:07:17.210
I've actually used both, but it really
just depends on what you need out of that

127
00:07:17.210 --> 00:07:20.290
particular publication
that you're creating.

128
00:07:20.290 --> 00:07:22.370
And this could be either for print or web.

129
00:07:22.370 --> 00:07:24.330
It's just like, which one am I designing?

130
00:07:24.330 --> 00:07:28.970
And so you can see that here we have
Illustrator is really great for

131
00:07:28.970 --> 00:07:30.990
single page layout.

132
00:07:30.990 --> 00:07:34.500
You don't really do multi-page
layouts within Illustrator.

133
00:07:34.500 --> 00:07:36.290
It just doesn't work that way.

134
00:07:36.290 --> 00:07:38.890
It doesn't have those capabilities.

135
00:07:38.890 --> 00:07:41.420
InDesign is definitely for
multi-page layouts.

136
00:07:41.420 --> 00:07:44.350
You wanna do a four page brochure?

137
00:07:44.350 --> 00:07:45.570
Go with InDesign.

138
00:07:45.570 --> 00:07:50.100
If you're talking about a single page,
it's really depending on what you need.

139
00:07:50.100 --> 00:07:54.340
If you're going for lots of text,
very text heavy documents,

140
00:07:54.340 --> 00:07:58.420
I would lean towards InDesign because
InDesign has a lot more capabilities with

141
00:07:58.420 --> 00:08:03.140
how you can style text with style.

142
00:08:03.140 --> 00:08:07.040
Illustrator has styles but
it just doesn't work as well.

143
00:08:07.040 --> 00:08:12.000
And I would not create a logo in InDesign.

144
00:08:12.000 --> 00:08:15.570
I would create it in Illustrator because
Illustrator has a lot more what I call

145
00:08:15.570 --> 00:08:16.070
crayons.

146
00:08:16.070 --> 00:08:19.120
It's got a lot more things
that you can play around with.

147
00:08:19.120 --> 00:08:22.690
And it's just got really great stuff.

148
00:08:22.690 --> 00:08:26.190
InDesign, page layout, text heavy.

149
00:08:26.190 --> 00:08:33.105
Illustrator, more creative, more crayons,
more things you can do with it.

150
00:08:33.105 --> 00:08:38.570
Another factor that would always determine
to me whether I would use InDesign

151
00:08:38.570 --> 00:08:41.160
versus Illustrator was
the package function.

152
00:08:41.160 --> 00:08:46.080
Now that's kind of old school now,
because package is actually

153
00:08:46.080 --> 00:08:50.800
in Illustrator starting in version CC6 and
above, like, what is package?

154
00:08:50.800 --> 00:08:53.070
When you think of a package,
what do you think about?

155
00:08:53.070 --> 00:08:54.060
What's a package?

156
00:08:54.060 --> 00:08:55.090
>> A Christmas present.

157
00:08:55.090 --> 00:08:56.230
>> A Christmas present, right?

158
00:08:56.230 --> 00:08:59.430
So, you have all the goodies
inside the present and

159
00:08:59.430 --> 00:09:00.940
you can take it around and move it.

160
00:09:00.940 --> 00:09:05.730
That's exactly what package
means within these two products

161
00:09:05.730 --> 00:09:10.030
because if you think about a flyer,
you're going to have some pictures,

162
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:12.230
you're going to have some logos,
you're going to have some text.

163
00:09:12.230 --> 00:09:16.930
So you're going to be using files
from other places if you wanna say

164
00:09:16.930 --> 00:09:21.610
within your computer and so,
if you're ready to transport that.

165
00:09:21.610 --> 00:09:24.040
Let's say send it to a printer or

166
00:09:24.040 --> 00:09:27.790
I'm sending it to you because you're
going to take over editing my brochure or

167
00:09:27.790 --> 00:09:33.240
something like that, you need everything
that comes along with that publication.

168
00:09:33.240 --> 00:09:37.900
And I might have put it on one hard drive,
and one folder here, one folder there.

169
00:09:37.900 --> 00:09:42.970
Package basically packages it all together
in a nice little package, in a folder.

170
00:09:42.970 --> 00:09:46.040
And that way that folder
becomes the single unit

171
00:09:46.040 --> 00:09:49.390
of all of the elements that I need for
that design.

172
00:09:49.390 --> 00:09:50.020
So it's really great.

173
00:09:50.020 --> 00:09:51.260
>> Makes it portable almost.

174
00:09:51.260 --> 00:09:52.190
>> Exactly, yeah.

175
00:09:52.190 --> 00:09:55.380
And so that was a huge determination for

176
00:09:55.380 --> 00:09:58.940
me of which product that I
was used back in the day.

177
00:09:58.940 --> 00:10:02.738
Now you got it in Illustrator and
it's super great.

178
00:10:04.485 --> 00:10:05.784
All right,
what do I have on my next slide?

179
00:10:05.784 --> 00:10:06.730
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

180
00:10:06.730 --> 00:10:07.688
>> I actually forgot what I was

181
00:10:07.688 --> 00:10:08.192
doing there.

182
00:10:08.192 --> 00:10:13.070
All right, so another important thing
to know about when you're working

183
00:10:13.070 --> 00:10:17.870
with Illustrator is what version of
Illustrator, well, do you have for

184
00:10:17.870 --> 00:10:20.797
one thing, and how that relates to others.

185
00:10:20.797 --> 00:10:25.460
If I have Adobe CC and you have Adobe Cs5.

186
00:10:25.460 --> 00:10:30.540
I create this awesome logo and
you're like can you send me that logo,

187
00:10:30.540 --> 00:10:35.020
because I wanna put it in our magazine or
something like that.

188
00:10:35.020 --> 00:10:37.606
So I send it to you,
you won't be able to open it.

189
00:10:37.606 --> 00:10:41.283
So old does not open new, okay, but

190
00:10:41.283 --> 00:10:46.431
new can open old like if you
sent me the logo that you

191
00:10:46.431 --> 00:10:51.231
created in CS5, me in CS6, no what I'm in?

192
00:10:51.231 --> 00:10:52.200
CS, CC.
>> Creative Cloud?

193
00:10:52.200 --> 00:10:53.470
>> That's what we're in.

194
00:10:53.470 --> 00:10:56.300
If I'm in CC I can open that file format.

195
00:10:56.300 --> 00:10:56.913
>> Okay.
>> Okay so

196
00:10:56.913 --> 00:11:00.991
it is something that you always need
to be aware of as a designer or

197
00:11:00.991 --> 00:11:05.085
in creating anything in Illustrator
is who else needs to use it.

198
00:11:05.085 --> 00:11:10.240
So it's always also better to stay
in the native version that you have.

199
00:11:10.240 --> 00:11:12.000
So, if you create the logo in CC,

200
00:11:12.000 --> 00:11:16.910
you should keep editing it in CC,
if at all possible.

201
00:11:16.910 --> 00:11:20.520
The reason I say that is because,
when you go down

202
00:11:20.520 --> 00:11:25.150
to lower versions of Illustrator,
you can lose some functionality, because,

203
00:11:25.150 --> 00:11:29.652
of course, the evolution of the product,
they've added a lot more crayons.

204
00:11:29.652 --> 00:11:32.450
They've added a lot more tools,
a lot more functionality.

205
00:11:32.450 --> 00:11:36.610
And so those newer versions support
all these great new things.

206
00:11:36.610 --> 00:11:38.810
The older versions don't
support all of that.

207
00:11:38.810 --> 00:11:44.601
So you could lose some of that formatting,
I guess you could say, and even more than

208
00:11:44.601 --> 00:11:50.595
that, you wouldn't be able to edit those
things in an older version of Illustrator.

209
00:11:50.595 --> 00:11:54.543
But one thing I can do in
newer versions of Illustrator,

210
00:11:54.543 --> 00:12:00.110
such as Adobe Illustrator CC, is I can
save down in compatibility for you.

211
00:12:00.110 --> 00:12:02.390
>> So if you knew somebody had
an older version of the program,

212
00:12:02.390 --> 00:12:06.510
you could save it as an older version
that they could then work with and edit.

213
00:12:06.510 --> 00:12:10.020
>> Correct, yeah I was,
I would actually take and do a Save As and

214
00:12:10.020 --> 00:12:14.150
save it as an Illustrator CS,
what do we say you're on five?

215
00:12:14.150 --> 00:12:15.435
>> Five.
>> You're on five, okay so

216
00:12:15.435 --> 00:12:17.230
I would save it as an Illustrator 5.

217
00:12:17.230 --> 00:12:20.710
It's still gonna show up
to you as an AI file.

218
00:12:20.710 --> 00:12:23.380
I see it as an AI file,
you see it as an AI file.

219
00:12:23.380 --> 00:12:25.740
So the file format doesn't change.

220
00:12:25.740 --> 00:12:29.590
It's just the compatibility
of who can actually open it.

221
00:12:29.590 --> 00:12:30.850
It's not like the DOC,

222
00:12:30.850 --> 00:12:32.850
DOCX thing that you have in-
>> Like Office.

223
00:12:32.850 --> 00:12:33.570
>> In Office.
>> Yeah.

224
00:12:33.570 --> 00:12:35.050
>> That was like a long time ago,
wasn't it?

225
00:12:35.050 --> 00:12:35.610
Okay.
[LAUGH]

226
00:12:35.610 --> 00:12:38.440
Well that's where I'm pulling from, so.

227
00:12:38.440 --> 00:12:42.630
So yeah, so you can see that as I haven't
too far, you might lose some features.

228
00:12:42.630 --> 00:12:45.220
And the different versions
I have over there on the,

229
00:12:45.220 --> 00:12:47.640
can we pop that slide there for a second.

230
00:12:47.640 --> 00:12:50.420
There we go.
I just have some different versions

231
00:12:50.420 --> 00:12:51.600
down here.

232
00:12:51.600 --> 00:12:57.120
We're in CC it goes all the way down to CS
and then is actually starts the numbers.

233
00:12:57.120 --> 00:12:57.880
So then it goes 10 to.

234
00:12:57.880 --> 00:12:59.110
>> Way back when.

235
00:12:59.110 --> 00:13:03.974
>> Yeah and do you know that I have
a little note here that illustrator 1.0

236
00:13:03.974 --> 00:13:05.822
was realized in 1987.

237
00:13:05.822 --> 00:13:06.634
>> Really?

238
00:13:06.634 --> 00:13:08.095
Wow.
>> Yes.

239
00:13:08.095 --> 00:13:09.625
Let's not talk about
where we were in 1987.

240
00:13:09.625 --> 00:13:10.134
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

241
00:13:10.134 --> 00:13:12.530
>> So we'll just go with that,

242
00:13:12.530 --> 00:13:13.810
so all right.

243
00:13:13.810 --> 00:13:16.560
So let's move on to Tips and Tricks.

244
00:13:16.560 --> 00:13:21.430
This is just me trying to give you
a little bit of insight that I have

245
00:13:21.430 --> 00:13:25.160
found from teaching this product for
over ten years,

246
00:13:25.160 --> 00:13:27.249
using the product for over ten years.

247
00:13:28.260 --> 00:13:30.520
It's all about your mouse cursor icon.

248
00:13:30.520 --> 00:13:36.310
You got to watch that little guy wherever
it's going on your screen, whatever you're

249
00:13:36.310 --> 00:13:42.150
doing in Illustrator, that's the key to
what's gonna happen when you click, okay?

250
00:13:42.150 --> 00:13:44.070
People get in and start clicking
all over the place and are like,

251
00:13:44.070 --> 00:13:44.590
why didn't it work,

252
00:13:44.590 --> 00:13:46.830
why didn't it work and I'm like well
what did the mouse cursor look like?

253
00:13:46.830 --> 00:13:47.840
I don't know.

254
00:13:47.840 --> 00:13:53.040
That's gonna be your tried tale true,
how do we say that?

255
00:13:53.040 --> 00:13:53.860
>> Tried and true?

256
00:13:53.860 --> 00:13:56.820
>> Yes, tried and
true method of what's gonna happen.

257
00:13:56.820 --> 00:13:58.850
So always watch your mouse cursor icon.

258
00:13:58.850 --> 00:14:02.280
Next thing, single click versus double
click, they do different things.

259
00:14:02.280 --> 00:14:04.185
So if you get all click happy,

260
00:14:04.185 --> 00:14:08.616
you'll get to some places where you
might not know how you got there.

261
00:14:08.616 --> 00:14:10.282
So, but we'll explain all of these and

262
00:14:10.282 --> 00:14:13.362
I'll show you all these different pit
falls to know how you can kinda back

263
00:14:13.362 --> 00:14:16.010
yourself out of a corner when
you double click too many times.

264
00:14:17.070 --> 00:14:20.742
My biggest key, learn your shortcuts,
key, did you get that?

265
00:14:20.742 --> 00:14:23.574
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Learn your keyboard shortcuts,

266
00:14:23.574 --> 00:14:28.070
it'll make you an extremely
efficient user of Illustrator.

267
00:14:28.070 --> 00:14:30.350
I didn't start out with
keyboard shortcuts.

268
00:14:30.350 --> 00:14:32.670
I had to evolve to it.

269
00:14:32.670 --> 00:14:37.065
But now that I do that like
all the time I can't go back.

270
00:14:37.065 --> 00:14:38.950
>> Mm-hm.
>> And I think you've actually,

271
00:14:38.950 --> 00:14:39.781
you've watched me.

272
00:14:39.781 --> 00:14:42.650
[LAUGH]
>> I have watched you make some documents

273
00:14:42.650 --> 00:14:45.762
in here and it's the most
amazing thing you've ever seen.

274
00:14:45.762 --> 00:14:46.768
>> [LAUGH]
>> One hand on the keyboard,

275
00:14:46.768 --> 00:14:47.385
one hand on the mouse.

276
00:14:47.385 --> 00:14:49.690
And things are flying all over the screen.

277
00:14:49.690 --> 00:14:52.810
But without those keyboard shortcuts
you wouldn't be able to do that.

278
00:14:52.810 --> 00:14:53.470
>> Yeah.

279
00:14:53.470 --> 00:14:53.970
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

280
00:14:53.970 --> 00:14:54.770
>> So very impressive.

281
00:14:54.770 --> 00:14:56.313
>> And it makes you look like you

282
00:14:56.313 --> 00:15:01.003
know what you're doing [LAUGH].
No, it just makes you look like a master

283
00:15:01.003 --> 00:15:05.670
behind the keyboard, it's just [SOUND].
So learn your shortcuts.

284
00:15:05.670 --> 00:15:08.610
There are tons of resources out there.

285
00:15:08.610 --> 00:15:10.610
So they're everywhere.

286
00:15:10.610 --> 00:15:15.040
The Internet is filled with them and
lots of great tips and tricks.

287
00:15:15.040 --> 00:15:15.840
Always keep learning.

288
00:15:15.840 --> 00:15:17.150
This product always evolves.

289
00:15:17.150 --> 00:15:19.840
You can never learn
everything about Illustrator,

290
00:15:19.840 --> 00:15:22.980
I just learned something like a couple
months ago, I was like are you serious?

291
00:15:22.980 --> 00:15:24.940
And it was like the smallest little thing,

292
00:15:24.940 --> 00:15:27.640
I don't remember what it is right now, but
it was like the tiniest little thing that

293
00:15:27.640 --> 00:15:30.499
was just like-
>> Could have saved you some time

294
00:15:30.499 --> 00:15:31.106
and, yeah.

295
00:15:31.106 --> 00:15:33.825
>> Yeah, and
we were just talking about that today,

296
00:15:33.825 --> 00:15:38.110
something in the select menu which
we'll go over in another episode.

297
00:15:38.110 --> 00:15:40.620
That I didn't learn for years, years.

298
00:15:40.620 --> 00:15:42.660
And I was like why didn't I do this?

299
00:15:42.660 --> 00:15:44.195
So I'll show you all that.

300
00:15:44.195 --> 00:15:45.050
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

301
00:15:45.050 --> 00:15:46.130
>> The other thing,

302
00:15:46.130 --> 00:15:48.060
everybody does it different.

303
00:15:48.060 --> 00:15:50.890
I use Illustrator a certain way.

304
00:15:50.890 --> 00:15:52.900
You, well I'm not sure if
you use Illustrator [LAUGH],

305
00:15:52.900 --> 00:15:54.260
but you would use it a different way.

306
00:15:54.260 --> 00:15:57.040
I use it for both print and web.

307
00:15:57.040 --> 00:16:01.031
Some people use it just for
printing or just for t-shirt design.

308
00:16:01.031 --> 00:16:04.934
So whatever way you use Illustrator
is the way that you know it and so

309
00:16:04.934 --> 00:16:10.027
it's funny when you start talking to other
people that know Illustrator really well,

310
00:16:10.027 --> 00:16:13.395
and they'll like I never do
it that way I do it this way.

311
00:16:13.395 --> 00:16:16.235
I'm like I didn't even know
you could do it that way, so

312
00:16:16.235 --> 00:16:19.840
it's like you can get to the same
end result so many different ways.

313
00:16:19.840 --> 00:16:25.310
And just keep that in mind, that it's
not a one size fits all type of product.

314
00:16:25.310 --> 00:16:27.190
Just like any of these Adobe products,
really.

315
00:16:27.190 --> 00:16:30.360
I mean Photoshop, InDesign, Illustrator,

316
00:16:30.360 --> 00:16:34.320
it's all everybody's own bag,
if you want to say it.

317
00:16:34.320 --> 00:16:37.480
I know my stuff,
if somebody came behind me,

318
00:16:37.480 --> 00:16:39.280
they'd be like,
why did they do it that way?

319
00:16:39.280 --> 00:16:42.410
That's just the way I do it, so
just kinda keep that in mind.

320
00:16:42.410 --> 00:16:47.000
And [COUGH] PDF files,
we mentioned that a couple times.

321
00:16:48.450 --> 00:16:53.650
You can do some amazing things by
opening PDFs in Illustrator, but

322
00:16:53.650 --> 00:16:55.290
it all depends on where it came from.

323
00:16:55.290 --> 00:16:58.310
If it is a PDF created from Word,

324
00:16:58.310 --> 00:17:02.110
you're not gonna be able to do too much
with it opening up in Illustrator.

325
00:17:02.110 --> 00:17:06.290
If it was created from another Adobe
product, to be created into a PDF,

326
00:17:06.290 --> 00:17:09.140
there's some really cool
things you can do with it,

327
00:17:09.140 --> 00:17:13.490
things that you would never think that,
I need to get that out of that file.

328
00:17:13.490 --> 00:17:16.366
If you open up in Illustrator,
you'd be surprised what you can do.

329
00:17:16.366 --> 00:17:19.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it will, just a little point.

330
00:17:19.040 --> 00:17:21.190
It creates a ton of clipping masks,

331
00:17:21.190 --> 00:17:25.320
you probably don't know what that is
right now, but it's just clipping mask

332
00:17:25.320 --> 00:17:30.255
heaven when you get into some PDFs
when you open up with Illustrator.

333
00:17:30.255 --> 00:17:36.479
You drill down enough in there,
you can get a lot of stuff out of the PDF.

334
00:17:36.479 --> 00:17:39.000
>> Wow, can't wait to see it.

335
00:17:39.000 --> 00:17:43.693
Vonne thanks for that information, a great
look or overview of what we can expect

336
00:17:43.693 --> 00:17:48.110
with Adobe Illustrator in the upcoming
episodes that we've got lined up for

337
00:17:48.110 --> 00:17:49.020
you out there.

338
00:17:49.020 --> 00:17:51.675
So I hope everybody out there
is as excited as I am and

339
00:17:51.675 --> 00:17:53.390
Vonne is to continue on.

340
00:17:53.390 --> 00:17:55.560
Look forward to seeing you back for
future episodes.

341
00:17:55.560 --> 00:17:56.950
For now, signing off.

342
00:17:56.950 --> 00:17:58.350
I'm Mike Rodrick.

343
00:17:58.350 --> 00:17:59.120
>> I'm Vonne Smith.

344
00:17:59.120 --> 00:18:00.230
>> And we'll see you next time.

345
00:18:00.230 --> 00:18:01.986
>> Bye.

346
00:18:01.986 --> 00:18:07.460
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Navigating in Illustrator

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.242 --> 00:00:10.242
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.580 --> 00:00:15.525
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:15.525 --> 00:00:16.370
I'm your host,

4
00:00:16.370 --> 00:00:21.090
Mike Rodrick, today we're gonna be going

5

And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:27.850
getting the program launched and
learning our way around so

7
00:00:27.850 --> 00:00:31.230

workers with Adobe Illustrator.

8
00:00:31.230 --> 00:00:34.620
And here to help guide us through
that is Ms. Vaughn Smith.

9
00:00:34.620 --> 00:00:35.740
How's it going Vaughn?

10
00:00:35.740 --> 00:00:38.110
>> Hello, I'm here to, like Mike said,

11
00:00:38.110 --> 00:00:40.730
I'm here to take you
through Adobe Illustrator.

12
00:00:40.730 --> 00:00:42.590
We're gonna go through the environment so

13
00:00:42.590 --> 00:00:46.630
we can get comfortable with all
the basics of what we're looking at.

14
00:00:46.630 --> 00:00:50.030
What are our tools,
what are our workspace, preferences,

15
00:00:50.030 --> 00:00:53.910
things like that so we can start creating

16
00:00:53.910 --> 00:00:56.640
>> I like it.
>> So I guess we should start by opening

17
00:00:56.640 --> 00:00:57.530

18
00:00:57.530 --> 00:01:00.150
So I'm going to go ahead and

19
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:04.100
And it's probably going to take just

20
00:01:04.100 --> 00:01:09.660
the good old Mac is a little old so-
>> Little tired but still kicking it.

21
00:01:09.660 --> 00:01:10.500
>> Yeah, got a new hard drive in,

22
00:01:10.500 --> 00:01:12.690
it working like a charm
>> Beautiful.

23
00:01:12.690 --> 00:01:16.420
>> All right so
when we start up Illustrator CC,

24
00:01:16.420 --> 00:01:20.710
it's always going to default to
starting at your start screen.

25
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:24.120
I don't really have much
going on on here because I,

26
00:01:24.120 --> 00:01:28.800
actually right before this episode,
I cleared all my preferences.

27
00:01:28.800 --> 00:01:34.750
I wanted to start clean so you could
see it almost like a fresh install.

28
00:01:34.750 --> 00:01:37.520
>> Cuz this is your everyday computer that
you've used and you've already done a lot

29
00:01:37.520 --> 00:01:39.730
of customizations to the interface and
things like that?

30
00:01:39.730 --> 00:01:40.280
>> Correct, yeah.

31
00:01:40.280 --> 00:01:41.368
>> So we'll have to reset all that.

32
00:01:41.368 --> 00:01:42.470
>> [CROSSTALK] I was
doing some practicing.

33
00:01:42.470 --> 00:01:45.976
Make sure I have everything ready to
go to show y'all the great things about

34
00:01:45.976 --> 00:01:47.110
Illustrator.

35
00:01:47.110 --> 00:01:49.220
So I wanted to reset it.

36
00:01:49.220 --> 00:01:52.610
And if you're curious of
how you actually do that,

37
00:01:52.610 --> 00:01:57.470
before you open Illustrator,
if you hold down, what is it?

38
00:01:57.470 --> 00:02:00.740
Command, Option, Ctrl, Shift.

39
00:02:00.740 --> 00:02:01.240
>> Wow.
>> Yeah.

40
00:02:01.240 --> 00:02:01.950
>> Now that's a keyboard

41
00:02:01.950 --> 00:02:02.630
shortcut.
[LAUGH]

42
00:02:02.630 --> 00:02:03.390
>> Exactly,

43
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:07.810
and, of course, any time I say Command,
that really is Ctrl.

44
00:02:07.810 --> 00:02:10.610
So you might have to look up
the exact Window shortcut.

45
00:02:10.610 --> 00:02:12.750
I might have thrown in an extra
key in there actually.

46
00:02:12.750 --> 00:02:15.690
But I held down a punch of keys, and

47
00:02:15.690 --> 00:02:20.700
it reset all my preferences so
I could show you it as it kind of starts.

48
00:02:21.810 --> 00:02:22.850
So anyways, that's what I did.

49
00:02:22.850 --> 00:02:26.080
We should probably look up the exact
[LAUGH] Key combinations somewhere.

50
00:02:26.080 --> 00:02:27.340
>> We'll put that in the notes for
you guys.

51
00:02:27.340 --> 00:02:28.030
>> It worked in there.

52
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:30.200
So, here's the start screen.

53
00:02:32.090 --> 00:02:35.195
I don't really like the start screen.

54
00:02:35.195 --> 00:02:36.530
[LAUGH] I don't know.

55
00:02:36.530 --> 00:02:40.830
Maybe I'm old school, we never had a start
screen in older versions of Illustrator,

56
00:02:40.830 --> 00:02:46.118
so it's just to me,
just not how I roll with it, really.

57
00:02:46.118 --> 00:02:51.519
[LAUGH] So it's up to you,
I mean I can see the benefits of it, 100%.

58
00:02:51.519 --> 00:02:53.370
It's just how I go with it.

59
00:02:53.370 --> 00:02:55.610
>> What kinda things do they have
on the start screen that we can-

60
00:02:55.610 --> 00:02:56.755
>> It can show you the most recent

61
00:02:56.755 --> 00:02:58.535
items like all the different files, so

62
00:02:58.535 --> 00:03:03.725
if you are doing a lot of different files
within a project it's all right there.

63
00:03:03.725 --> 00:03:07.905
You can also check, I have one single
file going on, you can do some previews.

64
00:03:07.905 --> 00:03:09.192
>> Nice.
>> And so you can change the,

65
00:03:09.192 --> 00:03:10.992
list view versus the icon view.

66
00:03:10.992 --> 00:03:13.497
So it's almost like your file browser.

67
00:03:13.497 --> 00:03:14.582
>> Mm-hm.
>> Okay so

68
00:03:14.582 --> 00:03:17.492
maybe it's just that I need to
get used to it a little bit more.

69
00:03:17.492 --> 00:03:22.352
[LAUGH] But I just wanted to give you that
option if you don't want the start screen,

70
00:03:22.352 --> 00:03:24.082
you can change the preferences.

71
00:03:24.082 --> 00:03:28.222
And it's actually right here on the start
screen in the upper right hand corner.

72
00:03:28.222 --> 00:03:31.040
There is the little wheel guy up here.

73
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:33.370
To where it actually
kinda gives you like hey,

74
00:03:33.370 --> 00:03:36.520
if you don't wanna see this start menu-
>> Mm-hm.

75
00:03:36.520 --> 00:03:40.400
>> When you start, you can go into
your preferences and change it.

76
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:46.750
>> Okay, so just kinda gives you a little
heads up that that's what you want to do.

77
00:03:46.750 --> 00:03:49.710
So, and let's talk about
the preferences for a brief moment.

78
00:03:49.710 --> 00:03:53.470
If you're on a Mac, you're preferences

79
00:03:53.470 --> 00:03:57.842
are always going to be in your Illustrator
menu, so illustrator preferences.

80
00:03:57.842 --> 00:04:01.500
If you're on a Windows machine, your
preferences are always in your edit menu.

81
00:04:01.500 --> 00:04:04.970
So it's always done on the bottom, so
edit preferences goes to that same thing.

82
00:04:04.970 --> 00:04:09.380
So you can see that right here from
my Illustrator preferences and

83
00:04:09.380 --> 00:04:13.220
if I go in general,
you can see right there.

84
00:04:13.220 --> 00:04:18.610
That is the show start workspace
when no documents are open.

85
00:04:18.610 --> 00:04:22.680
So that's the checkbox that's on by
default, so you can turn them off.

86
00:04:24.250 --> 00:04:26.910
>> Nice.
>> And just an overview about preferences.

87
00:04:26.910 --> 00:04:29.020
It's exactly what it sounds like,

88
00:04:29.020 --> 00:04:32.840
it's the preferences of your program,
and there's a lot of things in here.

89
00:04:32.840 --> 00:04:35.710
I mean, half of them, honestly,
I probably don't even know what they do.

90
00:04:35.710 --> 00:04:40.250
But, it's things that we'll probably be
going through as we go through episodes.

91
00:04:40.250 --> 00:04:44.250
I'll pull up, hey, this is a really good
point to point out, this preference,

92
00:04:44.250 --> 00:04:47.240
either turn it on or turn it off.

93
00:04:47.240 --> 00:04:49.600
But you can see over here
on the left hand side,

94
00:04:49.600 --> 00:04:53.540
it has all the different topics,
the units, and the guides.

95
00:04:53.540 --> 00:04:55.870
Great, one thing I would like to
point out right from the start,

96
00:04:55.870 --> 00:04:57.850
is the user interface.

97
00:04:57.850 --> 00:05:01.640
You see right now everything
is very medium dark.

98
00:05:01.640 --> 00:05:06.040
This is a newer feature that they started
doing in some of the CC products, or

99
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:10.550
maybe even CS 6, where you can actually
change the background color for

100
00:05:10.550 --> 00:05:14.090
you overall look of what
you've got going on.

101
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:18.100
So you can see if I make it lighter,
everything turns light, or

102
00:05:18.100 --> 00:05:19.710
you can go with a darker view.

103
00:05:19.710 --> 00:05:20.250
>> Nice.

104
00:05:20.250 --> 00:05:23.080
>> Yeah, so it's that kind of contrast,
whether you want white on dark, or

105
00:05:23.080 --> 00:05:23.825
dark on white.

106
00:05:23.825 --> 00:05:24.550
>> Mm-hm.

107
00:05:24.550 --> 00:05:30.070
>> It really is a personal preference I
tend to like it a little bit lighter for

108
00:05:30.070 --> 00:05:31.190
demonstration purposes.

109
00:05:31.190 --> 00:05:33.710
But see, it's got that kind of,
right at 50, it goes,

110
00:05:33.710 --> 00:05:36.360
like ooh, way too much and way too dark.

111
00:05:36.360 --> 00:05:42.070

00:17:10.740 --> 00:17:11.710
can we combine them.

341
00:17:11.710 --> 00:17:13.566
And I guess you can,
by making your own custom player.

342
00:17:13.566 --> 00:17:16.530
>> Exactly, but I like a lot of
the things that Essential gives me.

343
00:17:16.530 --> 00:17:20.340
And I do like to have it expanded,
but there is things that I am missing.

344
00:17:20.340 --> 00:17:22.530
Like, I'm missing the Character panel.

345
00:17:22.530 --> 00:17:24.130
I'm missing the Paragraph panel.

346
00:17:24.130 --> 00:17:26.240
There's the Pathfinder panel.

347
00:17:26.240 --> 00:17:28.120
I use that all the time.

348
00:17:28.120 --> 00:17:29.050
Where are they?

349
00:17:29.050 --> 00:17:30.820
Like, they're not in these presets.

350
00:17:30.820 --> 00:17:33.135
So, where do I go to find them?

351
00:17:33.135 --> 00:17:35.930
In all of your Adobe products,
you always go to your Window menu.

352
00:17:35.930 --> 00:17:37.915
Your Window menu is where you can go and

353
00:17:37.915 --> 00:17:40.718
find every panel that you
could ever think of, okay.

354
00:17:40.718 --> 00:17:43.694
So that you're kind of, it's weird,
because you say, you think View,

355
00:17:43.694 --> 00:17:45.340
like I want to see what I'm looking at.

356
00:17:45.340 --> 00:17:47.940
It's not, it's your Window, okay?

357
00:17:47.940 --> 00:17:50.758
So you can see here,
that I've got all sorts of things in here.

358
00:17:50.758 --> 00:17:53.990
And because my resolution's down
a little low so you guys can see it,

359
00:17:53.990 --> 00:17:57.820
I have to scroll through that,
there are a ton of panels in Illustrator.

360
00:17:57.820 --> 00:18:01.520
So you can see in the Type group,
I have Character right there.

361
00:18:01.520 --> 00:18:04.320
So I can bring up this Character,
which brings up these three.

362
00:18:04.320 --> 00:18:06.260
I don't always need the open type.

363
00:18:06.260 --> 00:18:08.420
I did ten I'll keep it there,
we'll keep it.

364
00:18:08.420 --> 00:18:11.240
But I want to,
I don't want it free flowing.

365
00:18:11.240 --> 00:18:12.910
So I just pull it into here.

366
00:18:12.910 --> 00:18:14.790
Now I can put it in with that same group.

367
00:18:14.790 --> 00:18:17.350
Remember the blue lines where
I can put it in between, so

368
00:18:17.350 --> 00:18:19.685
I can kinda give it it's own little space.

369
00:18:19.685 --> 00:18:20.670
>> Mm-hm.

370
00:18:20.670 --> 00:18:22.400
>> I can close out other things.

371
00:18:22.400 --> 00:18:24.988
I mean,
I actually use a lot of this stuff, so.

372
00:18:24.988 --> 00:18:28.210
[LAUGH] Maybe we'll cut out the Libraries,
just because.

373
00:18:28.210 --> 00:18:32.000
And I can click on the Panel Options, and

374
00:18:32.000 --> 00:18:37.478
I can delete the Library, or
I can just pull this out here.

375
00:18:37.478 --> 00:18:39.032
And I can then close that there,

376
00:18:39.032 --> 00:18:43.290
there's a whole bunch of ways that you can
kind of take panels out and put them in.

377
00:18:43.290 --> 00:18:49.748
So maybe this is exactly how I
want to have my panels arranged.

378
00:18:49.748 --> 00:18:54.416
I can come into here, and
I can go to New Workspace.

379
00:18:54.416 --> 00:18:56.337
And this does include your tools,

380
00:18:56.337 --> 00:19:00.458
placement stuff that we haven't gone
to that side of the screen just yet.

381
00:19:00.458 --> 00:19:03.188
But we'll get there in a second,
but I wanted to point that out.

382
00:19:03.188 --> 00:19:08.168
You go to New Workspace and
I can say Vaughan, right?

383
00:19:08.168 --> 00:19:09.148
>> Mm-hm.

384
00:19:09.148 --> 00:19:14.058
>> And now I have a workspace
that is part of the program.

385
00:19:14.058 --> 00:19:16.614
Close it, come back three weeks later,

386
00:19:16.614 --> 00:19:20.988
it's still gonna be in my list of
preset workspaces from here on out.

387
00:19:20.988 --> 00:19:21.600
>> Nice.

388
00:19:21.600 --> 00:19:24.218
>> So I could switch to Essentials, okay.

389
00:19:24.218 --> 00:19:26.490
Well, wait, why didn't it switch back?

390
00:19:26.490 --> 00:19:27.624
Why didn't that change?

391
00:19:27.624 --> 00:19:28.301
>> I don't know.

392
00:19:28.301 --> 00:19:29.595
>> [LAUGH] I don't know.

393
00:19:29.595 --> 00:19:30.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's because that's what

394
00:19:30.740 --> 00:19:31.570
we started with.

395
00:19:31.570 --> 00:19:32.635
We started with Essentials.

396
00:19:32.635 --> 00:19:33.220
>> Uh-huh.

397
00:19:33.220 --> 00:19:34.980
>> We customized it.

398
00:19:34.980 --> 00:19:38.700
>> And it's still remembering all of
those like, on the fly customizations.

399
00:19:38.700 --> 00:19:40.630
>> So
we need to reset Essentials at this point.

400
00:19:40.630 --> 00:19:41.430
>> Bingo.

401
00:19:41.430 --> 00:19:46.340
So if I reset Essentials, that goes
back to the way Essentials looks.

402
00:19:46.340 --> 00:19:49.536
I go to mine, and then it goes
back to the way that I like it.

403
00:19:49.536 --> 00:19:51.070
>> Gotcha, very nice.

404
00:19:51.070 --> 00:19:52.060
>> Yeah, it's great.

405
00:19:52.060 --> 00:19:55.789
So that's where if you have different
projects that you are working on that you

406
00:19:55.789 --> 00:19:59.307
need some panels for some things and
certain panels for the other things.

407
00:19:59.307 --> 00:20:01.690
Just save them as workspaces and
you can do that.

408
00:20:01.690 --> 00:20:05.110
So I’ve done project specific workspaces,

409
00:20:05.110 --> 00:20:09.348
just my specific workspaces
the way that I like things.

410
00:20:09.348 --> 00:20:13.390
And that’s what you can do with
your workspaces in Illustrator, and

411
00:20:13.390 --> 00:20:15.310
all of your Adobe products.

412
00:20:15.310 --> 00:20:17.076
>> Nice.
>> So, let's move over to tools.

413
00:20:17.076 --> 00:20:20.156
Let's go to the left-hand
side of the screen.

414
00:20:20.156 --> 00:20:21.914
Kind of the same stuff right here.

415
00:20:21.914 --> 00:20:24.890
Actually, I changed this before
we started this episode.

416
00:20:24.890 --> 00:20:29.770
I'm almost positive that it starts
as one single column when you start

417
00:20:29.770 --> 00:20:31.690
Illustrator by default.

418
00:20:31.690 --> 00:20:34.860
The two little triangles there on
the left-hand side can take it into two

419
00:20:34.860 --> 00:20:36.770
columns versus a single column.

420
00:20:38.340 --> 00:20:41.264
Again, I'm used to seeing
my tools in two columns, so

421
00:20:41.264 --> 00:20:46.220
that's just where I know where
tools are in a two column layout.

422
00:20:46.220 --> 00:20:47.688
I don't know where they are when
they're in single columns.

423
00:20:47.688 --> 00:20:48.698
>> Yeah, you gotta hunt and find them.

424
00:20:48.698 --> 00:20:50.098
>> Yeah, it's like muscle memory, right.

425
00:20:50.098 --> 00:20:51.830
I just know where they are.

426
00:20:51.830 --> 00:20:54.620
So I like to keep them
in the two column setup.

427
00:20:55.820 --> 00:20:59.640
There's some cool, new things
that you can do with your tools.

428
00:20:59.640 --> 00:21:02.420
You can actually make
your own toolbars now.

429
00:21:02.420 --> 00:21:03.887
What they've done,

430
00:21:03.887 --> 00:21:08.868
is they've like separated out the panels
from the tools in a workspace.

431
00:21:08.868 --> 00:21:10.540
It was always one entity.

432
00:21:10.540 --> 00:21:13.800
Like your workspace was the whole shebang.

433
00:21:13.800 --> 00:21:17.250
Now you can separate your tools
separate from your panels and

434
00:21:17.250 --> 00:21:18.088
put them in your workspaces.

435
00:21:18.088 --> 00:21:21.920
They're in your Window menu,
and you go to Tools,

436
00:21:21.920 --> 00:21:26.010
you can see you can actually
make a New Tools Panel.

437
00:21:26.010 --> 00:21:29.250
And it starts out,
I'm just gonna go for it now.

438
00:21:29.250 --> 00:21:32.821
So let's just go Test2,
cuz I might have a Test1 in there.

439
00:21:32.821 --> 00:21:39.178
[LAUGH] So you can see that it's just
kind of got the start of a tools panel.

440
00:21:39.178 --> 00:21:44.638
And then what you can do is you can
just drag and drop tools that you like,

441
00:21:44.638 --> 00:21:50.190
like maybe I only use the pen, the brush,
the seahorse tool as I call it.

442
00:21:50.190 --> 00:21:51.150
[LAUGH] It's the width tool.

443
00:21:52.780 --> 00:21:54.750
And maybe like the black arrow or
something like that.

444
00:21:54.750 --> 00:21:58.660
Those are the only tools I ever
use in Illustrator, like ever.

445
00:22:00.640 --> 00:22:01.630
That's your tool now.

446
00:22:01.630 --> 00:22:06.170
So you could take this guy and
you could close this guy out and

447
00:22:06.170 --> 00:22:08.230
then this is my tool.

448
00:22:08.230 --> 00:22:08.975
And then that's all I need.

449
00:22:08.975 --> 00:22:13.120
And if I wanted too I could switch
back and go back to my default.

450
00:22:13.120 --> 00:22:17.870
And then, my other guy is still there, and
then I can just bring back, I close them.

451
00:22:17.870 --> 00:22:18.730
And I can bring them back.

452
00:22:18.730 --> 00:22:21.330
So it's like you can
customize your toolbox.

453
00:22:21.330 --> 00:22:23.040
>> Wow.
>> Specifically to what you want.

454
00:22:23.040 --> 00:22:28.200
>> So you can really customize this
interface to exactly what you need, and

455
00:22:28.200 --> 00:22:30.940
just make it more efficient,
and really easier and

456
00:22:30.940 --> 00:22:32.430
almost pleasurable to work with.

457
00:22:32.430 --> 00:22:34.670
Because you know where everything is,
it's right where you want it.

458
00:22:34.670 --> 00:22:38.580
You're not stuck using somebody
else's idea of where stuff should be.

459
00:22:38.580 --> 00:22:40.940
>> It's all about you.

460
00:22:40.940 --> 00:22:43.630
All about you and what you want.

461
00:22:43.630 --> 00:22:45.142
Adobe will give it to you.

462
00:22:45.142 --> 00:22:48.292
I'm gonna go ahead and
close that little tools panel out.

463
00:22:48.292 --> 00:22:51.110
I'm gonna go ahead and
just reset my tools.

464
00:22:51.110 --> 00:22:53.170
Actually I'm just gonna
dock it back in here.

465
00:22:53.170 --> 00:22:55.530
So see, it's kind of got that,
see that little blue line?

466
00:22:55.530 --> 00:22:57.650
That lets me know that I've docked it.

467
00:22:57.650 --> 00:23:00.350
Because people will undock things and
they kind of freak out and

468
00:23:00.350 --> 00:23:03.250
they don't know what happened, so
just know that you've got that.

469
00:23:03.250 --> 00:23:04.100
>> Been there, done that.

470
00:23:04.100 --> 00:23:05.230
>> Yeah, right?

471
00:23:05.230 --> 00:23:08.540
And we'll go over all the tools and
details as we go through these episodes,

472
00:23:08.540 --> 00:23:11.170
so we don't need to go
over every single name.

473
00:23:11.170 --> 00:23:14.170
You do have the hover to discover
on any of your tools here.

474
00:23:14.170 --> 00:23:15.990
So if I hover over,
this is the rectangle tool.

475
00:23:15.990 --> 00:23:19.040
One thing I would like to point out now,
is that you see how,

476
00:23:19.040 --> 00:23:22.288
I'm trying to get the little guy,
that's not gonna let me go.

477
00:23:22.288 --> 00:23:23.296
I was trying to zoom in so
you guys could see it.

478
00:23:23.296 --> 00:23:28.289
But in the parentheses after every
tool tip name that you get when you

479
00:23:28.289 --> 00:23:31.892
hover to discover,
in parentheses is a letter.

480
00:23:31.892 --> 00:23:34.092
That letter indicates the hotkey.

481
00:23:34.092 --> 00:23:39.458
Okay, so the black arrow tool is the V,
just straight up V.

482
00:23:39.458 --> 00:23:42.878
And like the hand tool,
what do you think the hand tool might be?

483
00:23:42.878 --> 00:23:43.458
>> H.

484
00:23:43.458 --> 00:23:48.378
>> Yes, if you click the h it's going to
actually, now I tell you that and well,

485
00:23:48.378 --> 00:23:50.860
why isn't it working?

486
00:23:50.860 --> 00:23:51.520
Well anyways.

487
00:23:51.520 --> 00:23:53.401
It will work, so [LAUGH].

488
00:23:53.401 --> 00:23:57.016
When you go ahead and do your hotkeys,
but for some reason mine's not,

489
00:23:57.016 --> 00:23:57.929
we'll fix that.

490
00:23:57.929 --> 00:23:59.064
We'll just click on it for now.

491
00:23:59.064 --> 00:23:59.977
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

492
00:23:59.977 --> 00:24:01.091
>> Whoops, that backfired.

493
00:24:01.091 --> 00:24:05.683
Anyways, start recognizing them,
start learning those hot keys.

494
00:24:05.683 --> 00:24:09.071
Because that's another one of those things
where you can switch to different tools by

495
00:24:09.071 --> 00:24:11.422
just using your keyboard, and
you don't have to go over and

496
00:24:11.422 --> 00:24:12.850
click to get the tool that you need.

497
00:24:12.850 --> 00:24:17.460
But it is all about what tool
is in my hand to be able My-

498
00:24:17.460 --> 00:24:19.020
>> And we don't have a document open, so

499
00:24:19.020 --> 00:24:21.410
it's probably not letting us
switch to some of those tools.

500
00:24:21.410 --> 00:24:23.296
>> My gosh, I think you're right.

501
00:24:23.296 --> 00:24:24.070
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

502
00:24:24.070 --> 00:24:25.635
>> Hey, point for you!

503
00:24:25.635 --> 00:24:27.048
>> [NOISE]
>> Yay, good job.

504
00:24:27.048 --> 00:24:28.873
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Thank you.

505
00:24:28.873 --> 00:24:29.940
[LAUGH]
>> Awesome.

506
00:24:29.940 --> 00:24:33.920
So, that is the interface overall.

507
00:24:33.920 --> 00:24:36.925
Maybe just a few little points and
then we'll wrap this up.

508
00:24:36.925 --> 00:24:37.770
>> Mm-hm.

509
00:24:37.770 --> 00:24:40.470
>> One thing I, the tear off.

510
00:24:40.470 --> 00:24:41.650
Tear off right.

511
00:24:41.650 --> 00:24:43.990
This rectangle tool.

512
00:24:43.990 --> 00:24:46.520
This has multiple tools within it.

513
00:24:46.520 --> 00:24:48.350
As I call it under it.

514
00:24:48.350 --> 00:24:52.230
You know this because of the little
triangle that's on the bottom right hand

515
00:24:52.230 --> 00:24:55.955
corner of that tool, so
that let's you know that there's more.

516
00:24:55.955 --> 00:24:56.565
So if you click and

517
00:24:56.565 --> 00:25:00.795
hold on your mouse it actually
kind of flies out the other tools.

518
00:25:00.795 --> 00:25:03.575
And this is very similar
to all your products.

519
00:25:03.575 --> 00:25:07.305
But if I get there, okay that's great,
so if I want to come down and

520
00:25:07.305 --> 00:25:08.095
get the polygon tool.

521
00:25:08.095 --> 00:25:10.785
But now, what if I want to come back and
get the circle tool.

522
00:25:10.785 --> 00:25:16.450
Gotta click and hold and I go there
again this little guy right at the end,

523
00:25:16.450 --> 00:25:18.940
that, that is called a tear off.

524
00:25:18.940 --> 00:25:22.690
Okay, now I'm holding my mouse down as I'm
hovering over this because if I hold my

525
00:25:22.690 --> 00:25:26.990
mouse and let go over the tear off,

526
00:25:26.990 --> 00:25:30.910
it actually tears off this little tool.

527
00:25:30.910 --> 00:25:37.620
This little tool box of those particular
embedded or underneath or inside, tools.

528
00:25:37.620 --> 00:25:39.280
Like if I go over here to the seahorse,

529
00:25:39.280 --> 00:25:41.710
there's a lot of,
again sorry, the width tool.

530
00:25:41.710 --> 00:25:45.650
The width tool actually has
a lot of cool tools in here so

531
00:25:45.650 --> 00:25:48.920
if I could just tear this off,
then I can pull this up here.

532
00:25:48.920 --> 00:25:53.450
You know the pen tool, I use these all
the time when we talk about the pen, and

533
00:25:53.450 --> 00:25:56.270
you can actually see they kind
of snap next to each other.

534
00:25:56.270 --> 00:26:02.140
So you can tear off these part of
the tools are these multiple tools and

535
00:26:02.140 --> 00:26:04.010
have them available for you there.

536
00:26:04.010 --> 00:26:04.660
>> Nice.

537
00:26:04.660 --> 00:26:09.310
So then again, fully customizing
that interface to whatever you need.

538
00:26:09.310 --> 00:26:09.960
>> Exactly.

539
00:26:09.960 --> 00:26:11.580
So.
All right.

540
00:26:12.720 --> 00:26:14.460
So it brought us a lot of information.

541
00:26:14.460 --> 00:26:16.340
Again, learning that interface.

542
00:26:16.340 --> 00:26:18.080
Always important with any program and

543
00:26:18.080 --> 00:26:20.070
especially with this because
there's a lot to it.

544
00:26:20.070 --> 00:26:21.510
We've got panels, we've got tools,

545
00:26:21.510 --> 00:26:23.750
we haven't even opened up
our first document yet.

546
00:26:23.750 --> 00:26:25.230
We've got menus across the top.

547
00:26:25.230 --> 00:26:26.270
So thanks for that.

548
00:26:26.270 --> 00:26:27.420
Appreciate all that information.

549
00:26:27.420 --> 00:26:29.000
Anything else you want to throw in for
this episode?

550
00:26:30.140 --> 00:26:30.800
I don't think so,

551
00:26:30.800 --> 00:26:34.980
I think we've covered enough we'll
probably make a part two of this one too.

552
00:26:34.980 --> 00:26:36.050
>> Okay, so we've got more to go.

553
00:26:36.050 --> 00:26:39.350
All right, well there you go ladies and
gentleman we've got more to cover with

554
00:26:39.350 --> 00:26:42.850
that user interface, but we're gonna have
to come back for a part two for that.

555
00:26:42.850 --> 00:26:45.390
So, for now I hope you guys
enjoyed watching this one.

556
00:26:45.390 --> 00:26:47.140
Signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

557
00:26:47.140 --> 00:26:47.920
>> I'm Vaughn Smith.

558
00:26:47.920 --> 00:26:49.554
>> And we'll see you next time.

559
00:26:49.554 --> 00:26:54.800

>> Yep, yeah [LAUGH] A lot of ways.

249
00:11:30.470 --> 00:11:34.150
I never use those tools,
I never use those menu commands.

250
00:11:34.150 --> 00:11:37.590
I still do them,
I just do it all through shortcuts.

251
00:11:37.590 --> 00:11:43.050
So, control zero, control minus,
control plus then the other ones that

252
00:11:43.050 --> 00:11:48.240
I call part of the big six is
the toggles as we call it.

253
00:11:48.240 --> 00:11:52.820
It's like, I wanna temporarily use that
tool without actually switching to

254
00:11:52.820 --> 00:11:55.680
the tool and having to switch back
to the tool I have in my hand.

255
00:11:55.680 --> 00:11:58.150
I just wanna zoom in, move around, but

256
00:11:58.150 --> 00:12:01.130
always stay in this black arrow
tool that I have right now.

257
00:12:01.130 --> 00:12:04.720
Cuz right now, I just have the select
tool that I've got going on, and

258
00:12:04.720 --> 00:12:07.470
so, don't wanna switch.

259
00:12:07.470 --> 00:12:10.820
You hold your command and a spacebar down.

260
00:12:10.820 --> 00:12:12.860
So, you keep those keys held down.

261
00:12:12.860 --> 00:12:17.447
So, command or control spacebar, it
actually shows the mouse cursor icon that

262
00:12:17.447 --> 00:12:22.480
you have a zoom and then I can click,
click, click, click and kinda move around.

263
00:12:22.480 --> 00:12:27.700
I let got of my keys and
now I'm still in the black tool.

264
00:12:27.700 --> 00:12:31.306
I used the zoom and I stayed in the tool.

265
00:12:31.306 --> 00:12:33.190
>> Nice.
>> Very, very handy, so

266
00:12:33.190 --> 00:12:35.010
Ctrl+0 to zoom back out.

267
00:12:36.340 --> 00:12:39.230
Something you can do with that
zoom tool instead of click, click,

268
00:12:39.230 --> 00:12:42.290
click is you can do what
I call a zoom marquee.

269
00:12:42.290 --> 00:12:46.852
You click, hold and drag with
the zoom tool to make a rectangle or

270
00:12:46.852 --> 00:12:49.316
whatever a space that you want to.

271
00:12:49.316 --> 00:12:54.459
That becomes my zoom, and it just goes.

272
00:12:54.459 --> 00:12:57.153
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> So, I'm gonna use my toggle again,

273
00:12:57.153 --> 00:12:58.748
I'm gonna use my control spacebar.

274
00:12:58.748 --> 00:13:00.490
I'm gonna click hold and drag.

275
00:13:00.490 --> 00:13:04.260
So, I'm dragging a little box
around that arts and crafts.

276
00:13:04.260 --> 00:13:09.810
I let go of my mouse, I let go of
my keyboard and now I've zoomed in.

277
00:13:09.810 --> 00:13:12.230
Now I'm doing that very, very slowly,
but I did wanna emphasize.

278
00:13:12.230 --> 00:13:13.847
I let go of the mouse first and

279
00:13:13.847 --> 00:13:17.693
then let go of the keys because if
you don't keep the keys held down,

280
00:13:17.693 --> 00:13:21.829
it's gonna stop toggling, and
then it's gonna kinda do weird things.

281
00:13:21.829 --> 00:13:26.421
So, I can get to a specific zoom
magnification that I wanna get to by

282
00:13:26.421 --> 00:13:31.431
toggling to the zoom tool, get in
that marquee, going where I wanna be.

283
00:13:31.431 --> 00:13:32.011
And there you go.

284
00:13:32.011 --> 00:13:35.730
Now, while I'm here,
I wanna, I'm zoomed in.

285
00:13:35.730 --> 00:13:37.160
I like the zoom magnification, but

286
00:13:37.160 --> 00:13:41.800
I wanna kinda move over to the,
something with the treats.

287
00:13:41.800 --> 00:13:43.220
I can't remember what's over there.

288
00:13:43.220 --> 00:13:48.550
So, my temporary toggle to access
my hand tool is just the space bar.

289
00:13:48.550 --> 00:13:53.070
So, I hold the space bar down, got that
little hand, I click hold and drag.

290
00:13:53.070 --> 00:13:55.003
Tasty Treats that's what it says [LAUGH].

291
00:13:55.003 --> 00:13:58.330
So, we've got Tasty Treats right here,
I let go of the mouse.

292
00:13:58.330 --> 00:14:01.100
I let go of the key and now I'm here.

293
00:14:01.100 --> 00:14:02.950
So, use that space bar.

294
00:14:02.950 --> 00:14:04.950
I can kinda drag round until
I'm where I need to be.

295
00:14:04.950 --> 00:14:08.030
I move over here, now I'm there.

296
00:14:08.030 --> 00:14:10.080
I need to zoom out just a little bit,
control minus,

297
00:14:10.080 --> 00:14:12.730
because I need to see all the flowers.

298
00:14:12.730 --> 00:14:13.830
Okay, I do what I need to do.

299
00:14:13.830 --> 00:14:16.856
Now, I need to see the whole
document again, so control zero.

300
00:14:16.856 --> 00:14:20.709
Now I need to zoom back down in here
on Lucky's Orchard, command space,

301
00:14:20.709 --> 00:14:25.010
hold those keys, click hold and drag,
make a box, okay little too much.

302
00:14:25.010 --> 00:14:30.257
So, you can see that just using
those alone can just move your.

303
00:14:30.257 --> 00:14:32.440
Half a time and you're like,
wow you're doing so many things.

304
00:14:32.440 --> 00:14:34.230
I'm like, I'm just zooming.

305
00:14:34.230 --> 00:14:36.250
[LAUGH] I'm actually not doing anything.

306
00:14:36.250 --> 00:14:37.810
I'm just moving around the documents.

307
00:14:37.810 --> 00:14:38.663
>> Don't tell everybody that.

308
00:14:38.663 --> 00:14:39.174
>> Yeah, right.

309
00:14:39.174 --> 00:14:43.400
[LAUGH] Yeah,
you can look pretty great that way.

310
00:14:43.400 --> 00:14:45.051
So that was, I said six, didn't I?

311
00:14:45.051 --> 00:14:47.100
>> Mm-hm, the big six.

312
00:14:47.100 --> 00:14:47.901
>> If you're counting.

313
00:14:47.901 --> 00:14:48.986
>> Let's see, we've got.

314
00:14:48.986 --> 00:14:50.588
>> [LAUGH]
>> I can't remember now.

315
00:14:50.588 --> 00:14:51.238
>> Yeah, exactly.

316
00:14:51.238 --> 00:14:52.760
>> You've got the Ctrl+0, right?

317
00:14:52.760 --> 00:14:53.510
We talked about that.

318
00:14:53.510 --> 00:14:58.180
You've got the Ctrl+minus and
the Ctrl+plus, we've got the zoom tool.

319
00:14:58.180 --> 00:14:58.960
>> Toggle to the zoom.

320
00:14:58.960 --> 00:15:00.925
>> Toggle to the zoom, toggle to the hand.

321
00:15:00.925 --> 00:15:01.970
>> Mm-hm.

322
00:15:01.970 --> 00:15:02.690
We're one short.

323
00:15:02.690 --> 00:15:03.559
>> Exactly.

324
00:15:03.559 --> 00:15:04.261
>> That's our last one.

325
00:15:04.261 --> 00:15:10.183
>> [LAUGH] Our last one that you can
use to zoom in is if you have a mouse,

326
00:15:10.183 --> 00:15:15.919
now if you're on a touchpad it's
not gonna necessarily work.

327
00:15:15.919 --> 00:15:18.677
But, I know now you can do it
with gestures and everything, but

328
00:15:18.677 --> 00:15:20.980
if you are using a mouse
because I like to use a mouse.

329
00:15:20.980 --> 00:15:26.447
If you hold your alt key or option,
hold the ALT OPT key and scrolly wheel up.

330
00:15:26.447 --> 00:15:32.079
You can actually scrolly in, like zoom in,
and the technical term is scrolly.

331
00:15:32.079 --> 00:15:34.625
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so you scrolly wheel up,

332
00:15:34.625 --> 00:15:37.820
you scrolly wheel down and
you can zoom in and out.

333
00:15:37.820 --> 00:15:41.420
And it will actually focus
wherever your mouse is located.

334
00:15:41.420 --> 00:15:46.330
See I'm zoom there, move my mouse down and
see how I'm kinda focusing down on there.

335
00:15:46.330 --> 00:15:50.586
So, holding that alt and scrolling with
your mouse will actually move you to that

336
00:15:50.586 --> 00:15:53.651
specific [INAUDIBLE] So,
that's the sixth one.

337
00:15:53.651 --> 00:15:54.989
>> There we go.

338
00:15:54.989 --> 00:15:56.495
The suspense was killing me.

339
00:15:56.495 --> 00:15:57.475
I'm glad you got that one out.

340
00:15:57.475 --> 00:16:00.647
>> [LAUGH] Good, I'm glad, I'm glad.

341
00:16:00.647 --> 00:16:03.372
So that's all the basics of zooming,

342
00:16:03.372 --> 00:16:08.070
wanted to do one last thing with
work with multiple files, okay.

343
00:16:08.070 --> 00:16:11.810
And these little tear offs are kind of

00:16:11.810 --> 00:16:12.320
close this off.

345
00:16:12.320 --> 00:16:15.850
And I know since it's a tear off,
the tool's still here.

346
00:16:15.850 --> 00:16:21.210
I'm not actually removing it out
of the tool dock, it's just a,

00:16:21.210 --> 00:16:24.770
it's almost like a copy if you wanna say,
like a tear, a tored off, tored?

348
00:16:24.770 --> 00:16:25.619
>> Torn off?
>> Torn.

349
00:16:25.619 --> 00:16:26.282
Yeah, thank you.

350
00:16:26.282 --> 00:16:29.340
>> [LAUGH]
>> Torn off copy of those tools.

351
00:16:29.340 --> 00:16:31.120
All right, so
let's open up a couple more files.

352
00:16:31.120 --> 00:16:33.540
I did Cmd+ O right there.

353
00:16:33.540 --> 00:16:36.830
So let's open up this one,
and let's go there,

354
00:16:36.830 --> 00:16:41.590
and then maybe we'll open
up one more just for fun.

355
00:16:41.590 --> 00:16:44.970
Let's go with the Orchard logo, okay.

356
00:16:44.970 --> 00:16:48.930
So I have three files that
are open in Illustrator.

357
00:16:48.930 --> 00:16:51.730
How do I know, because I've
got three tabs across the top.

358
00:16:51.730 --> 00:16:53.860
Okay, so I can see they're in the tabs,

359
00:16:53.860 --> 00:16:56.980
just like you have the tabs
of the panels over there.

360
00:16:56.980 --> 00:17:02.080
It tabulates or, yeah it just goes,
it actually is called consolidating,

361
00:17:02.080 --> 00:17:06.450
I think, and
it puts all of the files in tabs.

362
00:17:06.450 --> 00:17:09.460
You just click on them,
you can double click,

363
00:17:09.460 --> 00:17:11.160
but it doesn't really matter in there.

364
00:17:11.160 --> 00:17:13.510
You can close them and all that,
that's fine, that's cool.

365
00:17:16.250 --> 00:17:20.910
You can undock them, and
that will throw people off sometimes.

366
00:17:20.910 --> 00:17:25.240
People will actually undock, whether
it's a multiple file or a single file,

367
00:17:25.240 --> 00:17:30.290
you undock it from this area and then it
becomes its own free-floating window.

368
00:17:30.290 --> 00:17:35.253
And I've had people where they'll go ahead
and they're like, I've lost everything.

369
00:17:35.253 --> 00:17:36.551
>> Yes, the happy face is gone.

370
00:17:36.551 --> 00:17:39.930
>> Yeah, exactly, I'm like where
are my tools and what is going on?

371
00:17:39.930 --> 00:17:43.520
It's just because you've
actually un-docked the file and

372
00:17:43.520 --> 00:17:45.360
then like, you've made it big,

373
00:17:45.360 --> 00:17:50.160
so you've got to kind of just, well,
actually I did it a little too quickly.

374
00:17:50.160 --> 00:17:53.340
But you can just take that title bar,
of that file and

375
00:17:53.340 --> 00:17:57.050
just kind of, bring it and dock it back
in just like we're docking the panels.

376
00:17:57.050 --> 00:17:58.248
All right, so
you can dock your files there too.

377
00:17:58.248 --> 00:18:00.630
>> That would be useful then with
multiple monitor setup maybe?

378
00:18:00.630 --> 00:18:01.280
>> Yeah.

379
00:18:01.280 --> 00:18:04.100
>> Where I could move that into
its own monitor or something.

380
00:18:04.100 --> 00:18:07.300
>> Yeah, I work on 2 monitors too, so
I mean, there are times where I wanna pull

381
00:18:07.300 --> 00:18:10.095
one file out of another and
just kind of move them off to the side.

382
00:18:10.095 --> 00:18:11.500
>> Mm-hm.

383
00:18:11.500 --> 00:18:13.120
And you can still use
your interface with it.

384
00:18:13.120 --> 00:18:15.000
It's just really however
you want to do it.

385
00:18:15.000 --> 00:18:16.960
But it is something to take notice of.

386
00:18:18.650 --> 00:18:21.910
And that actually prompted me for this.

387
00:18:21.910 --> 00:18:23.920
It just popped in my head.

388
00:18:23.920 --> 00:18:28.420
>> Something that you should be careful of
when working in actually a lot of Adobe

389
00:18:28.420 --> 00:18:32.340
products, is because remember I just like,
I took that so let me just back up.

390
00:18:32.340 --> 00:18:33.690
I know, suspense, right?

391
00:18:33.690 --> 00:18:34.280
>> Yep.
>> [LAUGH] And

392
00:18:34.280 --> 00:18:37.680
I expanded it and you're like,
where are my tools?

393
00:18:37.680 --> 00:18:40.850
And I don't know where to go and
I've lost all my tools.

394
00:18:40.850 --> 00:18:45.520
Well, you can also lose all your tools,
as you wanna say, by hitting the tab key.

395
00:18:45.520 --> 00:18:47.420
>> Yeah, like, by itself.

396
00:18:47.420 --> 00:18:49.970
Yeah, so it's what happened?

397
00:18:49.970 --> 00:18:53.370
So just be careful if you ever hit
the tab key while you're working.

398
00:18:53.370 --> 00:18:54.710
It's just kinda hiding everything.

399
00:18:54.710 --> 00:18:55.530
Just hit it again, it comes back so.

400
00:18:55.530 --> 00:18:58.020
>> Just giving you a little more real
estate to temporary look at your

401
00:18:58.020 --> 00:18:59.390
document that you're working with maybe?

402
00:18:59.390 --> 00:19:03.280
>> Yeah, and it scares people
when you're like, what happened?

403
00:19:03.280 --> 00:19:04.620
And so that's what you do.

404
00:19:04.620 --> 00:19:06.890
But you can always,
if you ever need to, remember,

405
00:19:06.890 --> 00:19:08.090
you can always reset your work space.

406
00:19:08.090 --> 00:19:09.310
You can always go back
to your window menu.

407
00:19:09.310 --> 00:19:13.860
So you do have your your fallbacks.

408
00:19:13.860 --> 00:19:15.440
>> Yeah, so don't panic, all is not lost.

409
00:19:15.440 --> 00:19:18.110
>> Exactly, just calm, breathe, and

410
00:19:18.110 --> 00:19:22.270
remember this really long episode
about the interface of Illustrator.

411
00:19:24.100 --> 00:19:26.470
So a few more things about open files.

412
00:19:26.470 --> 00:19:27.290
They're in tabs.

413
00:19:28.660 --> 00:19:34.770
You can arrange them very similarly

414
00:19:34.770 --> 00:19:37.885
You can put them next to each other,
let me just show you.

00:19:37.885 --> 00:19:40.300
See this guy right up here,
across the top?

416
00:19:40.300 --> 00:19:42.340
There is this arrange documents button,

417
00:19:42.340 --> 00:19:44.750
just like the same documents

418
00:19:44.750 --> 00:19:49.920
And it has the same command, so
you can see that If I put them two up,

00:19:49.920 --> 00:19:53.510
or vertical, or horizontal, so
if I have three files, I can do three up.

420
00:19:53.510 --> 00:19:58.090
And then it arranges all
of my files in this order.

421
00:19:58.090 --> 00:20:00.060
Or I can put them next to each other.

422
00:20:00.060 --> 00:20:03.042
Now two up, but I have three, so
see, it puts two of them on one and

423
00:20:03.042 --> 00:20:04.540
all that kind of stuff.

424
00:20:04.540 --> 00:20:09.060
So you can use all of these different
ways of arranging you files or

425
00:20:09.060 --> 00:20:12.510
your multiple open files within
Illustrator with that button.

426
00:20:12.510 --> 00:20:15.450
And you can see, remember we talked
about consolidating, I said,

427
00:20:15.450 --> 00:20:20.260
that's because that top item or
that top option of consolidate

428
00:20:20.260 --> 00:20:25.270
all means bring that all together
in that tab format, across the top.

429
00:20:25.270 --> 00:20:27.062
>> Very good, well all right, Van.

430
00:20:27.062 --> 00:20:30.610
That's again, a lot of information or
a part two about this interface.

00:20:30.610 --> 00:20:31.500
There's just a lot to it,

00:20:31.500 --> 00:20:35.120
and a lot of ways that you can customize

433
00:20:35.120 --> 00:20:37.520
Can you think of anything else you want

>> One last little shortcut,
if you're working on multiple files and

435
00:20:41.940 --> 00:20:45.880
you want to cycle through them,
like, instead of clicking on them.

436
00:20:45.880 --> 00:20:47.700
Cuz I'm all about keyboard shortcuts,
right?

437
00:20:47.700 --> 00:20:54.280
You can do a Cmd+ ~, the enye,
remember the little tilde button up there?

438
00:20:54.280 --> 00:20:58.428
So if you do Ctrl+ or Cmd+ ~, you see it
just actually cycles me through all of my

439
00:20:58.428 --> 00:21:02.759
open files, and there's sometimes where I
have a lot of files and it's like [SOUND],

440
00:21:02.759 --> 00:21:03.866
go right through it.

441
00:21:03.866 --> 00:21:05.866
And that's my last tip.

442
00:21:05.866 --> 00:21:07.003
>> Fantastic, love it.

443
00:21:07.003 --> 00:21:07.910
>> And I'm done.

444
00:21:07.910 --> 00:21:09.690
Love all the customization you do,

445
00:21:09.690 --> 00:21:12.700
love all the keyboard shortcuts
that you're teaching us.

446
00:21:12.700 --> 00:21:15.910
Like I said, watching Vonn work
on these programs is amazing,

447
00:21:15.910 --> 00:21:19.550
the keyboard shortcuts that she uses,
you can just tell,

448
00:21:19.550 --> 00:21:22.445
somebody like me that's new to this
program, I'm using the mouse and

449
00:21:22.445 --> 00:21:25.060
I'm clicking on each one of
those those tools one at a time.

450
00:21:25.060 --> 00:21:28.200
It'll take me 15 minutes to do something,

451
00:21:28.200 --> 00:21:30.890
Von's done in 3 because she's doing these
keyboard shortcuts and all the other

452
00:21:30.890 --> 00:21:34.070
magic that she's gonna share with you guys
throughout the rest of these episodes.

453
00:21:34.070 --> 00:21:35.570
So we thank you for that, Von.

454
00:21:35.570 --> 00:21:36.270
We appreciate it.

455
00:21:36.270 --> 00:21:38.260
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

456
00:21:38.260 --> 00:21:40.240
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

00:21:40.240 --> 00:21:40.970

458
00:21:40.970 --> 00:21:43.072
