things, like arrange and transform.

482
00:22:38.430 --> 00:22:41.100
So, if you're right clicking on something.

483
00:22:41.100 --> 00:22:45.440
Make sure that you have
the item selected first.

484
00:22:45.440 --> 00:22:50.520
For example, if I go here, if I select the
text and right-click on that you see how I

485
00:22:50.520 --> 00:22:55.700
have font and things associated
with formatting the text.

486
00:22:55.700 --> 00:22:59.520
But If I wasn't paying attention and
I'm like, well, let me go ahead and

487
00:22:59.520 --> 00:23:00.310
right click here.

488
00:23:00.310 --> 00:23:02.350
And I'm like wait, why is that on fonts?

489
00:23:02.350 --> 00:23:03.100
Why is that on fonts?

490
00:23:03.100 --> 00:23:05.300
It's because you still have that selected.

491
00:23:05.300 --> 00:23:09.520
Yeah, so that's the whole like, click
off of it, make sure you're on the item,

492
00:23:09.520 --> 00:23:10.410
then right click.

493
00:23:10.410 --> 00:23:11.799
So, it can start to get.

494
00:23:12.900 --> 00:23:14.460
You can almost get a little lost.

495
00:23:14.460 --> 00:23:17.360
I still do it,
after all these years [INAUDIBLE].

496
00:23:17.360 --> 00:23:24.567
Its something I just wanted to pull up for
you guys.

497
00:23:24.567 --> 00:23:30.310
So, I can select a single item, but
what if I want to select multiple items?

498
00:23:30.310 --> 00:23:33.060
I want both of these squares
selected because I want to

499
00:23:33.060 --> 00:23:35.255
change both of their colors or
something like that.

500
00:23:35.255 --> 00:23:38.000
Single-click to select one.

501
00:23:38.000 --> 00:23:40.980
You can hold your shift key
to select multiple items.

502
00:23:40.980 --> 00:23:43.520
So if I would single-click on this,
now I've selected that.

503
00:23:43.520 --> 00:23:46.230
I can keep holding that shift key and
then I can click over here.

504
00:23:46.230 --> 00:23:48.760
And you see how it kinda
makes a bounding box across

505
00:23:48.760 --> 00:23:51.400
all of the items that you have selected.

506
00:23:51.400 --> 00:23:53.911
So, shift click, and
I can get all of these.

507
00:23:53.911 --> 00:23:58.174
It says there's a question
mark in there because there

508
00:23:58.174 --> 00:24:02.073
are multiple fill colors
that you've selected.

509
00:24:02.073 --> 00:24:05.974
I just want to show you that
maybe I want them all orange or

510
00:24:05.974 --> 00:24:09.377
something like that So
I can go ahead and do that,

511
00:24:09.377 --> 00:24:14.370
I did Cmd+Z to undo, click off to
deselect, Shift+click to go here.

512
00:24:14.370 --> 00:24:18.170
But then maybe it's like I didn't want
that pink one, I selected too many.

513
00:24:19.190 --> 00:24:23.900
Just keep holding that Shift key,
and if Shift+click on that again it

514
00:24:23.900 --> 00:24:27.600
takes it out of the selecting of
the multiple items that you want.

515
00:24:27.600 --> 00:24:29.690
Okay, so that's always good.

516
00:24:29.690 --> 00:24:34.960
Another thing that you can do to select,
say these three squares right here, is you

517
00:24:34.960 --> 00:24:39.740
make a I call it a selection marquee, if I
say it, still have the blank arrow tool.

518
00:24:39.740 --> 00:24:44.210
And if I just click, hold,
and drag, and see as long as

519
00:24:44.210 --> 00:24:50.110
the the selection marquee
just like touches the pieces.

520
00:24:50.110 --> 00:24:54.270
See I am not fully around the purple
square, I'm just like that.

521
00:24:54.270 --> 00:24:55.460
As long as its touching and

522
00:24:55.460 --> 00:24:58.420
let go it selects all of those items
>> That was my question because I know

523
00:24:58.420 --> 00:25:01.900
some programs you have to get all
the way around the shape to select it,

524
00:25:01.900 --> 00:25:04.589
others you get just a little bit
of it in that selection marquee,

525
00:25:04.589 --> 00:25:05.976
and it's gonna include it.

526
00:25:05.976 --> 00:25:09.430
And that can get you in
trouble sometimes in a crowded

527
00:25:09.430 --> 00:25:13.010
document with lots of items on it,
it can be really hard to select that way.

528
00:25:13.010 --> 00:25:16.540
>> Definitely, so you can yeah, so
you can just click, hold, and drag.

529
00:25:16.540 --> 00:25:17.980
And I do this all the time.

530
00:25:17.980 --> 00:25:20.020
Just okay,
I want all these guys right here.

531
00:25:20.020 --> 00:25:21.520
Cuz I wanna move them over there.

532
00:25:21.520 --> 00:25:25.050
Or I wanna kinda go like this and
then move these guys.

533
00:25:25.050 --> 00:25:28.610
You can see right here while I'm
moving I should probably point out,

534
00:25:28.610 --> 00:25:31.700
you see all these little pink
lines going all over the place?

535
00:25:31.700 --> 00:25:32.530
They're crazy.

536
00:25:32.530 --> 00:25:34.590
They're awesome.
These are smart guides.

537
00:25:34.590 --> 00:25:38.180
Okay, so what's going on when I do this?

538
00:25:38.180 --> 00:25:41.740
It's separating the spaces and
then this is aligning with this.

539
00:25:41.740 --> 00:25:44.872
They can get a little overwhelming cuz
it's like [SOUND], it's spazzing out and

540
00:25:44.872 --> 00:25:45.443
everything.

541
00:25:45.443 --> 00:25:50.570
But it does help you when you
start getting into aligning.

542
00:25:50.570 --> 00:25:54.340
Like this right here,
if I kinda, I know that the tops

543
00:25:54.340 --> 00:25:58.910
of these squares are going to be aligned
because the smart guides have done that,

544
00:25:58.910 --> 00:26:01.900
I don't have to actually
have to do a lined command.

545
00:26:01.900 --> 00:26:02.580
>> Very convenient.

546
00:26:02.580 --> 00:26:06.057
>> Very great so that's what you're
seeing when we're going through

547
00:26:06.057 --> 00:26:09.046
all of those pink stuff that's
going all over the place and

548
00:26:09.046 --> 00:26:11.744
if you wanna know where that
is it is in the view menu.

549
00:26:11.744 --> 00:26:13.183
>> So we turn it off?
>> And you can see that smart, yeah.

550
00:26:13.183 --> 00:26:14.940
And right there actually the command.

551
00:26:14.940 --> 00:26:20.068
It is Cmd+U, so if you did that and
then where are all my cool little helper

552
00:26:20.068 --> 00:26:24.720
things, where are all my smart guys,
it might have turned it off.

553
00:26:24.720 --> 00:26:28.911
Okay, so the View menu is a good place to
start at least getting familiar with those

554
00:26:28.911 --> 00:26:30.997
little things that sometimes can hide.

555
00:26:30.997 --> 00:26:33.845
While I'm over hiding,
this Hide Edge thing,

556
00:26:33.845 --> 00:26:38.826
that can get you sometimes to where if I'm
here, and I selected these two squares,

557
00:26:38.826 --> 00:26:42.800
I know that there's that kind of-
>> Bounding box?

558
00:26:42.800 --> 00:26:45.860
>> Yeah, it's showing me that these
are the things that are selected, so

559
00:26:45.860 --> 00:26:47.360
I've got all of these items.

560
00:26:47.360 --> 00:26:50.060
If you go to that View and
you go to Hide Edges, see,

561
00:26:50.060 --> 00:26:54.580
it actually, it shows the big box,
but doesn't show the individual

562
00:26:54.580 --> 00:26:58.100
edges that those are the things that are,
it can throw you off.

563
00:26:58.100 --> 00:27:00.500
So it's-
>> Now you're not sure if that yellow box

564
00:27:00.500 --> 00:27:02.150
there is part of the selection or not.

565
00:27:02.150 --> 00:27:05.800
It's inside the outer bounding box, but
it might not be part of your selection.

566
00:27:05.800 --> 00:27:08.400
>> Yeah, and
it's thrown me off from time to time.

567
00:27:08.400 --> 00:27:11.290
So I figure since I'm in this View menu
I'll go ahead and throw that in for

568
00:27:11.290 --> 00:27:12.590
you too, so.

569
00:27:12.590 --> 00:27:14.830
We thank you for that
>> You're welcome [LAUGH].

570
00:27:14.830 --> 00:27:18.426
So I we know how to select multiple
items I'm gonna go ahead and

571
00:27:18.426 --> 00:27:20.810
switch over to my art board here.

572
00:27:20.810 --> 00:27:22.650
We talk about the control panel right?

573
00:27:22.650 --> 00:27:25.775
And that's going to indicate
to you what you’re on and

574
00:27:25.775 --> 00:27:29.780
what you're working with and
I wanted to show you this.

575
00:27:29.780 --> 00:27:33.170
Right here with these three,
those aren't squares, those are circles.

576
00:27:33.170 --> 00:27:37.290
These three circles right here,
they're all selected, but

577
00:27:37.290 --> 00:27:39.540
I single-clicked on just this top one,
right?

578
00:27:39.540 --> 00:27:42.270
So why did it give me all of them?

579
00:27:42.270 --> 00:27:43.410
Well, this is a group.

580
00:27:44.930 --> 00:27:46.790
I know it's a group, again,
because I made this, but

581
00:27:46.790 --> 00:27:49.890
up here it just says ellipse, doesn't it?

582
00:27:49.890 --> 00:27:51.680
But how is that one
different than that one?

583
00:27:51.680 --> 00:27:53.860
See, that one says group, right?

584
00:27:53.860 --> 00:27:55.250
Here let me pull that up so
you can see it.

585
00:27:55.250 --> 00:27:59.270
That says group, but
this one says ellipse.

586
00:28:00.790 --> 00:28:05.300
I find this a little distracting because
before it was always a group is a group.

587
00:28:05.300 --> 00:28:07.948
It doesn't matter if it was circles or
squares or what have you.

588
00:28:07.948 --> 00:28:12.521
But I've just noticed that's what they
do now if it's something I created with

589
00:28:12.521 --> 00:28:15.316
a shape tool,
even if it's grouped, it names,

590
00:28:15.316 --> 00:28:19.920
up there in the control panel the shape or
the tool that it was made from.

591
00:28:19.920 --> 00:28:21.670
So I thought that was a little weird.

592
00:28:21.670 --> 00:28:22.950
>> That's good to know for sure.

593
00:28:22.950 --> 00:28:25.620
>> Yeah, so
that's something with the groups.

594
00:28:25.620 --> 00:28:27.860
Why am I pulling that out?

595
00:28:27.860 --> 00:28:30.032
Because single-clicking, right?

596
00:28:30.032 --> 00:28:33.040
You single-click to get on something,
I want just this item.

597
00:28:33.040 --> 00:28:39.110
I want the group but if you start
double-clicking on things it takes

598
00:28:39.110 --> 00:28:42.200
you somewhere where you probably don't
know where you're going unless I tell you.

599
00:28:42.200 --> 00:28:44.950
All right so, it's not isolation mode.

600
00:28:44.950 --> 00:28:50.130
if I'm like in this group, we know
it's a group I'll stay on this one.

601
00:28:50.130 --> 00:28:56.700
So here's my group, if I wanted to change
just the color of this pink square, right.

602
00:28:56.700 --> 00:28:57.990
But I didn't want to ungroup it.

603
00:28:57.990 --> 00:28:59.160
Because you can always ungroup it.

604
00:28:59.160 --> 00:28:59.810
Do what you need to do.

605
00:28:59.810 --> 00:29:01.011
Select it back together and
group it back together.

606
00:29:01.011 --> 00:29:01.670
But that's too many steps.

607
00:29:01.670 --> 00:29:02.506
>> It is.
>> Right?

608
00:29:02.506 --> 00:29:03.283
And I said that really fast.
[LAUGH]

609
00:29:03.283 --> 00:29:04.752
>> Especially if it's a complex group with

610
00:29:04.752 --> 00:29:05.491
a lot of items in it.

611
00:29:05.491 --> 00:29:08.120
I don't wanna have to select them
all again and group them up.

612
00:29:08.120 --> 00:29:12.190
>> Yeah, just keep it as a group but
I want to edit one thing in particular.

613
00:29:12.190 --> 00:29:16.530
If you double-click,
to notice two things happen.

614
00:29:16.530 --> 00:29:18.240
This little guy across the top,

615
00:29:19.280 --> 00:29:22.960
this comes up to let you know
that you are isolation mode.

616
00:29:22.960 --> 00:29:24.040
And the other thing,

617
00:29:24.040 --> 00:29:27.670
let me zoom out, everything else
on the outboard gets dimmed down.

618
00:29:27.670 --> 00:29:34.220
So it's like I'm only on this,
so I'm inside this group, okay?

619
00:29:34.220 --> 00:29:35.900
Now let me zoom in a little bit more.

620
00:29:35.900 --> 00:29:40.000
So if I single-click here, see now
I can single-click on that one item

621
00:29:40.000 --> 00:29:42.930
within that group and
maybe change it to blue or something.

622
00:29:42.930 --> 00:29:47.400
If I single-click on this guy,
well there's another group.

623
00:29:47.400 --> 00:29:50.290
So I mean you can have a group inside of a
group inside of a group inside of a group.

624
00:29:50.290 --> 00:29:52.270
It really just depends on
how you want to organize it.

625
00:29:52.270 --> 00:29:56.530
But if I double-click one more time
because I'm on a group, if I double-click,

626
00:29:56.530 --> 00:30:01.950
now I'm in a group which is in a group,
which is in Layer 1, okay?

627
00:30:03.210 --> 00:30:05.040
So it's like a drill-down.

628
00:30:05.040 --> 00:30:06.580
>> Or kinda like a breadcrumb trail or
something.

629
00:30:06.580 --> 00:30:08.540
>> Yeah, breadcrumbs, there you go,
that's a good example [LAUGH].

630
00:30:08.540 --> 00:30:14.350
So I'm down in here, so I'm in there, and
I can change this one or what have you.

631
00:30:14.350 --> 00:30:17.360
If I want to get out of
isolation mode altogether,

632
00:30:17.360 --> 00:30:19.210
if I double-click off to the side, right?

633
00:30:19.210 --> 00:30:20.090
Remember?

634
00:30:20.090 --> 00:30:22.540
Or actually, yeah,
double-click cuz we're in isolation mode.

635
00:30:22.540 --> 00:30:25.360
If I double-click it takes
me all the way out, okay?

636
00:30:25.360 --> 00:30:27.520
Really quickly, last little part.

637
00:30:27.520 --> 00:30:31.500
If I'm inside my group you
can also go up one level or

638
00:30:31.500 --> 00:30:33.350
kind of go back up your levels.

639
00:30:33.350 --> 00:30:34.940
If you click back on your breadcrumbs,

640
00:30:34.940 --> 00:30:39.030
like I wanna just go back up to where
I'm inside the group but where I can

641
00:30:39.030 --> 00:30:42.870
edit this bottom square because I wanna
make that purple or something like that.

642
00:30:42.870 --> 00:30:45.180
So now I can be one level up,

643
00:30:45.180 --> 00:30:48.440
instead of completely coming all
the way out of it by double-clicking.

644
00:30:48.440 --> 00:30:52.289
So these little guys kinda let you
know how you can navigate inside

645
00:30:53.400 --> 00:30:56.110
a group within isolation mode.

646
00:30:56.110 --> 00:30:57.610
And one last thing,

647
00:30:57.610 --> 00:31:01.090
is that you can actually go into isolation
mode without it being in a group.

648
00:31:01.090 --> 00:31:05.070
Like, this is in a group, right,
this is just straight up ellipse.

649
00:31:05.070 --> 00:31:07.630
And it's red because it's
in a different layer.

650
00:31:07.630 --> 00:31:10.430
And, if I double-click on this,
that's another thing

651
00:31:10.430 --> 00:31:13.710
that throws people off is they
start double-clicking on things.

652
00:31:13.710 --> 00:31:15.010
I'm like why did everything dim down?

653
00:31:15.010 --> 00:31:16.060
Why am I in this place?

654
00:31:16.060 --> 00:31:17.660
Where am I?

655
00:31:17.660 --> 00:31:20.885
It always takes you to isolation mode but
it's only one piece.

656
00:31:20.885 --> 00:31:23.700
>> Is there a reason to go
into isolation mode like that?

657
00:31:23.700 --> 00:31:24.990
What is it preventing?

658
00:31:26.590 --> 00:31:30.260
>> Well, it's preventing you from
editing anything else around it.

659
00:31:30.260 --> 00:31:34.180
So, say you have just like a whole bunch
of circles, like really complex artwork

660
00:31:34.180 --> 00:31:38.590
that's all these different pieces, and
you just want to change one part of it.

661
00:31:38.590 --> 00:31:41.490
Even though it's not in a group,
if you just double-click it,

662
00:31:41.490 --> 00:31:45.370
you're not gonna, see, if I come over
here, I can't select any of this stuff.

663
00:31:45.370 --> 00:31:50.540
Nothing else is selected so
I only want to work on you, just you.

664
00:31:50.540 --> 00:31:53.530
Do something then I can
double-click get out of it.

665
00:31:53.530 --> 00:31:55.160
So it doesn't have to be in a group,

666
00:31:55.160 --> 00:31:57.480
it's just I want to just
isolate you by yourself.

667
00:31:57.480 --> 00:32:00.710
>> So I don't accidentally select any
other shapes or modify anything else,

668
00:32:00.710 --> 00:32:01.920
just that one I'm working on.

669
00:32:01.920 --> 00:32:03.598
>> Yup.
>> Fantastic.

670
00:32:03.598 --> 00:32:04.190
All right, Vonne,

671
00:32:04.190 --> 00:32:08.260
a lot of great information on how we can
go about selecting items in Illustrator.

672
00:32:08.260 --> 00:32:10.940
There's a lot more to it than
what we might of thought, right?

673
00:32:10.940 --> 00:32:12.810
There's a lot of different tricks.

674
00:32:12.810 --> 00:32:17.431
[SOUND] One more time.

675
00:32:17.431 --> 00:32:20.485
[LAUGH] What are you, keeping a tally?

676
00:32:20.485 --> 00:32:21.490
[LAUGH]
>> No, it's always like, god.

677
00:32:21.490 --> 00:32:25.839
It makes me feel so much better,
when I'm not the only one fucking up.

678
00:32:25.839 --> 00:32:27.579
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

679
00:32:27.579 --> 00:32:28.975
>> All right, Vonne, thanks for that.

680
00:32:28.975 --> 00:32:31.550
A lot of great information
there on selecting items.

681
00:32:31.550 --> 00:32:34.680
Who would've thought there would be so
much on how we can select, but really,

682
00:32:34.680 --> 00:32:38.580
a lot of different ways we can select,
a lot of different things we can select,

683
00:32:38.580 --> 00:32:42.980
and obviously a very important part
of being efficient with Illustrator.

684
00:32:42.980 --> 00:32:44.018
And I know you've got more to show us.

685
00:32:44.018 --> 00:32:44.715
>> I do.

686
00:32:44.715 --> 00:32:47.571
>> But, unfortunately,
we're out of time for this episode so

687
00:32:47.571 --> 00:32:49.139
we're gonna have to cut it here.

688
00:32:49.139 --> 00:32:51.780
But we'll come back for a part two.

689
00:32:51.780 --> 00:32:53.520
So hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

690
00:32:53.520 --> 00:32:55.416
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

691
00:32:55.416 --> 00:32:57.081
>> I'm Vonne Smith.
>> And we'll see you next time.

692
00:32:57.081 --> 00:32:57.847
>> Bye.

693
00:32:57.847 --> 00:33:02.978
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Selecting Items Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.302 --> 00:00:15.703
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.703 --> 00:00:17.560
I'm your host Mike Roderick and

4
00:00:17.560 --> 00:00:21.069
today we're going over
Adobe Illustrator CC 2015, and

5
00:00:21.069 --> 00:00:25.490
specifically in this episode we're
going to do some more selecting items.

6
00:00:25.490 --> 00:00:28.930
Now, this is a part two, so if you missed
part one, make sure you go back and

7
00:00:28.930 --> 00:00:32.810
watch that one first because we
covered a lot of stuff there.

8
00:00:32.810 --> 00:00:36.210
We're just going to kind of round out
some thoughts about selecting items, and

9
00:00:36.210 --> 00:00:38.220
here to do that for us is Ms. Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:38.220 --> 00:00:39.080
How's it going Vonne?

11
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:40.660
>> Good, back for more.

12
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:45.280
So just wanted to throw in a few
more things about selecting items.

13
00:00:45.280 --> 00:00:48.700
Because we didn't cover
the other selection tool,

14
00:00:48.700 --> 00:00:50.780
I only showed you the black arrow tool.

15
00:00:50.780 --> 00:00:51.430
>> There's more.

16
00:00:51.430 --> 00:00:52.530
>> There is, there is.

17
00:00:52.530 --> 00:00:57.370
So I, yeah, so I just want to show you
the different ways that I use them,

18
00:00:57.370 --> 00:01:00.540
how you can use them and
see which way is most comfortable for you.

19
00:01:00.540 --> 00:01:04.990
So let's get right into it, so,
black arrow tool, we got that and

20
00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:05.770
we're doing that.

21
00:01:05.770 --> 00:01:08.480
We did our click, hold, and
drags, and all of that.

22
00:01:08.480 --> 00:01:13.590
If I wanted to select, here, let's
actually go over to this other artboard,

23
00:01:13.590 --> 00:01:16.650
let me move over here, so I can go here.

24
00:01:16.650 --> 00:01:21.316
That's the wrong one,
[LAUGH] this one, okay, there we go.

25
00:01:21.316 --> 00:01:26.294
I've got this, what if I wanted
to select all the items on

26
00:01:26.294 --> 00:01:29.095
here that have yellow fills, or

27
00:01:29.095 --> 00:01:34.308
all the things that have pink fills or
something like that?

28
00:01:34.308 --> 00:01:37.671
So over in your toolbox you
have the black arrow tool, but

29
00:01:37.671 --> 00:01:41.315
underneath it you have the magic
wand tool and the lasso tool,

30
00:01:41.315 --> 00:01:44.350
which are tools that you
find in Photoshop as well.

31
00:01:44.350 --> 00:01:47.340
And they work pretty much the same, but

32
00:01:47.340 --> 00:01:52.580
it's the same but different, my favorite
saying, [LAUGH] which makes no sense.

33
00:01:52.580 --> 00:01:56.310
So we're gonna go with the magic wand,
because what does that do?

34
00:01:56.310 --> 00:02:01.660
It selects items of similar color,
I guess we could say it that way.

35
00:02:01.660 --> 00:02:07.820
That's how we talk about it in Photoshop,
but it's like, things that are the same.

36
00:02:07.820 --> 00:02:11.960
So, if I take my magic wand and
I single click on this yellow square,

37
00:02:11.960 --> 00:02:13.380
you can see that selects this one,

38
00:02:13.380 --> 00:02:16.620
this one, this one, and this one,
all by me just clicking on one part.

39
00:02:16.620 --> 00:02:20.750
If I single click on the pink you can
see that it selects one, two, three.

40
00:02:20.750 --> 00:02:24.435
It's kind of hard because I got a blue
outline on that but they are selected.

41
00:02:24.435 --> 00:02:29.060
So, you can kind of see that
way that you're selecting.

42
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:33.730
And so it's got that, so that's kind
of a nice way to select multiple items.

43
00:02:33.730 --> 00:02:35.960
Okay, and that's all well and good.

44
00:02:35.960 --> 00:02:42.010
If you go to the lasso tool, okay, let me
just click off of this so I can deselect.

45
00:02:42.010 --> 00:02:46.340
If I wanted to grab this guy,
all of these guys,

46
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:50.510
you could just click, hold and
drag around these weird shapes.

47
00:02:50.510 --> 00:02:55.180
I couldn't really draw, I couldn't
make a selection marquee with drawing

48
00:02:55.180 --> 00:03:00.060
a box with a black arrow tool around these
two items because it would grab the text.

49
00:03:00.060 --> 00:03:01.810
>> It was touching those other items.

50
00:03:01.810 --> 00:03:06.610
>> Yeah, exactly, so
you can make some kind of weird

51
00:03:06.610 --> 00:03:09.840
selection patterns basically, [LAUGH] I
don't know how else to really say it.

52
00:03:09.840 --> 00:03:12.650
So you can just lasso up what you want.

53
00:03:12.650 --> 00:03:14.510
>> That can be very handy.

54
00:03:14.510 --> 00:03:17.360
>> Yeah, so just different ways you
can select these different pieces.

55
00:03:17.360 --> 00:03:18.580
>> I got a question for you.

56
00:03:18.580 --> 00:03:22.070
If we go back to that magic wand, you
clicked on something that was yellow, and

57
00:03:22.070 --> 00:03:26.060
it selected all the other yellow items,
but yellow is kinda vague,

58
00:03:26.060 --> 00:03:28.340
we can have lots of
different shades of yellow.

59
00:03:28.340 --> 00:03:30.300
How does it handle that kind of thing?

60
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:34.730
>> Great point, because the magic wand
works on something known as tolerance,

61
00:03:34.730 --> 00:03:38.070
which is the exact same thing
that you had in Photoshop.

62
00:03:38.070 --> 00:03:40.480
So let me demonstrate one of them here.

63
00:03:40.480 --> 00:03:44.490
We have this select flowers file,
so this is kind like what

64
00:03:44.490 --> 00:03:47.900
the example you're talking about, it's not
yellow, but it's like this peachy color.

65
00:03:47.900 --> 00:03:49.020
>> And there's different shades.

66
00:03:49.020 --> 00:03:50.430
>> There are different shades, right.

67
00:03:50.430 --> 00:03:55.400
So if I clicked on this, you're like okay,
so that's all that same color, and just to

68
00:03:55.400 --> 00:03:59.800
change the color so you can see it's like,
wait, I thought there was multiples.

69
00:03:59.800 --> 00:04:05.180
So it was grabbing what it
saw within its tolerance

70
00:04:05.180 --> 00:04:10.610
of what varying shades of this peach color
it's allowed or it's going to select.

71
00:04:10.610 --> 00:04:12.310
>> So by default it's not exact,

72
00:04:12.310 --> 00:04:15.860
it'll give you a little leeway
either way on that color.

73
00:04:15.860 --> 00:04:17.650
>> With the default tolerance set.

74
00:04:17.650 --> 00:04:18.830
>> Okay.
>> So it's,

75
00:04:18.830 --> 00:04:21.240
well then how do I change the tolerance?

76
00:04:21.240 --> 00:04:25.890
>> What if I wanted to get all of those
and it was outside of the tolerance?

77
00:04:25.890 --> 00:04:30.010
>> Or if you were saying,
I did want it to be exact or less or more.

78
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:34.610
It's changing the preference
of the tool and

79
00:04:34.610 --> 00:04:37.750
that's how you get to it is by
double clicking on that tool.

80
00:04:37.750 --> 00:04:42.580
So if I double click on the magic wand
tool, that actually brings up the magic

81
00:04:42.580 --> 00:04:46.010
wand options and you can see that this
gives you a couple things right here.

82
00:04:46.010 --> 00:04:47.100
So I can go over the fill or

83
00:04:47.100 --> 00:04:51.020
the stroke because this always
gonna select the same fills,

84
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:55.600
cuz that's what the tool option and by
default and the tolerance has set at 20.

85
00:04:55.600 --> 00:04:58.380
And you can change that less or

86
00:04:58.380 --> 00:05:03.580
lower times means more exact color,
so not as wide range of colors.

87
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:07.070
The higher the tolerance,
the wider range of colors or

88
00:05:07.070 --> 00:05:09.530
things that it's going to
be selecting on there.

89
00:05:09.530 --> 00:05:10.960
Something to just point out,

90
00:05:10.960 --> 00:05:15.330
because a lot of people are like, it's
just gonna select this exact, not really.

91
00:05:15.330 --> 00:05:18.860
But our other file, the colors are so

92
00:05:18.860 --> 00:05:23.060
far apart from each other and so different
that it didn't make that distinction.

93
00:05:24.320 --> 00:05:29.520
So, that is the magic wand, like that.

94
00:05:30.860 --> 00:05:33.560
Something else that I like to do,

95
00:05:33.560 --> 00:05:39.760
because the magic wand just wasn't my tool
to go to, when I was in Illustrator, so,

96
00:05:39.760 --> 00:05:44.910
I use the select menu, which I actually
discovered long, much further down

97
00:05:44.910 --> 00:05:47.790
the road of using Illustrator, and came
back and, man, why didn't I know that?

98
00:05:47.790 --> 00:05:50.020
So I'm gonna show you.

99
00:05:50.020 --> 00:05:55.850
So if I have this particular
petal of this flower selected,

100
00:05:55.850 --> 00:06:02.530
and I want to select all of the ones
that have the same color, I can make it

101
00:06:02.530 --> 00:06:07.300
select first so it has to have something
to base itself upon, this is what I want.

102
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:12.160
View the select menu, you can go to same
and you can see I can say same fill.

103
00:06:12.160 --> 00:06:15.020
And notice tere's a lot of different
options in here so this is really,

104
00:06:15.020 --> 00:06:15.830
really great.

105
00:06:15.830 --> 00:06:20.620
So if I go to select same fill color,
it's gonna select just that particular

106
00:06:20.620 --> 00:06:22.610
fill color cuz I said
all right I want that.

107
00:06:22.610 --> 00:06:26.790
And then maybe just for fun we'll
like change that to that color blue.

108
00:06:26.790 --> 00:06:31.240
So now I wanna change this particular one,
so let me select all the same fill color,

109
00:06:31.240 --> 00:06:34.210
and we can keep on going I
think you get the idea here

110
00:06:34.210 --> 00:06:38.870
is that I can just keep on
selecting the same things.

111
00:06:38.870 --> 00:06:39.740
>> Nice.

112
00:06:39.740 --> 00:06:43.572
>> Now I have to finish this flower,
just because I have to.

113
00:06:43.572 --> 00:06:44.101
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Now,

114
00:06:44.101 --> 00:06:46.900
is that based on any type of tolerance,
or that's doing the exact color?

115
00:06:46.900 --> 00:06:48.220
>> That's the exact same, the exact.

116
00:06:48.220 --> 00:06:50.810
>> Okay.
So you can actually use that instead of

117
00:06:50.810 --> 00:06:52.518
changing your tolerance on the magic wand.

118
00:06:52.518 --> 00:06:53.722
>> Yeah, yeah,

119
00:06:53.722 --> 00:06:58.780
exactly, perfect that's exactly why I did
it and it's a one to one type of match.

120
00:06:58.780 --> 00:07:03.270
And if you come over here,
this is where it's not just the fill,

121
00:07:03.270 --> 00:07:05.600
there's a whole bunch of
other things you can do.

122
00:07:05.600 --> 00:07:07.210
Like the same opacity,

123
00:07:07.210 --> 00:07:12.695
maybe everything's at a different opacity
rating or the same fill and stroke,

124
00:07:12.695 --> 00:07:17.670
they have to have both, so it's like
criteria of what you want it to select.

125
00:07:17.670 --> 00:07:19.210
>> Wow that's nice.

126
00:07:19.210 --> 00:07:23.330
>> And another thing in this select menu
that I always like is in this object, so

127
00:07:23.330 --> 00:07:27.990
now I have nothing selected by the way,
nothing is on, if I go to select object

128
00:07:27.990 --> 00:07:34.080
and say maybe all text objects, that's
kind of cool, so give me all the text.

129
00:07:34.080 --> 00:07:36.850
>> So if I wanna change all the fonts
at one time I don't have to go around

130
00:07:36.850 --> 00:07:39.730
clicking on each instance of a text.

131
00:07:41.100 --> 00:07:41.870
>> Yeah.

132
00:07:41.870 --> 00:07:43.130
>> Nice.
>> Yeah, and

133
00:07:43.130 --> 00:07:46.078
this is one that straight points.

134
00:07:46.078 --> 00:07:46.686
Huge.
>> Yeah.

135
00:07:46.686 --> 00:07:49.410
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah, so that is really,

136
00:07:49.410 --> 00:07:50.850
really great.

137
00:07:50.850 --> 00:07:55.480
I use this a lot, especially when I'm
modifying logos or if I've done traces and

138
00:07:55.480 --> 00:07:58.430
things like that, I just need to get
all of the stray points away from it.

139
00:07:58.430 --> 00:08:00.360
>> Those can be really
hard to find sometimes.

140
00:08:00.360 --> 00:08:00.880
>> Yes.

141
00:08:00.880 --> 00:08:05.960
Very, yeah, they don't exist because they
don't have any, they exist, but not in

142
00:08:05.960 --> 00:08:10.102
this preview mode because it doesn't have
a color a lot of times, it's just a point.

143
00:08:10.102 --> 00:08:12.790
But that's pretty nice,
I wanted to show you guys that.

144
00:08:12.790 --> 00:08:17.532
And since we're talking about a point,
the other thing in this kinda

145
00:08:17.532 --> 00:08:22.330
group up of selection tools, cuz you
see in our tool bar, our tool box, it

146
00:08:22.330 --> 00:08:27.030
has these little kind of separation lines
like there's these and then there's these.

147
00:08:27.030 --> 00:08:29.920
These top four tools are the selection
tool and the one we didn't go

148
00:08:29.920 --> 00:08:33.010
over was the white arrow, there's
a black arrow and there's a white arrow.

149
00:08:33.010 --> 00:08:35.120
So what does the white arrow do?

150
00:08:35.120 --> 00:08:37.850
The white arrow is for points, so

151
00:08:37.850 --> 00:08:43.690
the points on a vector path because like
over here let's go with this square.

152
00:08:43.690 --> 00:08:49.630
This yellow square, it has four points,
because there's on the corners,

153
00:08:49.630 --> 00:08:52.790
and the then path or
lines are in between those points, so

154
00:08:52.790 --> 00:08:56.720
if I black arrow it gives me everything,
that's my whole thing.

155
00:08:56.720 --> 00:09:01.560
The white now, notice that I clicked
off first, my white if I hover,

156
00:09:01.560 --> 00:09:05.040
you still gotta look for
the end of the dot, the end of the tail,

157
00:09:05.040 --> 00:09:06.635
that's a little bit different on this one.

158
00:09:06.635 --> 00:09:12.130
See if I hover over here, you see how
its showing me with the smart guides,

159
00:09:12.130 --> 00:09:17.230
or the kind of helper guide thingies,
guide thingies, yeah, it says that

160
00:09:17.230 --> 00:09:22.850
I'm hovered over an anchor, and the dot
at the end of the white arrow is hollow.

161
00:09:22.850 --> 00:09:26.140
Versus here, see how that's solid?

162
00:09:27.150 --> 00:09:33.570
That's not a point, I'm on the path,
if I'm on a point, it's gonna go hollow,

163
00:09:33.570 --> 00:09:38.590
and it kind of highlights itself,
if you wanna say, on the path that you do.

164
00:09:38.590 --> 00:09:42.700
So if I single click it,
that is my selected point.

165
00:09:42.700 --> 00:09:46.570
It's kinda hard, it might be hard to
see but see how that little tiny.

166
00:09:46.570 --> 00:09:48.750
>> That one corner is now
a little bit highlighted.

167
00:09:48.750 --> 00:09:50.670
>> Yeah, and
then this one over here on the left,

168
00:09:50.670 --> 00:09:55.050
I don't know if I can make it any bigger,
that one is hollow.

169
00:09:55.050 --> 00:10:00.050
Okay, so I've selected,
this is my selected point that I have.

170
00:10:00.050 --> 00:10:04.360
And if I'm over that selected point,
I can do things like move it,

171
00:10:04.360 --> 00:10:06.810
because if I have, oops, too far up.

172
00:10:06.810 --> 00:10:10.710
If I have a square, if I take this and

173
00:10:10.710 --> 00:10:15.770
I move this anchor point,
well I could make it into a triangle.

174
00:10:15.770 --> 00:10:16.985
>> Yeah, pretty fancy.

175
00:10:16.985 --> 00:10:18.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you can move and

176
00:10:18.210 --> 00:10:23.995
you can select your points, so
black is for whole, white is for point.

177
00:10:23.995 --> 00:10:26.290
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> Or a piece, whole or piece,

178
00:10:26.290 --> 00:10:30.350
that's how I've always described it,
as the black and the white arrow tool.

179
00:10:31.840 --> 00:10:32.830
That's what we got.

180
00:10:32.830 --> 00:10:36.160
>> All right, Vonne, again a lot of great
information about selecting objects,

181
00:10:36.160 --> 00:10:39.120
kind of round it out
the thought process there about

182
00:10:39.120 --> 00:10:42.290
how we can select different objects so
that we can turn around and affect them.

183
00:10:42.290 --> 00:10:44.290
So thank you for that,
thank you for sharing that with us.

184
00:10:44.290 --> 00:10:47.970
I know we enjoyed shooting this episode,
hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

185
00:10:47.970 --> 00:10:49.900
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

186
00:10:49.900 --> 00:10:53.578
>> I'm Vonne Smith.

187
00:10:53.578 --> 00:10:58.391
>> And we'll see you next time.

188
00:10:58.391 --> 00:10:59.019
>> Bye.

189
00:10:59.019 --> 00:11:00.899
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Basic Shapes and Formatting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.038 --> 00:00:10.038
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.545 --> 00:00:16.005
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.005 --> 00:00:21.068
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today,
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:21.068 --> 00:00:25.267
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be focusing in on creating basic

5
00:00:25.267 --> 00:00:27.830
shapes and doing some basic formatting.

6
00:00:27.830 --> 00:00:29.930
And here as always is Ms. Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:29.930 --> 00:00:30.960
How's it going Vonne?

8
00:00:30.960 --> 00:00:31.870
>> I'm doing great.

9
00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:37.181
Glad to be back to actually creating
some items in our Photoshop documents.

10
00:00:37.181 --> 00:00:41.086
Cuz up until now, we've just been
kind of exploring the environment and

11
00:00:41.086 --> 00:00:41.988
getting ready.

12
00:00:41.988 --> 00:00:45.578
And I've been giving you all those teasers
of like well, that's coming up now.

13
00:00:45.578 --> 00:00:46.918
So we're gonna start again.

14
00:00:46.918 --> 00:00:48.118
>> That's kinda deflating,
let's get in there.

15
00:00:48.118 --> 00:00:52.645
>> Yes, now I can actually show you how
to create some of those awesome shapes,

16
00:00:52.645 --> 00:00:55.348
and how to organize them and
all of that, so.

17
00:00:55.348 --> 00:00:56.780
>> Sounds good.

18
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:58.218
>> Why don't we just jump right in to it?

19
00:00:58.218 --> 00:01:01.436
And I figure before we actually
start creating some basic shapes,

20
00:01:01.436 --> 00:01:04.138
we have to go over how to
actually make a new file?

21
00:01:04.138 --> 00:01:07.999
So we're gonna go over the new file
settings, give you kind of a quick

22
00:01:07.999 --> 00:01:11.338
overview, get into those art boards and
draw some shapes.

23
00:01:11.338 --> 00:01:12.276
>> Sounds good to me.

24
00:01:12.276 --> 00:01:13.490
>> Let's go.

25
00:01:13.490 --> 00:01:16.949
So I've got Illustrator
already opened up for me and

26
00:01:16.949 --> 00:01:19.548
I've got my workspace all organized.

27
00:01:19.548 --> 00:01:21.319
I try to minimize it a little bit, so

28
00:01:21.319 --> 00:01:25.740
I'm only focusing on panels that
we'll probably be working with right.

29
00:01:25.740 --> 00:01:29.160
So we're gonna go to File > New or
commander Ctrl+N is for File,

30
00:01:29.160 --> 00:01:32.230
New here and
here's the New Document settings.

31
00:01:32.230 --> 00:01:35.078
There's not too much going on in here, so.

32
00:01:35.078 --> 00:01:39.628
So we don't have a lot to really go over,
but when I'm making something new in

33
00:01:39.628 --> 00:01:42.988
Illustrator, you do have to
think of the final product.

34
00:01:42.988 --> 00:01:43.788
Where am I going?

35
00:01:43.788 --> 00:01:44.468
What am I creating?

36
00:01:44.468 --> 00:01:45.928
Am I creating a logo?

37
00:01:45.928 --> 00:01:49.366
Am I creating a web banner?

38
00:01:49.366 --> 00:01:53.236
Almost like taking out a piece of paper
and drawing, do I really even have

39
00:01:53.236 --> 00:01:57.050
to constrain myself to a specific size
that the document needs to be in?

40
00:01:57.050 --> 00:01:59.470
But if you are working in a web banner you

41
00:01:59.470 --> 00:02:03.770
do need to know the dimensions
that you're going to end up in.

42
00:02:03.770 --> 00:02:08.350
Like if I need a web banner that's
gonna be 500 pixels by 200 pixels,

43
00:02:08.350 --> 00:02:10.690
then I should know that and set that here.

44
00:02:10.690 --> 00:02:12.490
If I'm doing a half page ad,

45
00:02:12.490 --> 00:02:16.325
then I need to to a half page if its
a half letter size and that's, what?

46
00:02:16.325 --> 00:02:18.350
That's eight and
a half by four and a half.

47
00:02:18.350 --> 00:02:19.353
Wait, no.

So it's like here, here's a company logo.

00:25:01.438 --> 00:25:04.523
But I got purple blue and yellow.

499
00:25:04.523 --> 00:25:08.265
Now the order in which I drew these items.

500
00:25:08.265 --> 00:25:11.060
It's stacking on top of each other, okay?

501
00:25:11.060 --> 00:25:14.830
So the yellow is behind the blue,
wait, yes.

502
00:25:14.830 --> 00:25:17.360
And then the blue is behind the purple,
okay?

503
00:25:17.360 --> 00:25:18.550
So that's the order.

504
00:25:18.550 --> 00:25:22.940
Well, I really wanted the yellow to be
come forward a little bit more, right?

505
00:25:22.940 --> 00:25:24.310
So you can actually change this.

506
00:25:24.310 --> 00:25:25.929
I have left-clicked and
then I right-clicked.

507
00:25:25.929 --> 00:25:30.090
And then I go to the arrange, so you could
actually sent it front, forward, backward.

508
00:25:30.090 --> 00:25:33.910
What's the difference between forward and
backward, or front and forward?

509
00:25:33.910 --> 00:25:38.040
Like all the way up front,
versus all the way to, or just one level?

510
00:25:38.040 --> 00:25:38.970
If you don't know right now,

511
00:25:38.970 --> 00:25:41.500
and we haven't really gotten
super deep into layers.

512
00:25:41.500 --> 00:25:43.850
But it does kind of go
along that principle.

513
00:25:43.850 --> 00:25:46.070
So for right now,
I just wanna bring it up.

514
00:25:46.070 --> 00:25:47.700
So you bring it to the front.

515
00:25:47.700 --> 00:25:49.850
And then it comes to the front of it.

516
00:25:49.850 --> 00:25:55.240
So you can change that
stacking order from there.

517
00:25:55.240 --> 00:25:59.040
And I feel like I can't really say
that without getting into the layers,

518
00:25:59.040 --> 00:26:00.000
at least for a little bit.

519
00:26:00.000 --> 00:26:02.450
So I might as well go there
because I'm sure you're wondering.

520
00:26:02.450 --> 00:26:05.830
So you can see that everything
that I have is in layer one.

521
00:26:05.830 --> 00:26:10.390
And in this layer you can see that
this is the item that I have selected.

522
00:26:10.390 --> 00:26:15.390
The reason I know that it is selected, and
it might be a little bit above my head so

523
00:26:15.390 --> 00:26:16.660
let me bring this up.

524
00:26:16.660 --> 00:26:18.140
There we go, perfect.

525
00:26:18.140 --> 00:26:20.140
Okay, so let's kind of go there.

526
00:26:20.140 --> 00:26:25.490
So you can see that this is the item
that I have on, well there we go.

527
00:26:25.490 --> 00:26:27.440
So because there's a little
blue dot next to it.

528
00:26:27.440 --> 00:26:30.940
Might be hard to see right there so,
let me see if, yeah there we go.

529
00:26:30.940 --> 00:26:34.000
There's a little blue dot that let's me
know that that is the item that I have

530
00:26:34.000 --> 00:26:34.550
selected.

531
00:26:34.550 --> 00:26:38.030
If I click on the purple
arrow at the purple square,

532
00:26:38.030 --> 00:26:42.260
you can see over here a layers panel,

533
00:26:42.260 --> 00:26:47.270
that that little blue dot is next
to the purple rectangle layer.

534
00:26:47.270 --> 00:26:48.690
Okay, so that indicates where we're at.

535
00:26:48.690 --> 00:26:51.250
So I know that the yellow is on top.

536
00:26:51.250 --> 00:26:52.810
The purple is underneath it.

537
00:26:52.810 --> 00:26:55.390
The blue is all the way
down at the bottom, okay.

538
00:26:55.390 --> 00:27:00.230
So if I wanted to change the stacking
order, and the arrangement from the layers

539
00:27:00.230 --> 00:27:05.950
panel, you can take this and I can click,
hold, and drag, and move this up.

540
00:27:07.030 --> 00:27:09.640
Come on, let's go up, there we go.

541
00:27:09.640 --> 00:27:12.250
Okay, and now I go right there,
see now I'm between.

542
00:27:12.250 --> 00:27:15.130
You always gotta look for
the line when you're doing that.

543
00:27:15.130 --> 00:27:21.310
So the blue rectangle is now
between the yellow and the purple.

544
00:27:22.340 --> 00:27:27.400
And so if I wanted the purple to come
up I can pull the purple rectangle up.

545
00:27:27.400 --> 00:27:29.030
Gotta look for those lines.

546
00:27:29.030 --> 00:27:31.300
And I can change the stacking
order like that.

547
00:27:31.300 --> 00:27:35.830
So it's all based upon where those
items are within the layers.

548
00:27:35.830 --> 00:27:39.250
And then of course the layers also
have their own stacking order.

549
00:27:39.250 --> 00:27:43.840
But we'll get into a little bit more of
that when we go directly into layers.

550
00:27:43.840 --> 00:27:46.017
A little bit more in depth.

551
00:27:46.017 --> 00:27:46.517
So.

552
00:27:48.040 --> 00:27:49.308
All right, so we've got a few things here.

553
00:27:49.308 --> 00:27:52.647
Just maybe a few more little items.

554
00:27:52.647 --> 00:27:54.628
Cuz I can tell you're starting to say,
we're starting to get a little long.

555
00:27:54.628 --> 00:27:55.805
We should kinda move on.

556
00:27:55.805 --> 00:27:59.720
All right, and
I only got to the rectangles.

557
00:27:59.720 --> 00:28:02.551
>> Well that's what I was getting excited
about was the other tools in there.

558
00:28:02.551 --> 00:28:04.092
We haven't seen circles and other.

559
00:28:04.092 --> 00:28:08.925
>> [CROSSTALK] I know, because the other
things will apply to all the other tools.

560
00:28:08.925 --> 00:28:12.176
So, we'll kind of go through
kind of covering a lot at once.

561
00:28:12.176 --> 00:28:13.514
>> You've learned one,
you've learned them all.

562
00:28:13.514 --> 00:28:14.810
>> Exactly, yes.

563
00:28:14.810 --> 00:28:19.589
So, let's go to the black arrow tool,
removing this, we've done alt-drag, so

564
00:28:19.589 --> 00:28:21.590
now I'm kind of going over this.

565
00:28:21.590 --> 00:28:28.200
I know what I wanted to show you is
the black arrow versus the white arrow,

566
00:28:28.200 --> 00:28:33.030
okay that's another basic principle
when we're talking about path.

567
00:28:33.030 --> 00:28:36.940
The black arrow's always for the hole,
the white arrow's always for the points

568
00:28:36.940 --> 00:28:42.370
because I'm moving this whole square,
I'm changing the size of the whole square.

569
00:28:42.370 --> 00:28:47.350
I'm rotating the whole square but
this path has

570
00:28:47.350 --> 00:28:52.000
points along the way and if I wanted
to move this point in because this

571
00:28:52.000 --> 00:28:56.990
rectangle could actually look like
a triangle, if I really wanted it to.

572
00:28:56.990 --> 00:29:02.840
The white arrow or direct selection a is
the hotkey that is for your points, okay?

573
00:29:02.840 --> 00:29:07.570
So if I hover over this and I get right
there you can see it right there with that

574
00:29:07.570 --> 00:29:11.830
anchor point that actually tells me if I
click on that, I just clicked it once.

575
00:29:11.830 --> 00:29:16.620
That becomes my selected point and
I can move this point in.

576
00:29:16.620 --> 00:29:19.080
So I can move this here,
I can move this here.

577
00:29:19.080 --> 00:29:20.680
I can put it there.

578
00:29:20.680 --> 00:29:22.800
And so now I actually have a triangle.

579
00:29:23.850 --> 00:29:28.130
So white is for point, black is for hold.

580
00:29:28.130 --> 00:29:33.930
And I can make some very
interesting shapes like that.

581
00:29:33.930 --> 00:29:38.990
All right and then one last thing with the
rectangle because it will come up on some

582
00:29:38.990 --> 00:29:42.680
other tools cuz you're probably wondering
well you went over almost every single

583
00:29:42.680 --> 00:29:47.760
dot that's on this rectangle except those
little circle things in the corners.

584
00:29:47.760 --> 00:29:50.600
This is actually something newer to CC.

585
00:29:50.600 --> 00:29:53.855
These are known as live corners.

586
00:29:55.194 --> 00:29:56.420
>> Right here?
Yeah, right there.

587
00:29:56.420 --> 00:29:58.000
These little guys.

588
00:29:58.000 --> 00:29:58.610
That?

589
00:29:58.610 --> 00:29:59.890
That's what you're looking at, yeah.

590
00:29:59.890 --> 00:30:02.310
So those little,
looks like an eyeball almost or something.

591
00:30:02.310 --> 00:30:03.980
So we've got these little guys.

592
00:30:03.980 --> 00:30:06.310
These are our live corners.

593
00:30:06.310 --> 00:30:10.730
This is where you could take this
live corner, click, hold, and

594
00:30:10.730 --> 00:30:14.470
drag, and make rounded corners on the fly.

595
00:30:14.470 --> 00:30:19.520
Which was kind of not as
easy to do back in the day.

596
00:30:19.520 --> 00:30:21.920
You had to do like effects and
all these different things.

597
00:30:21.920 --> 00:30:24.390
So this is kind of a newer feature and
it is all like that.

598
00:30:24.390 --> 00:30:26.420
Now you can see that it's moving together.

599
00:30:26.420 --> 00:30:28.410
Right.
They're all moving at once.

600
00:30:28.410 --> 00:30:36.395
But, what if I wanted to maybe just change
the roundness, the cornerness as it were.

601
00:30:36.395 --> 00:30:38.430
[LAUGH] The corners of just this one.

602
00:30:38.430 --> 00:30:42.120
If you select, click, hold,
drag as well, click it again.

603
00:30:42.120 --> 00:30:47.040
Click once and you see how it almost
makes it a little darker versus that one.

604
00:30:47.040 --> 00:30:50.710
So this is the darker one, which means
that this is the only one that it's going

605
00:30:50.710 --> 00:30:55.320
to be affecting when I click, hold, and
drag in, so I can just make that one

606
00:30:55.320 --> 00:31:00.010
corner different than the other one,
which is pretty fun.

607
00:31:00.010 --> 00:31:03.838
All right, so
I think that's probably enough for now and

608
00:31:03.838 --> 00:31:06.246
we can go over the rest of the tools.

609
00:31:06.246 --> 00:31:09.349
>> All right Bon, I know we've got more
shapes to go over, but unfortunately,

610
00:31:09.349 --> 00:31:12.404
we're out of time for this episode so
we're gonna have to wait for part two,

611
00:31:12.404 --> 00:31:15.353
which means you guys are gonna have to
make sure you come back and join us.

612
00:31:15.353 --> 00:31:17.770
So that's gonna do it for
this particular episode.

613
00:31:17.770 --> 00:31:19.510
We hope everybody enjoyed watching.

614
00:31:19.510 --> 00:31:22.120
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

615
00:31:22.120 --> 00:31:22.800
>> I'm Bon Smith.

616
00:31:22.800 --> 00:31:25.056
>> And we'll see you next time.

617
00:31:25.056 --> 00:31:31.680
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Basic Shapes and Formatting Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.754 --> 00:00:10.754
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.328 --> 00:00:15.305
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.305 --> 00:00:16.925
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:16.925 --> 00:00:20.694
Today, we are doing
Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

5
00:00:20.694 --> 00:00:25.058
Specifically in this episode, we're
actually continuing a thought process on

6
00:00:25.058 --> 00:00:28.470
creating basic shapes and
doing some basic formatting.

7
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:31.300
This is part two so if you missed
part one you should go back and

8
00:00:31.300 --> 00:00:34.010
watch that and then come back and
join us for part two.

9
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:36.000
Here, as always, is Ms Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:36.000 --> 00:00:36.830
How's it going, Von?

11
00:00:36.830 --> 00:00:37.798
>> Good.

12
00:00:37.798 --> 00:00:41.594
I had so much I had to tell you guys in
the first part that I had to come back for

13
00:00:41.594 --> 00:00:43.440
part two we're gonna-
>> Yeah, we like it.

14
00:00:43.440 --> 00:00:46.560
We're gonna keep on moving,
keep on trucking, we

15
00:00:46.560 --> 00:00:50.045
were going over rectangles and I thought
we would actually get a lot farther.

16
00:00:50.045 --> 00:00:51.658
Again, I had so much to tell you about.

17
00:00:51.658 --> 00:00:52.838
>> That's great information.

18
00:00:52.838 --> 00:00:57.704
>> Yes, so lots of good things, so let's
keep on going with these good things and

19
00:00:57.704 --> 00:00:58.310
move on.

20
00:00:58.310 --> 00:01:03.580
I actually have the exact file that
I left off on, from the part one.

21
00:01:03.580 --> 00:01:07.778
So we've got these really, really
awesome looking things going on here.

22
00:01:07.778 --> 00:01:11.149
[LAUGH] So I want to basically
just wipe the slate clean and

23
00:01:11.149 --> 00:01:12.880
move on to our other shapes.

24
00:01:12.880 --> 00:01:17.690
So I'm going to do a Cmd+A or
Ctrl+A for select all, all right?

25
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:19.690
And that's also in your Edit menu.

26
00:01:19.690 --> 00:01:21.230
If you ever want, no, I lied,

27
00:01:21.230 --> 00:01:23.050
that's in the Select menu,
>> [LAUGH]

28
00:01:23.050 --> 00:01:24.180
>> Wrong one.

29
00:01:24.180 --> 00:01:28.430
So your Select menu would probably be
where you want to Select All on there.

30
00:01:28.430 --> 00:01:31.510
So, I did that, and I'm just gonna get rid
of it, so I'm just gonna hit the Delete

31
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:34.360
key, or the Backspace key, to say okay,
we're done, we're gonna move on.

32
00:01:34.360 --> 00:01:37.840
All right, so, brand new file,
it's not really a brand new file.

33
00:01:37.840 --> 00:01:38.550
>> Clean slate though.

34
00:01:38.550 --> 00:01:39.794
>> Thank you, there we go.

35
00:01:39.794 --> 00:01:42.070
>> Yes, and now we can give the other
shapes the attention they so deserve.

36
00:01:42.070 --> 00:01:44.754
>> Yes, because they've been
really wanting to come out and

37
00:01:44.754 --> 00:01:46.610
show you what they can do.

38
00:01:46.610 --> 00:01:49.344
So Rounded Rectangle Tool,
it almost explains itself.

39
00:01:49.344 --> 00:01:51.046
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

40
00:01:51.046 --> 00:01:51.751
>> Yeah, it's gonna be

41
00:01:51.751 --> 00:01:52.830
a rounded rectangle.

42
00:01:52.830 --> 00:01:54.160
So then they go.

43
00:01:54.160 --> 00:01:56.910
And it's already got the little
dots that we were doing for

44
00:01:56.910 --> 00:01:59.210
the live corners already there.

45
00:01:59.210 --> 00:02:00.750
It's a tool that's always been there, so

46
00:02:00.750 --> 00:02:02.970
it's like they can't really get
rid of the rounded rectangle tool.

47
00:02:02.970 --> 00:02:06.213
>> Really don't need it as much any more
since you've got the live corners on

48
00:02:06.213 --> 00:02:07.536
the normal rectangle?

49
00:02:07.536 --> 00:02:09.260
>> Yeah, it kind of is.

50
00:02:09.260 --> 00:02:12.590
We'll keep it in there,
it can do some things for us.

51
00:02:12.590 --> 00:02:14.863
It's got some predetermined
roundness to it.

52
00:02:14.863 --> 00:02:16.590
Okay, good.

53
00:02:17.590 --> 00:02:19.615
See?
Look at how fast that tool was.

54
00:02:19.615 --> 00:02:22.550
[LAUGH]
>> All the other things still apply to it.

55
00:02:22.550 --> 00:02:24.430
We can grab a corner and

56
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:28.580
we can hold down Shift to constrain it or
Alt to pull it from the middle.

57
00:02:28.580 --> 00:02:31.810
>> Exactly and Shift, and
Alt is all still applied here.

58
00:02:31.810 --> 00:02:33.770
Maybe I'll use it on the other
one just to demonstrate.

59
00:02:33.770 --> 00:02:35.620
Cuz I kinda forgot about those for
right now.

60
00:02:35.620 --> 00:02:37.301
So I can kinda move these around.

61
00:02:37.301 --> 00:02:39.640
Yep, everything is the exact same.

62
00:02:39.640 --> 00:02:45.510
It's just a different tool to create
a different predetermined closed path.

63
00:02:45.510 --> 00:02:49.240
>> Okay, so the path is different but
it still has a fill,

64
00:02:49.240 --> 00:02:51.150
still has a stroke,
all the same properties everything.

65
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:54.027
>> Yep, we can make this blue and,
well, that's green,

66
00:02:54.027 --> 00:02:57.250
or whatever color you feel like doing and,
there you go.

67
00:02:57.250 --> 00:03:00.715
So, let's take all those little
rounded rectangles guys off and

68
00:03:00.715 --> 00:03:02.830
let's go to the circle tool.

69
00:03:02.830 --> 00:03:04.710
So with circle tools, same idea.

70
00:03:04.710 --> 00:03:09.720
I can hold my Alt key and go from the
center so I'll just click hold and drag.

71
00:03:09.720 --> 00:03:14.160
I can hold that Shift key to go ahead
make that constrained proportions,

72
00:03:14.160 --> 00:03:15.440
make a perfect circle.

73
00:03:15.440 --> 00:03:18.030
When you're holding down your keys one
little thing you should always let go of

74
00:03:18.030 --> 00:03:21.720
your mouse first before
you let go of the keys.

75
00:03:21.720 --> 00:03:25.997
I do it almost the same, but when you're
first starting out, I know people, they're

76
00:03:25.997 --> 00:03:30.118
concentrating so much, and they'll let go
of the keys and then let go of the mouse.

77
00:03:30.118 --> 00:03:31.460
And it's like, what just happened?

78
00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:35.080
It's not remembering, it's not completing
the thought, if you want to say,

79
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:36.010
when you let go of the mouse.

80
00:03:36.010 --> 00:03:38.830
So just kinda be aware of that
when you first start out.

81
00:03:38.830 --> 00:03:40.800
After a while it just
becomes second nature.

82
00:03:40.800 --> 00:03:42.720
You don't even think about it really,
it just happens.

83
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:46.414
So we've got all of our wonderful circles.

84
00:03:46.414 --> 00:03:52.977
One thing that I would like to show
you about the circle tool particularly

85
00:03:52.977 --> 00:03:59.771
is that it's got some some new icons
in it that weren't there before in CC.

86
00:03:59.771 --> 00:04:02.990
And it almost is like the Pac-Man,
it's the pie making tool or

87
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:04.893
whatever you want to call it.

88
00:04:04.893 --> 00:04:08.104
I honestly don't know its real name,
it just makes it a pie.

89
00:04:08.104 --> 00:04:12.819
So you can see that right here on any
circle on the right hand side there's

90
00:04:12.819 --> 00:04:15.560
this little notch sticking out.

91
00:04:15.560 --> 00:04:16.310
Right there.

92
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:19.610
So that little guy right there,
that's my handle for

93
00:04:19.610 --> 00:04:22.370
when you hover over it actually
puts like a little Pac-Man.

94
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:26.930
I'm referring to it to a Pac-Man but it's
a little pie guy, and if you click, hold,

95
00:04:26.930 --> 00:04:32.605
and drag, you can actually open
up the circle to make well,

96
00:04:32.605 --> 00:04:36.110
a pie pr a Pac-Man.

97
00:04:36.110 --> 00:04:37.980
>> Which before we would have
had to create another shape and

98
00:04:37.980 --> 00:04:38.910
try to cut it out.

99
00:04:40.150 --> 00:04:45.968
>> Yeah, you would have to go into
more advanced Shape combinations to-

100
00:04:45.968 --> 00:04:47.025
>> Merging paths.

101
00:04:47.025 --> 00:04:51.536
>> Yes, yes, which we can go over with
the path finder panel, so [LAUGH].

102
00:04:51.536 --> 00:04:54.205
Good segue into advanced modifications.

103
00:04:54.205 --> 00:04:56.695
And so
you can kinda change things like that.

104
00:04:56.695 --> 00:05:01.328
You also have the same
corner modification but

105
00:05:01.328 --> 00:05:05.023
there's some newer guys in the top.

106
00:05:05.023 --> 00:05:09.140
There's like this little circle guy,
we got right here, hold on here we go.

107
00:05:09.140 --> 00:05:11.620
That guy right there,
it's a different icon.

108
00:05:11.620 --> 00:05:16.740
I think it's just indicating that
you have a pie circle going on,

Yeah.

570
00:28:05.638 --> 00:28:07.055
Double-click outside,

571
00:28:07.055 --> 00:28:10.861
then I'm coming all the way out of
isolation mode instead of going up.

572
00:28:10.861 --> 00:28:13.320
Might as well throw this in there, because
we talked about layers a little bit.

573
00:28:13.320 --> 00:28:15.372
There is one more other way
that you could do this.

574
00:28:15.372 --> 00:28:21.117
And you can control how you can select and
modify things from in your layers panel.

575
00:28:21.117 --> 00:28:23.464
If I expand out this group here, and

576
00:28:23.464 --> 00:28:27.699
here you can see it in the thumbnail
that these are my stars here.

577
00:28:27.699 --> 00:28:28.478
Little, oops.

578
00:28:28.478 --> 00:28:31.697
Sorry, I was trying to
get to my zoom tool.

579
00:28:31.697 --> 00:28:34.030
Hod on, let me back up.

580
00:28:34.030 --> 00:28:37.177
Okay.

581
00:28:37.177 --> 00:28:38.453
Let's back up a few more times.

582
00:28:38.453 --> 00:28:39.255
Now let's redo.

583
00:28:39.255 --> 00:28:40.636
There we go.
Now we go.

584
00:28:40.636 --> 00:28:41.878
Sorry, I had to get myself there.

585
00:28:41.878 --> 00:28:43.875
I was trying to do this,
I just hit the wrong key.

586
00:28:43.875 --> 00:28:45.233
So I'm in the layer one.

587
00:28:45.233 --> 00:28:45.999
I'm in the group, and I've expanded.

588
00:28:45.999 --> 00:28:52.456
So, there's my purple and
green stars right?

589
00:28:52.456 --> 00:28:54.184
Okay, from here I can take,

590
00:28:54.184 --> 00:28:58.955
now if you just single click on the layer
that's not actually doing anything.

591
00:28:58.955 --> 00:29:03.289
Okay you're just kind of getting into that
particular place within the layers panel.

592
00:29:03.289 --> 00:29:07.294
This little circle guy
over here to the right.

593
00:29:07.294 --> 00:29:08.676
Right there.

594
00:29:08.676 --> 00:29:16.045
If you click on that you're actually
selecting that item on the art board.

595
00:29:16.045 --> 00:29:20.832
So it's kind of a neat way of saying
I only want to be on that one thing

596
00:29:20.832 --> 00:29:24.180
that's all the way down
within those layers.

597
00:29:24.180 --> 00:29:28.540
So I click that, I know that I'm on it and
now I can just come over here and

598
00:29:28.540 --> 00:29:31.914
I can change this to like,
red or black, or whatever.

599
00:29:31.914 --> 00:29:33.795
So I don't even have to
go into isolation mode.

600
00:29:33.795 --> 00:29:36.011
I don't have to go ahead and ungroup.

601
00:29:36.011 --> 00:29:36.779
I don't have to do anything.

602
00:29:36.779 --> 00:29:40.034
I should select that particular
thing from the layers panel,

603
00:29:40.034 --> 00:29:43.237
by going over to that left hand side and
clicking the circle.

604
00:29:43.237 --> 00:29:46.931
>> In a complex logo, or diagram that
could be a lot easier than trying to drill

605
00:29:46.931 --> 00:29:49.347
down through the shape by
double clicking on it.

606
00:29:49.347 --> 00:29:49.941
>> Yeah, this is huge.

607
00:29:49.941 --> 00:29:51.044
I use this a lot.

608
00:29:51.044 --> 00:29:53.006
Complex drawings.

609
00:29:53.006 --> 00:29:55.559
You have layers upon layers and layers,

610
00:29:55.559 --> 00:30:00.075
just path after path and there
are groups and they're all the way down.

611
00:30:00.075 --> 00:30:04.730
And sometimes, I'll just actually,
if I'm getting somebody else's work or

612
00:30:04.730 --> 00:30:08.132
I just start clicking on
the circles on the layers panel and

613
00:30:08.132 --> 00:30:12.805
I'm watching what's out there on the art
board and seeing what's turning on.

614
00:30:13.815 --> 00:30:14.395
There's that.

615
00:30:14.395 --> 00:30:16.277
Okay, now I know what that is.

616
00:30:16.277 --> 00:30:19.079
I know that's in a group,
within a group, that's in layer one.

617
00:30:19.079 --> 00:30:20.078
>> Wow.

618
00:30:20.078 --> 00:30:21.274
>> So
you just kinda click up those circles.

619
00:30:21.274 --> 00:30:22.191
>> Alright Vaughn.

620
00:30:22.191 --> 00:30:26.927
Lot of great information there on doing
some basic shapes and basic formatting,

621
00:30:26.927 --> 00:30:29.240
as well as, some extra tips on layers.

622
00:30:29.240 --> 00:30:32.118
And some cool little tricks that
we can use in the future and

623
00:30:32.118 --> 00:30:35.727
we'll go over layers and much more
depth obviously in future episodes.

624
00:30:35.727 --> 00:30:37.131
So we thank you for that, enjoyed it.

625
00:30:37.131 --> 00:30:38.641
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

626
00:30:38.641 --> 00:30:41.764
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

627
00:30:41.764 --> 00:30:42.704
>> I'm Vaughn Smith.

628
00:30:42.704 --> 00:30:43.981
>> And we'll see you next time.

629
00:30:43.981 --> 00:30:44.504
>> Bye.

630
00:30:44.504 --> 00:30:52.400
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Grids, Guides and Aligning
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.053 --> 00:00:10.053
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.219 --> 00:00:15.230
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.230 --> 00:00:20.659
I'm your host Mike Roderick, and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:20.659 --> 00:00:24.811
And specifically, we're gonna be looking
at how we can arrange and place.

5
00:00:24.811 --> 00:00:30.340
And order and space and really lay out
our different objects in Illustrator.

6
00:00:30.340 --> 00:00:32.410
And here to help us, of course,
is Miss Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:32.410 --> 00:00:33.240
How's it going Vonne?

8
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:38.070
>> Great, glad to be back yet
again to talk about aligning.

9
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:42.720
And gridding, and guiding, and making sure
that everything is in its proper place.

10
00:00:42.720 --> 00:00:46.240
Cuz we could build shapes all day long and

11
00:00:46.240 --> 00:00:48.400
put all sorts of wonderful paths and
colors on it.

12
00:00:48.400 --> 00:00:52.750
But making sure our art project or

13
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:57.100
whatever document that we're
working on is aligned to the T.

14
00:00:57.100 --> 00:00:59.780
Or to the point I should say,
is very important, so

15
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:03.350
this is why I wanted to make this
episode that covers everything.

16
00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:07.820
Grids, guides, snaps, aligning,
even throw in some layers in there,

17
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:09.760
because I feel like they all go together.

18
00:01:09.760 --> 00:01:12.910
I think we've covered or touched a few
of these things on other episodes.

19
00:01:12.910 --> 00:01:18.190
But I wanted to get it in one central
location to go over all of these points.

20
00:01:18.190 --> 00:01:19.320
>> Perfect I like it.

21
00:01:19.320 --> 00:01:22.170
>> Yeah, all right so
let's just jump right in.

22
00:01:22.170 --> 00:01:23.920
And I've got Illustrator open.

23
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:28.410
We have gone over the new
file dialog box before and

24
00:01:28.410 --> 00:01:30.560
the different profiles and
it does start with our unit.

25
00:01:30.560 --> 00:01:34.476
So let's just say that I wasn't
really paying attention.

26
00:01:34.476 --> 00:01:37.330
And I went to go make a document and
I said okay,

27
00:01:37.330 --> 00:01:39.470
here we go let’s just go for it.

28
00:01:39.470 --> 00:01:44.470
And then I realize when I start
making something, I see my square or

29
00:01:44.470 --> 00:01:45.390
anything like that.

30
00:01:45.390 --> 00:01:52.090
When I'm go into my x and y or
my width and height in my transform panel.

31
00:01:52.090 --> 00:01:57.420
It's not in the measurement that I want it
to be in I'm not wanting to be in points.

32
00:01:57.420 --> 00:01:58.700
>> Delete it, start all over.

33
00:01:58.700 --> 00:02:01.780
>> Well you could, at this point yeah,
it might be a good option.

34
00:02:01.780 --> 00:02:05.580
And I did show you in the File >
New Document, the document settings, wait,

35
00:02:05.580 --> 00:02:06.750
let me get out of here first.

36
00:02:06.750 --> 00:02:10.000
There we go, and if I go into
the Document Setup, you could go ahead and

37
00:02:10.000 --> 00:02:12.590
change the units right there,
so that's fine.

38
00:02:12.590 --> 00:02:15.732
But you can do it one more way,
of course there's always 15

39
00:02:15.732 --> 00:02:19.255
ways to do things in Illustrator,
and that's through the rulers.

40
00:02:19.255 --> 00:02:24.592
And let's bring up the rulers first, and
talk about what we can do with them.

41
00:02:24.592 --> 00:02:28.885
Cuz it's not just changing the units,
it's actually using the rulers to make

42
00:02:28.885 --> 00:02:32.370
guides into measure things,
if you wanna say.

43
00:02:32.370 --> 00:02:37.210
So if we're looking for
something to see, it's in the view menu.

44
00:02:37.210 --> 00:02:39.200
So you can go to View Rulers, but

45
00:02:39.200 --> 00:02:43.670
the keyboard trick is Control+R or
Command+R for Show Ruler.

46
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:46.160
So I wanted to show you that before
I actually did it on the keyboard.

47
00:02:47.230 --> 00:02:50.500
So I have my rulers and it's in the pi,
no, it's not in the pica, we're in points.

48
00:02:51.700 --> 00:02:54.620
The measurement system so
if you right-click on your rulers

49
00:02:54.620 --> 00:02:57.627
you can actually change
the measurement system from here.

50
00:02:57.627 --> 00:02:58.471
>> Convinient.

51
00:02:58.471 --> 00:03:02.050
>> Yeah right, so I can go up to here and
really want to be in inches or

52
00:03:02.050 --> 00:03:05.680
in pixels and I go there and
you can see that changes on both.

53
00:03:05.680 --> 00:03:10.630
For Illustrator it does do both your x and
y rule at the same time.

54
00:03:10.630 --> 00:03:13.200
In some other products,
it actually does them independently.

55
00:03:13.200 --> 00:03:14.950
So if you're in other Adobe products,

56
00:03:14.950 --> 00:03:17.770
just watch to make sure that
it catches both of them.

57
00:03:19.500 --> 00:03:23.080
In Design actually has it separately also.

58
00:03:23.080 --> 00:03:26.790
So I've got my rulers in
the measurement system that I want.

59
00:03:26.790 --> 00:03:30.550
And so you can see that when I'm
moving it around, it's hard to see.

60
00:03:30.550 --> 00:03:35.690
Because it's, you see that little dotted
line that's moving across on my ruler?

61
00:03:35.690 --> 00:03:44.810
That's indicating to me about where it's
hitting on the document, on the ruling.

62
00:03:44.810 --> 00:03:48.420
It's kind of hard to see on that one,
but just look for

63
00:03:48.420 --> 00:03:51.120
the little dotted line when you're moving
around, so you know where you're at.

64
00:03:51.120 --> 00:03:54.342
Whoops, I just hit the wrong
keyboard shortcut.

65
00:03:54.342 --> 00:03:57.550
[LAUGH] I hit Ctrl+O or
Cmd+O instead of Cmd+0.

66
00:03:57.550 --> 00:03:59.070
And I do that a lot,

67
00:03:59.070 --> 00:04:02.045
actually, cuz they're very close together,
right on top of each other.

68
00:04:02.045 --> 00:04:04.250
[LAUGH] So that's what I did there.

69
00:04:04.250 --> 00:04:09.930
But, the other thing that I use
the rulers for is to make guides.

70
00:04:09.930 --> 00:04:11.552
Guides, what would a guide be?

71
00:04:11.552 --> 00:04:16.630
I wanna make sure that I have
things within a specific area or

72
00:04:16.630 --> 00:04:18.400
something that I wanted to align to.

73
00:04:18.400 --> 00:04:21.590
For example,
in Illustrator you don’t have margins.

74
00:04:21.590 --> 00:04:27.250
So If I’m doing a page layout that
requires half inch margins all around

75
00:04:27.250 --> 00:04:32.310
I don't just go into the margin command,
it doesn't exist.

76
00:04:32.310 --> 00:04:34.980
>> Okay.
>> So you have to make them for you,

77
00:04:34.980 --> 00:04:37.030
you have to make those margins or guides.

78
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:40.510
Or I wanna do a half page ad where I wanna
make sure I know exactly where that half

79
00:04:40.510 --> 00:04:42.800
page split is gonna go,
all those types of things.

80
00:04:42.800 --> 00:04:48.590
So to make ruler guides,
you drag a guide out from the ruler.

81
00:04:48.590 --> 00:04:52.970
So if I start from my x ruler and
I click, hold and

82
00:04:52.970 --> 00:04:58.360
drag down you can see that this
line comes down on my y axis.

83
00:04:59.520 --> 00:05:01.980
So I wanna make, and
I'm gonna guesstimate here,

84
00:05:01.980 --> 00:05:05.040
maybe that's about a half inch on here,
and then I let go.

85
00:05:05.040 --> 00:05:11.100
And you can see that your guides
always show up in this bright cyan or

86
00:05:11.100 --> 00:05:11.670
bright blue.

87
00:05:11.670 --> 00:05:16.210
Whatever color we want to talk about what
that is and that becomes my ruler guide.

88
00:05:16.210 --> 00:05:19.420
And let me just drag one out and
I don't know if I'm being exactly

89
00:05:20.600 --> 00:05:23.180
accurate right now but
I'll get to that in just a second.

90
00:05:23.180 --> 00:05:27.510
So now I'll grab another guide out here so
I've made this guide.

91
00:05:27.510 --> 00:05:30.190
So if I take a square and

92
00:05:30.190 --> 00:05:33.930
move it close you can almost feel it
kind of snap right to that guide.

93
00:05:33.930 --> 00:05:38.050
And I can put it up here, boop,
and then it goes right there.

94
00:05:38.050 --> 00:05:41.960
So it's just another way of
saying I know that this is

95
00:05:41.960 --> 00:05:44.160
hitting those guides right on those x and
y axis.

96
00:05:44.160 --> 00:05:47.170
I know that this is where
it's supposed to be.

97
00:05:47.170 --> 00:05:49.225
Now of course that's if I
know where the guides are.

98
00:05:49.225 --> 00:05:52.700
[LAUGH] On the ruler, because I don't know
if that's exactly half inch it doesn't

99
00:05:52.700 --> 00:05:54.280
really look like it right now.

100
00:05:54.280 --> 00:06:00.180
So how can I make sure that this guide
is in the place that I want to be?

101
00:06:00.180 --> 00:06:04.834
So just like if I had a square or any
item on my art board I would select it.

102
00:06:04.834 --> 00:06:10.600
So I go to take this guide and I click and
I click and it won't, I can't select it.

103
00:06:10.600 --> 00:06:14.800
That's because guides are locked by
default, which is a good thing because

104
00:06:14.800 --> 00:06:17.970
a lot of times you don't want
to accidentally move your guide.

105
00:06:17.970 --> 00:06:23.260
Because it's supposed to be a fixed point
of stay on there, yeah, don't move.

106
00:06:23.260 --> 00:06:29.355
So they're locked which is great, how do I
not lock them, I guess we can say unlock?

107
00:06:29.355 --> 00:06:32.510
[LAUGH] Okay, so if I wanna unlock
this guide the easiest way that

108
00:06:32.510 --> 00:06:36.070
I do it if I have nothing else
selected on my art board.

109
00:06:36.070 --> 00:06:40.950
If you right click in a blank area you
can see that you've got your options for

110
00:06:40.950 --> 00:06:42.130
your guides right here.

111
00:06:42.130 --> 00:06:45.790
So it says lock guides is checked,
and so I can click on that and

112
00:06:45.790 --> 00:06:47.420
I can unlock my guides.

113
00:06:47.420 --> 00:06:51.820
And now when I select this guide
I can actually drag it, and

114
00:06:51.820 --> 00:06:55.480
I can move it around and
I can do what I want with it.

115
00:06:55.480 --> 00:06:59.740
And while I have it selected,
just like if I had any other shape or

116
00:06:59.740 --> 00:07:01.000
anything else selected.

117
00:07:01.000 --> 00:07:06.520
I can type in the coordinates
that I want this guide to be at.

118
00:07:06.520 --> 00:07:09.240
Now because of the resolution on my
monitor, you can't see my transform,

119
00:07:09.240 --> 00:07:11.160
it will usually be up
in that control panel.

120
00:07:11.160 --> 00:07:16.020
So I'm just gonna go to Window,
and go to the Transform Panel.

121
00:07:17.120 --> 00:07:20.606
Because the Transform Panel is where you
can pick up all of those different things

122
00:07:20.606 --> 00:07:21.280
that you have.

123
00:07:21.280 --> 00:07:25.130
The x, y, h, and w and
some other things like that.

124
00:07:25.130 --> 00:07:29.030
So here, I've got my guide selected,

125
00:07:29.030 --> 00:07:34.244
I know I want that to be on
my x axis exactly 0.5 in.

126
00:07:34.244 --> 00:07:38.550
So now I know that this selected margin.

127
00:07:38.550 --> 00:07:41.130
Well I'm calling it a margin because I
said it when we were doing an example that

128
00:07:41.130 --> 00:07:41.825
it would be a margin.

129
00:07:41.825 --> 00:07:46.700
[LAUGH] but this guide is exactly
at that x coordinate of 0.5, so

130
00:07:46.700 --> 00:07:48.080
I know that that's good.

131
00:07:48.080 --> 00:07:52.511
So I can then take this guide here,
yeah, there we go, now it's selected.

132
00:07:52.511 --> 00:07:57.968
And now I can say that this right here,
see, it's at 0.5202.

133
00:07:57.968 --> 00:07:59.628
Yeah, we're just a little off.

134
00:07:59.628 --> 00:08:01.010
So then I can go again and
manually type it in.

135
00:08:01.010 --> 00:08:01.579
>> It was pretty close.

136
00:08:01.579 --> 00:08:02.902
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, pretty close, yeah,

137
00:08:02.902 --> 00:08:03.646
I was good on that one.

138
00:08:03.646 --> 00:08:06.000
>> But when you send these off to
printers and things like that,

139
00:08:06.000 --> 00:08:07.347
close is usually not good enough.

140
00:08:07.347 --> 00:08:10.590
>> Yeah, you wanna make sure that
you're accurate on anything.

141
00:08:10.590 --> 00:08:12.850
Whether it's print or Web.

142
00:08:12.850 --> 00:08:14.840
I'm very OCD about making sure that it is.

143
00:08:14.840 --> 00:08:16.020
Are we aligned in the right place?

144
00:08:16.020 --> 00:08:17.753
Are we all in the right segment?

145
00:08:17.753 --> 00:08:22.422
So once you've unlocked your guides,
set them in the place that you wanna be,

146
00:08:22.422 --> 00:08:24.064
you wanna lock them again.

147
00:08:24.064 --> 00:08:25.650
You can Right-click again, but

148
00:08:25.650 --> 00:08:29.000
I should probably show you where
the other options are in the menu.

149
00:08:29.000 --> 00:08:30.170
It's in the View menu still.

150
00:08:30.170 --> 00:08:33.344
So if you go into View and you go to
Guides, you have the Hide Guides,

151
00:08:33.344 --> 00:08:34.033
Lock Guides.

152
00:08:34.033 --> 00:08:38.000
We haven't got into the hides yet
but the Lock Guides is not checked.

153
00:08:38.000 --> 00:08:41.845
So if I click it, just to go back to
that View menu again so you can see it.

154
00:08:41.845 --> 00:08:46.500
You can see you've got Lock Guides, okay?

155
00:08:46.500 --> 00:08:47.528
That's, lovely.

156
00:08:47.528 --> 00:08:52.350
And with that hide guides, cuz sometimes
you might not want to see these.

157
00:08:52.350 --> 00:08:56.270
Because especially if you're
wanting to clear everything off so

158
00:08:56.270 --> 00:08:58.310
you can see it in Preview mode almost.

159
00:08:58.310 --> 00:09:02.870
You can hide the guides, so
if you go to View and you go to Guides and

160
00:09:02.870 --> 00:09:05.680
you go to Hide Guides,
notice that there is a shortcut for that.

161
00:09:05.680 --> 00:09:10.360
There is a Cmd-; or Ctrl-; to hide them.

162
00:09:10.360 --> 00:09:12.280
I actually use that quite often.

163
00:09:12.280 --> 00:09:15.770
So if I hide them,
you can kind of see them without it and

164
00:09:15.770 --> 00:09:17.030
then of course you can bring it back.

165
