617
00:32:33.490 --> 00:32:37.400
And we'll name this circles, off the bat,
and we'll say, these are my circles.

618
00:32:38.830 --> 00:32:42.600
In the layers,
anytime you have a layer you can

619
00:32:42.600 --> 00:32:47.360
see that you have items selected
by the little dots over here.

620
00:32:47.360 --> 00:32:53.100
Those little dots indicate that you are,
that is the selected item that you have,

621
00:32:53.100 --> 00:32:55.300
okay, just like if I click on
there there's a little dot, and

622
00:32:55.300 --> 00:32:58.480
everything right that, the other,
you can do it in reverse.

623
00:32:58.480 --> 00:33:02.210
If you wanted to select
an item from the layers panel,

624
00:33:02.210 --> 00:33:04.090
you don't just click on the layer.

625
00:33:04.090 --> 00:33:09.640
You have to click on the little circley
guy, little circle guy next to that layer

626
00:33:09.640 --> 00:33:14.770
item, and so I'm holding the shift key
over here, so I can click on the circles

627
00:33:14.770 --> 00:33:19.320
of each one of those layer items, and so
now I know that I have all the ellipses.

628
00:33:19.320 --> 00:33:24.570
This is really good to be able to isolate,
and select things in a very complex

629
00:33:24.570 --> 00:33:29.080
design, so you can have it ready to go,
so I've got all these dots going on here.

630
00:33:29.080 --> 00:33:32.670
Now, I don't go from the sub layers,

631
00:33:32.670 --> 00:33:36.950
if you wanna call it, you see there's that
top one, see, that's the squares layer.

632
00:33:36.950 --> 00:33:41.680
So, it's basically saying that all
of the selected items within this

633
00:33:41.680 --> 00:33:47.040
layer when I take this little dot,
and I click hold, and drag it.

634
00:33:47.040 --> 00:33:51.870
You can see how it goes from
there to there, then I let go,

635
00:33:51.870 --> 00:33:56.260
and all of those things just
moved up into the circles layer.

636
00:33:56.260 --> 00:33:57.540
>> Okay.
>> It's super handy,

637
00:33:57.540 --> 00:33:58.210
I use this all the time.

638
00:33:58.210 --> 00:34:00.620
>> So it's not saying you're
gonna move that entire layer,

639
00:34:00.620 --> 00:34:03.590
it's saying I'm gonna move all your
selected objects from this layer.

640
00:34:03.590 --> 00:34:06.830
>> From this, yeah, exactly, and
I mean you can do it individually,

641
00:34:06.830 --> 00:34:10.500
because if I was like,
let's say I'm on the hexagon layer.

642
00:34:10.500 --> 00:34:13.610
Right, I know I'm on the hexagon layer,
cuz you can see it's kinda highlighted,

643
00:34:13.610 --> 00:34:14.660
if you wanna say.

644
00:34:14.660 --> 00:34:17.820
That's where, if you start making layers
you gotta be very aware of where am I?

645
00:34:17.820 --> 00:34:21.830
What layer am I on, what do I need to
be on, so If I'm on the hexagon layer,

646
00:34:21.830 --> 00:34:27.280
and I start drawing a circle like this,
wait nope,

647
00:34:27.280 --> 00:34:30.240
you're in the wrong layer
there little circley guy.

648
00:34:30.240 --> 00:34:35.670
You need to be down in the circle layer,
so in this sense, I could draw, since

649
00:34:35.670 --> 00:34:39.700
it's just one item, I could just take that
little dot here, drag it down into there,

650
00:34:39.700 --> 00:34:44.600
and now it's in here, and so now I've
got my circles hanging out over there.

651
00:34:44.600 --> 00:34:46.480
Same thing with stacking order,

652
00:34:46.480 --> 00:34:50.150
if I take this guy and
arrange it to the back, right?

653
00:34:50.150 --> 00:34:55.370
It's going to the back of the circles
layer, it's not going down in the squares,

654
00:34:55.370 --> 00:34:59.950
or anything like that,
it's just staying within it's layer, okay?

655
00:34:59.950 --> 00:35:02.790
And I know we're like,
probably need to go soon Sam, but

656
00:35:02.790 --> 00:35:03.602
just give me two more seconds.

657
00:35:03.602 --> 00:35:04.142
[LAUGH]
>> No, no.

658
00:35:04.142 --> 00:35:05.892
No hurry, it's good stuff.

659
00:35:05.892 --> 00:35:06.512
>> It is, right?

660
00:35:06.512 --> 00:35:07.342
I just get, so excited and

661
00:35:07.342 --> 00:35:12.280
I want to complete the thought, so this
one right here with these two hexagons, if

662
00:35:12.280 --> 00:35:16.610
I take this, I just want to give you some
more examples of what happens in layers,

663
00:35:16.610 --> 00:35:18.370
if I group those two,

664
00:35:18.370 --> 00:35:23.830
you can see that, I've got a group
within that hexagon layer.

665
00:35:23.830 --> 00:35:28.550
So, groups will come into
layers like that, and I can

666
00:35:29.800 --> 00:35:34.360
see where they are, and I can go down
into each one of them, and I can go, so I

667
00:35:34.360 --> 00:35:38.630
just want to show that if you group stuff
and you can put layers inside of layers.

668
00:35:38.630 --> 00:35:42.000
You can put groups inside of groups,
so you just have to kind of watch for

669
00:35:42.000 --> 00:35:45.700
that organizational structure,
where are you in that layers panel,

670
00:35:45.700 --> 00:35:50.990
what layer do I have selected, and
all of that kind of wonderful stuff.

671
00:35:50.990 --> 00:35:55.450
You can also lock layers which is really
good, so let's just say like I wanted to

672
00:35:55.450 --> 00:35:58.180
take this, and make like, for example I
wanna make like a colored background,

673
00:35:58.180 --> 00:36:02.150
right, I wanna make a green maybe green's
not good, cuz I've got green on the other

674
00:36:02.150 --> 00:36:05.455
green stuff, there we go,
no let's go with this guy, I'm sorry.

675
00:36:05.455 --> 00:36:07.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just pick something Bon,

676
00:36:07.700 --> 00:36:08.293
okay there we go.

677
00:36:08.293 --> 00:36:12.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so I've got this in here,

678
00:36:12.170 --> 00:36:16.410
if I put this down, because I want
this to be the colored background,

679
00:36:16.410 --> 00:36:19.090
well if I start selecting things, and

680
00:36:19.090 --> 00:36:23.560
I'm trying to click off, I keep
accidentally selecting that background.

681
00:36:23.560 --> 00:36:25.590
>> Right.
>> That's where using layers,

682
00:36:25.590 --> 00:36:28.820
you can say lock this little guy here,
okay?

683
00:36:28.820 --> 00:36:30.890
So, I got this layer locked,

684
00:36:30.890 --> 00:36:36.530
now I'm never actually selecting it on
the document, so I can move things around,

685
00:36:36.530 --> 00:36:40.040
click off of it, and that guy's there,
does it have to be in its own layer?

686
00:36:40.040 --> 00:36:45.050
No, you can actually take individual ones,
like if I don't want to be

687
00:36:45.050 --> 00:36:51.020
able to select that, you can lock it
within sub layers within a layer,

688
00:36:51.020 --> 00:36:54.440
so it doesn't have to be by itself,
but, if you lock a layer,

689
00:36:54.440 --> 00:36:59.870
notice that it will lock all of
the items within the layer that it's in.

690
00:36:59.870 --> 00:37:05.540
So just kind of be aware of that option,
and be careful about turning them on,

691
00:37:05.540 --> 00:37:08.960
and off, but, those are different things,
like why can't I select it?

692
00:37:08.960 --> 00:37:10.190
Look in the layers panel.

693
00:37:10.190 --> 00:37:11.480
Where is all of these things?

694
00:37:11.480 --> 00:37:12.840
What's missing?

695
00:37:12.840 --> 00:37:16.560
Always, look at your layers panel, because
that will tell you everything that's in

696
00:37:16.560 --> 00:37:21.360
your document, and you can go through it,
and really pinpoint exactly,

697
00:37:21.360 --> 00:37:24.977
what is where you want it to be, and
how to select it to move around,

698
00:37:24.977 --> 00:37:27.970
there we go [LAUGH]
>> Wow, fantastic,

699
00:37:27.970 --> 00:37:32.980
well a lot of great information there, on
how we place objects, or how we organize

700
00:37:32.980 --> 00:37:37.440
the objects within our document aligning
them to the grid turning on our rulers,

701
00:37:37.440 --> 00:37:41.450
creating those guides, as well,
as organizing the document itself, right?

702
00:37:41.450 --> 00:37:44.320
With the different layers,
grouping, locking them, so

703
00:37:44.320 --> 00:37:47.220
we don't accidentally move them,
lots of great information.

704
00:37:47.220 --> 00:37:50.706
Thank you for that, hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching, signing off for

705
00:37:50.706 --> 00:37:51.895
now, I'm Mike Roderick.

706
00:37:51.895 --> 00:37:52.696
>> I'm Bon Smith.

707
00:37:52.696 --> 00:37:54.019
>> And we'll see you next time.

708
00:37:54.019 --> 00:38:02.430
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Advanced Shapes and Paths
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:10.003
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.022 --> 00:00:15.300
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.300 --> 00:00:19.370
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC2015.

4
00:00:21.070 --> 00:00:22.400
And specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:22.400 --> 00:00:25.360
we're gonna be doing some
advanced shapes and paths.

6
00:00:25.360 --> 00:00:27.410
Now, we've already taken
a look at some basic work,

7
00:00:27.410 --> 00:00:29.660
we're gonna be doing some
basic work with shapes.

8
00:00:29.660 --> 00:00:31.620
And now we're just going
to kick it up a notch.

9
00:00:31.620 --> 00:00:33.530
And here to help us with that is Ms.
Vaughn Smith.

10
00:00:33.530 --> 00:00:34.570
How's it going Vaughn?

11
00:00:34.570 --> 00:00:37.010
>> Good, back for more shaping.

12
00:00:37.010 --> 00:00:38.640
We did some basic shapes.

13
00:00:38.640 --> 00:00:41.050
We can draw circles and
squares all day long.

14
00:00:41.050 --> 00:00:46.540
But how we can use those simple shapes
to create more advanced shapes, or

15
00:00:46.540 --> 00:00:52.482
how do I modify my existing shapes to do
more than just be a circle or be a square.

16
00:00:52.482 --> 00:00:55.674
What if I wanna make a Christmas tree,
or some moons, or some mountains,

17
00:00:55.674 --> 00:00:56.453
or what have you?

18
00:00:56.453 --> 00:00:59.360
>> So shapes can grow up
to be whatever they want.

19
00:00:59.360 --> 00:01:00.927
>> Yeah, they start baby and
they get bigger.

20
00:01:00.927 --> 00:01:04.037
>> All right.
So we're gonna do things with that, and

21
00:01:04.037 --> 00:01:08.637
how it can combine all of our paths
because shapes really are paths.

22
00:01:08.637 --> 00:01:13.512
So that's probably something we should
start off right from the beginning is

23
00:01:13.512 --> 00:01:17.787
just reiterating and clarifying
an open path versus a closed path.

24
00:01:17.787 --> 00:01:19.515
Again, back to that basics.

25
00:01:19.515 --> 00:01:23.285
So, let's just jump in
here with our circles.

26
00:01:23.285 --> 00:01:27.983
I have file that I've already created
with a bunch of shapes called pathfinder.

27
00:01:29.835 --> 00:01:33.725
So this is a closed path that
we had talked about before.

28
00:01:33.725 --> 00:01:35.725
It has an inside and it has an outside.

29
00:01:35.725 --> 00:01:39.180
It has a fill and a stroke,
okay, and it's closed.

30
00:01:39.180 --> 00:01:43.050
Then I have an open path,
oops wrong one, there.

31
00:01:43.050 --> 00:01:45.840
This is an open path,
there is no fill here.

32
00:01:45.840 --> 00:01:49.600
All I have is a stroke because this
was created with a line segment tool.

33
00:01:49.600 --> 00:01:52.860
So just the stroke, not the fill.

34
00:01:52.860 --> 00:01:54.800
Okay, so open and closed.

35
00:01:54.800 --> 00:01:58.920
Another thing you'll hear me say,
and this is just me talking,

36
00:01:58.920 --> 00:02:03.450
the whole path versus pieces of a path.

37
00:02:03.450 --> 00:02:07.530
For example, if I go here and this, to me,

38
00:02:07.530 --> 00:02:10.372
looks like, well,
looks like a thing [LAUGH].

39
00:02:10.372 --> 00:02:14.442
>> [LAUGH]
>> It just looks like lines together, but

40
00:02:14.442 --> 00:02:17.850
this is two separate segments, okay?

41
00:02:17.850 --> 00:02:23.360
So there's this guy and then there's
this guy, they're not the same.

42
00:02:23.360 --> 00:02:26.410
They're not the whole path, as I say it.

43
00:02:26.410 --> 00:02:30.664
So you'll probably hear me referring
to that throughout this episode.

44
00:02:30.664 --> 00:02:34.432
And that's what I mean,
the whole versus parts of it.

45
00:02:34.432 --> 00:02:35.222
>> Okay.

46
00:02:35.222 --> 00:02:36.499
Okay.

47
00:02:36.499 --> 00:02:37.970
All right, so if I got this circle.

48
00:02:39.120 --> 00:02:42.735
We're gonna go over the erase,
knife, and scissors tool,

49
00:02:42.735 --> 00:02:45.580
okay, all of these things right over here.

50
00:02:46.960 --> 00:02:51.350
Cuz they do different things,
obviously, cuz they're different tools.

51
00:02:51.350 --> 00:02:52.860
So what do they do?

52
00:02:52.860 --> 00:02:55.010
And I'm gonna click off of everything so
you can see this.

53
00:02:55.010 --> 00:02:58.300
When I have my eraser tool,
you think it erases things, right?

54
00:02:58.300 --> 00:02:59.860
And that's exactly what it does.

55
00:02:59.860 --> 00:03:05.500
But I wanted to show you how it works with
closed paths versus open paths, okay?

56
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:08.580
So if I have this closed path,
you can see that there's like, well, you

57
00:03:08.580 --> 00:03:13.020
can't really see it too well, but I got
a little circle with a crosshair over it.

58
00:03:13.020 --> 00:03:17.797
Because it does have a diameter just
like you would have an eraser in some of

59
00:03:17.797 --> 00:03:21.897
your other products, like Photoshop,
and so on and so forth.

60
00:03:21.897 --> 00:03:24.528
And if I just take this, and
I'm not holding Shift or anything,

61
00:03:24.528 --> 00:03:26.005
I'm just gonna kinda freehand it.

62
00:03:26.005 --> 00:03:30.745
If I just click, hold and drag and
just kind of drag all the way through,

63
00:03:30.745 --> 00:03:35.090
through this shape,
you could see that it's actually cutting,

64
00:03:35.090 --> 00:03:39.514
if you wanna say, or erasing whatever
is between that open path and

65
00:03:39.514 --> 00:03:42.810
close, sorry, that's not an open path.

66
00:03:42.810 --> 00:03:43.650
>> Right.
>> I just told you that

67
00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:44.330
that's a closed path.

68
00:03:44.330 --> 00:03:45.455
That is so a closed path.

69
00:03:45.455 --> 00:03:50.500
[LAUGH] And I'm trying to show you that
when you use the eraser on a closed path

70
00:03:50.500 --> 00:03:51.780
it makes a closed path.

71
00:03:51.780 --> 00:03:55.740
>> So it didn't leave you with two open
paths like you might have thought,

72
00:03:55.740 --> 00:03:58.410
it actually said, all right I'm gonna
go ahead and close these two halves up.

73
00:03:58.410 --> 00:04:01.490
>> Exactly, yeah, so it's still
just saying, okay, here you are,

74
00:04:01.490 --> 00:04:05.480
you are going to be closed off, okay.

75
00:04:05.480 --> 00:04:08.027
Let's give another example so
maybe you can see this.

76
00:04:08.027 --> 00:04:14.304
If I take the eraser tool here, okay,
and I just take and erase this, right.

77
00:04:14.304 --> 00:04:16.614
I'm kind of erasing that thinking okay,

78
00:04:16.614 --> 00:04:21.237
well I'm gonna make this an open path with
a fill, so it's gonna be one whole path.

79
00:04:21.237 --> 00:04:23.322
No, you see how it actually
brings it back, okay?

80
00:04:23.322 --> 00:04:26.194
>> Right.
>> But see if I get it there, it's still

81
00:04:26.194 --> 00:04:32.261
closing it off enough, so you can see that
it will always close off your closed path.

82
00:04:32.261 --> 00:04:33.710
>> Okay.
>> That's just kinda what it does.

83
00:04:33.710 --> 00:04:37.476
And it does have a diameter, okay,
so that's something to watch for.

84
00:04:37.476 --> 00:04:41.780
If you wanted to change the diameter
of your eraser, I use my hotkeys,

85
00:04:41.780 --> 00:04:43.820
the bracket keys, okay?

86
00:04:43.820 --> 00:04:44.960
Same as in Photoshop,

87
00:04:44.960 --> 00:04:49.610
you can right bracket up and
you see how it makes the diameter bigger?

88
00:04:49.610 --> 00:04:51.070
Left bracket makes it smaller.

89
00:04:51.070 --> 00:04:53.400
You could also double-click on
your tool and you can go ahead and

90
00:04:53.400 --> 00:04:55.010
change the size of it.

91
00:04:55.010 --> 00:04:59.969
And you can also see that it can be a
random size, I'm not sure if I want that.

92
00:04:59.969 --> 00:05:02.797
>> [LAUGH]
>> But the angle on the roundness,

93
00:05:02.797 --> 00:05:05.194
it doesn't have to be a perfect circle for

94
00:05:05.194 --> 00:05:07.877
your eraser,
you can do other things, okay.

95
00:05:07.877 --> 00:05:09.988
But that's basically what it does.

96
00:05:09.988 --> 00:05:14.826
So if I wanna create a big open space,
if you wanna say I wannna cut it out

97
00:05:14.826 --> 00:05:18.769
with my eraser,
then that's what the eraser tool does.

98
00:05:18.769 --> 00:05:23.410
And it will work on a closed, sorry,
I keep mixing this up, don't I?

99
00:05:23.410 --> 00:05:26.243
>> Easy to do.

100
00:05:26.243 --> 00:05:30.343
>> This open path, see if I erase,
it's just gonna take out an entire

101
00:05:30.343 --> 00:05:35.190
section of that open path and still just
give me the pieces of that open path.

102
00:05:35.190 --> 00:05:38.550
>> So, basically, with the eraser,
if it starts as an open path it stays.

103
00:05:38.550 --> 00:05:41.340
If it starts as a closed path,
it'll remain a closed path.

104
00:05:41.340 --> 00:05:43.291
>> Yes, perfect, good job [LAUGH].

105
00:05:43.291 --> 00:05:46.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, now, you also have the knife and

106
00:05:46.120 --> 00:05:46.690
the scissors.

107
00:05:46.690 --> 00:05:52.660
Now, the knife is not extremely accurate,
okay, but it does what it does.

108
00:05:52.660 --> 00:05:54.440
So let me go through this.

109
00:05:54.440 --> 00:05:58.290
It basically will cut through something,
but

110
00:05:58.290 --> 00:06:03.290
it's not gonna give you a gap like
you have with the eraser tool, okay.

111
00:06:03.290 --> 00:06:05.918
Let's go with this.

112
00:06:05.918 --> 00:06:09.396
You don't have to have it selected, if you
have it selected, you're basically saying,

113
00:06:09.396 --> 00:06:11.850
I don't want you to cut anything else but
the thing that I have.

114
00:06:11.850 --> 00:06:14.680
But I wanted to show you
that it works without it.

115
00:06:14.680 --> 00:06:18.540
So if have this knife and I click,
hold and drag, and you can see

116
00:06:18.540 --> 00:06:23.550
even if I hold my Shift key, which I'm
doing right now, it doesn't stay straight.

117
00:06:23.550 --> 00:06:25.170
It just cuts it, okay.

118
00:06:25.170 --> 00:06:30.300
But do you see how it does not make
that space that the Eraser tool did?

119
00:06:30.300 --> 00:06:33.890
So, if I go back to my black arrow tool,
you can see, and I clicked off first.

120
00:06:33.890 --> 00:06:39.610
You see how it's creating,
it's cutting it, not very accurately,

121
00:06:39.610 --> 00:06:43.000
and it's making that closed
path with a closed path.

122
00:06:43.000 --> 00:06:44.420
>> Right, kinda makes sense.

123
00:06:44.420 --> 00:06:48.650
So I'm thinking of the eraser with my
kindergarten pencil, big fat thing.

124
00:06:48.650 --> 00:06:51.723
It's gonna leave a pretty
wide swath through there.

125
00:06:51.723 --> 00:06:54.910
But if I take that really sharp knife edge
and cut through that, it's nice and fine.

126
00:06:56.180 --> 00:06:59.161
>> Yes [LAUGH],
that's a great description, thank you.

127
00:06:59.161 --> 00:07:02.006

It's almost like a cutting it all out in
a sense, but it's not really cutting.

590
00:30:39.960 --> 00:30:46.800
And if I wanted to say have these
two pieces right here work together.

591
00:30:46.800 --> 00:30:49.560
Cuz right now I have a plus
sign on the mouse pointer.

592
00:30:49.560 --> 00:30:54.010
I can just click, hold and drag across,
and then it says, here is this one, okay.

593
00:30:54.010 --> 00:30:55.610
And notice it turned orange, right?

594
00:30:55.610 --> 00:30:56.400
Why'd it turn orange?

595
00:30:56.400 --> 00:31:01.205
Because that's the color of the path,
or the fill that I had before I started

596
00:31:01.205 --> 00:31:05.940
using the shape builder tool.

597
00:31:05.940 --> 00:31:07.000
I get them all mixed up.

598
00:31:07.000 --> 00:31:10.210
Okay, now what if I
wanted to take away this.

599
00:31:10.210 --> 00:31:13.580
You can take it out by holding Alt or
Option key here, and

600
00:31:13.580 --> 00:31:15.100
it turns a little minus.

601
00:31:15.100 --> 00:31:17.800
And I can say let's go ahead and
take this out, and

602
00:31:17.800 --> 00:31:21.070
it minuses that,
maybe I want to minus this guy out.

603
00:31:21.070 --> 00:31:24.020
Holding that Alt or Option.

604
00:31:24.020 --> 00:31:26.500
Maybe I want to add these two in together.

605
00:31:26.500 --> 00:31:28.480
So you can start creating
some interesting thing.

606
00:31:28.480 --> 00:31:32.240
I can hold that, that's actually
making a compound path, right,

607
00:31:32.240 --> 00:31:35.200
cuz it's knocking the holes out
of these two overlapping things.

608
00:31:35.200 --> 00:31:37.300
So, then I can create some, right now,

609
00:31:37.300 --> 00:31:40.080
some pretty weird looking-
>> Modern art?

610
00:31:40.080 --> 00:31:41.000
>> Yeah, exactly.

611
00:31:41.000 --> 00:31:45.050
But again, you can see,
look it's still individual pieces.

612
00:31:45.050 --> 00:31:49.503
So when I do that shape builders,
actually kinda cutting it all apart but

613
00:31:49.503 --> 00:31:52.507
also creating whatever
things that I need to do.

614
00:31:52.507 --> 00:31:55.293
Kind of a fun little tool that
you can play around with and

615
00:31:55.293 --> 00:31:57.550
do the things that you wanna do.

616
00:31:57.550 --> 00:31:59.450
Now the shaper tool.

617
00:31:59.450 --> 00:32:01.522
The shaper tool is new.

618
00:32:01.522 --> 00:32:06.316
And this is going to be really
good if you have a tablet or

619
00:32:06.316 --> 00:32:09.671
some type of Graphics stylus or something?

620
00:32:09.671 --> 00:32:13.322
>> Yeah, something with a stylus and
you could actually have a touch display,

621
00:32:13.322 --> 00:32:15.100
that's what I'm trying to go with.

622
00:32:15.100 --> 00:32:18.280
The Shaper tool is right there.

623
00:32:18.280 --> 00:32:19.340
So this is new.

624
00:32:21.080 --> 00:32:22.510
It's like, if I take my pencil, and

625
00:32:22.510 --> 00:32:27.340
I wanna draw a circle it's not
going to be very accurate, is it?

626
00:32:27.340 --> 00:32:30.400
Well, if you do this with the Shaper tool
and I click, hold and drag, and kinda,

627
00:32:30.400 --> 00:32:32.680
like, okay,
that's somewhat like a circle, right?

628
00:32:32.680 --> 00:32:34.520
So, it'll actually make a circle for me.

629
00:32:34.520 --> 00:32:37.220
>> Wow.
>> Or if I draw a square, okay,

630
00:32:37.220 --> 00:32:39.160
and sometimes it's like okay,
what is that?

631
00:32:39.160 --> 00:32:42.000
Okay, I guess that's an ellipse or
whatever.

632
00:32:42.000 --> 00:32:43.490
I want to draw a triangle.

633
00:32:43.490 --> 00:32:48.660
So, it will kind of detect
what you're drawing.

634
00:32:48.660 --> 00:32:49.920
And make that, okay?

635
00:32:49.920 --> 00:32:55.520
So I can do the straight lines, so
it's actually going to draw your shapes.

636
00:32:55.520 --> 00:32:57.870
I guess that's a hexagon,
or whatever I did.

637
00:32:57.870 --> 00:32:58.865
>> The circle was so bad.

638
00:32:58.865 --> 00:33:00.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz it says, it's gotta be a hexagon.

639
00:33:00.700 --> 00:33:03.240
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's like, what are you doing?

640
00:33:03.240 --> 00:33:07.982
So, if I take here at, okay,
I guess it's liking my hexagons,

641
00:33:07.982 --> 00:33:12.950
and let's make a triangle,
good, okay, I drew a triangle.

642
00:33:12.950 --> 00:33:17.590
And so you can see this, with this Shaper
tool, I'm not changing tools right now.

643
00:33:17.590 --> 00:33:19.205
I can, say all right,

644
00:33:19.205 --> 00:33:23.720
well I really wanted these two
pieces right here to take it out.

645
00:33:23.720 --> 00:33:26.247
So if I just kind of draw,
see it's like [SOUND],

646
00:33:26.247 --> 00:33:28.660
I'm saying no, no, no, it's like erase.

647
00:33:28.660 --> 00:33:33.548
Or if I wanted these two pieces to
act as one I just kinda draw like

648
00:33:33.548 --> 00:33:37.530
a squiggly line across them and
now it becomes one.

649
00:33:37.530 --> 00:33:41.186
Maybe I want this part
to take things out and

650
00:33:41.186 --> 00:33:46.070
then I can, wait, there we go,
well, close enough.

651
00:33:46.070 --> 00:33:47.660
So okay, there we go, it takes it out.

652
00:33:47.660 --> 00:33:50.230
But still, you can see the dotted
lines are still there.

653
00:33:50.230 --> 00:33:54.210
So it thinks that it's still,
it's almost like the compound shape.

654
00:33:54.210 --> 00:33:55.080
So it's still there.

655
00:33:55.080 --> 00:33:57.910
And I can say let's grab this guy.

656
00:33:57.910 --> 00:34:00.250
And I'm not changing tools again.

657
00:34:00.250 --> 00:34:04.590
And I can move this, and let's go
ahead and move this in a little bit.

658
00:34:04.590 --> 00:34:06.870
Maybe I can round the little corners here.

659
00:34:06.870 --> 00:34:12.160
So it's a lot more lifelike and
life gesture like that you can do.

660
00:34:12.160 --> 00:34:18.810
And so maybe I can come over here to
this guy right, come on, there we go.

661
00:34:18.810 --> 00:34:22.240
And then I can move this or
round the corners here.

662
00:34:22.240 --> 00:34:23.480
And then I can kinda do that.

663
00:34:23.480 --> 00:34:26.560
So it's trying to mimic lifelike drawing.

664
00:34:26.560 --> 00:34:29.330
With one single tool, so
you don't have to keep going back.

665
00:34:29.330 --> 00:34:33.343
You don't have to do the pathfinder panel,
you don't have to make a compound path and

666
00:34:33.343 --> 00:34:35.757
go back and isolate it,
it's all within one tool.

667
00:34:35.757 --> 00:34:39.904
That you can play around with and
make some drawings more natural,

668
00:34:39.904 --> 00:34:41.320
I guess you could say.

669
00:34:41.320 --> 00:34:44.530
>> Yeah, I can definitely see doing
this with a tablet and a stylus.

670
00:34:44.530 --> 00:34:47.010
>> Yeah, a little harder for
me with my mouse cuz it's,

671
00:34:47.010 --> 00:34:50.860
I'm not doing what it's, I'm not exactly.

672
00:34:50.860 --> 00:34:52.930
Yeah, it's much harder to do that.

673
00:34:52.930 --> 00:34:54.690
And I'm a little bit
more old school anyway.

674
00:34:54.690 --> 00:34:58.610
So that's how I roll, that's how I go.

675
00:34:58.610 --> 00:35:03.040
And the last couple of little things that
I wanted to show you, they're just fun.

676
00:35:03.040 --> 00:35:04.450
I call them the Play Doh tools.

677
00:35:04.450 --> 00:35:06.189
They're not really called
the Play Doh tools.

678
00:35:07.240 --> 00:35:09.926
Honestly, I not sure if I know
their real names anymore.

679
00:35:09.926 --> 00:35:13.958
The warp tools over here,
the warp, all of these little guys.

680
00:35:13.958 --> 00:35:17.790
So, I have a selected path, let me go
ahead and move this over a little bit so

681
00:35:17.790 --> 00:35:19.370
you can see it.

682
00:35:19.370 --> 00:35:26.190
This warp tool, it's like taking
your finger and smudging it.

683
00:35:26.190 --> 00:35:32.750
Okay, so if I take it from the outside and
just drag it in I can pull it in there.

684
00:35:32.750 --> 00:35:37.140
And if I come from the inside and
pull up, I can pull out.

685
00:35:37.140 --> 00:35:40.170
And so,
you can do some really neat things.

686
00:35:40.170 --> 00:35:41.400
That's why I call it, it's like Play Doh.

687
00:35:41.400 --> 00:35:43.080
>> I can see why you call
it the Play Doh tool.

688
00:35:43.080 --> 00:35:47.431
>> Right, remember taking it and squishing
it, and expanding, and twirling it?

689
00:35:47.431 --> 00:35:50.011
>> Yeah, all of these tools
remind me of Play Doh, and

690
00:35:50.011 --> 00:35:52.910
I loved playing with
Play Doh when I was a kid.

691
00:35:52.910 --> 00:35:57.440
And it does have a diameter,
like the eraser, but you change

692
00:35:57.440 --> 00:36:02.340
it by double clicking on the tool and
you can change the width and the height.

693
00:36:02.340 --> 00:36:05.830
So I could do something like that.

694
00:36:05.830 --> 00:36:07.220
And it doesn't have to be the same.

695
00:36:07.220 --> 00:36:08.410
Oops, click OK.

696
00:36:08.410 --> 00:36:13.340
And you see how it's a lot smaller now and
so it's a much more exact

697
00:36:13.340 --> 00:36:17.210
area that it's going to start
pulling things in or doing whatever.

698
00:36:17.210 --> 00:36:18.800
They can get the idea
with the rest of them.

699
00:36:18.800 --> 00:36:20.120
Pretty much just go down the line.

700
00:36:20.120 --> 00:36:21.510
The Twirl tool, it's kind of fun.

701
00:36:21.510 --> 00:36:22.889
You just click, hold, and [NOISE].

702
00:36:22.889 --> 00:36:25.364
That's it.
[NOISE] You can make little curly cues,

703
00:36:25.364 --> 00:36:28.485
you can make some really weird
blobby things coming out.

704
00:36:28.485 --> 00:36:29.950
So, that's kind of fun.

705
00:36:29.950 --> 00:36:32.800
The Pucker tool will
pucker together points.

706
00:36:32.800 --> 00:36:35.177
So, kind of [SOUND] sucks it in.

707
00:36:35.177 --> 00:36:36.802
That's a [SOUND] come on, suck it in.

708
00:36:36.802 --> 00:36:40.944
Then you've got the, [LAUGH],
I just saw you do that.

709
00:36:40.944 --> 00:36:41.689
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

710
00:36:41.689 --> 00:36:44.017
you've got the Bloat tools
kinda [NOISE] right?

711
00:36:44.017 --> 00:36:46.910
So you've gotta make the sound
effects while you do it.

712
00:36:46.910 --> 00:36:47.865
>> Absolutely.

713
00:36:47.865 --> 00:36:51.420
>> [LAUGH] So you get some kind of,
it just bloats it out.

714
00:36:51.420 --> 00:36:54.330
This little guy,
the Scallop tool will scallop the edges.

715
00:36:55.500 --> 00:36:58.098
Right, this little guy,
the Crystallize is kinda fun.

716
00:36:58.098 --> 00:37:02.169
It's like [NOISE], it's kind of
like explosion, you just do that.

717
00:37:02.169 --> 00:37:06.342
And then the Wrinkle tool
will just go ahead and

718
00:37:06.342 --> 00:37:11.053
wrinkle the edges and
not make it straight anymore.

719
00:37:11.053 --> 00:37:14.581
And then you get this, well I don't
even know what this guy is, but

720
00:37:14.581 --> 00:37:16.780
some really weird blob amoeba thing.

721
00:37:16.780 --> 00:37:20.520
So, the the Play Doh tools
they're really fun and

722
00:37:20.520 --> 00:37:24.400
it can create some like weird
organic looking things.

723
00:37:24.400 --> 00:37:27.140
And then the last guide
that I'd like to show you.

724
00:37:27.140 --> 00:37:30.890
Wow, we've really messed this pile up.

725
00:37:30.890 --> 00:37:33.300
Is the Blob tool.

726
00:37:33.300 --> 00:37:37.350
This is where it's more like drawing and

727
00:37:37.350 --> 00:37:41.880
painting to create organic, closed path.

728
00:37:41.880 --> 00:37:44.267
And I'm just erasing some of this stuff so
you can see.

729
00:37:44.267 --> 00:37:48.070
So where is the Blob tool?

730
00:37:48.070 --> 00:37:50.840
It's over,
it's under the paint brush, sorry.

731
00:37:50.840 --> 00:37:53.350
So we've got the Blob tool,
right here, and

732
00:37:53.350 --> 00:37:56.950
I'm just gonna show you that I'm going to
make this blue or something for my fill.

733
00:37:56.950 --> 00:38:02.090
Cuz it will create closed paths, okay.

734
00:38:02.090 --> 00:38:03.750
So it has a fill and a stroke.

735
00:38:03.750 --> 00:38:08.950
So if I maybe take this, right?

736
00:38:08.950 --> 00:38:10.980
It decides it's gonna be black,
okay, that's fine.

737
00:38:10.980 --> 00:38:14.560
And then I go ahead and
then kinda create this and that, and

738
00:38:14.560 --> 00:38:19.880
then maybe make some
little deer looking guy.

739
00:38:19.880 --> 00:38:20.380
I don't really know.

740
00:38:20.380 --> 00:38:22.890
And so I'm just kind of drawing this out.

741
00:38:23.990 --> 00:38:25.170
Medusa right?

742
00:38:25.170 --> 00:38:25.910
>> Yes.

743
00:38:25.910 --> 00:38:27.985
>> There we go, [SOUND], scary.

744
00:38:27.985 --> 00:38:31.060
I need to stop.

745
00:38:31.060 --> 00:38:33.810
So if I go back to the black
arrow tool and I click on this.

746
00:38:33.810 --> 00:38:38.300
Do you see that this is a whole path,
it says it's a group but

747
00:38:38.300 --> 00:38:39.880
I'll tell you why in a second.

748
00:38:39.880 --> 00:38:43.420
So I can just then change
all of the fill color.

749
00:38:43.420 --> 00:38:45.510
It has a stroke around it, and

750
00:38:45.510 --> 00:38:50.190
I can do all sorts of things that I
really would do with any other shape.

751
00:38:51.440 --> 00:38:56.790
And it's just a little bit more
organic looking and weird now.

752
00:38:56.790 --> 00:39:01.980
And if I un-group this,
you can see that it's actually,

753
00:39:01.980 --> 00:39:04.930
what did I say,
compound path look at that.

754
00:39:06.010 --> 00:39:08.860
Why is it a compound path, Mike?

755
00:39:08.860 --> 00:39:13.020
>> Because it has more than
one path intersecting.

756
00:39:13.020 --> 00:39:15.340
>> And it also has, what's this area?

757
00:39:15.340 --> 00:39:16.835
It's got a big old?

758
00:39:16.835 --> 00:39:17.355
>> Hole.

759
00:39:17.355 --> 00:39:19.230
>> Yes, it's a hole, yes.

760
00:39:19.230 --> 00:39:21.491
It creates a hole within two paths.

761
00:39:21.491 --> 00:39:23.752
>> Yes, yes, I'm close.

762
00:39:23.752 --> 00:39:24.913
>> You're on the right path.

763
00:39:24.913 --> 00:39:25.765
>> Thank you.

764
00:39:25.765 --> 00:39:30.320
>> Okay, so just to show you that
if I release this compound path,

765
00:39:30.320 --> 00:39:33.410
what it made when I was
drawing with that blob tool.

766
00:39:33.410 --> 00:39:38.680
It just made it in Illustrator's mind
like, there's a circle and I'm gonna cut

767
00:39:38.680 --> 00:39:42.870
the whole out of it, because you did not
draw within the Blob tool right middle.

768
00:39:42.870 --> 00:39:46.590
So that's again, see, compound paths,
they will show up a lot.

769
00:39:46.590 --> 00:39:47.690
>> They pop up everywhere.

770
00:39:47.690 --> 00:39:48.630
>> They will so,

771
00:39:48.630 --> 00:39:53.560
I think that about covers everything that
I wanted to cover with advanced shaping.

772
00:39:53.560 --> 00:39:55.840
>> Fantastic,
lot of great information there.

773
00:39:55.840 --> 00:39:59.343
Lot of really cool tools that we can use
where we get into some of those later one,

774
00:39:59.343 --> 00:40:02.759
the Play Doh tools, as you like to call
them, the Warps and things like that.

775
00:40:02.759 --> 00:40:08.240
And as well as the Blob brush we had,
and then back towards the beginning.

776
00:40:08.240 --> 00:40:10.110
Learning how to combine those shapes and

777
00:40:10.110 --> 00:40:13.420
working with the open paths
as well as the closed paths.

778
00:40:13.420 --> 00:40:15.090
So fantastic, thank you for that Von.

779
00:40:15.090 --> 00:40:17.100
Hope everybody out there
has enjoyed watching.

780
00:40:17.100 --> 00:40:19.660
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

781
00:40:19.660 --> 00:40:20.500
>> I'm Vonne Smith.

782
00:40:20.500 --> 00:40:21.461
>> And we'll see you next time.

783
00:40:21.461 --> 00:40:30.360
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Pen Tool
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.404 --> 00:00:10.404
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.768 --> 00:00:15.157
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode at ITPROTV.

3
00:00:15.157 --> 00:00:17.205
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and

4
00:00:17.205 --> 00:00:21.420
today we're going to be doing
Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

5
00:00:21.420 --> 00:00:24.790
And specifically in this episode
we're gonna be taking a look at

6
00:00:24.790 --> 00:00:28.500
some of the tools, more specifically
we're gonna be looking at the pen tool.

7
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:30.940
One of the very important
tools within illustrator.

8
00:00:30.940 --> 00:00:34.621
Here to guide us through how to use
this pen tool successfully, here's Ms.

9
00:00:34.621 --> 00:00:35.376
Vaughn Smith.

10
00:00:35.376 --> 00:00:36.258
How is it going Vaughn?

11
00:00:36.258 --> 00:00:39.351
>> Great, good to be back
again to tell you all about

12
00:00:39.351 --> 00:00:41.850
the fascinating world of the pen tool.

13
00:00:41.850 --> 00:00:48.040
So the pen tool is probably one of
the most important tools in Illustrator.

14
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:49.960
I'll probably say that about
another tool as well, but

15
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:56.120
I really do feel that the pen tool is
everything that there is in Illustrator.

16
00:00:56.120 --> 00:01:00.330
It's all about creating paths,
and mastering the pen yool

17
00:01:00.330 --> 00:01:05.240
in all the ways that you can modify a path
is extremely important in illustrator.

18
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:08.820
So you need to become
a pen proficienado or

19
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:11.480
we sure we can make some
other fun little sayings.

20
00:01:11.480 --> 00:01:13.000
>> A Pen professional.

21
00:01:13.000 --> 00:01:14.120
>> A Pen professional.

22
00:01:14.120 --> 00:01:15.609
>> Yes, there we go so.

23
00:01:15.609 --> 00:01:16.221
>> Certification.

24
00:01:16.221 --> 00:01:17.732
>> Yeah.
>> Well it's gonna be important for

25
00:01:17.732 --> 00:01:19.337
dedicating an entire episode to this guy.

26
00:01:19.337 --> 00:01:19.870
>> Yes.
Yes.

27
00:01:19.870 --> 00:01:21.790
So, it's awesome.

28
00:01:21.790 --> 00:01:27.650
It can be a little scary,
when I've taught this many, many years.

29
00:01:27.650 --> 00:01:29.800
People are like I don't understand,
it's going this way,

30
00:01:29.800 --> 00:01:33.220
but it's moving it that way and you're
pulling it up and it's going left and

31
00:01:33.220 --> 00:01:35.080
right and it's like I don't understand.

32
00:01:35.080 --> 00:01:37.450
So, it does take awhile to get used to,

33
00:01:37.450 --> 00:01:41.670
some people see it right away like,
I can get it all.

34
00:01:41.670 --> 00:01:45.460
But It sometimes it maybe
takes a little bit used to of

35
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:49.706
why am I doing up when it's going down or

00:14:02.310 --> 00:14:05.680
I think I might have moved them around,
and the same idea here.

259
00:14:05.680 --> 00:14:10.235
The points in the circle are here, and
the points on the diamond are here.

260
00:14:10.235 --> 00:14:12.972
We've just made them
from curved to straight.

261
00:14:12.972 --> 00:14:17.565
And that really does go back to,
look at all these,

262
00:14:17.565 --> 00:14:21.020
goes back to using this
convert tool to be able to say

263
00:14:21.020 --> 00:14:25.050
make a straight into a curve or
make a curve into a straight.

264
00:14:25.050 --> 00:14:26.220
>> Well that makes perfect sense.

265
00:14:26.220 --> 00:14:26.900
>> It does.

266
00:14:27.930 --> 00:14:30.430
And then I just got
a couple of more examples

267
00:14:30.430 --> 00:14:32.770
over here about we have open paths.

268
00:14:32.770 --> 00:14:35.730
Okay, all concepts that we've talked
about, closed and open paths.

269
00:14:35.730 --> 00:14:38.600
So here, of course, it's just gonna
be point, point, point, point,

270
00:14:38.600 --> 00:14:40.450
so straight and then curves here.

271
00:14:40.450 --> 00:14:42.300
This is just two points.

272
00:14:42.300 --> 00:14:43.210
Okay?

273
00:14:43.210 --> 00:14:45.520
>> You might, you could, okay?

274
00:14:45.520 --> 00:14:46.870
You could put a point here, but

275
00:14:46.870 --> 00:14:51.300
in this particular example,
it's only one, and one.

276
00:14:51.300 --> 00:14:55.450
It's only two points, so
same idea straight versus curved.

277
00:14:55.450 --> 00:15:01.300
This guy really demonstrates the,
it goes, it leaves this first point.

278
00:15:01.300 --> 00:15:02.210
So, this is point number one.

279
00:15:02.210 --> 00:15:02.960
This is point number two.

280
00:15:02.960 --> 00:15:04.670
This is point number three.

281
00:15:04.670 --> 00:15:07.110
Alright?
It leaves this point going up,

282
00:15:07.110 --> 00:15:12.010
and it comes into this
point going down and

283
00:15:12.010 --> 00:15:15.190
that’s for you go up, and then you’re
go down and it makes the curve.

284
00:15:15.190 --> 00:15:19.720
Now keeps on going because from
point two to three, it goes down and

285
00:15:19.720 --> 00:15:20.500
it then goes back up.

286
00:15:20.500 --> 00:15:27.890
It keeps continuing along its trajectory,
yeah, we'll go with that.

287
00:15:27.890 --> 00:15:29.760
The direction of which you're moving.

288
00:15:29.760 --> 00:15:32.020
You're going up and
you're up and you're down and

289
00:15:32.020 --> 00:15:35.790
everything's just kind of the same
as back on good old Bezzie.

290
00:15:35.790 --> 00:15:37.550
He was the same way too.

291
00:15:37.550 --> 00:15:41.170
We just kept on kind of moving around and
going which way.

292
00:15:41.170 --> 00:15:45.830
There wasn't any corner points, so that's
the next thing I want to talk about.

293
00:15:45.830 --> 00:15:50.610
Because look at this one is different,
it's one two, three, four.

294
00:15:50.610 --> 00:15:51.825
A little off in that third one, right?

295
00:15:51.825 --> 00:15:55.137
>> [LAUGH] Well, now this one,
I see the line comes in, but

296
00:15:55.137 --> 00:15:57.519
it doesn't go back out the other side.

297
00:15:57.519 --> 00:16:00.609
So we have point one,
two, three, four, okay?

298
00:16:00.609 --> 00:16:04.228
And in this one,
it leaves point one going up And

299
00:16:04.228 --> 00:16:09.130
comes into point two coming down,
just like the other example.

300
00:16:09.130 --> 00:16:14.309
But then in the same point
in same point number

301
00:16:14.309 --> 00:16:19.910
two it turns around and
then it goes out this way.

302
00:16:21.400 --> 00:16:23.270
So it comes in one way and

303
00:16:23.270 --> 00:16:26.850
travels out a separate way it’s like
going into the corner of the room, right.

304
00:16:26.850 --> 00:16:30.350
You can a go in and
the only way to go out is the other way,

305
00:16:30.350 --> 00:16:32.730
that's what they call a corner point.

306
00:16:32.730 --> 00:16:38.510
So then the same thing here from
two to three it goes up comes in

307
00:16:38.510 --> 00:16:43.310
down and then turns around and
I'm running out of colors.

308
00:16:43.310 --> 00:16:45.753
And then goes back out and
so on and so forth.

309
00:16:45.753 --> 00:16:52.880
So changing the directory
of a point is something

310
00:16:52.880 --> 00:16:58.380
that kind of going back over here,
is where you can

311
00:16:58.380 --> 00:17:02.750
toggle to what's known as the convert
point, because i have to convert it.

312
00:17:02.750 --> 00:17:08.370
t's not just, let me backup on that one
because when I say convert, we just said,

313
00:17:08.370 --> 00:17:13.673
straight to curve well in that seesaw
there was two handles, weren't they?

314
00:17:13.673 --> 00:17:18.092
So it's not just going straight to
curve it's actually breaking the seesaw

315
00:17:18.092 --> 00:17:20.684
to where one handle-
>> Can move independently than

316
00:17:20.684 --> 00:17:21.414
the other one.

317
00:17:21.414 --> 00:17:26.383
>> Yes, move independently than this one
so that's another reason why you want

318
00:17:26.383 --> 00:17:30.511
to use that convert Anchor point tool or
while you're drawing,

319
00:17:30.511 --> 00:17:34.420
you toggle to that tool,
cuz then you can say do it like this.

320
00:17:34.420 --> 00:17:37.812
Not just like this,
like that [CROSSTALK] kind of.

321
00:17:37.812 --> 00:17:39.685
Like my little demonstrations?

322
00:17:39.685 --> 00:17:43.670
[LAUGH] So, so that's the idea about
a corner point and so we're gonna do, and

323
00:17:43.670 --> 00:17:46.330
I'm gonna show you how to, how I
actually made all of these paths, okay?

324
00:17:46.330 --> 00:17:46.870
Okay.
But

325
00:17:46.870 --> 00:17:50.490
I like to be able to explain the concepts
behind it cause it makes it,

326
00:17:50.490 --> 00:17:52.270
I think makes a little bit more sense.

327
00:17:52.270 --> 00:17:53.130
>> I agree.

328
00:17:53.130 --> 00:17:59.470
>> Okay and then we have ways
that we can modify a shape and

329
00:17:59.470 --> 00:18:02.540
I maybe kind of did this in the shapes
where we actually just move the points,

330
00:18:02.540 --> 00:18:05.510
like we move that one point here.

331
00:18:05.510 --> 00:18:06.140
And we just say okay.

332
00:18:06.140 --> 00:18:07.310
We'll just move it in like that.

333
00:18:07.310 --> 00:18:08.810
We made a triangle.

334
00:18:08.810 --> 00:18:10.170
So this is still four points.

335
00:18:10.170 --> 00:18:12.830
But you could just take this guy.

336
00:18:12.830 --> 00:18:16.290
And you could just minus that one point.

337
00:18:16.290 --> 00:18:19.880
And if I subtract this
point now I have three.

338
00:18:19.880 --> 00:18:23.430
I have this, or the same thing over here.

339
00:18:23.430 --> 00:18:28.020
If I wanted to take this little guy and
make it like this.

340
00:18:28.020 --> 00:18:29.770
Well I could just add a point.

341
00:18:29.770 --> 00:18:31.340
I forgot I made these cute little brushes.

342
00:18:31.340 --> 00:18:32.595
So I can add a point here.

343
00:18:32.595 --> 00:18:34.470
>> Mm-hm.
>> Right, and then take this point,

344
00:18:34.470 --> 00:18:36.300
and then just move it up.

345
00:18:36.300 --> 00:18:36.800
>> Mm.

346
00:18:36.800 --> 00:18:41.130
>> And then I could add another point
here, and then just move that down.

347
00:18:41.130 --> 00:18:43.650
So it's taking one tool to add or
subtract,

348
00:18:43.650 --> 00:18:46.340
and then going back to
that white arrow tool,

349
00:18:46.340 --> 00:18:48.750
because that's the one that you can
use to actually select your points.

350
00:18:48.750 --> 00:18:50.470
And then moving them around.

351
00:18:50.470 --> 00:18:55.670
And then the same idea here would be,
I can take this straight point,

352
00:18:55.670 --> 00:19:00.020
and I can convert it into
a roundy point or a curvy point.

353
00:19:00.020 --> 00:19:02.730
So, actually, there we go,
there's the handle.

354
00:19:02.730 --> 00:19:06.740
So there's the see-saw, straight to curve.

355
00:19:06.740 --> 00:19:09.390
And then let me kind of go back over here.

356
00:19:09.390 --> 00:19:11.755
These guys I've done it on
the wrong layer, whoops.

357
00:19:11.755 --> 00:19:15.040
Okay.
[LAUGH] You can see that this one might

358
00:19:15.040 --> 00:19:16.970
be, this one's okay.

359
00:19:16.970 --> 00:19:19.120
This ones not the best example,
let me here.

360
00:19:19.120 --> 00:19:20.580
Sorry let me move this over for you guys.

361
00:19:20.580 --> 00:19:22.110
Whoops, what did I do wrong?

362
00:19:22.110 --> 00:19:23.950
Why can't I move this
whole path right now?

363
00:19:23.950 --> 00:19:27.660
>> Do you have the, you have the white
arrow and not the black arrow.

364
00:19:27.660 --> 00:19:28.180
>> Good job.

365
00:19:28.180 --> 00:19:30.750
See, I did that on purpose so
I could quiz you,

366
00:19:30.750 --> 00:19:32.361
to see if you're paying attention there,
Mike.

367
00:19:32.361 --> 00:19:35.718
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So you can see that over here,

368
00:19:35.718 --> 00:19:41.020
that if I go back to this, you see
there's the leave comes in this way.

369
00:19:41.020 --> 00:19:43.780
It's kinda weird to see
because it comes in this way.

370
00:19:43.780 --> 00:19:44.830
And then it goes that way.

371
00:19:44.830 --> 00:19:47.960
So you see that the seesaw is broken.

372
00:19:47.960 --> 00:19:51.050
This moves different than this.

373
00:19:51.050 --> 00:19:52.170
>> Independent.

374
00:19:52.170 --> 00:19:55.260
>> Exactly,
which is different than this guy moving.

375
00:19:55.260 --> 00:19:57.130
If I move one it moves the other.

376
00:19:57.130 --> 00:19:57.770
>> Very cool.

377
00:19:57.770 --> 00:20:01.650
>> With all of my demonstration
stuff on top of it, so.

378
00:20:01.650 --> 00:20:06.310
So, that's where we got
with the pen tool and

379
00:20:06.310 --> 00:20:07.910
how we explain all the different tools.

380
00:20:07.910 --> 00:20:11.360
So, I think now what
we'd like to do is show

381
00:20:11.360 --> 00:20:13.100
you how to actually make
that with the pen tool and

382
00:20:13.100 --> 00:20:15.560
go along with it but maybe we
should save that for our part two.

383
00:20:15.560 --> 00:20:16.480
>> Sounds like a plan.

384
00:20:16.480 --> 00:20:17.450
I think we'll do that.

385
00:20:17.450 --> 00:20:22.380
So, we will come back in a part two and
actually put all of these great tips and

386
00:20:22.380 --> 00:20:25.800
techniques that Von has been teaching
us to use, using her pen tool and

387
00:20:25.800 --> 00:20:27.570
play around with some busy a curves.

388
00:20:27.570 --> 00:20:29.870
So, hope everybody enjoyed
watching this one.

389
00:20:29.870 --> 00:20:31.440
Signing off for IT Pro TV.

390
00:20:31.440 --> 00:20:32.336
I'm Mike Rodrick.

391
00:20:32.336 --> 00:20:33.055
>> I'm Von Smith.

392
00:20:33.055 --> 00:20:34.309
>> And we'll see you next time.

393
00:20:34.309 --> 00:20:34.971
>> Bye.

394
00:20:34.971 --> 00:20:37.975

WEBVTT

And specifically in this episode,

we're actually continuing our

Now we're ready to actually use

00:00:43.300 --> 00:00:44.090

>> Good, ready to continue on

I think we probably should.

00:01:04.854 --> 00:01:07.950

00:01:07.950 --> 00:01:09.720

So first episode was more theory,

get into doing it.

27
00:01:15.567 --> 00:01:20.176
So let's get started, so
same file that we started with,

00:01:20.176 --> 00:01:24.138
I cleaned off all of my notations and
everything.

Just to give you a little background,

00:01:28.482 --> 00:01:31.287
You can see that right now I have,

31
00:01:31.287 --> 00:01:34.192
[LAUGH] Well, I've got the demo layer and

00:01:34.192 --> 00:01:36.561
Everything that I have

00:01:36.561 --> 00:01:40.778

34

The other thing I'm going to turn off for

35
00:01:45.936 --> 00:01:50.718
because all the pinks are gonna

36
00:01:50.718 --> 00:01:53.565
And when we were kind of going over

37
00:01:53.565 --> 00:01:56.360
was little distracting, so
I'm just gonna turn them off, but

38
00:01:56.360 --> 00:01:59.800
I wanted to show you guys

39
00:01:59.800 --> 00:02:03.098
And let me just check one more thing

40
00:02:03.098 --> 00:02:04.460
yep I did.

41
00:02:04.460 --> 00:02:09.270
And also before we turned this
episode on I wanted to turn on

00:02:09.270 --> 00:02:11.170
the rubber band option
that I mentioned before,

43
00:02:11.170 --> 00:02:15.015
I'm gonna turn it off for now so
I can show you the difference.

44
00:02:15.015 --> 00:02:20.010
Okay, so, we've got right here
all of our different icons of our

45
00:02:20.010 --> 00:02:24.090
mouse cursor that we need to pay attention
to and the black and white arrow.

46
00:02:24.090 --> 00:02:27.200
Now this square right here or the
rectangle whatever you want to call it,

47
00:02:27.200 --> 00:02:30.340
we could use the rectangle tool
very easily, and that's fine but

48
00:02:30.340 --> 00:02:31.410
we're using the pen tool.

49
00:02:31.410 --> 00:02:32.976
So we're gonna use the pen tool and

50
00:02:32.976 --> 00:02:36.173
right now my mouse cursor icon looks
like a star means it's a new path.

51
00:02:36.173 --> 00:02:40.461
So if I'm making straight paths,
straight points, straight closed, open,

52
00:02:40.461 --> 00:02:44.040
doesn't matter, it's just click,
click, click, click.

53
00:02:44.040 --> 00:02:46.710
Just like I was kind of demonstrating with
the there's a point here, point here,

54
00:02:46.710 --> 00:02:47.640
point here, point here.

55
00:02:47.640 --> 00:02:48.690
>> Okay.
>> Just click.

56
00:02:48.690 --> 00:02:50.570
So I click once and then I move over.

57
00:02:50.570 --> 00:02:54.700
You can see that now the circle, or
actually there's nothing there on the pen.

58
00:02:54.700 --> 00:02:55.790
>> It's gone, right.

59
00:02:55.790 --> 00:02:59.040
>> Yes, so
that means that it is continuing on

60
00:02:59.040 --> 00:03:00.790
with this path that I'm going on.

61
00:03:00.790 --> 00:03:04.745
So if I click one more time, and
then that's not really straight, is it?

62
00:03:04.745 --> 00:03:05.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

63
00:03:05.860 --> 00:03:09.460
if I wanted to make it straight,
you would hold the Shift key, okay.

64
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:11.420
Just like I constraining proportions and
anything we do.

65
00:03:11.420 --> 00:03:12.860
If I hold the Shift and then click,

66
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:15.935
now it actually made a straight
point from point two to point three.

67
00:03:15.935 --> 00:03:16.490
>> Mm-hm.

68
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:19.640
>> I hold the shift key one
more time coming on over.

69
00:03:19.640 --> 00:03:21.520
And then, to complete this,
you just move right back up.

70
00:03:21.520 --> 00:03:25.110
And you see how I'm hovering over
the first point that I started with,

71
00:03:25.110 --> 00:03:27.680
and it gives me that little
circle at the bottom of the pen.

72
00:03:27.680 --> 00:03:31.850
Which means that yes, I found the first,
I'm going to now close the path, and

73
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:36.920
if I click it, and move off, you can see
that I'm back to the pen with the star,

74
00:03:36.920 --> 00:03:40.050
which means that I am
ready to make a new path.

75
00:03:40.050 --> 00:03:42.049
>> Very cool.
>> So, that's how that was created.

76
00:03:42.049 --> 00:03:46.859
Okay, I wanted to make the triangle,
you could just click, click, click, click.

77
00:03:46.859 --> 00:03:50.490
Again it's not very straight but
you get the idea.

78
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:55.364
Same thing here as that I can just click,
click, click, click,

79
00:03:55.364 --> 00:04:00.780
click, obviously not using any type of
grid and just kinda free flowing around,

80
00:04:00.780 --> 00:04:03.350
but I could at least show you
that that's how you make it.

81
00:04:03.350 --> 00:04:07.270
Just keep on clicking, watch for
your cursors and so on and so forth.

82
00:04:08.370 --> 00:04:11.110
One thing that I am going
to do before we move,

83
00:04:11.110 --> 00:04:14.970
I'm gonna make this stroke a little
bit thicker so you can see,

84
00:04:14.970 --> 00:04:17.800
that's the wrong arrow, I'm gonna make
that a little thicker so you can see it.

85
00:04:17.800 --> 00:04:19.250
I'm also gonna take the fill off,

86
00:04:19.250 --> 00:04:22.130
this is something I probably
should have done to begin with.

87
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:23.480
Now, why would I do that?

88
00:04:23.480 --> 00:04:25.780
Because if I was going to do this over,

89
00:04:25.780 --> 00:04:28.035
let me show you that if I
was going to use this pen.

90
00:04:28.035 --> 00:04:30.946
Whoops, sorry, hold on, there we go.

91
00:04:30.946 --> 00:04:34.460
Back to the pen with the white
fill like it was before.

92
00:04:35.580 --> 00:04:41.010
If I was trying to show you how to do some
of this, if I click, you can see that if I

93
00:04:41.010 --> 00:04:47.040
start moving over, it's gonna create
a fill that I couldn't show on top of it.

And you might fight against it, but

550
00:27:00.072 --> 00:27:03.870
you will come around to it cuz
it's an awesome, awesome tool.

551
00:27:03.870 --> 00:27:04.680
>> Very good, all right, Vonne.

552
00:27:04.680 --> 00:27:07.530
Well thanks for all that information,
I know I'm ready to dive in,

553
00:27:07.530 --> 00:27:08.684
start using that pen tool.

554
00:27:08.684 --> 00:27:11.550
Hopefully everybody out
there is ready as well.

555
00:27:11.550 --> 00:27:13.370
Don't be scared of the pen.

556
00:27:13.370 --> 00:27:14.390
All right, we thank you for that.

557
00:27:14.390 --> 00:27:16.040
We hope everybody enjoyed watching.

558
00:27:16.040 --> 00:27:18.550
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

559
00:27:18.550 --> 00:27:19.092
>> I'm Vonne Smith.

560
00:27:19.092 --> 00:27:21.229
>> And we'll see you next time.

561
00:27:21.229 --> 00:27:28.900
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Transforming Objects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.369 --> 00:00:10.369
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.150 --> 00:00:13.360
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode at ITPRO TV.

3
00:00:15.870 --> 00:00:19.300
I'm your host Mike Roderick and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:19.300 --> 00:00:22.340
And specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:22.340 --> 00:00:24.610
we're going to be looking
at transforming objects.

6
00:00:24.610 --> 00:00:27.580
We've learned how to create
objets several different ways.

7
00:00:27.580 --> 00:00:30.980
And a lot of really cool objects we
can create with the tools that we've

8
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:31.940
seen so far.

9
00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:36.080
But sometimes, the object can maybe
be not exactly what you want and

10
00:00:36.080 --> 00:00:37.910
that's when these other
tools come into play.

11
00:00:37.910 --> 00:00:39.820
And here to help us with that is Ms.
Vaughn Smith.

12
00:00:39.820 --> 00:00:40.570
How you doing, Vaughn?

13
00:00:40.570 --> 00:00:41.430
>> Great.

14
00:00:41.430 --> 00:00:43.520
Yes, we are going to be
transforming objects.

15
00:00:43.520 --> 00:00:48.020
And I've actually kind of blended quite
a few different things together in this

16
00:00:48.020 --> 00:00:48.530
episode.

17
00:00:48.530 --> 00:00:54.270
Because almost all the things we're going
to cover falls under the object menu.

18
00:00:54.270 --> 00:00:56.090
So that's why we're transforming objects.

19
00:00:56.090 --> 00:00:59.800
But we're also going to look at
some tools, and some neat things.

20
00:00:59.800 --> 00:01:01.293
We're going do some blends.

21
00:01:01.293 --> 00:01:02.651
And some gradient meshes.

22
00:01:02.651 --> 00:01:07.455
And we're going to scale, and
we're going to move all over the place.

23
00:01:07.455 --> 00:01:08.810
[LAUGH]
>> Sounds exciting.

24
00:01:08.810 --> 00:01:10.690
>> Yes, it's going to be very exciting.

25
00:01:10.690 --> 00:01:12.670
So, why don't we jump on in.

26
00:01:12.670 --> 00:01:14.580
So I've got a file here.

27
00:01:14.580 --> 00:01:17.600
With quite a few different
art boards to just

28
00:01:17.600 --> 00:01:20.240
give the examples of all the different
techniques that I want to show you.

29
00:01:20.240 --> 00:01:23.010
So we have what we've learned
about our black arrow tool, right?

30
00:01:23.010 --> 00:01:26.480
We go ahead and take the black
arrow tool to select things.

31
00:01:26.480 --> 00:01:28.900
And I mean, we can move things around.

32
00:01:28.900 --> 00:01:32.300
We can rotate it, so I've got the black
arrow with this square selected.

33
00:01:32.300 --> 00:01:34.400
We can rotate with the bendies.

34
00:01:34.400 --> 00:01:37.510
We went ahead and used our shift
key to go ahead and size it.

35
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:40.570
We can use our alt key or
our option key to keep it center.

36
00:01:40.570 --> 00:01:44.330
There's a lot of things that we can
do just with the black arrow tool.

37
00:01:44.330 --> 00:01:46.870
So why would we need a command to move or

38
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:49.950
why do we have a scale tool if
I can just scale it right here?

39
00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:51.490
Well, it's really just options.

40
00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:52.600
I mean different ways to do it.

41
00:01:52.600 --> 00:01:55.230
So that's what I want to go ahead and
go through with you.

42
00:01:55.230 --> 00:01:58.320
Because, yes, rotate scale, move.

43
00:01:58.320 --> 00:01:59.630
All the black arrow tool, but

44
00:01:59.630 --> 00:02:04.270
what if I want to turn it over,
okay, like reflect, okay?

45
00:02:04.270 --> 00:02:08.000
So that's one of the transformations
that you could do.

46
00:02:08.000 --> 00:02:11.280
I mean, you could turn it around and
flip it this way,

47
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:15.110
but it's just easier if I can
say just flip horizontal, okay.

48
00:02:15.110 --> 00:02:18.390
In Photoshop, I know there's
the flip horizontal, flip vertical.

49
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:20.190
It's the exact same thing, basically.

50
00:02:20.190 --> 00:02:22.680
Just in Illustrator so let me show you.

51
00:02:22.680 --> 00:02:26.555
I have this arrow that I created and
I'm going to ahead and select.

52
00:02:26.555 --> 00:02:29.080
So I'm going to go to the Object menu.

53
00:02:29.080 --> 00:02:29.875
See Object.

54
00:02:29.875 --> 00:02:31.780
[LAUGH] We got our transform.

55
00:02:31.780 --> 00:02:34.990
And you can see,
there's a couple different ones we can do.

56
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:38.070
Move, rotate, reflect, scale and shear.

57
00:02:38.070 --> 00:02:41.130
Well, since I said we were going to
reflect, we're going to choose that one.

58
00:02:41.130 --> 00:02:43.120
All right?
So then, what can I do with this?

59
00:02:43.120 --> 00:02:46.470
Again, flip on horizontal or
the vertical axis.

60
00:02:46.470 --> 00:02:49.690
You could also specifically choose
which angle you want to go with.

61
00:02:49.690 --> 00:02:52.670
But the biggest thing to remember,
I think, is to just turn on the preview.

62
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:54.680
Because you could change
all these options, but

63
00:02:54.680 --> 00:02:56.340
it's like, what is it actually doing?

64
00:02:56.340 --> 00:02:57.690
Because I can't remember.

65
00:02:57.690 --> 00:03:00.500
Am I supposed to go up or down, vertical?

66
00:03:00.500 --> 00:03:01.430
Which way?

67
00:03:01.430 --> 00:03:02.750
That's exactly what I wanted.

68
00:03:02.750 --> 00:03:06.360
I wanted to flip it over, so
that way I chose vertical.

69
00:03:06.360 --> 00:03:07.770
That's what I want to do.

70
00:03:07.770 --> 00:03:10.530
You can see that you can
change your different options.

71
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:12.290
You can change the angle.

72
00:03:12.290 --> 00:03:13.580
Nope.
I just wanted to go ahead and

73
00:03:13.580 --> 00:03:16.060
flip it over, and that's great.

74
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:17.860
And that's all I have to do,
and I can click OK.

75
00:03:17.860 --> 00:03:20.892
But then there's another option
if you wanted to copy it.

76
00:03:20.892 --> 00:03:24.670
Okay so just do the transformation
to that option, or

77
00:03:24.670 --> 00:03:27.140
to that object, or
copy it over to another one.

78
00:03:27.140 --> 00:03:29.640
So just for fun,
I'm going to go ahead and copy it.

79
00:03:29.640 --> 00:03:31.420
And then I can go ahead and
move this over.

80
00:03:31.420 --> 00:03:33.335
And now I have two
arrows pointed together,

81
00:03:33.335 --> 00:03:35.150
because maybe that’s what I wanted to do.

82
00:03:35.150 --> 00:03:37.625
>> So, did the transformation but
created a new object.

83
00:03:37.625 --> 00:03:38.390
>> Mm-hm, yeah.
>> And

84
00:03:38.390 --> 00:03:41.220
then applied the transformation to that,
but not the original object.

85
00:03:41.220 --> 00:03:42.060
>> Cool.

86
00:03:42.060 --> 00:03:44.745
>> Hence,
I’ve always loved to use the word hence.

87
00:03:44.745 --> 00:03:45.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hence the copy.

88
00:03:45.970 --> 00:03:48.670
All right and I think you can get the idea

89
00:03:48.670 --> 00:03:51.900
here from the other arrow
>> I did want to show

90
00:03:51.900 --> 00:03:55.390
you that once you have it selected with
the black arrow, you can right click.

91
00:03:55.390 --> 00:03:57.130
Instead of going into the object menu.

92
00:03:57.130 --> 00:04:00.490
And, you can go to the transform,
and I can go through reflect here.

93
00:04:00.490 --> 00:04:02.670
And because I have that preview on,

94
00:04:02.670 --> 00:04:05.370
I can say that verticals' definitely
not the way I want to go.

95
00:04:05.370 --> 00:04:08.200
>> And then I go with horizontal,
that's what I want.

96
00:04:08.200 --> 00:04:10.870
And just to keep on going with that copy,
I'll copy that and

97
00:04:10.870 --> 00:04:13.170
now I'll go ahead and
have that arrow that way.

98
00:04:13.170 --> 00:04:14.970
So, really a quick command.

99
00:04:14.970 --> 00:04:18.660
And I have to use it a lot, so
now you guys know where it's at.

100
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:19.790
All right.
And

101
00:04:19.790 --> 00:04:24.365
then there's some fun ones to
do with this Transform again.

102
00:04:24.365 --> 00:04:29.160
Because what if I took this square,
and I went ahead and made it smaller?

103
00:04:29.160 --> 00:04:30.210
And I'm just using the black arrow tool.

104
00:04:30.210 --> 00:04:34.710
I'm not using any of the transform
commands in the object menu,

105
00:04:34.710 --> 00:04:37.140
I just made it smaller, right?

106
00:04:37.140 --> 00:04:40.760
Well, there is,
I'm selecting the other square.

107
00:04:40.760 --> 00:04:44.260
There is an option to transform again,
exactly what it sounds like.

108
00:04:44.260 --> 00:04:47.520
Do the same transformation that I just did

109
00:04:47.520 --> 00:04:50.390
again to this other object
that I have selected.

110
00:04:50.390 --> 00:04:52.010
>> Wow!
>> So I've selected the second one,

111
00:04:52.010 --> 00:04:56.400
I'm going to go to show you in
the Menu where the command is.

112
00:04:56.400 --> 00:04:57.260
It's transform again.

113
00:04:57.260 --> 00:05:01.380
It's command D or control D,
which is duplicate.

114
00:05:01.380 --> 00:05:03.950
So you can kind of think of it that way.

115
00:05:03.950 --> 00:05:05.280
So control, there you go.

116
00:05:05.280 --> 00:05:08.260
So now I've done that, and
I can even select this one.

117
00:05:08.260 --> 00:05:09.435
And I'm going to do the shortcut.

118
00:05:09.435 --> 00:05:10.710
Command D, and that just goes forward.

119
00:05:10.710 --> 00:05:13.110
So that's where it's really cool.

120
00:05:13.110 --> 00:05:14.340
Do the same thing.

121
00:05:14.340 --> 00:05:16.910
I made everything smaller, but
all these other guys need to be smaller.

122
00:05:16.910 --> 00:05:20.910
And I could have selected
all of those two together.

123
00:05:20.910 --> 00:05:23.340
Just to show you one more time,
I did this.

124
00:05:23.340 --> 00:05:26.040
And then I can go ahead and
say, yep, do that again.

125
00:05:27.120 --> 00:05:28.830
And I can have them both
selected at the same time.

126
00:05:28.830 --> 00:05:32.480
So that's another really handy
command that I use frequently.

127
00:05:32.480 --> 00:05:35.190
It's like nope,
I just gotta get it a little bit more.

128
00:05:35.190 --> 00:05:39.930
So that command or control D is
really fun for the transform again.

129
00:05:39.930 --> 00:05:44.713
And then there's
the transform each option.

130
00:05:44.713 --> 00:05:49.770
And that's where you don't want to just
move or just scale or just rotate.

131
00:05:49.770 --> 00:05:51.940
You can do it all in one dialogue box.

132
00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:56.560
And that's where it can get a lot easier
so I'm going to select this square.

133
00:05:56.560 --> 00:05:58.220
I'm going to go to the object.

134
00:05:58.220 --> 00:06:00.830
I'm going to go to transform and
transform them each.

135
00:06:00.830 --> 00:06:03.020
Okay.
It means like each option.

136
00:06:03.020 --> 00:06:03.710
>> Mm.
>> If you want to say.

137
00:06:03.710 --> 00:06:07.600
So you see, there's scale, move, rotate.

138
00:06:07.600 --> 00:06:10.220
The reflect we were doing
with the reflect command.

139
00:06:10.220 --> 00:06:12.160
They're all in one dialogue box.

140
00:06:12.160 --> 00:06:13.520
So it's like, okay.

141
00:06:13.520 --> 00:06:15.790
So I'll check that Preview back on.

142
00:06:15.790 --> 00:06:21.030
And I can maybe scale it down and
scale it down horizontally.

143
00:06:21.030 --> 00:06:25.400
And of course I could type it in if
I want it 75% of the original size.

144
00:06:25.400 --> 00:06:28.000
I can move it over a little bit maybe,

145
00:06:28.000 --> 00:06:31.590
Move it up a little bit,
rotate it on an angle, so on and so forth.

146
00:06:31.590 --> 00:06:34.840
I think you get the idea, I can just
go ahead and change each one of these.

147
00:06:34.840 --> 00:06:36.170
And, of course, you do have that copy.

148
00:06:36.170 --> 00:06:38.910
Okay, just like before I'm just going
to go ahead and click OK for this one.

149
00:06:38.910 --> 00:06:43.030
And there you go, I did a whole
bunch of transformations in one

150
00:06:43.030 --> 00:06:47.410
shot rather than individually
with some of the other ones.

151
00:06:47.410 --> 00:06:50.120
There’s some fun things you
can do with the repeat.

152
00:06:50.120 --> 00:06:54.440
And this is always one of my favorite
examples, because it’s very colorful and

153
00:06:54.440 --> 00:06:56.880
it’s always with stars and
I love stars and color.

154
00:06:56.880 --> 00:07:01.120
So we're going to go back
to that transform each.

155
00:07:01.120 --> 00:07:02.700
Okay, oops,
I don't want to have all of these.

156
00:07:02.700 --> 00:07:05.650
So, I'll just go back and let's type in.

157
00:07:05.650 --> 00:07:11.130
We'll do 80% of the original on both
the horizontal and the vertical scaling.

158
00:07:11.130 --> 00:07:12.860
So, I'm just going to
make it a little smaller.

159
00:07:12.860 --> 00:07:13.990
I don't want to move it, okay?

160
00:07:13.990 --> 00:07:16.530
So, I'm just going to
put those back to zero.

161
00:07:16.530 --> 00:07:18.120
And because I don't want that.

162
00:07:18.120 --> 00:07:21.330
I'll make it rotate just a little bit,
everything else is fine.

163
00:07:21.330 --> 00:07:26.940
Now I'm going to go ahead and
click copy and it makes this.

164
00:07:26.940 --> 00:07:31.650
And if you do that command D,
it just kind of makes it.

165
00:07:31.650 --> 00:07:32.530
See?

166
00:07:32.530 --> 00:07:33.706
Isn't that pretty?

167
00:07:33.706 --> 00:07:34.510
>> Very cool.

168
00:07:34.510 --> 00:07:37.520
>> This is where I could just go on and
on and on.

169
00:07:37.520 --> 00:07:42.450
If you just supply a gradient and
just do the scaling and rotate it,

170
00:07:42.450 --> 00:07:44.550
now it looks like a beautiful flower.

171
00:07:44.550 --> 00:07:45.896
>> It does.
>> All right.

172
00:07:45.896 --> 00:07:49.388
So fun with command or control d.

173
00:07:49.388 --> 00:07:51.161
And transformations.

174
00:07:51.161 --> 00:07:55.745
Now there's another command that I
wanted to show you called off set path.

175
00:07:55.745 --> 00:08:01.707
Which will look similar to what I was
doing here without the rotate part but

176
00:08:01.707 --> 00:08:04.970
why is it different and why do we use it?

177
00:08:04.970 --> 00:08:07.064
It's just a different way of doing it,
right.

178
00:08:07.064 --> 00:08:07.883
Option, options.

179
00:08:07.883 --> 00:08:15.140
And I can specify how far I
want this path to be offsetted.

180
00:08:15.140 --> 00:08:18.110
And it can either go bigger or smaller.

181
00:08:18.110 --> 00:08:19.860
It's easiest to just demonstrate.

182
00:08:19.860 --> 00:08:23.640
So let's take this star,
I'm going to go to object, and

183
00:08:23.640 --> 00:08:27.970
I'm going to go to path, and I'm going
to go to, there it is, offset path.

184
00:08:29.558 --> 00:08:30.270
All right.

185
00:08:30.270 --> 00:08:31.230
Now, again that preview.

186
00:08:31.230 --> 00:08:33.700
You're gonna see why I'm
trying to pre balance.

187
00:08:33.700 --> 00:08:36.060
I'm just offsetting this shape.

188
00:08:36.060 --> 00:08:39.985
A whole, or however many,
however much distance?

189
00:08:39.985 --> 00:08:42.500
>> Mm-hm.
>> And space I want to go ahead and

190
00:08:42.500 --> 00:08:43.780
go off that original path.

191
00:08:43.780 --> 00:08:48.340
So if I go ahead and
say that I want it to be .15, or whatever,

192
00:08:48.340 --> 00:08:53.090
you can see that it’s
exactly .15 inches off of it.

193
00:08:53.090 --> 00:08:55.800
Now, if it’s a positive,
it’s going to go bigger.

194
00:08:55.800 --> 00:08:57.480
I’m going to click okay so you can see it.

195
00:08:57.480 --> 00:08:59.160
And it goes behind it.

196
00:08:59.160 --> 00:09:01.210
I’m going to change this color right here.

197
00:09:01.210 --> 00:09:06.090
It’s just like a, it’s basically
duplicating it, and offsetting it.

198
00:09:06.090 --> 00:09:08.890
That's just what offset path means.

199
00:09:08.890 --> 00:09:14.920
Okay, and so you can specify how far off
that whole shape is going to come off.

200
00:09:14.920 --> 00:09:15.730
>> Very cool.
>> So

201
00:09:15.730 --> 00:09:19.920
it's very similar to that
transform scale and do a copy.

202
00:09:19.920 --> 00:09:21.120
But you can't do a Cmd+D.

203
00:09:21.120 --> 00:09:24.290
You cannot transform again,
transform again on an offset path.

204
00:09:24.290 --> 00:09:29.310
So that is one big differentiating factor,
so and

205
00:09:29.310 --> 00:09:34.950
you can do an offset path in a negative,
and it will go small and on top.

206
00:09:34.950 --> 00:09:40.240
So positive bigger beneath,
negative smaller on top.

207
00:09:40.240 --> 00:09:43.660
So just to show you I'm clicking
back on my original yellow star.

208
00:09:43.660 --> 00:09:50.970
Go back to the offset path and
this time I can do a negative .15.

209
00:09:50.970 --> 00:09:53.650
I can preview so you can see it goes in.

210
00:09:53.650 --> 00:09:57.850
So you can go ahead and
make something like that.

211
00:09:57.850 --> 00:09:58.510
>> Very cool.
So

212
00:09:58.510 --> 00:10:02.980
again you can have more fun with
modifying an original object and

213
00:10:02.980 --> 00:10:05.720
how you can transform it,
transforming objects.

214
00:10:05.720 --> 00:10:06.335
>> Nice.

215
00:10:06.335 --> 00:10:09.210
[LAUGH]
>> So those are the few,

216
00:10:09.210 --> 00:10:12.940
that's the first art board with
a few examples I wanted to show you.

217
00:10:12.940 --> 00:10:16.960
So I'm gonna come over, whoops,
I'm gonna come over here [LAUGH] sorry.

218
00:10:16.960 --> 00:10:22.840
And just wanted to show you how you could
use that move command, not just with using

219
00:10:22.840 --> 00:10:27.160
your black arrow tool, but use it cuz you
want to make a specific grid of something.

220
00:10:27.160 --> 00:10:30.340
Like I want four circles across and

221
00:10:30.340 --> 00:10:35.000
ten circles down that all need to
be .25 inches away from each other.

222
00:10:35.000 --> 00:10:35.960
Okay.

223
