00:33:12.580 --> 00:33:17.204
It makes it look like an actual 3D object,
and it's not vector, it's really,

688
00:33:17.204 --> 00:33:18.029
really cool.

689
00:33:18.029 --> 00:33:18.947
>> I'll be darned.

690
00:33:18.947 --> 00:33:23.410
>> I think if you look up, I think it
is gradient mesh flower, you'll see.

691
00:33:23.410 --> 00:33:24.960
It's so pretty, it's so neat.

692
00:33:24.960 --> 00:33:26.311
[LAUGH] Very intense.

693
00:33:26.311 --> 00:33:30.340
You have to have that artistic eye.

694
00:33:30.340 --> 00:33:37.240
I don't think I could ever recreate what I
have seen people do with gradient meshes.

695
00:33:37.240 --> 00:33:37.800
But it's amazing.

696
00:33:37.800 --> 00:33:40.228
So yep, grab your points,
move them around.

697
00:33:40.228 --> 00:33:43.953
You can go ahead and start applying
colors, and this is where, yeah,

698
00:33:43.953 --> 00:33:47.425
you can go ahead and move these points and
this is where it starts,

699
00:33:47.425 --> 00:33:50.330
I start thinking about,
remember those marbles?

700
00:33:50.330 --> 00:33:51.606
>> Yes.
[LAUGH]

701
00:33:51.606 --> 00:33:53.260
>> The colored marbles?

702
00:33:53.260 --> 00:33:57.080
My aunt had a whole collection of them,
I just love playing with those things.

703
00:33:57.080 --> 00:33:59.880
So you can see when I click off of them,
I mean, I don't know

704
00:33:59.880 --> 00:34:04.210
exactly if that's a real looking marble,
but it just reminds me of that idea.

705
00:34:04.210 --> 00:34:07.980
These kind of swirling colors together,
and you can do some really neat

706
00:34:07.980 --> 00:34:12.590
options with gradient meshes, and
that's what I got for you in this episode.

707
00:34:12.590 --> 00:34:15.562
>> Fantastic, some really cool
things you can do, above and

708
00:34:15.562 --> 00:34:18.353
beyond what we were used to
with our normal transform,

709
00:34:18.353 --> 00:34:21.886
really cool things that we can do
to our objects within Illustrator.

710
00:34:21.886 --> 00:34:24.006
So, is that right?

711
00:34:24.006 --> 00:34:24.714
Are we doing Illustrator?

712
00:34:24.714 --> 00:34:26.157
>> Yeah, right.

713
00:34:26.157 --> 00:34:26.732
>> Yeah, let's do that again.

714
00:34:26.732 --> 00:34:29.097
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

715
00:34:29.097 --> 00:34:30.255
>> I can't believe I haven't

716
00:34:30.255 --> 00:34:30.914
fucked up yet.

717
00:34:30.914 --> 00:34:33.516
So I'm very proud of myself.

718
00:34:33.516 --> 00:34:35.230
>> [COUGH] [SOUND] Excuse me.

719
00:34:35.230 --> 00:34:37.481
>> I realize I went a little over, but-
>> No, that was fine.

720
00:34:37.481 --> 00:34:43.302
>> [SOUND] I'm so glad it was you,
gotta end on a bang.

721
00:34:43.302 --> 00:34:45.526
>> I didn't want to do the last
episode with no edits.

722
00:34:45.526 --> 00:34:47.091
Megan wants something to do tomorrow.

723
00:34:47.091 --> 00:34:49.735
>> Right?

724
00:34:49.735 --> 00:34:51.894
We're looking out for you Megan.

725
00:34:51.894 --> 00:34:55.552
We want to give you work.

726
00:34:55.552 --> 00:35:00.860
[LAUGH] Cuz we're bastards.

727
00:35:00.860 --> 00:35:01.920
>> Because we suck.

728
00:35:01.920 --> 00:35:02.920
>> Pretty much.

729
00:35:02.920 --> 00:35:07.040
>> For the life of me I couldn't remember
the name of any of the freaking tools,

730
00:35:07.040 --> 00:35:07.615
we just went over.

731
00:35:07.615 --> 00:35:08.740
[LAUGH]
>> I was just like,

732
00:35:08.740 --> 00:35:11.340
we can do cool things with shapes and
such that we saw.

733
00:35:11.340 --> 00:35:14.360
>> We blended, we transformed,
we used menu options and tools.

734
00:35:14.360 --> 00:35:15.937
>> Yeah.
>> You did some cool things with

735
00:35:15.937 --> 00:35:17.022
the blends and the warps.

736
00:35:17.022 --> 00:35:17.823
>> That's right.

737
00:35:17.823 --> 00:35:18.609
Warps too.

738
00:35:18.609 --> 00:35:20.738
>> Yeah, warps and blends and
something about envelopes.

739
00:35:20.738 --> 00:35:22.759
>> Yeah, there we go, okay.

740
00:35:22.759 --> 00:35:25.070
>> See,
I'm gonna end up doing your work now.

741
00:35:25.070 --> 00:35:25.670
>> I know, right?

742
00:35:25.670 --> 00:35:30.690
Can we just put her voice over my face,
and I'll just go, ba ba ba ba.

743
00:35:32.060 --> 00:35:35.860
Wow, found some really cool things we can
do with the warps and the blends, and

744
00:35:35.860 --> 00:35:37.750
the emblems, and the meshes,

745
00:35:37.750 --> 00:35:40.920
really takes our transformation of
these objects up to the next level.

746
00:35:40.920 --> 00:35:42.744
We thank you for
those fantastic demonstrations.

747
00:35:42.744 --> 00:35:44.804
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

748
00:35:44.804 --> 00:35:47.740
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Rodrick and I'm Vonne Smith, and

749
00:35:47.740 --> 00:35:48.844
we'll see you next time.

750
00:35:48.844 --> 00:35:55.402
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Color Theory
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.117 --> 00:00:15.461
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.461 --> 00:00:20.857
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:20.857 --> 00:00:24.512
And specifically, in this episode,
we're gonna be taking a look at color, and

5
00:00:24.512 --> 00:00:25.600
color theory.

6
00:00:25.600 --> 00:00:28.330
Believe it or not,
there's a lot more to it than just

7
00:00:28.330 --> 00:00:31.810
randomly picking some color
from your color palette.

8
00:00:31.810 --> 00:00:34.940
Here to help explain color and
color theory is Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:34.940 --> 00:00:35.750
How you doing, Vonne?

10
00:00:35.750 --> 00:00:38.170
>> Great, good to be here to
talk to you about colors.

11
00:00:38.170 --> 00:00:43.460
As Mike was saying, it's not just let
me just pick some random color and

12
00:00:43.460 --> 00:00:45.373
throw it in my production.

13
00:00:45.373 --> 00:00:48.040
It means something, and so
that's what we're here to talk about.

14
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:51.970
Now, color theory is
a subject that is huge.

15
00:00:53.030 --> 00:00:56.018
Whole books are written
on just this one subject.

16
00:00:56.018 --> 00:00:58.460
We're just gonna try to
hit the main points and

17
00:00:58.460 --> 00:01:02.280
all the things that you will be seeing
in your Illustrator environment

18
00:01:02.280 --> 00:01:05.920
later when we actually get into
the color panel, into the swatches.

19
00:01:05.920 --> 00:01:10.385
But for now, we're just here to
talk about the theory behind it and

20
00:01:10.385 --> 00:01:13.655
get some vocabulary and
some topics covered, so

21
00:01:13.655 --> 00:01:19.099
we can understand what these numbers mean
and what are these colors saying to us.

22
00:01:19.099 --> 00:01:20.490
So we're gonna go with that.

23
00:01:20.490 --> 00:01:21.080
>> Sounds fun!

24
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:25.222
>> And we're gonna start off with
talking about our good friend ROYGBIV,

25
00:01:25.222 --> 00:01:26.750
remember who ROYGBIV is?

26
00:01:26.750 --> 00:01:28.840
>> I haven't heard his
name in a long time, but

27
00:01:28.840 --> 00:01:32.300
I do, I remember him from gosh,
elementary school, I believe.

28
00:01:32.300 --> 00:01:36.110
>> Yeah, there was always some song
we had to sing to remember it.

29
00:01:36.110 --> 00:01:38.860
And what was ROYGBIV about?

30
00:01:38.860 --> 00:01:41.410
>> It was the colors of the rainbow.

31
00:01:41.410 --> 00:01:43.500
Let's see, you had ROYGBIV.

32
00:01:43.500 --> 00:01:48.580
You have red, orange, yellow,
green, blue, indigo, violet.

33
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:49.503
>> Yeah.
>> If I remember.

34
00:01:49.503 --> 00:01:50.394
>> Good job.

35
00:01:50.394 --> 00:01:51.122
>> That was a long time ago.

36
00:01:51.122 --> 00:01:52.640
>> [LAUGH] It was.

37
00:01:52.640 --> 00:01:55.405
So let me bring up a little
document to help us along and

38
00:01:55.405 --> 00:01:59.221
remember our notes from kindergarten or
wherever we learned about this.

39
00:01:59.221 --> 00:02:05.250
So yes, ROYGBIV, is exactly what Mike was
saying, it's the colors of the rainbow.

40
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:07.570
Whoops, sorry,
just didn't mean to zoom out.

41
00:02:07.570 --> 00:02:11.916
We have these colors, and it's funny,
cuz I remember being like what's indigo?

42
00:02:11.916 --> 00:02:15.654
Violet, it's purple, yes, that's true.

43
00:02:15.654 --> 00:02:18.692
We think of it as purple but
if you actually Google this,

44
00:02:18.692 --> 00:02:22.506
there's all sorts of different
articles about indigo is not a color,

45
00:02:22.506 --> 00:02:25.176
and violet's not here,
and it's like, what?

46
00:02:25.176 --> 00:02:25.997
I don't know.

47
00:02:25.997 --> 00:02:30.179
There's a lot of misconceptions
of whether this is a color,

48
00:02:30.179 --> 00:02:33.951
because the way that we think
about color has changed so

49
00:02:33.951 --> 00:02:37.969
much from when these types of
theories became dogmas, and

50
00:02:37.969 --> 00:02:41.500
this is what we talk about
when we talk about color.

51
00:02:41.500 --> 00:02:44.982
Because this was originally
from Sir Isaac Newton.

52
00:02:44.982 --> 00:02:46.422
>> Yeah, it was a long time ago.

53
00:02:46.422 --> 00:02:49.230
>> Yeah, a very long time ago
before science and computers and

54
00:02:49.230 --> 00:02:50.430
numbers and everything.

55
00:02:50.430 --> 00:02:54.959
And it was really all based on light and
the rainbows and the prisms and

56
00:02:54.959 --> 00:03:01.310
all the different ways of the optics that
he discovered and introduced to the world.

57
00:03:01.310 --> 00:03:05.717
They're talking about rainbow
colors being spectral colors,

58
00:03:05.717 --> 00:03:08.909
optical colors, so
that's just what we see.

59
00:03:08.909 --> 00:03:13.203
Now when you get into how that goes
into how we work with color and

60
00:03:13.203 --> 00:03:16.446
then painting and
how that moved through ages,

61
00:03:16.446 --> 00:03:22.080
then you get into what is a primary color,
secondary color, tertiary color.

62
00:03:22.080 --> 00:03:23.270
Let's go over that.

63
00:03:23.270 --> 00:03:24.274
So do you remember these?

64
00:03:24.274 --> 00:03:26.259
>> I do, barely.

65
00:03:26.259 --> 00:03:29.333
>> [LAUGH] Red, yellow, and blue.

66
00:03:29.333 --> 00:03:30.990
So those are our primary colors.

67
00:03:30.990 --> 00:03:35.179
Those are the ones that we use, remember
when we talked about mixing paint and

68
00:03:35.179 --> 00:03:36.673
what colors can make what?

69
00:03:36.673 --> 00:03:40.180
Well, that becomes what we'd
think of are secondary colors.

70
00:03:40.180 --> 00:03:44.690
When you mixed a primary and
primary together, you get our other

71
00:03:44.690 --> 00:03:49.770
colors of the rainbows as we wanna call
it, like orange, green and purple.

72
00:03:49.770 --> 00:03:52.820
Wasn't there like the Baggies that
the yellow and blue make green,

73
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:54.201
there was that commercial?

74
00:03:54.201 --> 00:03:56.250
>> Right, to make sure your
Ziploc was closed properly.

75
00:03:56.250 --> 00:03:58.660
>> Yes, and
that means you know you got that there.

76
00:03:58.660 --> 00:04:02.706
So that was mixing two primary colors.

77
00:04:02.706 --> 00:04:05.708
Well, if you take a primary and
a secondary,

78
00:04:05.708 --> 00:04:09.070
you get what are called tertiary colors.

79
00:04:09.070 --> 00:04:13.050
So you have what we think of as
red-orange, and yellow-green, but

80
00:04:13.050 --> 00:04:17.524
they also have some other names that
they can be referred to, as chartreuse.

81
00:04:17.524 --> 00:04:18.476
>> Chartreuse.

82
00:04:18.476 --> 00:04:22.472
>> You can get kinda fancy on there,
and teal, and there's always that,

83
00:04:22.472 --> 00:04:23.279
what is teal?

84
00:04:23.279 --> 00:04:24.090
That's not teal.

85
00:04:24.090 --> 00:04:28.564
And then how we actually see color and
what we think of as this is blue or

86
00:04:28.564 --> 00:04:32.590
this is green is really based on
a whole bunch of other things.

87
00:04:32.590 --> 00:04:36.530
But these are the names that you're going
to come across when you're talking about

88
00:04:36.530 --> 00:04:37.710
tertiary colors.

89
00:04:37.710 --> 00:04:40.942
This is one of those where if you if you
start Googling and get into Wikipedia

90
00:04:40.942 --> 00:04:44.586
articles and you have all those links, you
can sit there for hours, just clicking on

91
00:04:44.586 --> 00:04:47.992
different topics, and like what is this,
what is that and where does that go?

92
00:04:47.992 --> 00:04:49.469
And so it's a really quite fun.

93
00:04:49.469 --> 00:04:52.845
>> It is, I was looking at something and
you talk about colors that maybe not be

94
00:04:52.845 --> 00:04:56.180
colors, cuz pink is one of the ones I
remember reading about is maybe not.

95
00:04:56.180 --> 00:04:59.510
Some people don't think it's an actual
color, you can't reproduce it.

96
00:04:59.510 --> 00:05:02.249
Yeah, you end up down the rabbit hole of
these different arguments of why it is, or

97
00:05:02.249 --> 00:05:02.778
why it isn't.

98
00:05:02.778 --> 00:05:07.906
>> Yeah, and you can't reproduce that
with light, or we talk about light or

99
00:05:07.906 --> 00:05:13.130
inks, or what have you, so this yeah,
this definitely a big rabbit hole.

100
00:05:14.393 --> 00:05:18.850
So let's just keep on that kinda surface
of the color theory, and go along with

101
00:05:18.850 --> 00:05:21.960
the things that we do need to know about
when we're gonna start user Illustrator,

102
00:05:21.960 --> 00:05:26.190
because these terms are gonna come
up when we get into those panels,

103
00:05:26.190 --> 00:05:27.500
like I was saying.

104
00:05:27.500 --> 00:05:33.080
It's also good to know about when you're
taking any type of Adobe certifications,

105
00:05:33.080 --> 00:05:34.180
cuz these things will come up.

106
00:05:35.500 --> 00:05:39.820
Let's go into this color wheel and this
is where it goes back to Isaac Newton,

107
00:05:39.820 --> 00:05:42.630
where he was the first
one that introduced this.

108
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:46.265
And there's other people that came
along throughout history to use it and

109
00:05:46.265 --> 00:05:48.980
move it through its
progression of what we see.

110
00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:53.960
But it really kind of is based on these
16 colors and so this is our wheel.

111
00:05:53.960 --> 00:05:56.300
I'm sure we've seen this in
many different representations.

112
00:05:56.300 --> 00:06:00.095
Anytime we're talking about color or
you're learning, in kindergarten, or

113
00:06:00.095 --> 00:06:04.072
in tenth grade, we're taking art history
and things like that so we've got here.

114
00:06:04.072 --> 00:06:08.642
So we're going to be working with these
colors and talking about different

115
00:06:08.642 --> 00:06:13.700
ways that you can group colors together,
in a sense, and what those terms are.

116
00:06:13.700 --> 00:06:15.040
>> So let's just start over here.

117
00:06:15.040 --> 00:06:18.435
I have my Layers panel open just so
you can see, I've got a little,

118
00:06:18.435 --> 00:06:22.453
it's almost like a PowerPoint presentation
in Illustrator, using layers.

119
00:06:22.453 --> 00:06:23.248
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

120
00:06:23.248 --> 00:06:25.990
we're gonna first talk
about analagous colors.

121
00:06:25.990 --> 00:06:29.360
Analagous colors are ones that
are similar to each other.

122
00:06:29.360 --> 00:06:33.644
So I've kinda demonstrated here like
the ones that are greenish and blue,

123
00:06:33.644 --> 00:06:35.844
those would be similar to each other.

124
00:06:35.844 --> 00:06:38.639
And then the orangey colors or
the greeny colors and

125
00:06:38.639 --> 00:06:42.356
I'm gonna start adding wise to
the end of everything probably now.

126
00:06:42.356 --> 00:06:44.826
[LAUGH] All right, so analogous colors.

127
00:06:44.826 --> 00:06:48.427
Then you also have things
like complementary colors, so

128
00:06:48.427 --> 00:06:52.860
to me, when I Iook at this,
it's automatically Christmas, right?

129
00:06:52.860 --> 00:06:53.403
>> Yes.

130
00:06:53.403 --> 00:06:55.153
>> Red and green and that's all you see.

131
00:06:55.153 --> 00:07:00.349
And that's because those two colors
are across from the color wheel,

132
00:07:00.349 --> 00:07:05.910
and so they are opposite but yet
they also complement each other very well.

133
00:07:05.910 --> 00:07:10.056
Because they're on those different ends
of the spectrum, if you wanna say.

134
00:07:10.056 --> 00:07:14.658
And we have another one, so you have here,
since we're here in Florida,

135
00:07:14.658 --> 00:07:18.012
this is where you automatically
think of our Gators.

136
00:07:18.012 --> 00:07:20.850
Good old Gators there,
and so on and so forth.

137
00:07:20.850 --> 00:07:23.730
You can see another one here,
purple and yellow.

138
00:07:23.730 --> 00:07:25.939
You've probably seen
these color combinations,

139
00:07:25.939 --> 00:07:27.228
you see this a lot in schools.

140
00:07:27.228 --> 00:07:29.690
>> I was just gonna say,
that makes me think of several schools.

141
00:07:29.690 --> 00:07:33.860
Like LSU, for example, use purple and
yellow and now I understand why

142
00:07:33.860 --> 00:07:36.420
that looks so good on their uniform,
because they're complementary colors.

143
00:07:36.420 --> 00:07:40.990
>> Yes, they make each color stand
out really well against each other,

144
00:07:40.990 --> 00:07:46.130
because of that complete
opposite end of what the color

145
00:07:46.130 --> 00:07:50.040
is in this color wheel,
in this color theory, so now we see this.

146
00:07:50.040 --> 00:07:52.010
Now, let's keep going down the line.

147
00:07:52.010 --> 00:07:55.669
We have our triadic colors, or
our triads, and when you look at this,

148
00:07:55.669 --> 00:07:58.523
it's a perfect triangle on
this 16 color wheel, and

149
00:07:58.523 --> 00:08:02.867
these kind of go back to that these are
complementary colors, not complementary,

150
00:08:02.867 --> 00:08:05.560
these are primary colors,
that's what they are.

151
00:08:05.560 --> 00:08:06.297
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

152
00:08:06.297 --> 00:08:09.280
>> Primary colors are red,
yellow and blue.

153
00:08:09.280 --> 00:08:14.648
It makes a perfect equilateral
triangle across these 16 colors,

154
00:08:14.648 --> 00:08:16.727
so that's a triad color.

155
00:08:16.727 --> 00:08:20.714
And then you get into your
split complementary colors.

156
00:08:20.714 --> 00:08:25.510
So this split complementary,
it's where red and

157
00:08:25.510 --> 00:08:29.900
green are the complementary colors,
but you take your base,

158
00:08:29.900 --> 00:08:33.150
which would be green in this situation,

159
00:08:33.150 --> 00:08:37.800
and then you take the two adjacent
colors from that complementary.

160
00:08:37.800 --> 00:08:41.230
You have that kind of maroonishy color,

161
00:08:41.230 --> 00:08:45.020
see, I'm going with the y's again,
and a red-orange color.

162
00:08:45.020 --> 00:08:50.050
Those would be your split
complements based off of green.

163
00:08:50.050 --> 00:08:52.288
Let me give you another example over here.

164
00:08:52.288 --> 00:08:56.109
You can see that the base color
would be this blue right here and

165
00:08:56.109 --> 00:09:00.464
so the split complement would be
that lighter orange and that yellow.

166
00:09:00.464 --> 00:09:03.505
>> So you could start with any color,
that would be your base color, and

167
00:09:03.505 --> 00:09:05.761
then you would just go over
to the complementary and

168
00:09:05.761 --> 00:09:07.666
then to either side of the complementary.

169
00:09:07.666 --> 00:09:10.066
>> Yep, go across and
then one on each side.

170
00:09:10.066 --> 00:09:11.282
>> Okay.

171
00:09:11.282 --> 00:09:17.220
>> Now we're gonna get in to
our tetradic rectangular.

172
00:09:17.220 --> 00:09:21.450
This is where you have two pairs
of complementary colors, okay, so

173
00:09:21.450 --> 00:09:25.090
you have the red and the green and
then blue and then the orange, and

174
00:09:25.090 --> 00:09:30.050
those two complementary colors
together make a tetradic, or

175
00:09:30.050 --> 00:09:34.500
a rectangular, type of color combination.

176
00:09:34.500 --> 00:09:39.080
I got another one here so you can just see
that we've just got different complements

177
00:09:39.080 --> 00:09:42.330
together to make that rectangle.

178
00:09:42.330 --> 00:09:44.720
What's the difference between
a rectangle and a square?

179
00:09:44.720 --> 00:09:50.040
Squares are equal sides, so
then you go to the equal distance of

180
00:09:50.040 --> 00:09:53.090
the colors in a square
rather than a rectangle.

181
00:09:53.090 --> 00:09:56.788
So they're four evenly spaced
colors around the color wheel.

182
00:09:56.788 --> 00:10:00.876
We've got another one here just for
demonstration purposes and so

183
00:10:00.876 --> 00:10:03.583
that's where we've got, square colors.

184
00:10:03.583 --> 00:10:08.292
If we keep on moving down the color theory
pipeline [LAUGH], then you get into warm

185
00:10:08.292 --> 00:10:12.816
and cool colors, and I almost feel
that this is almost self-explanatory.

186
00:10:12.816 --> 00:10:17.014
When you think of warm, it's red,
it's like on the shower handle, right,

187
00:10:17.014 --> 00:10:20.110
you got the red for the hot and
the blue for the cold.

188
00:10:20.110 --> 00:10:23.910
So that's where you have your warm and
your cool colors.

189
00:10:23.910 --> 00:10:27.760
And that's really the basics
of color theory and

190
00:10:27.760 --> 00:10:32.366
how colors complement and
work together on this color wheel.

191
00:10:32.366 --> 00:10:35.020
>> It's fascinating Vonne, and
you say that's the basics, so

192
00:10:35.020 --> 00:10:37.060
I assume that means there's even more.

193
00:10:37.060 --> 00:10:39.500
>> Yes, we have a few more
things to go over in here.

194
00:10:39.500 --> 00:10:42.310
Let's go move on down my art board.

195
00:10:42.310 --> 00:10:46.778
I wanna just throw this in over here,
is that we're talking about color, but

196
00:10:46.778 --> 00:10:49.910
another word that you can use for
color is hue.

197
00:10:49.910 --> 00:10:53.650
You might see that throughout any
type of readings that you do.

198
00:10:53.650 --> 00:10:56.723
And actually, a lot of this terminology,
you're gonna see kinda intermixed in

199
00:10:56.723 --> 00:10:59.670
between each other, so but that comes
down a little lower on my art board.

200
00:10:59.670 --> 00:11:02.230
Let's go on to what is a tint?

201
00:11:02.230 --> 00:11:04.720
A tint is when you add white to a color.

202
00:11:06.640 --> 00:11:09.070
You can think of tint in
a couple of different ways, but

203
00:11:09.070 --> 00:11:14.530
in this area of color theory,
this is what they mean.

204
00:11:14.530 --> 00:11:19.040
You add white to a base color like red,
and then you're going to get

205
00:11:19.040 --> 00:11:23.280
it's almost lighter and that's for
like lighter, less saturated.

206
00:11:23.280 --> 00:11:26.650
All of these words that people
could use to describe it.

207
00:11:26.650 --> 00:11:31.350
There are some more technical ways of
that Adobe thinks of as lightness and

208
00:11:31.350 --> 00:11:34.040
brightness, or in photography,

209
00:11:34.040 --> 00:11:36.370
it might actually mean
something slightly different.

210
00:11:36.370 --> 00:11:37.981
But a lot of the same terminology.

211
00:11:37.981 --> 00:11:40.220
So we have tints, we also have shades.

212
00:11:40.220 --> 00:11:43.356
So shades means is when you're
actually adding black to a hue.

213
00:11:43.356 --> 00:11:46.984
Okay, think about shade,
you're gonna get darker, so

214
00:11:46.984 --> 00:11:51.310
anywhere from that red and
then to that darker or almost black.

215
00:11:51.310 --> 00:11:54.040
You can see the progression of where
those colors would go from here.

216
00:11:55.410 --> 00:11:58.490
Tones would be if you add grey to a hue.

217
00:11:58.490 --> 00:12:01.670
You can see just right here like
almost in the middle, right,

218
00:12:01.670 --> 00:12:06.270
with this one, this one and
this one, they're all shades of red,

219
00:12:06.270 --> 00:12:09.430
you might say, in regular terminology,
if we're talking about this.

220
00:12:09.430 --> 00:12:12.510
Or these are tones, or tints of red.

221
00:12:12.510 --> 00:12:16.310
But specifically, it's adding white,
adding black or adding grey.

222
00:12:16.310 --> 00:12:18.740
>> So,
it is important how you got to that color.

223
00:12:18.740 --> 00:12:20.270
Did you start with a base and add white?

224
00:12:20.270 --> 00:12:23.165
Did you start with a base and
add blacks, or did you add greys?

225
00:12:23.165 --> 00:12:27.490
>> Mm-hm, yeah, and that's what,
in the eyes of color theory, that's

226
00:12:27.490 --> 00:12:31.960
the definition of those particular terms,
and I threw in a couple more, down here.

227
00:12:31.960 --> 00:12:36.280
You've got the chroma, saturation,
value, purity, brightness, lightness.

228
00:12:36.280 --> 00:12:38.450
You go to five different websites,

229
00:12:38.450 --> 00:12:40.990
they're probably gonna say
five different definitions.

230
00:12:40.990 --> 00:12:44.850
And then the levels of brightness and
lightness.

231
00:12:44.850 --> 00:12:49.429
But you can look these up and
look at them in different ways.

232
00:12:49.429 --> 00:12:54.380
But the saturation, if it's a saturated
color, it's really bright or vibrant.

233
00:12:54.380 --> 00:12:57.130
But then somebody might
call that a brightness.

234
00:12:57.130 --> 00:13:00.530
I think it's all of how
we determine what that

235
00:13:00.530 --> 00:13:03.000
word is when we use it in regular talk.

236
00:13:03.000 --> 00:13:06.071
But when you're talking about
it from a theory point,

237
00:13:06.071 --> 00:13:10.563
it does have more definitive definitions
and they're all a little different.

238
00:13:10.563 --> 00:13:12.560
Yeah, it's the same but
different, my favorite saying.

239
00:13:12.560 --> 00:13:13.860
>> Yeah, same but different.

240
00:13:13.860 --> 00:13:15.400
Context is always important, right,

241
00:13:15.400 --> 00:13:18.418
how we're using that term in relation
to whatever we're talking about.

242
00:13:18.418 --> 00:13:23.780
>> And that kinda goes right into,
then what are these colors saying to us?

243
00:13:23.780 --> 00:13:28.830
Why would we not paint
a hospital room red?

244
00:13:30.020 --> 00:13:34.130
>> Because red makes you feel,
I don't know, it makes me feel angry or

245
00:13:34.130 --> 00:13:38.260
excited, or-
>> Fire, danger.

246
00:13:38.260 --> 00:13:39.854
Why is a stop sign red?

247
00:13:39.854 --> 00:13:43.555
It's to say stop,
you need to not to go forward anymore,

248
00:13:43.555 --> 00:13:46.884
because there's danger
ahead if you don't stop.

249
00:13:46.884 --> 00:13:49.986
It means a lot of different things, but

250
00:13:49.986 --> 00:13:54.610
that's those general,
what does this color say to us?

251
00:13:54.610 --> 00:13:57.012
That's what we're kinda gonna do,
so let's keep on going.

252
00:13:57.012 --> 00:13:57.810
Let's play this game.

253
00:13:57.810 --> 00:14:01.061
What do you think of
when we think of green?

254
00:14:01.061 --> 00:14:02.740
>> Green, I think money.

255
00:14:02.740 --> 00:14:04.150
>> Yeah.
>> Grass.

256
00:14:04.150 --> 00:14:05.544
>> Grass, yes.

257
00:14:05.544 --> 00:14:07.050
I have some notes over here.

258
00:14:07.050 --> 00:14:08.250
New beginnings.

259
00:14:08.250 --> 00:14:09.630
>> New beginnings, right.

260
00:14:09.630 --> 00:14:10.300
>> Nature.

261
00:14:10.300 --> 00:14:11.640
>> Growth, yeah, absolutely.

262
00:14:11.640 --> 00:14:12.330
>> Growth, wealth.

263
00:14:12.330 --> 00:14:14.910
>> Springtime, I can see that.

264
00:14:14.910 --> 00:14:16.610
>> What about purple?

265
00:14:16.610 --> 00:14:19.003
>> Purple, I think of royalty.

266
00:14:19.003 --> 00:14:20.559
>> Mm-hm, that's another one.

267
00:14:20.559 --> 00:14:22.840
They also talk about wealth.

268
00:14:22.840 --> 00:14:26.670
Royalty is definitely the first one
that is on a lot of people's list,

269
00:14:26.670 --> 00:14:27.440
when we talk about that.

270
00:14:27.440 --> 00:14:28.679
Yes, so point one for you.

271
00:14:28.679 --> 00:14:31.683
>> [LAUGH]
>> What about brown?

272
00:14:31.683 --> 00:14:34.013
>> Hm, dirt, earthy.

273
00:14:34.013 --> 00:14:35.058
>> Mm-hm, nature.

274
00:14:35.058 --> 00:14:35.995
>> Nature, yeah.

275
00:14:35.995 --> 00:14:37.397
>> Nature, what about white?

276
00:14:37.397 --> 00:14:44.780
>> Clean, crisp, almost like sanitary,
I don't know a good way to say it.

277
00:14:44.780 --> 00:14:45.706
>> Pure.
>> Pure, yes.

278
00:14:45.706 --> 00:14:48.170
>> Pure and clean, yeah.

279
00:14:48.170 --> 00:14:51.954
And you can go for hours talking
about what every color means and

280
00:14:51.954 --> 00:14:56.239
why you would want to pick one versus
the other, but I just figured it'd

281
00:14:56.239 --> 00:15:01.050
be kinda fun to talk about color and what
we mean when we use it in certain places.

282
00:15:01.050 --> 00:15:04.652
>> And I know, sometimes those meanings,
it's a cultural thing too,

283
00:15:04.652 --> 00:15:08.752
where white in our culture might mean
something slightly different in another

284
00:15:08.752 --> 00:15:09.875
culture
>> Yes, and

285
00:15:09.875 --> 00:15:11.224
now we're getting really deep, aren't we?

286
00:15:11.224 --> 00:15:12.989
>> Yes, we'll go back, we digress.

287
00:15:12.989 --> 00:15:17.917
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, just keep it on the
surface, but yes, that is completely true

288
00:15:17.917 --> 00:15:23.415
and it's one of those things of why whole
books are written on this specific topic.

289
00:15:23.415 --> 00:15:24.025
>> Very good.
>> So

290
00:15:24.025 --> 00:15:29.568
we've kinda covered what the colors mean
and the way that they can work together.

291
00:15:29.568 --> 00:15:34.168
But when we're talking about color in
relationship to what we're doing in

292
00:15:34.168 --> 00:15:38.768
creating graphics and design and
using them in Illustrator or Photoshop or

293
00:15:38.768 --> 00:15:43.340
InDesign or any product,
we really start talking about the numbers.

294
00:15:43.340 --> 00:15:48.560
Because then we get into the scientific of
well, what is the value of this color, not

295
00:15:48.560 --> 00:15:53.350
just value of what it means on the wall or
to culture, but what are the numbers?

296
00:15:53.350 --> 00:15:58.733
What does it mean to be 52, 175, and 25?

297
00:15:58.733 --> 00:16:00.103
What does that mean?

298
00:16:00.103 --> 00:16:01.473
What's 172c?

299
00:16:01.473 --> 00:16:02.657
What is that?

300
00:16:02.657 --> 00:16:06.332
In the next episodes, we'll get into
the difference between our web colors,

301
00:16:06.332 --> 00:16:10.500
our print colors and what all those
numbers mean when we make our graphics.

302
00:16:10.500 --> 00:16:12.310
>> All right, Vonne, great stuff there.

303
00:16:12.310 --> 00:16:15.920
Fascinating information, thank you for
that and those great demonstrations.

304
00:16:15.920 --> 00:16:17.750
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

305
00:16:17.750 --> 00:16:20.250
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

306
00:16:20.250 --> 00:16:20.958
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

307
00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.685
>> And we'll see you next time.

308
00:16:22.685 --> 00:16:23.185
>> Got staticky.

309
00:16:24.346 --> 00:16:25.565
>> Yeah?

310
00:16:25.565 --> 00:16:27.340
All right, one more time.

311
00:16:27.340 --> 00:16:30.300
>> I'm just having all sorts of
technical problems, aren't I?

312
00:16:31.640 --> 00:16:32.749
Making your life hell.

313
00:16:32.749 --> 00:16:36.225
>> No, that was, honestly, that was
one of the best episodes [CROSSTALK].

314
00:16:36.225 --> 00:16:39.290
>> Yeah, poor Titus has to edit all this.

315
00:16:39.290 --> 00:16:40.684
>> [INAUDIBLE] jump again.

316
00:16:40.684 --> 00:16:41.914
>> Me?

317
00:16:41.914 --> 00:16:45.327
>> [INAUDIBLE] man, I don't know.

318
00:16:45.327 --> 00:16:46.195
>> Okay, we just won't move.

319
00:16:46.195 --> 00:16:48.340
[LAUGH]
>> [INAUDIBLE]

320
00:16:48.340 --> 00:16:49.719
>> Yeah, statues.

321
00:16:53.805 --> 00:16:54.850
>> All right, Vonne.

322
00:16:54.850 --> 00:16:56.233
Thank you for that great information.

323
00:16:56.233 --> 00:16:58.680
Fantastic, shoot.

324
00:16:58.680 --> 00:16:59.571
>> Actually, I looked at you.

325
00:16:59.571 --> 00:17:08.194
[LAUGH]
>> Ready?

326
00:17:08.194 --> 00:17:09.541
>> Yeah.

327
00:17:09.541 --> 00:17:11.231
>> I'm not looking at you or anything.

328
00:17:11.231 --> 00:17:13.060
>> Okay.
>> I just wanna be turning to the camera

329
00:17:13.060 --> 00:17:14.788
so he has some place to cut it into.

330
00:17:14.788 --> 00:17:15.949
>> Got it.

331
00:17:15.949 --> 00:17:20.063
>> [COUGH] All right,
great stuff Vonne, there.

332
00:17:20.063 --> 00:17:21.456
Great stuff Vonne, there?

333
00:17:21.456 --> 00:17:23.531
>> [LAUGH]
>> Great information.

334
00:17:23.531 --> 00:17:24.971
>> Yeah, sorry, one more time.

335
00:17:24.971 --> 00:17:30.332
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> All right, Vonne,

336
00:17:30.332 --> 00:17:33.710
a lot of great information there when
it comes to the world of color theory.

337
00:17:33.710 --> 00:17:35.800
Fascinating stuff.

338
00:17:35.800 --> 00:17:37.600
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

339
00:17:37.600 --> 00:17:40.003
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

00:17:40.003 --> 00:17:40.885
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

00:17:40.885 --> 00:17:42.356
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Color Values
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.040 --> 00:00:10.040
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.450 --> 00:00:12.710
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at IT ProTV.

3
00:00:15.740 --> 00:00:18.860
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC2015.

4
00:00:18.860 --> 00:00:24.450
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be looking at color values.

5
00:00:24.450 --> 00:00:28.790
In a previous episode, we spent a lot
of time going over color theory.

6
00:00:28.790 --> 00:00:32.150
But at some point we gotta take
that theory, right, and put it into

7
00:00:32.150 --> 00:00:36.670
practical use, actually get the colors
that we want into our application.

8
00:00:36.670 --> 00:00:39.470
And that can be a tricky process
because there's many different ways and

9
00:00:39.470 --> 00:00:40.810
methods that we can use.

10
00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:42.960
And here to explain all
that is Miss Vaughn Smith.

11
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:43.680
How's it going, Vaughn?

12
00:00:43.680 --> 00:00:47.200
>> Great, I'm glad to be here to
talk to you all about color and

13
00:00:47.200 --> 00:00:50.800
all of the fancy numbers that go
along with working with numbers.

14
00:00:50.800 --> 00:00:57.961
And we're gonna understand what it means
to be talking about 122550 versus 52%,

15
00:00:57.961 --> 00:01:02.619
all sorts of fun numbers, so
we're going to get into that.

16
00:01:02.619 --> 00:01:03.804
>> Is math involved?

17
00:01:03.804 --> 00:01:05.862
>> There actually will be math.

18
00:01:05.862 --> 00:01:06.650
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

19
00:01:06.650 --> 00:01:09.062
it's good because you're here to help us,
so.

20
00:01:09.062 --> 00:01:09.574
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

21
00:01:09.574 --> 00:01:12.048
>> So, hopefully together we'll be able to

22
00:01:12.048 --> 00:01:13.107
add up to five, or

23
00:01:13.107 --> 00:01:14.723
something close to that.
[LAUGH]

24
00:01:14.723 --> 00:01:15.916
>> Sounds like

25
00:01:15.916 --> 00:01:17.094
a plan.
[LAUGH]

26
00:01:17.094 --> 00:01:19.440
>> All right, so I've got my document

27
00:01:19.440 --> 00:01:24.940
here, ready to go for us to start
the lecture about color values.

28
00:01:24.940 --> 00:01:29.750
Because, like Mike said, we were talking
about, what does it mean to be red, and

29
00:01:29.750 --> 00:01:33.530
is that a warm color,
do we have analogous colors, but

30
00:01:33.530 --> 00:01:38.310
that's fine as the actual look and
the aesthetics of a design.

31
00:01:38.310 --> 00:01:41.880
But understanding what that
number means is very important.

32
00:01:41.880 --> 00:01:46.270
And are we designing an ad that's
going to go into a website?

33
00:01:46.270 --> 00:01:52.040
Are we designing an ad that's going
into a commercial-printed brochure,

34
00:01:52.040 --> 00:01:53.400
or magazine, something like that.

35
00:01:53.400 --> 00:01:56.240
So it's very important to understand
the differentiation between that.

36
00:01:56.240 --> 00:01:59.520
So here we have The whole
web versus print or

37
00:01:59.520 --> 00:02:03.820
you can also just say screen because when
I just talk about web, you could do video.

38
00:02:03.820 --> 00:02:08.310
Anything is gonna displayed on
an actual monitor of some sort.

39
00:02:08.310 --> 00:02:12.400
So that's where we get in to
whether we are RGB for screen or

40
00:02:12.400 --> 00:02:17.240
web, or your print, which is CMYK,
and what that stands for.

41
00:02:17.240 --> 00:02:20.120
But we'll get into all of
that throughout this lecture.

42
00:02:20.120 --> 00:02:21.640
I just wanna give a quick overview,

43
00:02:21.640 --> 00:02:26.480
because this orange right here,
you think it's just orange, right?

44
00:02:26.480 --> 00:02:33.240
Well, the value of what that orange is
in In our programs is different for

45
00:02:33.240 --> 00:02:37.910
web, for CMYK, for print, for spot colors.

46
00:02:37.910 --> 00:02:40.180
Or for what else is on here?

47
00:02:40.180 --> 00:02:40.970
Our hex numbers.

48
00:02:40.970 --> 00:02:41.640
Okay.

49
00:02:41.640 --> 00:02:46.650
So this means something
in different places.

50
00:02:46.650 --> 00:02:49.830
And it's important to understand
the differentiation between it.

51
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:54.590
Because if I'm working for a company and
I'm doing some freelance work and

52
00:02:54.590 --> 00:02:58.950
I need to make sure that I am using
the University of Florida orange.

53
00:02:59.950 --> 00:03:02.960
I have to make sure that I
understand that that is 0, 87, 100,

54
00:03:02.960 --> 00:03:07.800
0 when I'm sending that to
a commercial printer or

55
00:03:07.800 --> 00:03:10.670
that that is spot color 172.

56
00:03:10.670 --> 00:03:13.890
Because God forbid,
if you do not use Gator orange and

57
00:03:13.890 --> 00:03:15.870
you use Tennessee orange in a brochure.

58

00:15:32.092 --> 00:15:33.800

286
00:15:33.800 --> 00:15:38.258
You could go ahead and
put it into three numbers,

287
00:15:38.258 --> 00:15:43.817
because if you have F0F,
it just knows that it is FF00FF.

288
00:15:43.817 --> 00:15:46.458
So it's just-
>> With web-safe, they're always gonna be

289
00:15:46.458 --> 00:15:49.320
doubled, it's never gonna be a FE
>> It's always gonna be two Fs.

290
00:15:49.320 --> 00:15:50.742
So you can put one F.

291
00:15:50.742 --> 00:15:53.380
So it doesn't seem like it
saves you a lot of typing, but

292
00:15:53.380 --> 00:15:57.104
I can imagine with thousands of lines of
code, that could really help you out.

293
00:15:57.104 --> 00:15:57.754
>> Yes.

294
00:15:57.754 --> 00:16:03.490
And just to kind of go off of that
short handing of the hexidecimal value,

295
00:16:03.490 --> 00:16:08.380
I was kind of dovetailing it on
to the WEBSAFE with the 0, 3,

296
00:16:08.380 --> 00:16:12.630
6, 9, C and F cuz that's the only numbers.

297
00:16:12.630 --> 00:16:17.710
In a hexidecimal notation, that would be
considered web-safe, as the double values.

298
00:16:17.710 --> 00:16:21.470
But, you can have 44ee22,

299
00:16:21.470 --> 00:16:25.513
I mean you can have double values.

300
00:16:25.513 --> 00:16:26.384
>> That are web safe.

301
00:16:26.384 --> 00:16:29.102
>> Yes, they are websafe that
you can shorthand them that way.

302
00:16:29.102 --> 00:16:32.978
So you can do for example E F and
two whatever combination I tried to

303
00:16:32.978 --> 00:16:36.575
demonstrate there [LAUGH] so
you can shorthand it there it just

304
00:16:36.575 --> 00:16:41.750
means that it will be doubled for the
values so it doesn't have to be websafe.

305
00:16:41.750 --> 00:16:44.930
So kinda going down here, if we've got,

306
00:16:44.930 --> 00:16:48.440
we said that zero is off and
F is all the way on.

307
00:16:48.440 --> 00:16:53.750
Kinda the same game that we were
playing back before, with the RGB.

308
00:16:53.750 --> 00:16:55.970
>> I knew I should have taken notes.

309
00:16:55.970 --> 00:16:57.757
>> [LAUGH] Right.

310
00:16:57.757 --> 00:17:01.839
[LAUGH] It's still in
the additive color mode that RGB,

311
00:17:01.839 --> 00:17:05.130
cuz we're still talking about light here.

312
00:17:05.130 --> 00:17:06.530
We're talking about display.

313
00:17:06.530 --> 00:17:10.840
So all on would be white,
so what would white be?

314
00:17:10.840 --> 00:17:14.895
>> FFF or FFFFFF.

315
00:17:14.895 --> 00:17:18.170
>> Yes you are correct and I just
realized that, why is it not talking?

316
00:17:18.170 --> 00:17:19.010
There we go.

317
00:17:19.010 --> 00:17:23.320
I'm playing around with my layers to be,
are hiding and everything, and

318
00:17:23.320 --> 00:17:27.770
I forgot that my group eyeball, the group
visibility wasn't on, so that way,

319
00:17:27.770 --> 00:17:29.700
I couldn't toggle the actual
individual parts.

320
00:17:29.700 --> 00:17:33.960
So F, yes, and
I did it in the six number notation.

321
00:17:33.960 --> 00:17:35.456
So black would be what?

322
00:17:35.456 --> 00:17:37.910
>> 000000?

323
00:17:37.910 --> 00:17:39.970
>> Yes, with [INAUDIBLE] one, two, three.

324
00:17:39.970 --> 00:17:41.064
Yeah, I do six of them.

325
00:17:41.064 --> 00:17:42.810
[LAUGH]
>> [INAUDIBLE] six zeroes.

326
00:17:42.810 --> 00:17:44.330
>> Correct, yes.

327
00:17:44.330 --> 00:17:50.730
So back over to the red, green and
blues, where we're gonna go?

328
00:17:50.730 --> 00:17:56.290
We're gonna go with with red being?

329
00:17:56.290 --> 00:17:57.530
>> FF0000.
>> Mm-hm.

330
00:17:57.530 --> 00:17:58.415
>> Green would be 00FF00.

331
00:17:58.415 --> 00:17:59.089
Mm-hm.

332
00:17:59.089 --> 00:18:01.642
>> And then blue would be 0000FF.

333
00:18:01.642 --> 00:18:02.689
>> Good, yes.

334
00:18:02.689 --> 00:18:03.665
>> Got those down pat.

335
00:18:03.665 --> 00:18:04.185
>> All right.

336
00:18:04.185 --> 00:18:05.260
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

337
00:18:05.260 --> 00:18:08.034
>> So back from our yellow is really green

338
00:18:08.034 --> 00:18:12.010
and red combined,
what would our yellow value be?

339
00:18:12.010 --> 00:18:15.250
>> Green and red, so
we'll turn on the red FF,

340
00:18:15.250 --> 00:18:18.385
we'll turn on the green FF and
we'll leave the blue off, 00.

341
00:18:18.385 --> 00:18:19.705
>> Yes.

342
00:18:19.705 --> 00:18:21.987
[LAUGH] Good job.

343
00:18:21.987 --> 00:18:25.528
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so let's go on to,

344
00:18:25.528 --> 00:18:30.250
orange is always a little tougher, but we
know that that's gonna be a lot of what?

345
00:18:30.250 --> 00:18:34.552
>> A lot of reds and a lot of blues?

346
00:18:36.097 --> 00:18:36.734
>> No.

347
00:18:36.734 --> 00:18:37.809
[LAUGH]
>> A lot of green?

348
00:18:37.809 --> 00:18:40.131
>> Green, but not as much green.

349
00:18:40.131 --> 00:18:41.041
>> But not as much green?

350
00:18:41.041 --> 00:18:41.777
>> Yes, and a lot more red.

351
00:18:41.777 --> 00:18:46.970
>> So then we could do FF and
then about halfway through it'd be 7700.

352
00:18:46.970 --> 00:18:48.940
>> Yeah, close, yeah, so, well,

353
00:18:48.940 --> 00:18:53.600
at least in this particular shade that
I was creating from, it is FF7300.

354
00:18:53.600 --> 00:18:56.188
But yes, you're close enough so.

355
00:18:56.188 --> 00:19:00.110
[LAUGH] And since you've done so
well, I'll give you the last two.

356
00:19:00.110 --> 00:19:01.760
>> Okay.
>> So we'll just go with, all right, so

357
00:19:01.760 --> 00:19:05.380
we know that sky blue is gonna be
a lot of the red and the blue.

358
00:19:05.380 --> 00:19:10.740
And then the pink is going to be
a lot of the red and the blue.

359
00:19:10.740 --> 00:19:13.410
And I think I just messed the sky,
it's actually a lot of green.

360
00:19:13.410 --> 00:19:17.490
Again, I'm so glad that our Adobe products
are going to give us the numbers for us.

361
00:19:17.490 --> 00:19:18.947
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right.

362
00:19:18.947 --> 00:19:20.604
>> So we don't have to keep guessing.

363
00:19:20.604 --> 00:19:21.386
So all right, wonderful.

364
00:19:21.386 --> 00:19:27.878
All right, so let's move on to another way
that you can actually notate values for

365
00:19:27.878 --> 00:19:32.691
screen display, and
that's a little known one called HSB.

366
00:19:32.691 --> 00:19:35.650
This is hue, saturation and brightness.

367
00:19:35.650 --> 00:19:40.010
Now I will tell you right from the start,
that I don't really measure colors for

368
00:19:40.010 --> 00:19:41.920
web in HSB.

369
00:19:41.920 --> 00:19:45.930
Or there's HSL, cuz you can see there,
I got B, V versus L.

370
00:19:47.340 --> 00:19:48.890
But really, boils down to,

371
00:19:48.890 --> 00:19:52.510
they're all different
representations of RGB values, okay?

372
00:19:52.510 --> 00:19:57.510
And you will see HSB values
displayed when you're

373
00:19:57.510 --> 00:20:01.370
picking colors in the color picker
in all of your Adobe products, so

374
00:20:01.370 --> 00:20:04.870
at least it's good to understand what
the letters even stand for, okay?

375
00:20:04.870 --> 00:20:07.250
And it goes on this degree,

376
00:20:07.250 --> 00:20:12.620
this color wheel form 0 to 360 if you
think about a circle being 360 degrees.

377
00:20:12.620 --> 00:20:18.630
And where the hue falls within that
circular spectrum if you want to say.

378
00:20:18.630 --> 00:20:24.170
Then how much light and dark, the
saturation and the brightness would be.

379
00:20:24.170 --> 00:20:28.350
And so they represent this
in this little graphic here.

380
00:20:28.350 --> 00:20:32.770
It's not to scale,
it's just trying to show you something.

381
00:20:32.770 --> 00:20:35.100
So just to give you some
examples down here.

382
00:20:35.100 --> 00:20:37.110
These are all HSB values.

383
00:20:37.110 --> 00:20:41.810
As you could see that
00100 like the brightness,

384
00:20:41.810 --> 00:20:43.110
we're talking about light again.

385
00:20:43.110 --> 00:20:45.630
It's very bright, so all the bright is on.

386
00:20:45.630 --> 00:20:48.250
But then when you look at black you
can see the saturation is 100 and

387
00:20:48.250 --> 00:20:50.230
the brightness is at zero.

388
00:20:50.230 --> 00:20:56.276
So it's like the S is the black and
the B is like the light, kind of.

389
00:20:56.276 --> 00:20:59.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] In it's weird way,

390
00:20:59.940 --> 00:21:03.850
so and then you can see red,
green and blue.

391
00:21:03.850 --> 00:21:08.667
You can see that the hue is a different
degree along that 360 degree.

392
00:21:08.667 --> 00:21:12.068
Like the color wheel that we were talking
about when we were doing color theory,

393
00:21:12.068 --> 00:21:14.340
when we had all of those
values going around.

394
00:21:14.340 --> 00:21:20.080
You can think of it that way, of where
is that color within that hue spectrum,

395
00:21:20.080 --> 00:21:23.270
if you wanna say, and I've even seen,
you can see that this,

396
00:21:23.270 --> 00:21:28.830
if you're saturation brightness is on,
at 100 percent on a lot of them or,

397
00:21:28.830 --> 00:21:32.960
the hue value actually is,
this could be 0 or 360,

398
00:21:32.960 --> 00:21:37.560
cuz 0 and 360 are the same, and
if you have the whole saturation up.

399
00:21:37.560 --> 00:21:42.680
It doesn't matter what the hue value is,
it could be 0 or 200 or a 120.

400
00:21:42.680 --> 00:21:45.630
If the saturation is
all the way up to 100,

401
00:21:45.630 --> 00:21:47.530
it's gonna be black no matter what it is.

402
00:21:47.530 --> 00:21:51.460
So it's kind of a weird, I think it's
a little bit of a weird measurement system

403
00:21:51.460 --> 00:21:52.690
but it is something to at least see.

404
00:21:52.690 --> 00:21:55.430
>> Definitely different, but I'm sure
it has it's application somewhere.

405
00:21:55.430 --> 00:21:59.700
>> Yeah and I mean it just goes along with
the, it's a different representation of

406
00:21:59.700 --> 00:22:03.874
>> RGB light values within a display and

407
00:22:03.874 --> 00:22:11.966
one quick thing is that the HSL value
is not actually the same as the HSB.

408
00:22:11.966 --> 00:22:17.747
So HSL is lightness and
B and V value is brightness.

409
00:22:17.747 --> 00:22:20.308
But the conversion between it.

410
00:22:20.308 --> 00:22:21.075
You can look it up.

411
00:22:21.075 --> 00:22:22.643
There's like this huge equation.

412
00:22:22.643 --> 00:22:23.721
I'm like, no, never mind.

413
00:22:23.721 --> 00:22:26.137
Just find an app that can
actually do it for you.

414
00:22:26.137 --> 00:22:29.538
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you Google HSB to HSL converter,

415
00:22:29.538 --> 00:22:34.400
there's websites that will
just convert it for you.

416
00:22:34.400 --> 00:22:36.710
>> Now, why does that mean anything to us?

417
00:22:36.710 --> 00:22:38.752
Well, that comes down to our next slide.

418
00:22:38.752 --> 00:22:44.058
Is again, how can we use these
numerical representations,

419
00:22:44.058 --> 00:22:49.154
these numbers, In HTML or
really than more modern version

420
00:22:49.154 --> 00:22:54.267
would be our CSS or
cascading style sheets for our coding.

421
00:22:54.267 --> 00:22:58.559
And just click if you guys were taught,
what is HTML Hypertext markup language

422
00:22:58.559 --> 00:23:01.890
is the language that is used to
actually code your websites.

423
00:23:01.890 --> 00:23:06.110
It's what we look at all day long,
when we're looking at our pages online.

424
00:23:06.110 --> 00:23:09.410
CSS cascade style sheets,
that's the formating.

425
00:23:09.410 --> 00:23:11.670
I always like to think
HTML is the structure.

426
00:23:11.670 --> 00:23:13.080
It's like the house.

427
00:23:13.080 --> 00:23:15.130
CSS is like what color
you paint the house.

428
00:23:15.130 --> 00:23:19.540
So you have paragraphs, images,
things that you see text on a page,

429
00:23:19.540 --> 00:23:23.660
but then what color, does it move,
that kind of stuff that could be CSS, so

430
00:23:23.660 --> 00:23:28.920
that's like your HTML CSS
coding in a nut shell.

431
00:23:28.920 --> 00:23:33.290
And how you would refer to it, you can see
that I've got some representations here

432
00:23:33.290 --> 00:23:37.570
is that I could use a color,
a named color value.

433
00:23:38.610 --> 00:23:40.120
So color name.

434
00:23:40.120 --> 00:23:45.760
I can use the hex number, or
I could use the HSL value.

435
00:23:45.760 --> 00:23:48.610
That weird remember HSB to HSL.

436
00:23:48.610 --> 00:23:50.280
You can use that here.

437
00:23:50.280 --> 00:23:53.030
How many web sites do
I see coded with HSL?

438
00:23:53.030 --> 00:23:58.800
I have seen a few, I have, I don't code
that way, I code with just straight hex

439
00:23:58.800 --> 00:24:03.785
numbers, cuz that is what makes more
sense to me, but it can be available.

440
00:24:03.785 --> 00:24:08.665
And you can see that RGBA, that alpha
value, that does mean something when

441
00:24:08.665 --> 00:24:13.395
you're doing HTML coding of like
the see-throughness of whatever color or

442
00:24:13.395 --> 00:24:15.730
a thing that you're
applying that color to.

443
00:24:15.730 --> 00:24:18.200
And I just threw in some numbers here.

444
00:24:18.200 --> 00:24:27.120
There's actually 140 color names
in the HTML and CSS web code.

445
00:24:27.120 --> 00:24:30.695
Things like red black, dark slate blue.

446
00:24:30.695 --> 00:24:32.616
Cuz I know what that means [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

447
00:24:32.616 --> 00:24:37.740
>> And then your hex number is 16,777,216.

448
00:24:37.740 --> 00:24:41.100
That number should probably make
sense to you as well because that's.

449
00:24:41.100 --> 00:24:44.730
>> It does,
that's because that is 24 bits, yes.

450
00:24:44.730 --> 00:24:46.830
And you're talking about 24-bit color.

451
00:24:46.830 --> 00:24:48.530
>> Mhm.
Yes, so.

452
00:24:48.530 --> 00:24:52.340
Cuz 24 bits,
that's three eight sets, right?

453
00:24:52.340 --> 00:24:53.050
Yes.

454
00:24:53.050 --> 00:24:54.760
Three groups of eight bits each.

455
00:24:54.760 --> 00:24:58.550
>> Yeah, that, again,
[LAUGH] I know about this much.

456
00:24:58.550 --> 00:25:00.400
[LAUGH]
>> Well, you teach me about colors,

457
00:25:00.400 --> 00:25:02.160
I will teach you about binary.

458
00:25:02.160 --> 00:25:04.756
>> Perfect.
That's why we make a good team together.

459
00:25:04.756 --> 00:25:05.694
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

460
00:25:05.694 --> 00:25:06.550
>> And then again,

461
00:25:06.550 --> 00:25:10.040
that 216 for our websafe values,
I kinda already mentioned that and

462
00:25:10.040 --> 00:25:14.230
the whole reason of why
that 216 is there for

463
00:25:14.230 --> 00:25:19.050
back in the day whether Apple
versus Windows displays.

464
00:25:19.050 --> 00:25:23.654
So that is probably all
I could probably cover.

465
00:25:23.654 --> 00:25:25.690
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's everything you could probably

466
00:25:25.690 --> 00:25:33.220
ever wanna know about Web values or color
values when dealing with Web or Screen.

467
00:25:33.220 --> 00:25:34.280
It's a lot.

468
00:25:34.280 --> 00:25:37.950
It might seem almost like Greek,
it's a lot of numbers.

469
00:25:37.950 --> 00:25:39.930
I don't know exactly what they mean, but

470
00:25:39.930 --> 00:25:43.470
hopefully after this lesson it
makes a little bit more sense.

471
00:25:43.470 --> 00:25:46.280
But that's what your Adobe profs
are here to guide you through.

472
00:25:46.280 --> 00:25:50.690
You don't have to memorize these numbers,
it's really just more about understanding

473
00:25:50.690 --> 00:25:54.480
What they're doing, and
what it means when they're there.

474
00:25:54.480 --> 00:25:56.320
>> That's fantastic information, Vonn.

475
00:25:56.320 --> 00:25:57.440
I know I enjoyed it.

476
00:25:57.440 --> 00:25:59.280
I learned a ton about colors.

477
00:25:59.280 --> 00:26:00.780
I hope everybody out there did, too.

478
00:26:00.780 --> 00:26:03.100
And remember,
we're not done with color values.

479
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:06.900
We still gotta deal with the print world,
so make sure you come back for that.

480
00:26:06.900 --> 00:26:10.140
Meanwhile, signing off for
IT Pro TV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

481
00:26:10.140 --> 00:26:11.058
>> And I'm Vonn Smith.

482
00:26:11.058 --> 00:26:12.864
>> And we'll see you next time.

487
00:26:47.220 --> 00:26:51.490
this is something you do need to just
at least be aware of, all right?

488
00:26:51.490 --> 00:26:52.950
So, they all look the same.

489
00:26:52.950 --> 00:26:53.550
Well, let me show you.

490
00:26:53.550 --> 00:26:57.640
So if I go to the Illustrator menu,
and I go to my Preferences.

491
00:26:57.640 --> 00:26:59.890
It's in your Edit menu for Windows.

492
00:26:59.890 --> 00:27:01.029
And see Appearance Of Black?

493
00:27:02.600 --> 00:27:06.910
It is set to my on-screen,
displays all black as rich black, and

494
00:27:06.910 --> 00:27:09.440
it has a description down there, and
you might not be able to read it.

495
00:27:09.440 --> 00:27:12.745
So, it says displaying all blacks as
rich black will show both pure blacks,

496
00:27:12.745 --> 00:27:17.340
100% k, and rich blacks, blacks with
mixed CMYK values as rich black.

497
00:27:17.340 --> 00:27:21.460
This will not change the color
values in the document, but how it

498
00:27:21.460 --> 00:27:25.740
actually shows on the screen, but all
blacks will appear as dark as possible.

499
00:27:25.740 --> 00:27:28.276
>> So if I leave that setting on my
screen they're gonna look the same, but

500
00:27:28.276 --> 00:27:30.065
the printer would be able
to tell the difference.

501
00:27:30.065 --> 00:27:35.397
>> Yes, if I sent it to a printer and
the default black of rich black is there,

502
00:27:35.397 --> 00:27:38.590
it's not just black, it's all of the ink.

503
00:27:38.590 --> 00:27:42.850
So, I'm gonna show this to where
it's going to on screen display

504
00:27:42.850 --> 00:27:45.730
all blacks accurately to where the values

505
00:27:45.730 --> 00:27:48.290
are a more true representation
of what it's gonna look like.

506
00:27:48.290 --> 00:27:49.830
And let's just see before.

507
00:27:49.830 --> 00:27:50.632
See, all the blacks.

508
00:27:50.632 --> 00:27:54.974
Now let's go with, okay,
those are not the same colors are they?

509
00:27:54.974 --> 00:27:55.985
>> Wow.
Big difference.

510
00:27:55.985 --> 00:27:57.480
>> Huge, yeah.

511
00:27:57.480 --> 00:28:01.890
So this is a black that has
a higher magenta value.

512
00:28:01.890 --> 00:28:04.890
This is a black that has
a higher cyan value.

513
00:28:04.890 --> 00:28:09.760
This is actually 000100 but
it looks gray to us.

514
00:28:09.760 --> 00:28:15.592
And so, that's why Adobe is trying to show
you on the screen that it's black but

515
00:28:15.592 --> 00:28:19.740
if I'm showing you accurately
it looks a little gray.

516
00:28:19.740 --> 00:28:23.200
And so, that's why the default setting
in Illustrator is set to rich black.

517
00:28:23.200 --> 00:28:24.240
>> That would throw people off.

518
00:28:24.240 --> 00:28:27.442
I swear I'm picking black and it's
coming up gray, so they fix that for us.

519
00:28:27.442 --> 00:28:33.590
>> Yes, so, and that is when
you're in a CMYK color mode file.

520
00:28:33.590 --> 00:28:35.948
This doesn't really mean
anything in RGB because RGB,

521
00:28:35.948 --> 00:28:38.103
we're working in a file that's for
the screen, so

522
00:28:38.103 --> 00:28:41.381
it's just whatever the screen looks like,
that's what you're gonna get.

523
00:28:41.381 --> 00:28:44.972
You don't have the same limitations
of doing any graphics for

524
00:28:44.972 --> 00:28:48.218
web in a sense,
because it's already on the screen, so

525
00:28:48.218 --> 00:28:51.341
whatever it looks like,
it's gonna look like that.

526
00:28:51.341 --> 00:28:55.872
Whether it's on a website, yes you
have monitor differentiations between

527
00:28:55.872 --> 00:29:01.390
operating systems, but it's so slight, and
it's just what you see is what you get.

528
00:29:01.390 --> 00:29:02.760
Print is a whole other world.

529
00:29:02.760 --> 00:29:06.180
You have to trust the numbers,
you have to know the numbers.

530
00:29:06.180 --> 00:29:09.775
And you have to know when to use what and
what it really means.

531
00:29:09.775 --> 00:29:13.845
And you do not use RGB values
in commercial printing and

532
00:29:13.845 --> 00:29:17.615
you do not send RGB values to
a printer cuz they will not like you.

533
00:29:17.615 --> 00:29:19.785
[LAUGH] Well,
they'll convert it for you and

534
00:29:19.785 --> 00:29:23.345
everything but it's just kind of
one of those rules of the land.

535
00:29:23.345 --> 00:29:27.493
It's CMYK, 300 resolution and I know this
isn't an episode about resolution but

536
00:29:27.493 --> 00:29:29.174
that will come in later episodes.

537
00:29:29.174 --> 00:29:35.444
RGB, RGB 72, CMYK, 300, print.

538
00:29:35.444 --> 00:29:36.837
That's how it works.

539
00:29:36.837 --> 00:29:38.160
>> All right, Vonne.
Fantastic.

540
00:29:38.160 --> 00:29:42.100
Again, a lot of great information about
color values in the world of print and

541
00:29:42.100 --> 00:29:45.211
heck a lot of great information
about the printing process.

542
00:29:45.211 --> 00:29:51.388
Even get to see some of those big bad
printers, not your old deskjet, right?

543
00:29:51.388 --> 00:29:53.490
All right, we thank you for that Vonn.

544
00:29:53.490 --> 00:29:56.420
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching,
signing off for ITProTV,

545
00:29:56.420 --> 00:29:57.790
I'm Mike Roderick.

546
00:29:57.790 --> 00:29:58.790
>> And I'm Vonn Smith.

547
00:29:58.790 --> 00:29:59.562
>> And we'll see you next time.

548
00:29:59.562 --> 00:30:08.390
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Color in Illustrator
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.250 --> 00:00:12.750
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.760 --> 00:00:19.640
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:19.640 --> 00:00:25.550
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be looking at colors in Illustrator.

5
00:00:25.550 --> 00:00:29.000
On other episodes we took at
look at some color theory

6
00:00:29.000 --> 00:00:32.990
we talked about the different
values to represent the colors.

7
00:00:32.990 --> 00:00:36.230
Hex RGB other things like that.

8
00:00:36.230 --> 00:00:38.540
And now we're going to
get into Illustrator and

9
00:00:38.540 --> 00:00:40.920
see how we actually go
about picking our colors.

10
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:44.100
And here to help us out of course is Ms.
Vonsmith how's it going Von.

11
00:00:44.100 --> 00:00:44.820
>> Great.

12
00:00:44.820 --> 00:00:49.370
Good to be back again to continue
our coloring and swatching and

13
00:00:49.370 --> 00:00:52.500
all sorts of different [LAUGH]
>> Things we need to find

14
00:00:52.500 --> 00:00:55.180
in Illustrator to represent our colors.

15
00:00:55.180 --> 00:00:59.300
There's a lot of different places
that you can go to in Illustrator to,

16
00:00:59.300 --> 00:01:03.050
find the color value that we were
going over in the last episode.

17
00:01:03.050 --> 00:01:07.210
I wanna to just jump right in, show you
where everything is and show you all

18
00:01:07.210 --> 00:01:10.440
the 15,000 different ways [LAUGH]
to find your colors in Illustrator.

19
00:01:10.440 --> 00:01:11.470
Illustrator.

20
00:01:11.470 --> 00:01:15.490
So let's go ahead and get rolling, I'm
actually right here on the same file that

21
00:01:15.490 --> 00:01:18.470
we've left off on when we were
talking about the values.

22
00:01:18.470 --> 00:01:20.340
This should look familiar.

23
00:01:20.340 --> 00:01:23.100
If you haven't seen those episodes,
of course, go back and watch them.

24
00:01:23.100 --> 00:01:26.210
So we've got here, and
I'm just gonna start anywhere.

25
00:01:26.210 --> 00:01:29.700
Maybe we'll just start on the web values.

26
00:01:29.700 --> 00:01:33.600
So, where can I find the values For

27
00:01:33.600 --> 00:01:38.220
any colors that I wanna apply, or
even have on my document already.

28
00:01:38.220 --> 00:01:40.440
Well, let's start first of
all with the color picker.

29
00:01:40.440 --> 00:01:43.470
The color picker is over
here in the tools panel,

30
00:01:43.470 --> 00:01:47.540
and it's where you have either the fill or
the stroke.

31
00:01:47.540 --> 00:01:50.240
Now, something to point out here in this,

32
00:01:50.240 --> 00:01:53.760
before we actually get into the color
picker Is which ones on top.

33
00:01:53.760 --> 00:01:58.520
Right now you see the overlap here that
the fill corner on those two right there.

34
00:01:58.520 --> 00:02:03.100
That's on top as opposed to if I click
from this one you can see that the stroke

35
00:02:03.100 --> 00:02:04.280
is now on top.

36
00:02:04.280 --> 00:02:07.370
So whichever one is on top
when you double click that's

37
00:02:07.370 --> 00:02:09.290
where we're going to get
in to the color picker.

38
00:02:09.290 --> 00:02:12.790
But something to notice before we
get in to it because it does make

39
00:02:12.790 --> 00:02:16.120
a little bit of a difference
as off to put a meaning

40
00:02:16.120 --> 00:02:18.600
as when you're going to apply it to
something that might be selected.

41
00:02:18.600 --> 00:02:22.520
Now right now I don't have any objects or
shapes or

42
00:02:22.520 --> 00:02:26.030
anything like that selected on my
document so we're good with that.

43
00:02:26.030 --> 00:02:28.690
I just want to show you
the Color Picker so let’s get into it.

44
00:02:28.690 --> 00:02:32.480
Double clicking on there brings up this
Color Picker this is the same thing you

45
00:02:32.480 --> 00:02:36.800
can do in Photoshop, so if you're
used to that this is very similar.

46
00:02:36.800 --> 00:02:39.980
So you can see here that I
had actually left off on

47
00:02:39.980 --> 00:02:43.230
selecting an orange color in the document.

48
00:02:43.230 --> 00:02:46.930
So it still has orange in the fill and

49
00:02:46.930 --> 00:02:50.020
you can see right over here all
of those wonderful numbers.

50
00:02:50.020 --> 00:02:53.610
That we were talking about in the other
episode, which is really, really fun.

51
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:54.110
>> Nice.

52
00:02:54.110 --> 00:02:57.340
>> So you can see I've got my RGB value.

53
00:02:57.340 --> 00:02:58.900
I have my CMYK value.

54
00:02:58.900 --> 00:03:01.350
I have my HEX value.

55
00:03:01.350 --> 00:03:03.950
>> Can you zoom in to that
part just a little bit?

56
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:04.790
>> Sure, there we go.

57
00:03:04.790 --> 00:03:05.550
>> There it is.

58
00:03:05.550 --> 00:03:06.730
It is.
>> Probably a little easier to

59
00:03:06.730 --> 00:03:07.432
see for y'all on that.

60
00:03:07.432 --> 00:03:08.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you can see right here,

61
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:10.250
that's the RGB value.

62
00:03:10.250 --> 00:03:12.900
We have over here, the CMYK value,
and the percentages,

63
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:16.450
because that's how CMYK
values are represented.

64
00:03:16.450 --> 00:03:20.050
We have our hex number there with
that little hashtag or pound sign,

65
00:03:20.050 --> 00:03:23.440
whichever way you wanna call it there,
to represent that hex number.

66
00:03:23.440 --> 00:03:28.400
And then up at the top we have our, HSBR
our hue saturation brightness values for

67
00:03:28.400 --> 00:03:31.580
this particular color so
let me go ahead and do this.

68
00:03:31.580 --> 00:03:35.940
You have over here ,you have our
Hughes Spectrum to where you can go up and

69
00:03:35.940 --> 00:03:38.900
down and
then you have this big square over here.

70
00:03:38.900 --> 00:03:42.740
And then these two guys I’ll show you in
just a second so I can take it cuz maybe

71
00:03:42.740 --> 00:03:47.520
I'm looking for I don't want orange I
wanna make something of a pink color or

72
00:03:47.520 --> 00:03:50.550
purple color because I wanna use
that somewhere in my document.

73
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:53.010
So I can take this hue slider and
I can slide this up,

74
00:03:53.010 --> 00:03:57.090
and you can see as I slide up through
here, it's going to change over on that

75
00:03:57.090 --> 00:04:02.970
big square on the left to that different
hue of where I'm at right now.

76
00:04:02.970 --> 00:04:04.465
If that makes any sense.

77
00:04:04.465 --> 00:04:09.540
[LAUGH] So the thing to notice here in
the big square is where is the circle.

78
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:13.960
OK, you can see right here I'm moving
it and it's changing the big square but

79
00:04:13.960 --> 00:04:16.290
wherever that little
circle is right there,

80
00:04:16.290 --> 00:04:19.850
that's what color you're going to
end up with when you say okay.

81
00:04:19.850 --> 00:04:22.760
And that's where these
two squares right here.

82
00:04:22.760 --> 00:04:23.440
Are showing you.

83
00:04:23.440 --> 00:04:27.110
The one on top is where you are right now,

84
00:04:27.110 --> 00:04:31.020
based on that circle, and the bottom
one was this color you started with.

85
00:04:31.020 --> 00:04:33.970
So, if I was trying to find
a different shade of blue,

86
00:04:33.970 --> 00:04:37.250
or, maybe, a different shade of orange,
let me come back down here.

87
00:04:37.250 --> 00:04:37.830
So, I could see that,

88
00:04:37.830 --> 00:04:41.560
maybe, that orange is a little bit
darker than the one I started with, so

89
00:04:41.560 --> 00:04:45.370
it's kind of like a compare and contrast,
and saying, whatever's right here,

90
00:04:45.370 --> 00:04:52.230
that's gonna be the color that is now
in that fill area, when you say okay.

91
00:04:52.230 --> 00:04:54.790
So, that's why you have the top and
bottom.

92
00:04:54.790 --> 00:04:57.210
And, if I'm in this,
let's go back up to the pink,

93
00:04:57.210 --> 00:04:59.260
cuz that's where I was going with first.

94
00:04:59.260 --> 00:05:01.180
That's kind of more Purple y.

95
00:05:01.180 --> 00:05:02.700
I don't really want it to be that bright,

96
00:05:02.700 --> 00:05:05.120
maybe I want it to be a little
bit more of a pastel.

97
00:05:05.120 --> 00:05:07.410
Well, then, that's where I have to
come over in this big square and

98
00:05:07.410 --> 00:05:14.095
actually click into the area that is, kind
of, showing me the actual color I want.

99
00:05:14.095 --> 00:05:16.220
>> Mm hm.
>> Okay, so it's actually two pieces,

100
00:05:16.220 --> 00:05:19.480
moving the hue slider and
then picking the color in the big box.

101
00:05:20.550 --> 00:05:25.280
And so, I get a lot of people, that
they'll come up to the very top corner.

102
00:05:25.280 --> 00:05:27.420
See that's white and
then of course that's black.

103
00:05:27.420 --> 00:05:30.560
You can slide this hue slider up and
down all day long and

104
00:05:30.560 --> 00:05:34.330
nothing's going to happen because
it'll all the way to black, okay.

105
00:05:34.330 --> 00:05:37.420
So that's where you got to
make sure you got the circle.

106
00:05:37.420 --> 00:05:39.270
Always watch whats in that box.

107
00:05:39.270 --> 00:05:43.190
Alright lets go over a few other
things that's going on in.

108
00:05:43.190 --> 00:05:46.870
This dialog box are these
two little icons.

109
00:05:46.870 --> 00:05:49.770
Now notice they're not
gonna show up all the time.

110
00:05:49.770 --> 00:05:54.450
If I come over here that little
warning sign goes away and

111
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:56.320
there it comes back again,
then it goes away.

112
00:05:56.320 --> 00:05:57.990
You'll probably always
get this bottom one.

113
00:05:57.990 --> 00:05:59.180
Okay, so, what does this mean?

114
00:05:59.180 --> 00:06:01.540
What do we got going on here?

115
00:06:01.540 --> 00:06:04.820
Well, this is where understanding
the difference between RGB and CMYK,

116
00:06:04.820 --> 00:06:09.730
and that whole color gamut that we have,
that we have certain colors in a CMYK that

117
00:06:09.730 --> 00:06:13.530
will not be able to be reproduced,
that's this warning.

118
00:06:13.530 --> 00:06:16.290
And if I hover over this little warning,
it's actually telling me,

119
00:06:16.290 --> 00:06:18.940
I don't know if I can zoom in on this
cuz if I move my mouse, it'll show.

120
00:06:18.940 --> 00:06:21.460
It says out of the gamut warning.

121
00:06:21.460 --> 00:06:22.700
And it says CMYK.

122
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:24.180
Here, let me move back over there.

123
00:06:24.180 --> 00:06:25.830
So, it says click to correct.

124
00:06:25.830 --> 00:06:27.930
If I actually click on this,

125
00:06:27.930 --> 00:06:33.390
you see how it moved the circle to
the closest value that it could find.

126
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:37.680
That would be able to be
in that CMYK color gamut.

127
00:06:37.680 --> 00:06:40.130
So it's actually very
handy where if I'm like,

128
00:06:40.130 --> 00:06:43.480
I really love this color, it's gonna say,
wait, wait, wait, you're gonna have

129
00:06:43.480 --> 00:06:47.950
issues if you send this to a printer,
it's not gonna look the same.

130
00:06:47.950 --> 00:06:51.310
It doesn't say that you
can't have that value, but

131
00:06:51.310 --> 00:06:54.480
when you get to the part
where you send the file,

132
00:06:54.480 --> 00:06:57.430
the printer's going to call you
hopefully if they're a good printer,

133
00:06:57.430 --> 00:07:00.660
they're doing the right print, pre
press for you or pre flighting for you.

134
00:07:00.660 --> 00:07:01.600
And pre press.

135
00:07:01.600 --> 00:07:05.040
They'll say, well,
your colors might actually shift.

136
00:07:05.040 --> 00:07:06.750
Okay?
So I don't want you think it's completely

137
00:07:06.750 --> 00:07:07.890
not allowed.

138
00:07:07.890 --> 00:07:11.930
You're just going to have color shifting
when it's in the final product.

139
00:07:11.930 --> 00:07:14.770
>> So if you were designing
something that was for screen and

140
00:07:14.770 --> 00:07:16.990
you had no intention of ever printing it.

141
00:07:16.990 --> 00:07:17.650
It'd be fine.

142
00:07:17.650 --> 00:07:19.400
>> Doesn't matter, yeah, exactly.

143
00:07:19.400 --> 00:07:22.940
And that also kinda comes back to when
you start the new file, which we'll get

144
00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:26.890
into and I'll show you some demonstrations
so you can really see the differences.

145
00:07:26.890 --> 00:07:32.310
If I'm going to be working in
an RGB File new, from the start,

146
00:07:32.310 --> 00:07:34.470
is all the values are going to be in RGB.

147
00:07:34.470 --> 00:07:39.220
If I start in a CMYK file, then all my
values are gonna be in the CMYK, but

148
00:07:39.220 --> 00:07:42.400
the color picker doesn't matter,
whether you're in a RGB or

149
00:07:42.400 --> 00:07:45.240
a CMYK files, it's just saying,
here's all your colors.

150
00:07:45.240 --> 00:07:50.170
It's giving you all the options so knowing
the numbers and where you're going.

151
00:07:50.170 --> 00:07:51.760
I would say I design backwards.

152
00:07:51.760 --> 00:07:53.960
You have to know where you're
going before you start.

153
00:07:53.960 --> 00:07:57.671
So if you know you're designing for
print then you work within those confines.

154
00:07:57.671 --> 00:07:59.574
And screen is a lot easier,
like we were talking about,

155
00:07:59.574 --> 00:08:00.802
it's just whatever it looks like.

156
00:08:00.802 --> 00:08:03.762
Okay, so
one last thing that I want to further,

157
00:08:03.762 --> 00:08:07.025
there was one other warning
dialog thing over here.

158
00:08:07.025 --> 00:08:08.802
And that was this little guy.

159
00:08:08.802 --> 00:08:13.376
And this tells you that you are out
of the gamut for web safe colors.

160
00:08:13.376 --> 00:08:15.600
Now back from our other lesson.

161
00:08:15.600 --> 00:08:17.140
There's only 256 web safe colors.

162
00:08:17.140 --> 00:08:19.360
There's not a lot of
