00:20:40.270 --> 00:20:41.340
Are we gonna do the eyedropper?

388
00:20:41.340 --> 00:20:42.250
I was like, yes we are.

389
00:20:42.250 --> 00:20:44.295
It's like, I'm so excited I love
the eyedropper, I'm like, great.

390
00:20:44.295 --> 00:20:47.945
>> Well before this episode that was
the one way I knew how to pick a color.

391
00:20:47.945 --> 00:20:49.190
[LAUGH]
>> Well hopefully I've shown you

392
00:20:49.190 --> 00:20:50.740
a few more since then.

393
00:20:50.740 --> 00:20:55.910
But yes, the eye dropper it sounds
exactly like what it does, it's going to

394
00:20:55.910 --> 00:21:01.030
actually drop over somewhere and actually
pick up whatever color you're over.

395
00:21:01.030 --> 00:21:05.800
So let's go over and find this, this is
a tool, so if not a panel like we've been

396
00:21:05.800 --> 00:21:08.990
going over before but it does
correspond to our panels like whatever

397
00:21:08.990 --> 00:21:12.890
is in the color picker and whatever is
going to be over here in a color panel.

398
00:21:12.890 --> 00:21:15.460
So I have my eye dropper
which is hotkey of i,

399
00:21:15.460 --> 00:21:20.070
and if I wanted to see what
exactly is this color?

400
00:21:20.070 --> 00:21:23.640
I can click on it, and
then that becomes the color

401
00:21:23.640 --> 00:21:27.310
that is in the field that's over here,
and that's in the color panel there.

402
00:21:27.310 --> 00:21:29.450
I can click here, and

403
00:21:29.450 --> 00:21:32.900
there, and it's just going to go
ahead and, that's the color I want.

404
00:21:32.900 --> 00:21:36.130
Now, that's fine for
colors right here that I've been

405
00:21:36.130 --> 00:21:40.160
actually creating in Illustrator,
these are vector objects that I made.

406
00:21:40.160 --> 00:21:45.240
But it can be used, I have down here,
remember I have an image that's here.

407
00:21:45.240 --> 00:21:50.670
And it can actually sample colors in the
image that you've placed within your file.

408
00:21:50.670 --> 00:21:53.140
So, more on images in other episodes.

409
00:21:53.140 --> 00:21:56.160
So, if I wanted to see, what is
that color, see it's picking there.

410
00:21:56.160 --> 00:21:58.520
Or if I can go right here
it's going to pick up,

411
00:21:58.520 --> 00:22:03.070
now remember watch over here on my
screen to where you can, see I've got

412
00:22:03.070 --> 00:22:07.745
that yellowish green and the pinks,
well that's not pink that's blue.

413
00:22:07.745 --> 00:22:09.200
[LAUGH] And it'll just go ahead and

414
00:22:09.200 --> 00:22:14.870
sample any of those colors that I'm
clicking on and then I could take this and

415
00:22:14.870 --> 00:22:19.480
then use it to apply my fill or
draw squares and things like that.

416
00:22:19.480 --> 00:22:23.640
So there's another way you could
use this is let's go over here.

417
00:22:23.640 --> 00:22:27.920
Let's say I wanted, I'm gonna go back
to my black arrow tool to select.

418
00:22:27.920 --> 00:22:33.940
I want to select these four squares so I'm
Shift+clicking to select these four items,

419
00:22:33.940 --> 00:22:38.830
and I actually want them to
be the color of this green.

420
00:22:38.830 --> 00:22:42.780
I want to sample that color and
apply it there.

421
00:22:42.780 --> 00:22:44.210
So, that's something you could do first,

422
00:22:44.210 --> 00:22:46.900
is select the items that you
want to become that color.

423
00:22:46.900 --> 00:22:50.460
You come over to your eyedropper tool,
you then click on the thing that you want

424
00:22:50.460 --> 00:22:55.220
the color to be, and then it applies
all of those things to be that color.

425
00:22:55.220 --> 00:22:57.140
So that's probably the way you
were doing it, a little bit?

426
00:22:57.140 --> 00:22:57.850
>> Yes, absolutely.

427
00:22:57.850 --> 00:23:02.202
The little bit of work that I've done in
here has been working with somebody else's

428
00:23:02.202 --> 00:23:03.134
stuff or files and

429
00:23:03.134 --> 00:23:06.941
I needed to duplicate an exact color and
that was the easiest way to do it.

430
00:23:06.941 --> 00:23:10.233
>> And that actually is the easiest way
to do it, so you were doing it right.

431
00:23:10.233 --> 00:23:11.214
>> Good [LAUGH].

432
00:23:11.214 --> 00:23:15.240
>> But where we can find it in other
places of course is always good to know.

433
00:23:15.240 --> 00:23:18.040
So, that is the eyedropper.

434
00:23:18.040 --> 00:23:20.770
And now what we're going to go into next,
in the next episode,

435
00:23:20.770 --> 00:23:22.610
is we're going to go into swatches.

436
00:23:22.610 --> 00:23:26.590
Because we can do all this color picking
through all these different places,

437
00:23:26.590 --> 00:23:30.550
but if I wanted to come back say,
tomorrow, and

438
00:23:30.550 --> 00:23:35.140
use that same color that I
had found in this modality or

439
00:23:35.140 --> 00:23:40.380
whatever, and now I wanna use it again,
that's where we get into our swatches.

440
00:23:40.380 --> 00:23:44.410
So, that's going to be coming up next,
and that's it.

441
00:23:44.410 --> 00:23:45.140
>> All right, Vonne.

442
00:23:45.140 --> 00:23:47.200
Well very good, great information there.

443
00:23:47.200 --> 00:23:50.110
Really taking what we learned in the
previous episode about colors and color

444
00:23:50.110 --> 00:23:54.480
theory and seeing how we can apply that in
many different ways within Illustrator.

445
00:23:54.480 --> 00:23:57.980
All the different ways that we can go
about choosing the color we want to use

446
00:23:57.980 --> 00:23:59.010
in our particular files.

447
00:23:59.010 --> 00:24:01.940
So we thank you for that, Vonne, we hope
everybody out there enjoyed watching.

448
00:24:01.940 --> 00:24:04.552
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

449
00:24:04.552 --> 00:24:05.438
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

450
00:24:05.438 --> 00:24:12.100
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Swatches
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.009 --> 00:00:10.009
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.026 --> 00:00:14.570
Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode of

3
00:00:14.570 --> 00:00:15.509
here at IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:15.509 --> 00:00:20.881
I'm your host MIke Rodrick and today we're
doing our Adobe illustrator CC 2015,

5
00:00:20.881 --> 00:00:25.900
and specifically in this episode we're
gonna be looking at color swatches.

6
00:00:25.900 --> 00:00:28.840
Now I've been told these are not
the swatches that we wore on our wrists

7
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:31.890
back in the day,
it's something completely different.

8
00:00:31.890 --> 00:00:34.868
So here to help us figure out what
the heck they are is Miss Von Smith,

9
00:00:34.868 --> 00:00:35.824
how you doing, Von?

10
00:00:35.824 --> 00:00:39.120
Great, [LAUGH] wonderful
old school reference there.

11
00:00:39.120 --> 00:00:41.780
>> Date myself a little bit but
I hear they're making a come back.

12
00:00:41.780 --> 00:00:44.160
>> Yea and I totally knew
what you were talking about,

13
00:00:44.160 --> 00:00:46.350
because I had quite a few when

00:00:46.350 --> 00:00:47.700
So.
>> But not what we're hear to

18
00:00:53.030 --> 00:00:54.510

19

They're ways that you can make colors and

20
00:00:57.380 --> 00:01:00.690

21
00:01:00.690 --> 00:01:04.222
We're going to be talking

22
00:01:04.222 --> 00:01:08.760
I'm gonna first, actually, show you the
end result, go through the swatches panel,

23
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:11.240
show you some files that
already have some swatches.

24
00:01:11.240 --> 00:01:14.810
Then we'll go back and actually show

25
00:01:14.810 --> 00:01:16.503
Talk about libraries,
talk about It's about lots of fun stuff.

26
00:01:16.503 --> 00:01:17.610
>> Awesome.
>> Yes.

27
00:01:17.610 --> 00:01:20.663
>> Yeah, cuz you know you can,
after watching our other episodes you can

00:01:20.663 --> 00:01:23.713
do a lot of things with colors,
come up with a lot of custom colors, and

although fun, could be tedious if you had
the same project to work on for the same

customer over and over again, it'd be nice
not to have to make those every time.

31
00:01:30.741 --> 00:01:31.400
>> Yes.

00:01:31.400 --> 00:01:33.250
Just as you were saying I know

the eye dropper tool where like hey I used

00:01:36.750 --> 00:01:40.310
else but this is where, if you

00:01:40.310 --> 00:01:43.431
maybe it's a lot easier, really,

00:01:43.431 --> 00:01:44.721
>> [INAUDIBLE] With the eyedropper,

I had to open up an old file that
had that color in it to go find it.

38
00:01:47.171 --> 00:01:48.460
Yeah, pain in and the but.

39
00:01:48.460 --> 00:01:50.040

we're gonna make some swatches.

And actually sharing

It's a trick.

>> Well.
>> It's something that's

probably not right there in front of you

00:02:00.410 --> 00:02:01.830
>> I looking forward to it.

I actually have the file

With our color theory lessons, and

So I wanted to show you the swatches

00:02:18.790 --> 00:02:19.480
things like that.

00:02:19.480 --> 00:02:20.390
So here we go.

52
00:02:20.390 --> 00:02:22.220
We have our swatches.

53
00:02:22.220 --> 00:02:26.180
We have four different types

54
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:28.050
You can have a solid swatch.

55
00:02:28.050 --> 00:02:30.830
And you can see one's like this guy.

00:02:30.830 --> 00:02:32.780
That's a solid color.

As opposed to one right here,

And how we can make gradients and

00:02:40.990 --> 00:02:41.910
So, we'll get into that.

And we have a few other things that

00:02:44.940 --> 00:02:48.260
You have Swatches that have a corner.

00:02:49.440 --> 00:02:50.700
That's not yellow that's white.

A white corner and

00:02:54.750 --> 00:02:57.530
The one that is solid what.

65
00:02:57.530 --> 00:02:59.300
That is known as a global swatch.

66
00:02:59.300 --> 00:03:03.260
We'll talk about what that actually means,
and then we have the one with

67
00:03:03.260 --> 00:03:07.850
the dot in it and that is a spot
swatch cause it's got a spot in it.

68
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:09.510
Okay so we're talking about our.

69
00:03:09.510 --> 00:03:14.280
Process colors or
CMYK versus our Pantone spot colors,

70
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:18.660
that's what indicates to us in our
Swatches panel that that is a Spot Swatch.

71
00:03:18.660 --> 00:03:21.260
That is if used in a document,

72
00:03:21.260 --> 00:03:24.930
it would show to a printer as
a Spot color not a Process color.

73
00:03:26.010 --> 00:03:29.430
Then we have a few guys over
here those are Pattern Swatches.

74
00:03:29.430 --> 00:03:31.230
Patterns, well kind of self explanatory.

75
00:03:31.230 --> 00:03:34.380
It's gonna make a patterned fill,
or a patterned stroke, depending on

76
00:03:34.380 --> 00:03:38.490
which place you apply it to for
that particular item that you're using.

77
00:03:38.490 --> 00:03:42.140
And then, just one other thing that
we'll point out is, down below you have

00:03:42.140 --> 00:03:45.160
things that are indicated with
that looks like a little folder,

79
00:03:45.160 --> 00:03:49.780
those are known as Swatch groups,
and why would you want to do that?

80
00:03:49.780 --> 00:03:51.690
Really just for organizational purposes,

81
00:03:51.690 --> 00:03:54.750
maybe you have all the company
colors in one place?

82
00:03:54.750 --> 00:03:58.800
Or I'm gonna use all of these colors in
just this logo, it's really up to you how

83
00:03:58.800 --> 00:04:03.220

your swatches into groups.

84
00:04:03.220 --> 00:04:04.470
But they can be very handy.

85
00:04:04.470 --> 00:04:08.600
They're almost like sub
sets of the swatches panel.

86
00:04:08.600 --> 00:04:10.010
And just a little note right now.

00:04:10.010 --> 00:04:13.390
So I'm thinking about
it is when you use or

00:04:13.390 --> 00:04:18.410
create swatch groups you can
only use them with Solid colors.

89
00:04:18.410 --> 00:04:24.510
You cannot use patterns and
gradients in a swatch group.

90
00:04:24.510 --> 00:04:26.480
Just throwing that out there.

91
00:04:26.480 --> 00:04:29.940
And just like any panel
you have in Illustrator,

00:04:29.940 --> 00:04:33.140
you have your Panel Options button
up in the top right-hand corner.

00:04:33.140 --> 00:04:34.630
And I just wanna go over a few things.

00:04:34.630 --> 00:04:37.970
We'll be coming back to that a little bit
later when we talk about libraries and

00:04:37.970 --> 00:04:38.830
things like that.

96
00:04:38.830 --> 00:04:44.395
But if these icons, or the swatch in

00:04:44.395 --> 00:04:46.100

[LAUGH]

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

00:04:51.270 --> 00:04:57.900

00:04:57.900 --> 00:04:58.440
There you go.

00:04:58.440 --> 00:04:59.465

00:04:59.465 --> 00:05:03.220
[LAUGH] So you can them a little bit

00:05:03.220 --> 00:05:07.430

you can actually use them in list view.

00:05:07.430 --> 00:05:12.170
So you can see, remember the different

00:05:12.170 --> 00:05:14.710

00:05:14.710 --> 00:05:17.970
So I might go ahead and throw them back

00:05:17.970 --> 00:05:19.460

111
00:05:19.460 --> 00:05:23.550
And maybe make my swatches

We of course have the icons on

00:05:28.200 --> 00:05:31.810
that's just you know the same things that
we had in any panel in illustrator you

00:05:31.810 --> 00:05:33.380
have in the swatches panel.

115
00:05:33.380 --> 00:05:38.090
So, in this particular document you

Notice you don't have the same

That's because swatches are document

So you're talking about, well, if I had

well what if I want to use those

>> Okay.
>> Until I show you how, you can actually

>> Share out your swatches across

00:06:07.610 --> 00:06:08.910
documents.

127
00:06:08.910 --> 00:06:09.920
We’ll get to there as well.

128
00:06:09.920 --> 00:06:13.720
>> Patience is not one of my virtues.

00:06:13.720 --> 00:06:15.340
>> No it’s not but that's okay.

00:06:15.340 --> 00:06:16.360
You go me here so.

OK so I just wanted to point that out so

00:06:21.420 --> 00:06:24.528
where I was at starches starches swatch
>> Starches

00:06:24.528 --> 00:06:27.110
>> [LAUGH] We'll try that again,

00:06:27.110 --> 00:06:28.670
how about swatches start.

00:06:28.670 --> 00:06:33.440
All right, we went over the color

we went over to our color panel, where

00:06:40.070 --> 00:06:43.570
All of these places is where

00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:46.240
then you can
>> Add into your swatches.

00:06:46.240 --> 00:06:51.480
Now this file is an RGB, just to show

00:06:51.480 --> 00:06:54.810
So by default it was going to give

00:06:54.810 --> 00:06:59.820
So let's just come over here and say I

00:06:59.820 --> 00:07:00.640
That sounds good.

right?

Now, I could from the color panel

Okay because of course it's always tied

So either way you wanna do it,

00:07:35.220 --> 00:07:38.470
So I'm gonna, since I'm still here,

And now you can see in

In the color that I was mixing.

Or, if I wanted to change the color
you just double-click it.

392
00:19:32.630 --> 00:19:36.350
It actually brings up the panel to
where you can change your colors.

393
00:19:36.350 --> 00:19:38.446
Maybe I did want it to be
a little bit more green.

394
00:19:38.446 --> 00:19:39.708
Now, these are the sliders, right?

395
00:19:39.708 --> 00:19:42.520
But I had a specific
green that I had mixed.

396
00:19:42.520 --> 00:19:45.177
Well, that's because here over here
on the corner, that's not the corner,

397
00:19:45.177 --> 00:19:45.832
that's the side.

398
00:19:45.832 --> 00:19:51.207
The side is where you could choose that
I want the stops to show by my swatches,

399
00:19:51.207 --> 00:19:57.040
not by my color mixer, so good reason why
we have all our swatches ready to go.

400
00:19:57.040 --> 00:19:59.900
And then I can change that
gradient stop to green and

401
00:19:59.900 --> 00:20:02.880
now you can see I've got
the white to green to blue.

402
00:20:02.880 --> 00:20:05.040
I can move these houses around so

403
00:20:05.040 --> 00:20:08.890
I could do all sorts of different
fun color combinations.

404
00:20:08.890 --> 00:20:13.520
But maybe I don't really like this
blue here anymore, this second house.

405
00:20:13.520 --> 00:20:16.460
If you don't like the house, you just
pull it off the ramp, as I call it.

406
00:20:16.460 --> 00:20:17.980
You grab it, and you drag it.

407
00:20:17.980 --> 00:20:19.200
And then you let go.

408
00:20:19.200 --> 00:20:23.170
If you drag drop,
you can pull stops off the Gradient Ramp.

409
00:20:23.170 --> 00:20:25.110
Same way that if you wanted to add,

410
00:20:25.110 --> 00:20:28.080
you can see that, it's kind of
probably hard to see with my mouse.

411
00:20:28.080 --> 00:20:28.860
Cuz it's not gonna show up.

412
00:20:28.860 --> 00:20:32.150
But it actually has like a little plus
sign next to my mouse of where you just

413
00:20:32.150 --> 00:20:35.300
click it just adds a house
on that Gradient Ramp and

414
00:20:35.300 --> 00:20:38.040
them you can go through and
you can change the colors.

415
00:20:38.040 --> 00:20:40.940
Okay, now we're getting a little crazy
with the color combinations that I

416
00:20:40.940 --> 00:20:45.549
got going on but
that's how you can modify your gradients

417
00:20:47.000 --> 00:20:52.260
on the Gradient Ramp in the Gradient
panel to whatever you want it to be.

418
00:20:52.260 --> 00:20:56.738
And so I've got this beautiful weird
rainbow looking thing right now.

419
00:20:56.738 --> 00:20:58.525
>> [LAUGH]
>> I've mixed my gradient.

420
00:20:58.525 --> 00:21:02.711
You can see that it's the color in my fill
over here it's the color of the fill in

421
00:21:02.711 --> 00:21:04.530
the item I have selected.

422
00:21:04.530 --> 00:21:07.470
If I want that to become a swatch, for

423
00:21:07.470 --> 00:21:11.620
me to be able to use this gradient later,
down the road.

424
00:21:11.620 --> 00:21:13.720
So, same way that we did it before.

425
00:21:13.720 --> 00:21:20.610
You you can go to the Swatches panel and
then you can go to New Swatch right there.

426
00:21:20.610 --> 00:21:22.420
You can see that it's [INAUDIBLE].

427
00:21:22.420 --> 00:21:24.575
It's not doing the sliders
cause it's not a solid color,

428
00:21:24.575 --> 00:21:27.980
it knows that you have a gradient
selected that it's wanting to add.

429
00:21:27.980 --> 00:21:32.222
And we can just name this, Crazy Rainbow.

430
00:21:32.222 --> 00:21:36.430
And you didn't have to name it, but I'm
going to, you click OK, and there it goes.

431
00:21:36.430 --> 00:21:40.770
And there's my gradient
swatch in my Swatches panel.

432
00:21:40.770 --> 00:21:42.510
>> That's pretty neat, and not that hard.

433
00:21:42.510 --> 00:21:43.370
>> No, not hard at all.

434
00:21:43.370 --> 00:21:47.690
Now I was showing you how you could modify

00:21:47.690 --> 00:21:53.350
the gradient in the Gradient panel cuz
that is the one place that you can do it,

436
00:21:53.350 --> 00:21:56.730
or you have the Gradient tool, okay.

437
00:21:56.730 --> 00:21:59.750
The Gradient tool is right here, okay.

438
00:21:59.750 --> 00:22:04.050
And notice that I still have the item that
I wanted to modify selected first, so

439
00:22:04.050 --> 00:22:06.830
always that select to effect,
so I've got that going.

440
00:22:06.830 --> 00:22:10.216
And it's gonna show me
the Gradient Ramp right on the item,

441
00:22:10.216 --> 00:22:14.018
which is to me super cool,
you can actually see where it's going.

442
00:22:14.018 --> 00:22:14.970
>> That is cool.

443
00:22:14.970 --> 00:22:17.715
>> Yeah, and now what you can
do with the Gradient tool,

444
00:22:17.715 --> 00:22:20.140
is you can still modify it the same way.

445
00:22:20.140 --> 00:22:24.600
You could, instead of changing the angle,
you can just draw it.

446
00:22:24.600 --> 00:22:26.539
And you can draw the length of how and

447
00:22:26.539 --> 00:22:29.650
where you want the gradient
to apply within that object.

448
00:22:29.650 --> 00:22:32.952
So I just, doesn't matter where,
I'm just gonna click hold and drag.

449
00:22:32.952 --> 00:22:34.800
I'm gonna drag across,
and I'm going to let go.

450
00:22:34.800 --> 00:22:37.227
And you see how wherever I
actually drew that line,

00:22:37.227 --> 00:22:39.140
the gradient is going to follow.

452
00:22:39.140 --> 00:22:42.290
I can make even wider than
the item that it has.

453
00:22:42.290 --> 00:22:43.630
It's only showing part of the gradient.

454
00:22:43.630 --> 00:22:45.250
I can make it super small.

455
00:22:45.250 --> 00:22:47.330
Like that, and I can just keep on,
just click, hold, and

456
00:22:47.330 --> 00:22:51.200
drag, and I can drag this gradient
to wherever I want to be.

457
00:22:51.200 --> 00:22:55.095
You can then afterwards, you can click the
one end and you can shorten it this way,

458
00:22:55.095 --> 00:22:58.426
you could also take the other end and
you can kind of move it up and down,

459
00:22:58.426 --> 00:23:01.720
which doesn't really matter
since it's a linear gradient.

460
00:23:01.720 --> 00:23:05.920
But really just click, hold, and drag and
you can reapply that gradient and

461
00:23:05.920 --> 00:23:07.060
however you want.

462
00:23:07.060 --> 00:23:09.950
You can double-click on the houses,
just like we did before.

463
00:23:09.950 --> 00:23:14.220
You can add the houses, you can pull
the houses off, all the same stuff.

464
00:23:14.220 --> 00:23:15.860
That's not very pretty.

465
00:23:15.860 --> 00:23:18.130
Blue to orange in a gradient
doesn't look so good.

466
00:23:18.130 --> 00:23:19.170
Let's throw that white in the middle.

467
00:23:19.170 --> 00:23:21.036
There we go,
that's a little bit better, okay.

468
00:23:21.036 --> 00:23:22.900
And now I've got a new gradient.

469
00:23:22.900 --> 00:23:27.400
Right, I took that green stop
off the Gradient Ramp so

470
00:23:27.400 --> 00:23:29.210
I can come back over here and
add a new swatch.

471
00:23:29.210 --> 00:23:34.135
And see, I have a new variation of my
swatch from the Gradient tool rather

472
00:23:34.135 --> 00:23:35.929
than the Gradient panel.

473
00:23:35.929 --> 00:23:36.518
>> Wow.

474
00:23:36.518 --> 00:23:37.600
>> So, super fun.

475
00:23:37.600 --> 00:23:39.620
>> Just two different ways
you can do the same thing.

476
00:23:39.620 --> 00:23:40.550
It really just depends
on which way you go.

477
00:23:40.550 --> 00:23:46.301
But it is good to know because on a lot of
your test questions on either the ACE or

00:23:46.301 --> 00:23:49.750
the ACA, it will ask you for
certain things and

479
00:23:49.750 --> 00:23:53.484
you do need to know where
it is in Multiple places.

480
00:23:53.484 --> 00:23:57.080
So it's just always good
to know all the angles.

481
00:23:57.080 --> 00:24:01.360
>> Very good,
you really do like gradients don't you?

482
00:24:01.360 --> 00:24:02.910
>> I do.
I love them.

483
00:24:02.910 --> 00:24:04.160
I love colors.

484
00:24:04.160 --> 00:24:07.680
And anything that blends together,
and kind of looks like rainbows.

485
00:24:07.680 --> 00:24:08.180
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

486
00:24:08.180 --> 00:24:09.830
>> Any variation on rainbows is awesome.

487
00:24:11.270 --> 00:24:14.170
>> All right, so
what do you have for us next?

488
00:24:14.170 --> 00:24:16.416
>> Well we went over,
what's the one thing we didn't go over?

We went over-
>> Spot swatches, I don't think we hit or

00:24:21.660 --> 00:24:23.370

00:24:23.370 --> 00:24:26.180
>> I like it.
>> Because the spots are in a special

[LAUGH]
>> All right.

495
00:24:31.028 --> 00:24:34.200
[LAUGH]
>> So patterns, patterns are fun.

00:24:34.200 --> 00:24:36.060
We can start over here.

00:24:36.060 --> 00:24:41.120
I'm gonna go ahead and apply an already
existing pattern swatch, so you can see.

00:24:41.120 --> 00:24:46.380
Got the square selected, and
I'm going to use this Alyssa, there we go.

00:24:46.380 --> 00:24:47.260
That's crazy.

500
00:24:47.260 --> 00:24:49.310
Maybe this other one, that's nice too.

00:24:49.310 --> 00:24:49.820
Nice?

502
00:24:49.820 --> 00:24:50.675
That's nice.

00:24:50.675 --> 00:24:52.150
[LAUGH] Our jive pattern.

504
00:24:52.150 --> 00:24:53.940
So fun, right?

505
00:24:53.940 --> 00:24:55.920
I can go ahead and apply it.

00:24:55.920 --> 00:24:58.280
You're like well,
what about making my own, or

No, you have more already configured or

Which I know I've said quite a few times,

But I want to show you how you

00:25:16.260 --> 00:25:19.350
So just like we had with any other swatch,

you could get into other swatch options

00:25:23.860 --> 00:25:25.120
You can do the same thing

it does take you somewhere

00:25:28.240 --> 00:25:29.670
It takes you to the pattern editor.

00:25:29.670 --> 00:25:31.850
So I'm gonna double click
on this jive pattern and

00:25:31.850 --> 00:25:34.900
notice I am in a totally

00:25:34.900 --> 00:25:36.750
Where did my document go?

00:25:36.750 --> 00:25:38.410
Always, whoops sorry.

00:25:38.410 --> 00:25:39.870
Let me get back in there.

00:25:39.870 --> 00:25:43.800
I did undo instead of my zoom,

524
00:25:43.800 --> 00:25:48.740
So you can see that up Here,
I'm actually in the pattern, right?

00:25:48.740 --> 00:25:52.120
Remember, going into isolation mode

00:25:52.120 --> 00:25:54.190
That's where I'm at right now.

00:25:54.190 --> 00:25:58.340
So I'm in the jive and

00:25:58.340 --> 00:26:00.330
So let's just start with the panel first.

00:26:00.330 --> 00:26:01.620
Notice that it's in this grid.

You can change how the pattern repeats.

00:26:04.500 --> 00:26:08.360
So I could make it go by a hex, and

00:26:08.360 --> 00:26:12.040
And by brick you can

00:26:12.040 --> 00:26:14.970
Really, instead of explaining everything

00:26:14.970 --> 00:26:16.260

00:26:16.260 --> 00:26:20.480
This is one where like, click around and

00:26:20.480 --> 00:26:25.770
And it really is best demonstrated

00:26:25.770 --> 00:26:32.170
then, how wide or high the panel, or sorry
the pattern goes and how it can overlap.

538
00:26:32.170 --> 00:26:33.810
Really, just start messing around.

00:26:33.810 --> 00:26:36.710
When we get into our own pattern,
I think I have in a much

00:26:37.790 --> 00:26:41.730
Simpler pattern and I think you can

But at least I wanted to show you where

00:26:46.320 --> 00:26:51.320
I can either say, done, yes I want to

00:26:51.320 --> 00:26:57.700
Or if I wanted to then make a new

00:26:57.700 --> 00:27:00.370
you just go ahead and save a copy and

00:27:00.370 --> 00:27:02.470
>> Very neat.
>> For now I'm just going to go ahead and

cancel on this one just so
you can see where we're gonna go here.

547
00:27:06.760 --> 00:27:10.550
Now I made these three stars
in this particular size for

548
00:27:10.550 --> 00:27:14.180
a reason because I'm getting
ready to make our own patterns.

549
00:27:14.180 --> 00:27:16.150
Okay.
>> All right Von I'm dying to know

550
00:27:16.150 --> 00:27:17.630
what you're gonna do with those stars, but

551
00:27:17.630 --> 00:27:20.220
unfortunately I'm going to
have to stop you there.

552
00:27:20.220 --> 00:27:23.320
We're running out of time for
this particular episode.

553
00:27:23.320 --> 00:27:23.835
>> Okay.

554
00:27:23.835 --> 00:27:27.680
>> [LAUGH] So if you guys want to see
what happens when those stars and

00:27:27.680 --> 00:27:30.380
figure out what else we can do these
color swatches, make sure you tune in for

00:27:30.380 --> 00:27:31.510

557
00:27:31.510 --> 00:27:33.560
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

558
00:27:33.560 --> 00:27:41.280
And I'm Von Smith and
we'll see you next time.

WEBVTT

And specifically, in this episode,
we're actually gonna be continuing

00:00:28.770 --> 00:00:31.903

And there's really a lot to cover,

We've still got the spots,

13
00:00:47.030 --> 00:00:51.030
So, yes, we were right at

14
00:00:51.030 --> 00:00:55.980

15
00:00:55.980 --> 00:00:58.120
>> All right.

00:00:58.120 --> 00:01:00.130

18
00:01:02.755 --> 00:01:04.206
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

All right.
So, as I was saying,

I made these stars in this dimension,

because whatever you create, or

00:01:18.605 --> 00:01:24.400
the size it is when you make it into that,
that's going to be the repeating pattern.

24
00:01:24.400 --> 00:01:25.360

25

>> So, if I'm going to apply it
to something as small as this,

26
00:01:29.540 --> 00:01:31.420
I don't want really big stars.

00:01:32.858 --> 00:01:36.070
>> Of a repeating pattern if one
star took up the entire fill.

00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:37.170
>> Correct, yes.

00:01:37.170 --> 00:01:39.921
I mean now if I was on a really
large-scale, designing for

00:01:39.921 --> 00:01:43.290

00:01:43.290 --> 00:01:45.700

we're gonna just kind of keep it small.

But just really kind of emphasizing

00:01:49.243 --> 00:01:50.810

00:01:50.810 --> 00:01:52.380
All right, so how do I do this?

00:01:52.380 --> 00:01:54.850
I've got these three items created.

I've just selected them.

00:01:56.240 --> 00:02:02.120
I'm going to then just take them and

00:02:02.120 --> 00:02:06.380
And when I let go, you can see there's

00:02:06.380 --> 00:02:09.430

40
00:02:09.430 --> 00:02:11.810

00:02:11.810 --> 00:02:13.320
Too many steps involved.

42

>> Really?
>> [LAUGH] I'm kidding,

00:02:14.670 --> 00:02:18.210
that was amazingly easy to
create a new pattern swatch.

00:02:18.210 --> 00:02:19.910
>> I was like, did I stutter?

00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:20.750
What did I do here?

46
00:02:20.750 --> 00:02:23.420
Did I miss something?
It was just drag and drop.

47
00:02:23.420 --> 00:02:24.720
You're trying to be funny.

48
00:02:24.720 --> 00:02:25.470
>> I was.
>> Okay.

49

Anyways, you're interrupting me again,

00:02:29.713 --> 00:02:30.995
[LAUGH]

51
00:02:30.995 --> 00:02:32.460
[LAUGH]
>> Kidding, not kidding.

52

Okay.
[LAUGH] So, I'm back to here.

00:02:36.201 --> 00:02:40.176
And I've got my swatch, and

54
00:02:40.176 --> 00:02:44.170
I can just go ahead and click here,
and apply it, and there's my pattern.

55
00:02:44.170 --> 00:02:44.990
It's awesome.

56
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:45.700
>> Nice.

57
00:02:45.700 --> 00:02:47.550
>> But
if I wanted it to repeat differently, and

00:02:47.550 --> 00:02:50.630
I'm gonna make this a little bit

00:02:50.630 --> 00:02:52.300
Actually I'm gonna show
you a few things here.

60
00:02:52.300 --> 00:02:56.160
I can see that, all right,
I see how it's repeating and that's it.

00:02:56.160 --> 00:03:00.120
There are a few things to notice, that

00:26:22.550 --> 00:26:23.810
>> You've been listening.

520
00:26:23.810 --> 00:26:24.565
Good job.

521
00:26:24.565 --> 00:26:27.130
[LAUGH] Yes, I love this option.

522
00:26:27.130 --> 00:26:28.950
I use it a lot.

523
00:26:28.950 --> 00:26:31.990
And this is my other favorite one,
is this gradient, right?

524
00:26:31.990 --> 00:26:35.770
Love these colors and these gradients, and
I could use the gradient in other places,

525
00:26:35.770 --> 00:26:37.080
but I want the colors out of them.

526
00:26:37.080 --> 00:26:37.890
I want the solid color,

527
00:26:37.890 --> 00:26:41.730
maybe I want to add text in that
same exact purple on that stop.

528
00:26:41.730 --> 00:26:43.810
Same idea, you select the gradient,

529
00:26:43.810 --> 00:26:49.150
you click on the new color group,
and it is from the selected artwork.

530
00:26:49.150 --> 00:26:52.390
I could be naming these along the way,
but I am not, and I'm going to click ok,

531
00:26:52.390 --> 00:26:57.570
and notice that these are the actual
color stops in the gradient.

532
00:26:57.570 --> 00:27:01.480
So it basically disassembled that gradient
and gave you each one of the solid colors.

533
00:27:01.480 --> 00:27:03.765
>> Yes, every single one of those houses.

534
00:27:03.765 --> 00:27:05.220
>> Uh-huh.
>> Remember on the gradient ramp, or

535
00:27:05.220 --> 00:27:06.380
the color stops.

536
00:27:06.380 --> 00:27:09.160
That's actually showing me,
and it creates me a group.

537
00:27:09.160 --> 00:27:12.425
I can make them global and then I can go
on my merry way and go crazy with them.

538
00:27:12.425 --> 00:27:15.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> I love this option.

539
00:27:15.100 --> 00:27:16.180
Fantastic, Von.

540
00:27:16.180 --> 00:27:18.100
Great look at colors and

541
00:27:18.100 --> 00:27:22.090
color swatches and how we could take
advantage of those pre-built libraries.

542
00:27:22.090 --> 00:27:25.550
We can create our own libraries,
we can add colors,

543
00:27:25.550 --> 00:27:29.690
solid spot, pattern,
gradient swatches, right.

544
00:27:29.690 --> 00:27:31.510
We can create groups out of some of them.

545
00:27:31.510 --> 00:27:35.350
Remember not gradients and
not patterns if I remember that correctly.

546
00:27:35.350 --> 00:27:37.620
But lots of really cool information Von.

547
00:27:37.620 --> 00:27:39.440
We appreciate that, really enjoyed it.

548
00:27:39.440 --> 00:27:41.550
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

549
00:27:41.550 --> 00:27:44.600
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

550
00:27:44.600 --> 00:27:45.720
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

551
00:27:45.720 --> 00:27:46.722
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

00:00:12.643 --> 00:00:14.890
Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode

00:00:14.890 --> 00:00:15.541

I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at typography and fonts.

6
00:00:27.090 --> 00:00:31.090
And here to help us make our way through
the myriad of fonts we had to choose from

00:00:31.090 --> 00:00:32.970
is Vonne Smith, how you doing Vonne?

>> Great, decided to talk about text and
typography.

9
00:00:36.550 --> 00:00:39.640
I'm almost as excited to
talk about typography

00:00:39.640 --> 00:00:42.130
as I am to talk about colors and
everything else.

11
00:00:42.130 --> 00:00:44.630
I could talk for days on it but
don't worry, I won't talk for

12
00:00:44.630 --> 00:00:46.390
days about typography.

13
00:00:46.390 --> 00:00:51.340
But I did want to take this episode to
explore the myriad of fonts as you said.

14
00:00:51.340 --> 00:00:53.150
You did that on purpose, didn't you?

15
00:00:53.150 --> 00:00:54.300
Myriad of fonts?

16
00:00:54.300 --> 00:00:55.060
>> There's a lot of them, I know.

17
00:00:55.060 --> 00:00:57.601
>> Well, cuz, Myriad is a font.

18
00:00:57.601 --> 00:00:58.295
>> Is it?
>> Yes!

19
00:00:58.295 --> 00:00:59.293
[LAUGH]
>> I knew that, yes, yes.

20
00:00:59.293 --> 00:01:00.095
I meant to do that.

21
00:01:00.095 --> 00:01:01.556
[LAUGH]
>> Good job.

22
00:01:01.556 --> 00:01:03.760
Well anyways,
I'm here to tell you about that.

23
00:01:03.760 --> 00:01:07.720
Yes, Myriad is a font, and
you actually have that as a type face.

24
00:01:07.720 --> 00:01:11.590
So this is really more the like the,
the theory behind text.

25
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:14.930
And just some basics of what
you need to know about.

26
00:01:14.930 --> 00:01:18.460
Now this is a topic that
whole books are written on.

27
00:01:18.460 --> 00:01:24.070
I mean the whole subjects maybe like
a whole semester worth of information.

28
00:01:24.070 --> 00:01:25.120
Well maybe not a semester.

29
00:01:25.120 --> 00:01:30.040
But there's a lot of information about
the topography and the theory of fonts.

30
00:01:30.040 --> 00:01:32.630
Cuz you can,
I'm sure you see it all over the place.

31
00:01:32.630 --> 00:01:34.950
And I'm one of those I look at stuff,

32
00:01:34.950 --> 00:01:38.700
I look at different things that come
in the mail or I look at magazines.

33
00:01:38.700 --> 00:01:40.030
I think you've actually been there like,

34
00:01:40.030 --> 00:01:41.500
do you see this font
that they're using it?

35
00:01:41.500 --> 00:01:45.380
And you don't see it, I see it but
that's because I do this.

36
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:47.725
>> But you have pointed it out
before on a few occasions.

37
00:01:47.725 --> 00:01:48.550
[LAUGH]
>> I know,

38
00:01:48.550 --> 00:01:50.090
I'm like, why do they use that font?

39
00:01:50.090 --> 00:01:52.110
Because fonts say something.

40
00:01:52.110 --> 00:01:55.850
You know, why did company X use that font.

41
00:01:55.850 --> 00:01:57.420
Because it actually says something.

42
00:01:57.420 --> 00:02:01.450
So I mean, there's that whole world
of picking the right font for

43
00:02:01.450 --> 00:02:04.210
the right purpose and the right message.

44
00:02:04.210 --> 00:02:05.760
Not of what it's saying.

45
00:02:05.760 --> 00:02:07.370
But what does the font say to you.

46
00:02:07.370 --> 00:02:08.210
How do you feel?

47
00:02:08.210 --> 00:02:09.267
Kinda like how the colors, remember?

48
00:02:09.267 --> 00:02:11.430
>> Right. Yes. >> But
I wont give you a quiz.

49
00:02:11.430 --> 00:02:12.249
Like I did last time.

50
00:02:12.249 --> 00:02:13.050
>> [INAUDIBLE] my goodness.

51
00:02:13.050 --> 00:02:15.230
I tell you though you could
really help me out with this.

52
00:02:15.230 --> 00:02:16.100
Because I know for

53
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:20.040
some of you that doesn't understand
about what fonts are saying to me.

54
00:02:20.040 --> 00:02:22.010
I look at a list of fonts like that.

55
00:02:22.010 --> 00:02:24.990
Ilustrator gives you
a lot of fonts built in.

56
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:27.870
I don't know which one I'm picking,
I'm just randomly selecting one.

57
00:02:27.870 --> 00:02:28.470
>> Yes.
And

58
00:02:28.470 --> 00:02:31.940
that way we're going to look
at the text a little bit more.

59
00:02:31.940 --> 00:02:33.520
What does it actually mean?

60
00:02:33.520 --> 00:02:39.467
The open type fonts, two type fonts,
and we're gonna have a myriad of fun.

61
00:02:39.467 --> 00:02:40.291
>> [LAUGH] All right.

62
00:02:40.291 --> 00:02:45.289
>> [LAUGH] All right, so
I have a file that I've created to help

63
00:02:45.289 --> 00:02:48.970
us along through this typography theory.

64
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:50.720
This is typography 101.

65
00:02:50.720 --> 00:02:53.950
We're talking about type faces.

66
00:02:53.950 --> 00:02:55.920
You can actually look this up.

67
00:02:55.920 --> 00:02:59.200
If you do a little search info, type
face versus font and what does it mean?

68
00:02:59.200 --> 00:03:03.190
There's all sorts of different
definitions of trying to explain it.

69
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:09.680
One talks about it as it's a song
within an album that you're looking at.

70
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:12.310
So, when you're talking about type face,

71
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:14.820
it's also you can refer to
it as like a font family.

72
00:03:14.820 --> 00:03:16.360
Okay?
Because for

73
00:03:16.360 --> 00:03:20.010
example, I think it's best to
even just start right here.

74
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:21.500
Like Garamond, okay?

75
00:03:21.500 --> 00:03:28.340
Garamond, you can call that a type face or
a font family.

76
00:03:28.340 --> 00:03:33.880
It's just like the look of what
that font is, if you want to say.

77
00:03:33.880 --> 00:03:38.400
You can have different variations
of the Garamond type face.

78
00:03:38.400 --> 00:03:41.780
Like for example, here you have regular
Garamond, and you have Adobe Garamond Pro.

79
00:03:41.780 --> 00:03:46.340
And if you actually searched online for
Garamond,

80
00:03:46.340 --> 00:03:48.580
there's tons of ones that you can find.

81
00:03:48.580 --> 00:03:52.150
And we can talk about font foundries
where you can find free fonts.

82
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:55.650
Not where you find them, but you know
free fonts versus how you purchase them.

83
00:03:55.650 --> 00:03:59.388
But there's many variations on
the same theme if you want to say.

84
00:03:59.388 --> 00:04:01.940
Not all Garamond's are the same.

85
00:04:01.940 --> 00:04:04.000
Okay, but that is a typeface,

86
00:04:04.000 --> 00:04:08.450
and then there's the font would be
the actual name that you're using.

87
00:04:08.450 --> 00:04:10.530
>> That particular style of Garamond.

88
00:04:10.530 --> 00:04:13.450
>> Correct, yes,
you could throw it that way.

89
00:04:13.450 --> 00:04:19.140
And with talking about style, that's
another way that people can describe.

90
00:04:19.140 --> 00:04:24.910
There's Garamond but
then there's Garamond Italic, Bold.

91
00:04:24.910 --> 00:04:30.030
Okay so those are, you could have
full fonts that's a Garamond Bold,

92
00:04:30.030 --> 00:04:32.610
or it could be a font style off of a font.

93
00:04:32.610 --> 00:04:35.570
I don't wanna get too in the weeds of

94
00:04:35.570 --> 00:04:38.790
understanding is it a typeface,
is it a font?

95
00:04:38.790 --> 00:04:41.420
A lot of people use it interchangeably.

96
00:04:41.420 --> 00:04:44.480
It's a font, it's a typeface,
it's a font family.

97
00:04:44.480 --> 00:04:48.720
There are people and there are things
out there that they are separate and

98
00:04:48.720 --> 00:04:49.930
they do have separate meanings.

99
00:04:49.930 --> 00:04:53.480
I think it's a little too technical
honestly, I just kind of use the word

100
00:04:53.480 --> 00:04:54.960
interchangeably like
we're going to as well.

101
00:04:54.960 --> 00:04:58.330
But just know that there
is a slight difference if

102
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:00.660
you get to somebody that's
like no it's different.

103
00:05:00.660 --> 00:05:03.240
Yes it is.
>> [LAUGH] But in Illustrator for us for

104
00:05:03.240 --> 00:05:04.920
all intents and purposes.

105
00:05:04.920 --> 00:05:06.610
>> We're just gonna call them fonts.

106
00:05:06.610 --> 00:05:07.110
>> Okay.
>> Okay?

107
00:05:07.110 --> 00:05:08.850
[LAUGH] It's just, that's what it is.

108
00:05:08.850 --> 00:05:11.910
So, and then the font style,
I did specifically put that

109
00:05:11.910 --> 00:05:15.410
in there because when we get into
the formatting of that font,

110
00:05:15.410 --> 00:05:18.720
that's where it will actually show
in the drop down, is the font style.

111
00:05:18.720 --> 00:05:23.155
That's what they call it, as that thing,

112
00:05:23.155 --> 00:05:25.690
[LAUGH] that thing that
you do in the Panel.

113
00:05:25.690 --> 00:05:28.200
Wow, that was a really
great description [LAUGH].

114
00:05:28.200 --> 00:05:29.280
More to come.

115
00:05:29.280 --> 00:05:31.000
Okay, I think you guys
get the idea though.

116
00:05:31.000 --> 00:05:36.700
All right, so, now we're going to move on
to the wonderful world of sans serif and

117
00:05:36.700 --> 00:05:38.400
serif fonts.

118
00:05:38.400 --> 00:05:45.820
So, whats the difference between this and
this?

119
00:05:45.820 --> 00:05:47.650
This is a quiz Mikey so what is this?

120
00:05:47.650 --> 00:05:50.710
>> This one I know in dealing
with computers as I do.

121
00:05:50.710 --> 00:05:55.210
I know that the San Serif
is without the little,

122
00:05:55.210 --> 00:05:57.560
now I'm gonna call them
a highly technical term.

123
00:05:57.560 --> 00:06:02.160
Without the little feet whereas serif has
the little feet or tails on the letters.

124
00:06:02.160 --> 00:06:03.375
>> I go with doohickeys.

125
00:06:03.375 --> 00:06:03.875
[LAUGH]
>> Do you?

126
00:06:03.875 --> 00:06:04.675
That's even more

127
00:06:04.675 --> 00:06:05.295
technical.
[LAUGH]

128
00:06:05.295 --> 00:06:05.825
>> Exactly.

129
00:06:05.825 --> 00:06:07.440
But I would actually call them feet.

130
00:06:07.440 --> 00:06:08.000
>> Okay.
>> Feet and

131
00:06:08.000 --> 00:06:10.220
no feet if you wanna say, because.

132
00:06:10.220 --> 00:06:13.415
What we mean by the feet are these
little things right here on the ends of

133
00:06:13.415 --> 00:06:15.537
the h like that's an actual,
that's a foot.

134
00:06:15.537 --> 00:06:16.129
>> Mm-hm.

135
00:06:16.129 --> 00:06:17.499
>> At the end of the i.

136
00:06:17.499 --> 00:06:20.449
As opposed to the serif
fonts there's no feet,

137
00:06:20.449 --> 00:06:23.120
there's no feet on this particular font.

138
00:06:23.120 --> 00:06:25.940
This is a non, or sans-serif font.

139
00:06:25.940 --> 00:06:28.420
And this is a serif font.

140
00:06:28.420 --> 00:06:31.390
>> I always think of the serif fonts
as maybe being a little more formal.

141
00:06:32.450 --> 00:06:33.700
>> Yeah you can say that.

142
00:06:33.700 --> 00:06:35.660
>> Yeah.
>> And probably why you think it's formal.

143
00:06:35.660 --> 00:06:40.720
Do you know where you normally see this
font very prevalantly in the world?

144
00:06:40.720 --> 00:06:43.393
>> Literature.
Mature books?

145
00:06:43.393 --> 00:06:44.210
>> Mm-hm.

146
00:06:44.210 --> 00:06:46.570
Maybe, yes.
And newspapers.

147
00:06:46.570 --> 00:06:47.470
>> Newspapers, yes.

148
00:06:47.470 --> 00:06:52.750
>> Yeah, and do you know why you see this
particular font in books and newspapers?

149
00:06:52.750 --> 00:06:56.500
Because those feet, they actually add,

150
00:06:56.500 --> 00:07:01.220
they acts as guides for
your eyes to travel across the page

151
00:07:01.220 --> 00:07:06.000
because that Serif gives you that line
of where you're supposed to go across.

152
00:07:06.000 --> 00:07:06.966
>> Okay, very cool.
>> Yeah.

153
00:07:06.966 --> 00:07:13.780
And now why would you use a Serif font or
Sans Serif font in a book?

154
00:07:13.780 --> 00:07:14.780
Yes, it's totally fine.

155
00:07:14.780 --> 00:07:20.230
So it's not, it's really a stylistic
choice, but that is some of the psychology

156
00:07:20.230 --> 00:07:25.230
behind why you would want to use a Serif
font verses, this is a sans serif font.

157
00:07:25.230 --> 00:07:29.320
They say that you can usually
reserve your sans serif for

158
00:07:29.320 --> 00:07:31.380
your headlines, so bigger fonts.

159
00:07:31.380 --> 00:07:35.630
You know, you dont see a lot of serif
fonts on street signs, things like that,

160
00:07:35.630 --> 00:07:38.360
its all in a sans serif font,
because its a heading.

161
00:07:38.360 --> 00:07:41.900
Again, you can always break the rules But
it's just,

162
00:07:41.900 --> 00:07:45.140
that's kind of the norm,
if you want to say, so they say.

163
00:07:45.140 --> 00:07:49.361
All right, so we have Sans Serif and
we have Serif fonts.

164
00:07:49.361 --> 00:07:53.393
Now down here, I said I wouldn't
be quizzing you but guess what?

165
00:07:53.393 --> 00:07:54.201
>> Another one?

166
00:07:54.201 --> 00:07:55.080
>> I want to quiz you some more.

167
00:07:55.080 --> 00:08:00.900
[LAUGH] So
what's the difference between this,

168
00:08:00.900 --> 00:08:03.740
and over here, this?

169
00:08:03.740 --> 00:08:07.410
Can you see the difference?

170
00:08:07.410 --> 00:08:09.585
>> One looks a little bit thinner and
lighter.

171
00:08:09.585 --> 00:08:10.330
>> Mm-hm.

172
00:08:10.330 --> 00:08:11.745
>> Both 14 points.

173
00:08:11.745 --> 00:08:12.480
>> Mm-hm.

174
00:08:12.480 --> 00:08:13.520
>> So maybe one is bold?

175
00:08:15.190 --> 00:08:19.720
That was totally not right, but
[LAUGH] I didn't prep you on this one, so

176
00:08:19.720 --> 00:08:21.270
you're going a little cold.

177
00:08:21.270 --> 00:08:22.870
So, I'll give you this one.

178
00:08:22.870 --> 00:08:25.460
Look at the overall width.

179
00:08:25.460 --> 00:08:26.350
Let's go with that.

180
00:08:26.350 --> 00:08:30.236
Do you see the letters here in Myriad?

181
00:08:30.236 --> 00:08:30.952
>> Uh-huh.

182
00:08:30.952 --> 00:08:34.634
>> All right, versus Courier over here.

183
00:08:34.634 --> 00:08:37.191
>> A little more spaced out.

184
00:08:37.191 --> 00:08:42.980
>> Yes,
cuz we're getting into proportioned fonts.

185
00:08:42.980 --> 00:08:45.920
Or mono spaced fonts.

186
00:08:45.920 --> 00:08:47.310
So I actually have something here.

187
00:08:47.310 --> 00:08:51.440
So you see right here,
proportional fonts and mono spaced fonts.

188
00:08:51.440 --> 00:08:53.550
You can really see it here on Courier.

189
00:08:53.550 --> 00:08:58.130
You see that each letter
actually occupies the same space.

190
00:08:58.130 --> 00:09:00.440
>> Even though some of those
letters are not quite as wide,

191
00:09:00.440 --> 00:09:01.735
they still take up the same space.

192
00:09:01.735 --> 00:09:02.860
>> Mm-hm.
Like an I,

193
00:09:02.860 --> 00:09:07.020
as opposed to over here, in our
proportional fonts, you can see look,

194
00:09:07.020 --> 00:09:11.370
whoops wrong zoom, you can see
that the I is actually smaller.

195
00:09:11.370 --> 00:09:14.651
>> Much thinner than the [CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah thinner and then the a and

196
00:09:14.651 --> 00:09:19.193
the m, of uppercase m takes a lot
more space than Myriad, and so

197
00:09:19.193 --> 00:09:24.440
that would be a proportional font
versus a mono spaced font, so.

198
00:09:24.440 --> 00:09:26.420
So that's always a fun one.

199
00:09:26.420 --> 00:09:30.130
And, talking about what does this say,
Courier New,

200
00:09:30.130 --> 00:09:32.540
that's a very, it's like a typewriter.

201
00:09:32.540 --> 00:09:37.690
It's a very old-school, if you wanna say,
and that's what it looks like to me.

202
00:09:37.690 --> 00:09:39.040
>> Right.
>> As our proportional fonts.

203
00:09:39.040 --> 00:09:42.870
>> Cuz those typewriters, they moved

00:21:14.690 --> 00:21:18.760
And the other thing that the OpenType
fonts will do is how it treats figures and

436
00:21:18.760 --> 00:21:20.346
fractions, figures meaning numbers.

437
00:21:20.346 --> 00:21:25.940
Fractions here versus here, okay.

438
00:21:25.940 --> 00:21:27.090
So you have that.

439
00:21:27.090 --> 00:21:30.150
And each font, of course, is going to show
your fractions a little bit differently,

440
00:21:30.150 --> 00:21:32.010
this again is Garamond Pro.

441
00:21:32.010 --> 00:21:36.870
And then how it treats your letters,
sorry figures.

442
00:21:36.870 --> 00:21:39.720
It's almost like
the monospace a little bit.

443
00:21:39.720 --> 00:21:41.180
But it's closer to that but

444
00:21:41.180 --> 00:21:47.155
it's really lining up your decimal
points to where it finds that.

445
00:21:47.155 --> 00:21:49.355
And then it also has
the old style numbers.

446
00:21:49.355 --> 00:21:52.365
This is almost like, you see
the numbers on the sides of houses?

447
00:21:52.365 --> 00:21:53.215
>> Yes.
>> Right?

448
00:21:53.215 --> 00:21:57.190
Like at the hardware store,
you can actually buy that looks this way.

449
00:21:57.190 --> 00:21:58.345
>> Uh-huh.
>> That's what they call

450
00:21:58.345 --> 00:21:59.490
old style figures.

451
00:21:59.490 --> 00:22:02.370
So these are all the different things and

452
00:22:02.370 --> 00:22:04.900
features you can have
with an open type font.

453
00:22:04.900 --> 00:22:07.050
True type fonts you
won't get any of these,

454
00:22:07.050 --> 00:22:09.920
it's just going to have your regular,
I think it was like 256 characters?

455
00:22:09.920 --> 00:22:14.190
Don't quote me on that particular
number that you could have, but

456
00:22:14.190 --> 00:22:16.440
I know 256 goes to all out our eight bits.

457
00:22:16.440 --> 00:22:17.460
>> Go back to eight bits.

458
00:22:17.460 --> 00:22:20.020
>> Yeah, Yeah, there you go.

459
00:22:20.020 --> 00:22:21.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> So just a few more things here.

460
00:22:21.740 --> 00:22:26.130
When you have fonts, your font has
to be installed on your computer.

461
00:22:26.130 --> 00:22:30.010
I have certain fonts on this computer that
I know you don't have on this computer.

462
00:22:30.010 --> 00:22:33.430
Because I've either purchased them,
I've downloaded them,

463
00:22:33.430 --> 00:22:37.300
or I've got it from like maybe
a company I was working for.

464
00:22:37.300 --> 00:22:39.850
Because if I am working and
doing freelancing for a company,

465
00:22:39.850 --> 00:22:44.730
they might have specific fonts that they
use in all of their marking material.

466
00:22:44.730 --> 00:22:46.350
Well, they need to give that to me,

467
00:22:46.350 --> 00:22:50.840
and so I can be able to use that
particular branded font that they have.

468
00:22:50.840 --> 00:22:54.830
So, you do have to have like
the permission to use that font and

469
00:22:54.830 --> 00:22:56.740
you will get the warning,

470
00:22:56.740 --> 00:23:01.820
like hey make sure you have the right
licenses to be able to use this font.

471
00:23:01.820 --> 00:23:07.360
And that's where you can purchase fonts
from what they call font foundries.

472
00:23:07.360 --> 00:23:11.130
There's companies that make specific
fonts where you have to buy them.

473
00:23:11.130 --> 00:23:16.190
Like I, like ad agents,
will purchase large amounts of fonts.

474
00:23:16.190 --> 00:23:18.840
I mean, I have a lot of designer
friends that they're like, for

475
00:23:18.840 --> 00:23:20.890
Christmas, you know what my boss got me?

476
00:23:20.890 --> 00:23:22.075
They got me 200 new fonts.

477
00:23:22.075 --> 00:23:24.220
>> [LAUGH]
>> And to me I'm like, that's amazing.

478
00:23:24.220 --> 00:23:27.280
And people are like,
you got fonts for Christmas, really?

479
00:23:27.280 --> 00:23:31.040
But it's a huge thing,
because there's so many to choose from.

480
00:23:31.040 --> 00:23:32.320
You run out of your options.

481
00:23:32.320 --> 00:23:37.355
When you get 200 new licensed fonts that
were purchased for you, that's awesome.

482
00:23:37.355 --> 00:23:38.760
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

483
00:23:38.760 --> 00:23:40.146
>> Okay, I'm a little bit of a,

484
00:23:40.146 --> 00:23:41.039
[LAUGH] a font geek.

485
00:23:41.039 --> 00:23:41.539
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay.

486
00:23:41.539 --> 00:23:44.154
[LAUGH] But kind of going back to that is,

487
00:23:44.154 --> 00:23:49.387
they aren't computer and file specific,
so if I'm using fonts in this file,

488
00:23:49.387 --> 00:23:54.223
And I have specific installed fonts
on my computer, and I send it to you,

489
00:23:54.223 --> 00:23:57.390
and you don't have those fonts.
And you open this file up,

490
00:23:57.390 --> 00:23:59.000
you're gonna be like.
It's gonna say,

491
00:23:59.000 --> 00:24:00.910
hey you don't have this font.

492
00:24:00.910 --> 00:24:05.180
And your application is going to tell you,
Illustrator is going to be like, hey,

493
00:24:05.180 --> 00:24:08.570
she was using font blah blah blah and

494
00:24:08.570 --> 00:24:12.800
you don't have blah blah blah so I can't
show you what it actually looks like.

495
00:24:12.800 --> 00:24:14.770
>> That's a very expensive one,
blah blah blah.

496
00:24:14.770 --> 00:24:15.641
I looked it up.

497
00:24:15.641 --> 00:24:16.980
>> [LAUGH] Yes.
[LAUGH] You should ask for

498
00:24:16.980 --> 00:24:17.621
it for Christmas.

499
00:24:17.621 --> 00:24:20.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> So yes, you need to make sure that,

500
00:24:20.430 --> 00:24:26.860
if you are sending files to somebody else,
you need to send the fonts with the file.

501
00:24:26.860 --> 00:24:31.270
So that way they know when they open it,
okay, I can install this font.

502
00:24:32.500 --> 00:24:34.000
They're all over the place.

503
00:24:34.000 --> 00:24:37.660
>> I might be jumping the gun a little
bit, but is that a save option?

504
00:24:37.660 --> 00:24:39.620
When you save the file you
can say to include the fonts?

505
00:24:39.620 --> 00:24:41.220
Are we gonna get to that later?

506
00:24:41.220 --> 00:24:44.589
>> There is an option that you can do
that and that's known as packaging.

507
00:24:44.589 --> 00:24:48.060
Which is packaging, think of,
if I'm packaging this file for

508
00:24:48.060 --> 00:24:51.100
you, I'm basically putting it up into
a nice little box with a little bow on it,

509
00:24:51.100 --> 00:24:54.330
that's gonna give you everything
you need for that file for you.

510
00:24:54.330 --> 00:24:56.900
And that's not just going
to package your fonts,

511
00:24:56.900 --> 00:24:59.560
it's also gonna package your images.

512
00:24:59.560 --> 00:25:02.170
But we're not talking about images in this
episode, we have other ones in there.

513
00:25:02.170 --> 00:25:05.260
But that feature does work,
and it's really great.

514
00:25:05.260 --> 00:25:10.050
And packaging used to not
be an Illustrator feature.

515
00:25:10.050 --> 00:25:11.510
It was only in InDesign.

516
00:25:11.510 --> 00:25:14.384
And then when they added it into
Illustrator, I was like, [SOUND].

517
00:25:14.384 --> 00:25:15.810
I was so excited.

518
00:25:15.810 --> 00:25:16.970
>> What was your other option then?

519
00:25:16.970 --> 00:25:18.560
Actually get the font file and

520
00:25:18.560 --> 00:25:21.530
send them that separate from
the artwork or the file?

521
00:25:21.530 --> 00:25:23.470
>> Yeah, I would have to go into my fonts,

522
00:25:23.470 --> 00:25:27.760
and actually get the fonts, and
then put them into a folder.

523
00:25:27.760 --> 00:25:30.660
And then I make sure I get all my images
and make sure I'm in the right place.

524
00:25:30.660 --> 00:25:33.590
Yeah, I would have to manually package
>> Create this

525
00:25:33.590 --> 00:25:34.470
package
>> Yeah, so

526
00:25:34.470 --> 00:25:35.472
>> And explain to them how to

527
00:25:35.472 --> 00:25:36.895
install the font and all that.

528
00:25:36.895 --> 00:25:40.090
>> Mm-hm, yeah, and so
that's why, sometimes when,

529
00:25:40.090 --> 00:25:43.600
back in the day, if I was choosing,
>> am I gonna use Illustrator or

530
00:25:43.600 --> 00:25:45.830
am I gonna use InDesign
to do this document?

531
00:25:45.830 --> 00:25:47.990
I would choose InDesign just
because of the package feature,

532
00:25:47.990 --> 00:25:51.630
when I really wanted to use Illustrator,
but it didn't have the package.

533
00:25:51.630 --> 00:25:58.460
So I actually avoided using the product
for that particular project.

534
00:25:58.460 --> 00:26:00.933
>> Nice.
>> So, I love packaging in Illustrator.

535
00:26:00.933 --> 00:26:02.366
>> [LAUGH].
>> It's very awesome.

536
00:26:02.366 --> 00:26:03.919
Okay, so let's move on.

537
00:26:03.919 --> 00:26:08.310
Just a few more thing in
our overview of typography.

538
00:26:08.310 --> 00:26:10.734
This is getting into type formatting.

539
00:26:10.734 --> 00:26:13.509
And it breaks up into two different types.

540
00:26:13.509 --> 00:26:18.465
You can have character formatting and
we're gonna have paragraph formatting.

541
00:26:18.465 --> 00:26:23.035
Again we're just explaining the topics and
the ideas here and then we're gonna show

542
00:26:23.035 --> 00:26:26.010
you, in later episodes, how you
actually change all of these things.

543
00:26:26.010 --> 00:26:29.060
But character formatting,
these are to the actual letters.

544
00:26:29.060 --> 00:26:31.730
There's things like
letting kerning tracking.

545
00:26:31.730 --> 00:26:34.480
Its okay if you don't know what they mean,
I'll show you.

546
00:26:34.480 --> 00:26:37.220
But its to the actual letters.

547
00:26:37.220 --> 00:26:38.420
>> Individual characters.

548
00:26:38.420 --> 00:26:41.760
>> Yes, and
individual words within a paragraph.

549
00:26:41.760 --> 00:26:46.670
Now, paragraph level formatting would
be left aligned, right aligned,

550
00:26:46.670 --> 00:26:47.990
center aligned.

551
00:26:47.990 --> 00:26:51.323
The spaces before or
after paragraphs, like full,

552
00:26:51.323 --> 00:26:55.210
actual paragraphs where you type and
then you hit enter.

553
00:26:55.210 --> 00:26:59.490
When you hit enter, you're making a
paragraph, as opposed to just type, space,

554
00:26:59.490 --> 00:27:00.980
type, space, type, space.

555
00:27:00.980 --> 00:27:03.035
Those are your characters
within the paragraph.

556
00:27:03.035 --> 00:27:07.410
And so
there's different levels of formatting.

557
00:27:07.410 --> 00:27:11.195
Paragraph level formatting, or
character level formatting.

558
00:27:11.195 --> 00:27:12.065
And see?

559
00:27:12.065 --> 00:27:14.165
Drop tabs, remember talking about that?

560
00:27:14.165 --> 00:27:15.160
You must have read my notes.

561
00:27:15.160 --> 00:27:17.470
>> [LAUGH] I was looking
over your shoulder there.

562
00:27:17.470 --> 00:27:18.870
>> [LAUGH] No you didn't.

563
00:27:18.870 --> 00:27:22.205
[LAUGH] But that's great, I'm so
glad that you actually brought that up.

564
00:27:22.205 --> 00:27:27.168
Okay and then another thing,
a concept of formatting with formatting

565
00:27:27.168 --> 00:27:30.460
our text is you can use
things known as styles.

566
00:27:30.460 --> 00:27:32.570
Remember we talked about swatches.

567
00:27:32.570 --> 00:27:35.470
With swatches where you could go ahead and
I want that, I want that swatch,

568
00:27:35.470 --> 00:27:36.720
be able to apply it everywhere I want.

569
00:27:36.720 --> 00:27:39.100
It's almost like swatches for text.

570
00:27:39.100 --> 00:27:42.160
It's where you can use your formatting.

571
00:27:42.160 --> 00:27:48.380
It's a collection of formatting that
you can then apply in one quick step.

572
00:27:48.380 --> 00:27:54.300
Okay, so something that I want all
of my paragraphs to be left-aligned,

573
00:27:54.300 --> 00:27:58.620
six point space after, and no hyphenation.

574
00:27:58.620 --> 00:28:00.995
Make that a style, and
I can [NOISE] just click it.

575
00:28:00.995 --> 00:28:02.267
>> And, the other cool thing,

576
00:28:02.267 --> 00:28:05.606
is that it's attached to the style You
change the style, it can go ahead and

577
00:28:05.606 --> 00:28:08.210
apply to all the places where
you have that style applied.

578
00:28:08.210 --> 00:28:11.090
Kinda like a global swatches,
we're talking about swatches.

579
00:28:11.090 --> 00:28:11.810
>> Convenient.

580
00:28:11.810 --> 00:28:12.690
>> Very convenient.

581
00:28:12.690 --> 00:28:17.110
I love styles, and
doing full textbook layouts,

582
00:28:17.110 --> 00:28:20.790
I'm formatting a book
that's over 200 pages.

583
00:28:20.790 --> 00:28:21.730
Yeah.
I'm going

584
00:28:21.730 --> 00:28:25.370
to use some styles because if I go back
and I go to the person, you know what?

585
00:28:25.370 --> 00:28:29.332
I really want that headline to
be about three points smaller.

586
00:28:29.332 --> 00:28:31.550
>> [LAUGH] How many places
have you used that?

587
00:28:31.550 --> 00:28:33.209
Yes.
>> Yeah, I better have a style.

588
00:28:33.209 --> 00:28:37.000
[LAUGH] Because all I've got to do is
change it in the style and it's done.

589
00:28:37.000 --> 00:28:37.600
Really great.

590
00:28:37.600 --> 00:28:38.910
Okay, so styles.

591
00:28:38.910 --> 00:28:44.240
I will tell you that, in Illustrator
specifically, styles are a little wonky.

592
00:28:44.240 --> 00:28:48.860
They're not as fluid
as styles in InDesign.

593
00:28:48.860 --> 00:28:49.980
They work.

594
00:28:49.980 --> 00:28:51.840
They're just a little
bit more temperamental.

595
00:28:51.840 --> 00:28:54.850
At least for me, being somebody
that uses InDesign a lot and

596
00:28:54.850 --> 00:28:58.050
uses styles like nobody's business.

597
00:28:59.140 --> 00:29:00.320
When I have to go to Illustrator,

598
00:29:00.320 --> 00:29:05.000
I have to remember the little quirks
that Illustrator has with styles.

599
00:29:05.000 --> 00:29:08.170
But I'll show you,
I'll try to point them out.

600
00:29:08.170 --> 00:29:12.390
And the last little part that I wanted
to go over is Show Hidden Characters.

601
00:29:12.390 --> 00:29:16.910
Paragraph formatting and
character formatting, where is it at?

602
00:29:16.910 --> 00:29:19.530
And if you've ever been in a file, where,

603
00:29:19.530 --> 00:29:23.060
if you move something over,
your just space,

604
00:29:23.060 --> 00:29:25.910
space, space, space, space, space, space,-
>> [LAUGH]

605
00:29:25.910 --> 00:29:27.120
>> And, yes, I'm sure I do it too.

606
00:29:27.120 --> 00:29:31.795
But, how do I know when there's a line
break, or a space, or a character term?

607
00:29:31.795 --> 00:29:33.578
>> Mm-hm.
>> I call them character terms,

608
00:29:33.578 --> 00:29:37.030
like the enters,
showing hidden characters?

609
00:29:37.030 --> 00:29:38.690
>> In Illustrator specifically,

610
00:29:38.690 --> 00:29:42.200
that's in your Type menu,
that Show Hidden Characters.

611
00:29:42.200 --> 00:29:44.500
It's in all of your products,
you just have to know where to find it.

612
00:29:44.500 --> 00:29:46.435
It's in Word, okay.

613
00:29:46.435 --> 00:29:47.720
>> Mm-Hm.

614
00:29:47.720 --> 00:29:49.620
>> I love Word, so there we go.

615
00:29:49.620 --> 00:29:55.190
Now you can see that it is showing
things that are actually in the type,

616
00:29:55.190 --> 00:29:56.890
they're not displaying.

617
00:29:56.890 --> 00:30:00.530
It's the non-printing,
or non-displaying, or

618
00:30:00.530 --> 00:30:02.600
actually, it's non-printing,
I should really clarify that.

619
00:30:02.600 --> 00:30:07.600
It's the non-printing
characters within the text.

620
00:30:07.600 --> 00:30:12.620
So you can see, right here,
that I know that is a full paragraph

621
00:30:13.670 --> 00:30:16.430
and that is a line-break,
that's not a paragraph.

622
00:30:16.430 --> 00:30:19.900
So if I was trying to apply paragraphable
formatting of space after and

623
00:30:19.900 --> 00:30:22.390
I couldn't understand why was
it not spacing after line-break.

624
00:30:22.390 --> 00:30:23.640
I think that's a new line.

625
00:30:23.640 --> 00:30:28.810
It's not a new paragraph,
it's a new line within a paragraph.

626
00:30:28.810 --> 00:30:32.690
It is not an Enter,
it's a Shift+Enter, it's a line break.

627
00:30:32.690 --> 00:30:38.190
And how do I know when somebody's done
a whole bunch of spaces versus using tabs?

628
00:30:38.190 --> 00:30:43.590
Because if I'm trying to format tab stops
with a document that doesn't have tabs,

629
00:30:43.590 --> 00:30:44.730
its not going to do anything.

630
00:30:44.730 --> 00:30:47.200
So that's really, really helpful.

631
00:30:47.200 --> 00:30:52.010
I pretty much always have non-printing

632
00:30:52.010 --> 00:30:56.055
hidden characters when I'm doing
extensive text formatting.

633
00:30:56.055 --> 00:30:57.740
>> Mm-hm.
>> Because I need this.

634
00:30:57.740 --> 00:31:01.830
I live in this world when
I'm doing text layouts.

635
00:31:01.830 --> 00:31:04.540
And it's everything for me.

636
00:31:04.540 --> 00:31:05.370
>> Right.

637
00:31:05.370 --> 00:31:06.980
>> When I do that.

638
00:31:06.980 --> 00:31:09.510
So, that is my Typography 101.

639
00:31:09.510 --> 00:31:12.540
>> All right, Vaughn, again,
a lot of information about fonts.

640
00:31:12.540 --> 00:31:15.974
I bet some of you, including me,
didn't realize there was that much to

641
00:31:15.974 --> 00:31:18.620
learn about Typography and
were not done yet, right?

642
00:31:18.620 --> 00:31:22.250
We've got more to do, but that's gonna
do it for this particular episode.

643
00:31:22.250 --> 00:31:24.230
We hope everybody enjoyed watching.

644
00:31:24.230 --> 00:31:27.240
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

645
00:31:27.240 --> 00:31:28.000
>> And I'm Vaughn Smith.

646
00:31:28.000 --> 00:31:31.212
>> And we'll see you next time.

We're gonna dive a little bit more into
fonts on your machine and a very common

00:00:48.591 --> 00:00:53.589

17
00:00:53.589 --> 00:00:57.720
The fonts that you have on your computer,
the fonts that I have on my computer.

00:00:57.720 --> 00:01:02.300
Are going to be completely different
