anybody messing with the font itself.

70
00:03:42.087 --> 00:03:46.010
Cuz then they could just take
the text tool, type something else.

71
00:03:46.010 --> 00:03:47.540
I want it to be shapes.

72
00:03:47.540 --> 00:03:50.910
Now, yes, they could modify it,
but it's not text.

73
00:03:50.910 --> 00:03:53.550
>> And as a vector,
I would imagine it scales well, as well.

74
00:03:53.550 --> 00:03:56.220
>> Exactly, yeah, totally great point.

75
00:03:56.220 --> 00:03:56.760
>> Very good.

76
00:03:56.760 --> 00:04:01.050
>> So now that I have it created
as outlines, I've ungrouped it.

77
00:04:01.050 --> 00:04:03.990
Now you can see that
this is a compound path,

78
00:04:03.990 --> 00:04:06.370
right, we talked about that
in some other episodes.

79
00:04:06.370 --> 00:04:09.176
So you could release it
from its compound path.

80
00:04:09.176 --> 00:04:10.810
I mean,
you could do whatever you want with this,

81
00:04:10.810 --> 00:04:14.390
because maybe I want this O
to be a little bit bigger.

82
00:04:14.390 --> 00:04:19.070
Outlines, and I wanna kind of
extend this and I wanna tilt this.

83
00:04:19.070 --> 00:04:21.840
And I wanna do all sorts of different
things that I wanna do to my text.

84
00:04:21.840 --> 00:04:24.912
I couldn't do this to text as text.

85
00:04:24.912 --> 00:04:27.330
It's not possible, okay.

86
00:04:27.330 --> 00:04:32.189
And one other thing I wanted to point out
that, why you might wanna create outlines

87
00:04:32.189 --> 00:04:36.075
to text for formatting reasons,
not just to play around with it.

88
00:04:36.075 --> 00:04:38.597
If I click on this one and
I go to, I mean,

89
00:04:38.597 --> 00:04:41.805
I can change it to different solid colors,
right.

90
00:04:41.805 --> 00:04:44.445
I could do blues, I could do patterns.

91
00:04:44.445 --> 00:04:47.421
But notice as soon as I click on
a gradient, the gradient doesn't work.

92
00:04:47.421 --> 00:04:54.330
Okay, you cannot apply gradients as fill
to text as text, it just doesn't work.

93
00:04:54.330 --> 00:04:57.510
So the way you can is if you
create outlines with it.

94
00:04:57.510 --> 00:04:59.724
So now that these are in outlines already,

95
00:04:59.724 --> 00:05:02.192
you could see that I've
got the text selected.

96
00:05:02.192 --> 00:05:05.560
Now it's just shapes, so
I could add my gradient.

97
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:09.150
I could go to my gradient tool, I could,
whoops, gotta get to the gradient tool.

98
00:05:09.150 --> 00:05:14.290
Go ahead and draw the line across of
all my letters, or so on and so forth.

99
00:05:14.290 --> 00:05:18.358
So that's another reason why there are
some times where I wanna create outlines

100
00:05:18.358 --> 00:05:20.430
as text, is to do the fun formatting.

101
00:05:20.430 --> 00:05:21.805
>> Very cool.
>> Mm-hm, so

102
00:05:21.805 --> 00:05:24.570
I mean, that's really what it is.

103
00:05:24.570 --> 00:05:26.266
You just create outlines, okay.

104
00:05:26.266 --> 00:05:28.851
But just to kind of go
over a few other things,

105
00:05:28.851 --> 00:05:32.170
just to kind of in
the practicality of when and why.

106
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:35.162
You see here, I have this
Hop Along Hills logo that I've created.

107
00:05:35.162 --> 00:05:37.476
I didn't create the art
board in the right size,

108
00:05:37.476 --> 00:05:39.293
cuz I was just kind of playing around.

109
00:05:39.293 --> 00:05:42.460
And it was just do it, and
I can change the art board later.

110
00:05:42.460 --> 00:05:47.440
Here, this is not text,
this is just a group of shapes.

111
00:05:47.440 --> 00:05:52.290
Because I wanted to make
sure that this logo has

112
00:05:52.290 --> 00:05:55.470
just paths when I go off and send it.

113
00:05:55.470 --> 00:05:59.070
Now, just from me having
many years of experience,

114
00:05:59.070 --> 00:06:03.310
do you know how many times I've gone
back to old files or old logos and

115
00:06:03.310 --> 00:06:07.475
said, I don't know what the font is,
cuz I already created it into outlines.

116
00:06:07.475 --> 00:06:10.315
Right, so it's gone, I have no idea,
and I have to go back and

117
00:06:10.315 --> 00:06:11.747
look through all these fonts.

118
00:06:11.747 --> 00:06:12.408
I'm like, does that match?

119
00:06:12.408 --> 00:06:13.307
Does that match?

120
00:06:13.307 --> 00:06:16.104
>> So if you wanted to make a change
to the actual text at this point.

121
00:06:16.104 --> 00:06:18.437
>> Yeah, or
even just remember what font I used.

122
00:06:18.437 --> 00:06:20.375
>> [LAUGH]
>> Which I do all the time.

123
00:06:20.375 --> 00:06:25.931
So what I've done, just as my little
thing, I will either, if it's a logo

124
00:06:25.931 --> 00:06:31.582
like this, I'll create a layer that's
in here, and I'll just add here.

125
00:06:31.582 --> 00:06:33.870
Here, yeah, sorry,
that the Layers panel is a little hidden.

126
00:06:33.870 --> 00:06:38.770
So I can just create this layer, and you
see I've just made a layer called text.

127
00:06:38.770 --> 00:06:44.420
So I kept a version of this text as text,
so I know that this is Helvetica Neue.

128
00:06:44.420 --> 00:06:48.717
So if I ever came back to this file later,
I could remember, that's what it is.

129
00:06:48.717 --> 00:06:52.094
So now that's just me,
I'll make a hidden layer like that,

130
00:06:52.094 --> 00:06:54.757
because it's kind of
burned me a couple times.

131
00:06:54.757 --> 00:06:56.420
>> Yes [LAUGH]
>> Yes,

132
00:06:56.420 --> 00:07:01.360
the other thing is you'd make another
version, you do a whole other file.

133
00:07:01.360 --> 00:07:03.150
That's how I used to do it,
and especially sometimes,

134
00:07:03.150 --> 00:07:06.280
I don't want to keep
this text in this file.

135
00:07:06.280 --> 00:07:08.660
Cuz if I send it to you, then I
still have that whole font issue and

136
00:07:08.660 --> 00:07:09.450
everything like that.

137
00:07:10.610 --> 00:07:14.230
So I actually have my production file.

138
00:07:14.230 --> 00:07:17.660
I call it production,
like logo_production.

139
00:07:17.660 --> 00:07:20.150
And then the other one, logo_final.

140
00:07:20.150 --> 00:07:24.660
And that version of that file is
the one I create outlines with and

141
00:07:24.660 --> 00:07:26.420
then use it for however I want.

142
00:07:26.420 --> 00:07:30.698
So whatever technique you wanna do,
just giving you a little tip here,

143
00:07:30.698 --> 00:07:33.712
just make sure you remember,
where is that font.

144
00:07:33.712 --> 00:07:34.330
>> All right.

145
00:07:34.330 --> 00:07:35.642
>> And what is it and
however which way you want.

146
00:07:35.642 --> 00:07:36.468
>> A great little tip there.

147
00:07:36.468 --> 00:07:41.598
>> Yeah, and there's also times
where I've, in print production,

148
00:07:41.598 --> 00:07:45.468
to where they will request
all text is in outlines,

149
00:07:45.468 --> 00:07:48.720
where they're like outline all texts.

150
00:07:48.720 --> 00:07:50.350
If you have the specs for an ad or

151
00:07:50.350 --> 00:07:52.878
something that you're
putting in a magazine,

152
00:07:52.878 --> 00:07:56.250
that sometimes they will say that, because
they don't want to deal with font files.

153
00:07:56.250 --> 00:07:59.980
Think about they're getting ads created
from all sorts of different people and

154
00:07:59.980 --> 00:08:03.520
into this huge production for
a conference or whatever.

155
00:08:03.520 --> 00:08:04.700
They're not dealing with that.

156
00:08:04.700 --> 00:08:08.890
So they're saying, okay, give me all
of the, here are the dimensions.

157
00:08:08.890 --> 00:08:14.144
Here's CMYK, 300 dpi or
ppi, and outline all text.

158
00:08:14.144 --> 00:08:17.610
So I would take this whole,
even though it's body text-

159
00:08:17.610 --> 00:08:19.830
>> Can you outline even that body text?

160
00:08:19.830 --> 00:08:21.136
>> Exactly,
that's where we're going, yeah.

161
00:08:21.136 --> 00:08:25.510
So I could take both of this, all
the text, I could actually do a Ctrl+A or

162
00:08:25.510 --> 00:08:28.652
an Option+A to say select everything,
right.

163
00:08:28.652 --> 00:08:34.130
And I can go ahead and say take all
the type and create outlines out of it.

164
00:08:34.130 --> 00:08:36.859
So even though I selected shapes,
it's like, well that's not text, so

165
00:08:36.859 --> 00:08:38.809
it's not going to create
outlines out of your text.

166
00:08:38.809 --> 00:08:42.590
So I can just say, get everything
that I got, make it all outlines.

167
00:08:42.590 --> 00:08:48.162
And now, when I send this file, there's no
fonts, there's no text in this document.

168
00:08:48.162 --> 00:08:51.090
It's all vector paths, vector shapes.

169
00:08:51.090 --> 00:08:54.470
Don't have to worry about those font
files, and then it's fantastic.

170
00:08:54.470 --> 00:08:56.320
But again, what should you do?

171
00:08:56.320 --> 00:08:57.009
Make a backup.

172
00:08:57.009 --> 00:08:58.478
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

173
00:08:58.478 --> 00:08:59.288
>> Make sure you have

174
00:08:59.288 --> 00:09:02.046
a version that's text and
have a version that's outlines.

175
00:09:02.046 --> 00:09:05.430
And that's the one you send off to
your printer, and so on and so forth.

176
00:09:05.430 --> 00:09:11.222
And that is creating outlines from text
>> Probably a very important tip,

177
00:09:11.222 --> 00:09:13.279
especially if you're gonna
do the body text like that,

178
00:09:13.279 --> 00:09:15.710
cuz there's a good chance they find
a typo or want a word changed.

179
00:09:15.710 --> 00:09:19.130
And once you had converted that
to outline, you're in trouble.

180
00:09:19.130 --> 00:09:21.496
>> Exactly yeah, yeah, and I've done it.

181
00:09:21.496 --> 00:09:22.564
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

182
00:09:22.564 --> 00:09:24.118
>> So don't do it.

183
00:09:24.118 --> 00:09:27.050
All right, so
now we've come to your favorite part.

184
00:09:27.050 --> 00:09:28.230
>> Drum roll, please.

185
00:09:28.230 --> 00:09:32.660
Is it finally time to figure out
what this Touch Type tool is?

186
00:09:32.660 --> 00:09:34.006
>> Yes, so we're ready to go.

187
00:09:34.006 --> 00:09:36.880
So this is actually a fun little tool.

188
00:09:36.880 --> 00:09:40.530
And I wanted to put it in here with the
create outlines, because I think this is

189
00:09:40.530 --> 00:09:43.990
where it really exemplifies why
you'd want to use it, okay.

190
00:09:43.990 --> 00:09:46.999
So when I did this first one,
right, I created outlines.

191
00:09:46.999 --> 00:09:48.070
And then I ungrouped it so

192
00:09:48.070 --> 00:09:51.450
I could change the letters, turn it,
all that kind of fun stuff.

193
00:09:51.450 --> 00:09:53.730
But it's no longer text,
I can't format it any more.

194
00:09:55.030 --> 00:09:59.460
With the Touch Type tool,
it's like you're creating outlines, but

195
00:09:59.460 --> 00:10:02.400
you're not going all
the way to the outlines.

196
00:10:02.400 --> 00:10:07.473
It's kinda like this cool limbo
world to where you can still change

197
00:10:07.473 --> 00:10:12.730
individual characters individually
without making it outlines.

198
00:10:12.730 --> 00:10:14.325
Let me show you,
I think is the best way to demonstrate.

199
00:10:14.325 --> 00:10:18.275
Now I can show you here in the Character
panel there is the Touch Type tool,

200
00:10:18.275 --> 00:10:20.430
right there at the top.

201
00:10:20.430 --> 00:10:23.120
So that's the easiest place
that I can go to, and

202
00:10:23.120 --> 00:10:26.410
you can also get it in
the group of the type tools.

203
00:10:26.410 --> 00:10:27.400
It's down there at the bottom.

204
00:10:27.400 --> 00:10:28.840
So either which way you can find it.

205
00:10:28.840 --> 00:10:30.650
I just always seem to find it here.

206
00:10:30.650 --> 00:10:32.860
So if I take my selected, whoops, sorry.

207
00:10:32.860 --> 00:10:35.801
Let me go back to the black arrow tool,
and I go to the Touch Type tool.

208
00:10:35.801 --> 00:10:41.240
You can see that now what it does is
it's actually creating each letter,

209
00:10:41.240 --> 00:10:46.560
or it's allowing me to take each letter,
individually.

210
00:10:46.560 --> 00:10:50.010
And I can make it bigger,
or I could take this and

211
00:10:50.010 --> 00:10:52.190
maybe I could go ahead and
oops, there it is.

212
00:10:52.190 --> 00:10:56.427
I can rotate this, maybe go ahead and
extend this out, or

213
00:10:56.427 --> 00:11:02.275
I can do whatever I want with this,
almost like it was a regular shape, right?

214
00:11:02.275 --> 00:11:03.100
>> Mm-hm.

215
00:11:03.100 --> 00:11:05.934
>> But it's still not outlines,
because if I go back here,

216
00:11:05.934 --> 00:11:08.035
now this,to me this is the coolest part.

217
00:11:08.035 --> 00:11:11.290
I've done all these kinda tweaks and
formats and everything like that.

218
00:11:11.290 --> 00:11:12.940
Well, I don't want it to be Arial anymore.

219
00:11:12.940 --> 00:11:16.900
Well, I could go ahead and
make it whatever font I want.

220
00:11:16.900 --> 00:11:19.680
It keeps it text as text.

221
00:11:19.680 --> 00:11:21.250
Yeah, it's super cool.

222
00:11:21.250 --> 00:11:25.370
So now it keeps the way that I scaled
each letter or rotated it, but

223
00:11:25.370 --> 00:11:28.170
I can change the fonts,
I can do whatever I want.

224
00:11:28.170 --> 00:11:33.160
And that is a pretty awesome
new feature that Illustrator CC

225
00:11:33.160 --> 00:11:35.110
has with the Touch Type tool.

226
00:11:35.110 --> 00:11:36.570
And I think it's awesome.

227
00:11:36.570 --> 00:11:37.340
>> That is really cool.

228
00:11:37.340 --> 00:11:39.380
Now, could you get your text tool and
go in there and

229
00:11:39.380 --> 00:11:41.165
modify that text at this point?

230
00:11:41.165 --> 00:11:44.081
>> Like with a text or-
>> Change of letter to-

231
00:11:44.081 --> 00:11:46.353
>> Exactly, yes, good point.

232
00:11:46.353 --> 00:11:51.321
Like I want to outlinesies,
[LAUGH] because I

233
00:11:51.321 --> 00:11:56.030
like to put y's and ie's on everything.

234
00:11:56.030 --> 00:11:58.370
So yeah, you could do whatever.

235
00:11:58.370 --> 00:12:00.240
I just,
I can't think of anything to change.

236
00:12:00.240 --> 00:12:02.644
I could just like aaaa [LAUGH].

237
00:12:02.644 --> 00:12:04.971
So yes, you can put and add type.

238
00:12:04.971 --> 00:12:09.680
It is type as type, font,
formatting, anything you want.

239
00:12:09.680 --> 00:12:10.370
>> Fantastic.

240
00:12:10.370 --> 00:12:11.208
>> Yeah, pretty cool.

241
00:12:11.208 --> 00:12:12.400
>> We love it.
All right,

242
00:12:12.400 --> 00:12:15.720
that was definitely worth the wait,
really cool tool there.

243
00:12:15.720 --> 00:12:18.628
That was the new one, the Touch Type tool.

244
00:12:18.628 --> 00:12:21.330
So we thank you for
those fantastic demonstrations, Vonne.

245
00:12:21.330 --> 00:12:23.490
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

246
00:12:23.490 --> 00:12:26.250
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

247
00:12:26.250 --> 00:12:27.030
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

248
00:12:27.030 --> 00:12:28.912
>> And we'll see you next time.

249
00:12:28.912 --> 00:12:37.159
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Formatting Lists and Tab Stops
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.084 --> 00:00:10.084
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.100 --> 00:00:14.410
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:14.410 --> 00:00:16.810
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.810 --> 00:00:20.026
Today we're doing
Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

5
00:00:20.026 --> 00:00:24.898
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at formatting lists and

6
00:00:24.898 --> 00:00:25.900
tab stops.

7
00:00:25.900 --> 00:00:28.190
And here to help us with
that is Miss Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:28.190 --> 00:00:29.010
How you doing Vonne?

9
00:00:29.010 --> 00:00:32.500
>> Great, I'm actually really
excited to teach this lesson because

10
00:00:32.500 --> 00:00:34.850
it's actually one of my favorites.

11
00:00:34.850 --> 00:00:35.980
>> Really?
>> Yes, it's weird.

12
00:00:35.980 --> 00:00:40.160
I don't know why, I'm just so
drawn to tab stops and bullets and

13
00:00:40.160 --> 00:00:45.182
formatting list because if
you learn what they do.

14
00:00:45.182 --> 00:00:51.060
It kinda changes your life in the world
of text formatting and typesetting and

15
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:55.720
especially when you're doing
extensive type setting in like books.

16
00:00:55.720 --> 00:01:01.846
I can't tell you how much tab stops and
formatting bullets has changed my world.

17
00:01:01.846 --> 00:01:02.861
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

18
00:01:02.861 --> 00:01:05.770
everybody out there get ready
to have your world changed.

19
00:01:05.770 --> 00:01:09.340
As we learn about tab stops and
formatting our lists.

20
00:01:09.340 --> 00:01:13.730
>> Yes, and what I'm going to teach
you in Illustrator you can use this in

21
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:16.970
any other program that
actually has text formatting.

22
00:01:16.970 --> 00:01:21.220
You can use this in In Design,
Microsoft Word, it's all there.

23
00:01:21.220 --> 00:01:22.810
You can do this.

24
00:01:22.810 --> 00:01:24.260
Maybe the icons might be
a little different but

25
00:01:24.260 --> 00:01:27.720
the concepts are the most
important thing to understand.

26
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:29.350
>> Fantastic.
>> So that's what hopefully I will

27
00:01:29.350 --> 00:01:30.360
be able to show you.

28
00:01:30.360 --> 00:01:31.730
So, let's go.

29
00:01:31.730 --> 00:01:32.755
So I've got this document.

30
00:01:32.755 --> 00:01:36.470
[COUGH] And I've got just
a few little notes right here.

31
00:01:36.470 --> 00:01:40.390
Just to kind of get us started is that for
one thing,

32
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:43.680
if you're gonna do tab stops
you need to have tabs, okay.

33
00:01:43.680 --> 00:01:47.660
That whole like, space,space,space,space
is not gonna cut it here.

34
00:01:47.660 --> 00:01:52.240
Okay there's a reason why we like
to use tabs because you can format

35
00:01:52.240 --> 00:01:54.550
where the tabs actually stop.

36
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:55.770
And that's really fun.

37
00:01:55.770 --> 00:01:59.500
But if you're going to do that you need
to make sure you can see all of those

38
00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:00.580
non printing characters.

39
00:02:00.580 --> 00:02:01.830
Those hidden characters,

40
00:02:01.830 --> 00:02:05.250
that's something to definitely make sure
you always have up in any of the product.

41
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:07.520
But since we're doing Illustrator
that's what we're going to do.

42
00:02:07.520 --> 00:02:08.600
It is in the tabs panel.

43
00:02:08.600 --> 00:02:10.930
You will be needing to
get the glyphs panel,

44
00:02:10.930 --> 00:02:13.950
which we've talked about before,
to add those bullets.

45
00:02:13.950 --> 00:02:19.400
And then the different little icons that
are on the tabs panel is what controls.

46
00:02:19.400 --> 00:02:24.620
What type of tab it is, your first line
and hanging indents are very important

47
00:02:24.620 --> 00:02:27.910
on that and it's all just putting all
of these different things on the ruler.

48
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:29.350
So here we go.

49
00:02:29.350 --> 00:02:32.690
Let's go with the type menu to
show the hidden characters,

50
00:02:32.690 --> 00:02:38.380
because I have text that I actually
just copied out from a text file, a Word

51
00:02:38.380 --> 00:02:43.380
file that I went ahead and pasted in here

Cuz maybe I just for demonstration
I wanted it a little bit more.

281
00:14:05.850 --> 00:14:10.320
But where the hanging line, where the next
line, not the first line, but the hanging

282
00:14:10.320 --> 00:14:14.890
line goes I want that to basically align
right where that tab stop is right?

283
00:14:14.890 --> 00:14:15.550
>> Right.

284
00:14:15.550 --> 00:14:18.890
>> So you take this, it's very small,
so that's where you gotta be really.

285
00:14:18.890 --> 00:14:20.190
The bottom, not the top.

286
00:14:20.190 --> 00:14:23.990
The bottom triangle is
your hanging indent and

287
00:14:23.990 --> 00:14:28.630
its hard with my mouse cursor magnified,
cuz I can't really get it.

288
00:14:30.220 --> 00:14:31.185
There we go, there we go.

289
00:14:31.185 --> 00:14:34.120
See that tiny little guy right there.

290
00:14:34.120 --> 00:14:37.620
I'm just gonna line it
right with the tab stop.

291
00:14:39.470 --> 00:14:40.690
And there you go.

292
00:14:40.690 --> 00:14:41.270
Exactly.

293
00:14:41.270 --> 00:14:42.960
The hanging text, not the first.

294
00:14:42.960 --> 00:14:44.550
The first line, see right there.

295
00:14:44.550 --> 00:14:46.260
The first line is all the way out here.

296
00:14:46.260 --> 00:14:48.560
I don't wanna indent
the first of the line.

297
00:14:48.560 --> 00:14:54.390
I want all of the hanging text to
align right where that tab stop is and

298
00:14:54.390 --> 00:14:56.100
that's exactly what I wan to do.

299
00:14:56.100 --> 00:14:58.510
So, that's where you can
change your bullets.

300
00:14:58.510 --> 00:14:59.760
Now I just did one right?

301
00:14:59.760 --> 00:15:03.208
The reason why I did that is because
once I get one formatted the right way,

302
00:15:03.208 --> 00:15:05.200
I just go ahead and take this.

303
00:15:05.200 --> 00:15:07.500
Oops!
Wrong keyboard!

304
00:15:07.500 --> 00:15:09.160
I'm going to copy this.

305
00:15:09.160 --> 00:15:13.360
And that's just control or command C,
and that's where I go ahead,

306
00:15:13.360 --> 00:15:15.520
whoops I did the wrong one, sorry.

307
00:15:15.520 --> 00:15:17.400
There we go, copy, go here.

308
00:15:17.400 --> 00:15:19.220
You paste it, okay.

309
00:15:19.220 --> 00:15:22.530
And you can go ahead and paste it here and
then it keeps all of the formatting.

310
00:15:22.530 --> 00:15:24.940
It actually didn't carry over
the paragraph formatting but

311
00:15:24.940 --> 00:15:28.830
I can still go ahead and
get that right there.

312
00:15:28.830 --> 00:15:31.880
And now I'm going to start getting
into my obsessive tweaking so

313
00:15:31.880 --> 00:15:33.440
I should probably stop right now.

314
00:15:33.440 --> 00:15:35.470
But I think you guys got the idea there.

315
00:15:35.470 --> 00:15:38.970
>> At this time we have
different tab stops for

316
00:15:38.970 --> 00:15:41.540
each one of those paragraphs, so
you got to try to line them up.

317
00:15:41.540 --> 00:15:43.156
>> Yes, so I was doing it the long way.

318
00:15:43.156 --> 00:15:44.990
I should've just really
taken all these and

319
00:15:44.990 --> 00:15:48.630
then just taken all these weird
tab stops off and just had one.

320
00:15:48.630 --> 00:15:52.240
And then now it controls the tab for
all of them, I can do that.

321
00:15:52.240 --> 00:15:54.520
Second line indent right there.

322
00:15:54.520 --> 00:15:56.236
I can't grab it with my magnifier.

323
00:15:56.236 --> 00:15:58.105
[LAUGH] It's really hard.

324
00:15:58.105 --> 00:16:01.760
But it's where I can take and
do all of them.

325
00:16:01.760 --> 00:16:02.870
Now the other thing, there we go.

326
00:16:02.870 --> 00:16:04.050
I got it, perfect.

327
00:16:05.060 --> 00:16:08.350
There, so now, that will line
up maybe just a little bit more.

328
00:16:08.350 --> 00:16:09.510
Okay, I need to stop tweaking.

329
00:16:09.510 --> 00:16:11.260
I think you guys get the point, okay.

330
00:16:11.260 --> 00:16:12.660
You get the idea, the concept.

331
00:16:12.660 --> 00:16:16.050
The hanging and the tab, you get one,
you can select all of them.

332
00:16:16.050 --> 00:16:17.250
You can format your tabs.

333
00:16:17.250 --> 00:16:19.840
The reason I was doing one, is usually
take the same amount of text and

334
00:16:19.840 --> 00:16:21.550
paste it down and change up text.

335
00:16:21.550 --> 00:16:22.450
That's usually how I do it.

336
00:16:22.450 --> 00:16:25.400
So I was combining two
techniques of what I do in one.

337
00:16:25.400 --> 00:16:26.632
>> Love those shortcuts.

338
00:16:26.632 --> 00:16:27.503
>> Yep, exactly.

339
00:16:27.503 --> 00:16:29.350
[LAUGH] So now I've got that.

340
00:16:29.350 --> 00:16:32.480
And again right here this is
the same idea you can go ahead and

341
00:16:32.480 --> 00:16:34.138
change where you want.

342
00:16:34.138 --> 00:16:36.790
The tab stop to go for
each one of these and

343
00:16:36.790 --> 00:16:40.650
then change that little line,
the hanging indent to line up.

344
00:16:40.650 --> 00:16:41.840
And there you go.

345
00:16:41.840 --> 00:16:44.030
Cuz maybe you like that bullet,
and that's fine.

346
00:16:44.030 --> 00:16:47.710
>> Now this is the text that you
brought in from the other program.

347
00:16:47.710 --> 00:16:49.860
Did that tab stop come in with it?

348
00:16:49.860 --> 00:16:51.960
It was already there or
did you have to add that tab stop?

349
00:16:51.960 --> 00:16:53.850
>> The tab character or

350
00:16:53.850 --> 00:16:57.490
the actual keystroke of I added a tab,
that came over.

351
00:16:57.490 --> 00:17:00.670
Because that's actually what
Microsoft Word does automatically.

352
00:17:00.670 --> 00:17:03.470
As soon as you select paragraphs and
add bullets.

353
00:17:03.470 --> 00:17:04.760
It's adding a tab in there.

354
00:17:04.760 --> 00:17:06.337
>> It puts a glyph and a tab in there and

355
00:17:06.337 --> 00:17:10.050
then you just have to add your tab stop
once you've put it into Illustrator.

356
00:17:10.050 --> 00:17:15.110
>> Correct, yes, that tab was
brought in from where it came from.

357
00:17:15.110 --> 00:17:18.130
As opposed to me in the first
one having to manually add this.

358
00:17:18.130 --> 00:17:21.150
This is what came over
I've already got it.

359
00:17:21.150 --> 00:17:24.488
Now I just kinda format it cuz
maybe I like the tiny little dot.

360
00:17:24.488 --> 00:17:25.300
>> Mm-hm.

361
00:17:25.300 --> 00:17:27.844
>> I think the hearts would
be a little more cute, so.

362
00:17:27.844 --> 00:17:31.280
[LAUGH] All right, and
that's tabs and bullets.

363
00:17:31.280 --> 00:17:35.090
>> Fantastic look at some
techniques that we can use to add

364
00:17:35.090 --> 00:17:38.730
that level of formatting to our documents,
we end up with a lot of lists.

365
00:17:38.730 --> 00:17:41.940
A lot of times we have unordered
lists that just use those bullets.

366
00:17:41.940 --> 00:17:44.670
So we got a whole panel of glyphs
that we can throw in there.

367
00:17:44.670 --> 00:17:48.294
And a great look at using those tab
stops and how we've got our left,

368
00:17:48.294 --> 00:17:51.570
center, right-aligned tab
stops our decimal tab stops.

369
00:17:51.570 --> 00:17:54.070
And really how easy they
are to work with other

370
00:17:54.070 --> 00:17:55.695
than the fact that they're really small.

371
00:17:55.695 --> 00:17:58.660
[LAUGH] So
break out the magnifying glass for that.

372
00:17:58.660 --> 00:18:01.140
We thank you, Vonne, for
all those fantastic demonstrations.

373
00:18:01.140 --> 00:18:03.420
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

374
00:18:03.420 --> 00:18:05.820
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

375
00:18:05.820 --> 00:18:08.109
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.
>> And we'll see you next time.

376
00:18:08.109 --> 00:18:15.792
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Image Resolution and File Types
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.131 --> 00:00:10.131
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.082 --> 00:00:15.246
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.246 --> 00:00:15.746
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.950 --> 00:00:20.034
And today we're doing
Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

5
00:00:20.034 --> 00:00:22.601
And specifically in this
episode we're gonna be

6
00:00:22.601 --> 00:00:25.300
looking at image resolution
as well as file types.

7
00:00:25.300 --> 00:00:28.650
These are some important concepts when
we're working within Illustrator,

8
00:00:28.650 --> 00:00:30.710
as well as when you're
working with other programs.

9
00:00:30.710 --> 00:00:32.800
So here to help us with
that is Miss Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:32.800 --> 00:00:33.500
How you doing, Vonne?

11
00:00:33.500 --> 00:00:34.620
>> Wonderful.

12
00:00:34.620 --> 00:00:38.760
Excited to talk to you about the world
of image resolution and file types.

13
00:00:38.760 --> 00:00:41.110
This is a core concept.

14
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:42.640
This is like Design 101.

15
00:00:42.640 --> 00:00:47.930
Something that whether you're doing print,
web, video, it goes across the board.

16
00:00:47.930 --> 00:00:50.830
So this is very important to understand

17
00:00:50.830 --> 00:00:55.290
why you want to use a JPEG
versus a gif versus a tif.

18
00:00:55.290 --> 00:00:58.730
We're gonna talk about all that
resolution and what these numbers mean,

19
00:00:58.730 --> 00:01:02.140
and this is again very important for
when you're done.

20
00:01:02.140 --> 00:01:04.490
Where am I going, what is my end result?

21
00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:05.590
Am I designing for print?

22
00:01:05.590 --> 00:01:06.920
Am I designing for web?

23
00:01:06.920 --> 00:01:08.310
Am I designing for both?

24
00:01:08.310 --> 00:01:13.240
And going back to how you actually
build your presentations,

25
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:15.830
your brochures,
whatever medium that you're working with,

26
00:01:15.830 --> 00:01:19.160
it all kinda stems from
knowing the basics.

27
00:01:19.160 --> 00:01:23.650
So I have a handout,
if you wanna say, a guide for

28
00:01:23.650 --> 00:01:27.280
us to go along on our journey
through resolution and file types.

29
00:01:27.280 --> 00:01:30.070
So, you can see our wonderful title.

30
00:01:30.070 --> 00:01:34.460
And the word resolution, so
normally when you think of resolution,

31
00:01:34.460 --> 00:01:37.150
what do you think of when you think
of the word resolution in general?

32
00:01:37.150 --> 00:01:40.727
>> In general,
it's a solution to a problem.

33
00:01:40.727 --> 00:01:43.255
>> [LAUGH] That's an interesting response.

34
00:01:43.255 --> 00:01:46.220
>> [LAUGH] If you take it out of
the world of computers, right?

35
00:01:46.220 --> 00:01:48.750
To resolve something, it's the resolution.

36
00:01:48.750 --> 00:01:50.060
You want to stick with computers?

37
00:01:50.060 --> 00:01:50.942
>> Okay, I'll give you that one.

38
00:01:50.942 --> 00:01:54.450
All right, so let's talk about when you
think of it in the world of computers.

39
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:57.020
>> I always think of mine,
my screen resolution, right?

40
00:01:57.020 --> 00:02:00.440
How detailed or
how many pixels I'm fitting on my screen.

41
00:02:01.570 --> 00:02:06.080
>> That works, and then maybe
when we're talking about images,

42
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:10.840
another concept you wanna say
that comes up when resolution,

43
00:02:10.840 --> 00:02:13.845
I would always get people
that say quality or clarity.

44
00:02:13.845 --> 00:02:18.956
Yeah, cuz it's we talk about TVs and
our images, like high resolution TVs and

45
00:02:18.956 --> 00:02:23.060
you've got these clear thingies and
and pixelly things, right?

46
00:02:23.060 --> 00:02:23.980
>> Right, absolutely.

47
00:02:23.980 --> 00:02:25.860
>> Yeah.
And so the more the better, right?

48
00:02:25.860 --> 00:02:27.000
>> That's what I always thought.

49
00:02:27.000 --> 00:02:32.320
>> Yeah, and that's kind of what in
a general speak people think of,

50
00:02:32.320 --> 00:02:34.285
is resolution equals quality.

51
00:02:34.285 --> 00:02:39.490
And while it's true, when we're
talking in the world of images and

52
00:02:39.490 --> 00:02:43.230
using them within a design area,

53
00:02:43.230 --> 00:02:46.874
in a sense it means something
a little bit different, okay?

54
00:02:46.874 --> 00:02:52.340
So, in this sense resolution
really means pixels per inch.

55
00:02:52.340 --> 00:02:57.030
How many pixels are in an inch,
and what that means for

56
00:02:57.030 --> 00:03:01.435
whether using the medium of web or
print, okay?

57
00:03:01.435 --> 00:03:05.080
Cuz that's probably something where if
you've ever, maybe back in the day,

58
00:03:05.080 --> 00:03:08.652
maybe not as much any more cause,
I mean, who uses printers, all right?

59
00:03:08.652 --> 00:03:10.980
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't have a printer at home.

60
00:03:10.980 --> 00:03:12.940
But you would take a picture and
you'd print it.

61
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:14.900
It might look this big on the screen,
but when you print it,

62
00:03:14.900 --> 00:03:17.250
it looks like this big, right?

63
00:03:17.250 --> 00:03:21.060
>> Yes.
>> Or you put it into a PowerPoint and

64
00:03:21.060 --> 00:03:25.810
it looks all weird, it looks all pixelated
and the quality doesn't look so good.

65
00:03:25.810 --> 00:03:27.110
It comes down to the resolution.

66
00:03:27.110 --> 00:03:31.510
And not just resolution, it also talks
about the total number of pixels and

67
00:03:31.510 --> 00:03:32.520
the image dimensions.

68
00:03:32.520 --> 00:03:35.772
So I'm gonna try to spell it all out for
you and

69
00:03:35.772 --> 00:03:39.600
kind of show you those different things
of, yeah, I know where that happened.

70
00:03:39.600 --> 00:03:41.050
Why that happened.

71
00:03:41.050 --> 00:03:43.050
Now you'll understand why.

72
00:03:43.050 --> 00:03:43.575
>> Awesome-
>> Yes.

73
00:03:43.575 --> 00:03:44.820
>> Looking forward to it.

74
00:03:44.820 --> 00:03:48.680
>> So, you have here,
I've got resolution is pixels per inch.

75
00:03:48.680 --> 00:03:52.600
Sometimes you can also refer to it as dpi,
which is dots per inch.

76
00:03:52.600 --> 00:03:58.140
When you're using dpi,
that technically is reserved for printers.

77
00:03:58.140 --> 00:04:02.590
Printers print in dots of ink and
how many dots are together.

78
00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:05.420
So dpi is really a printer thing, ppi,

79
00:04:05.420 --> 00:04:08.650
pixels per inch,
is when you're talking about images.

80
00:04:08.650 --> 00:04:10.780
Images have pixels, they don't have dots.

81
00:04:10.780 --> 00:04:12.250
But, you know what,
it's such a loose term.

82
00:04:12.250 --> 00:04:14.050
I've heard people say,
I have a 300 dpi image.

83
00:04:14.050 --> 00:04:16.270
That's fine, okay.

84
00:04:16.270 --> 00:04:17.960
>> Right.
>> We're not gonna get that technical,

85
00:04:17.960 --> 00:04:21.082
it all means basically the same thing.

86
00:04:21.082 --> 00:04:26.180
So, but again, like I said, the total
number of pixels that are occupying that

87
00:04:26.180 --> 00:04:28.680
file, that's what is
the most important because

88
00:04:28.680 --> 00:04:33.050
you have to have enough to work with
to get to the place you want to go.

89
00:04:33.050 --> 00:04:38.090
More on that when we get to
image resolution for printing.

90
00:04:38.090 --> 00:04:41.140
And it's really all about knowing the
right file type for the medium, like I've

91
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:44.570
said I think a couple times so far, so
I think we're driving home that point.

92
00:04:44.570 --> 00:04:45.580
[LAUGH] All right, so

93
00:04:45.580 --> 00:04:48.340
let's move on to those different
mediums that we're working in.

94
00:04:48.340 --> 00:04:50.590
Are we working in web, or
are we working in print?

95
00:04:52.020 --> 00:04:54.780
And the kind of baseline,

96
00:04:54.780 --> 00:04:58.660
this is what all designers know,
it's 72 for web, 300 for print.

97
00:04:58.660 --> 00:04:59.800
That's just what it is.

98
00:04:59.800 --> 00:05:03.880
So if you are sending files to
a commercial printer to get your

99
00:05:03.880 --> 00:05:08.160
ad printed in a magazine or just a flyer,

100
00:05:08.160 --> 00:05:12.360
they will require you to have
images of 300 ppi, most places,

101
00:05:12.360 --> 00:05:15.740
always check the specs for wherever your
going, but this is just a general rule.

102
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:16.530
And those color modes.

103
00:05:16.530 --> 00:05:20.350
We talked a lot about color in some
other episodes, RGB versus CMYK.

104
00:05:20.350 --> 00:05:24.710
The red, green, and blue versus the cyan,
magenta, yellow, and black.

105
00:05:24.710 --> 00:05:28.310
So having the images in the right
color modes is important.

106
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:31.685
And then the file types that
are associated with each medium.

107
00:05:31.685 --> 00:05:36.726
JPEG, GIF, PNG, and
SVGs over there on the web side.

108
00:05:36.726 --> 00:05:40.880
EPS, PDF and
TIFF files over there on the print side.

109
00:05:42.080 --> 00:05:46.360
And the most important thing in printing
is making sure you have the right

110
00:05:46.360 --> 00:05:49.799
resolution and
making sure you have the right color mode,

111
00:05:49.799 --> 00:05:54.361
because the whole light versus inks,
and inks don't talk in light numbers,

112
00:05:54.361 --> 00:05:58.042
you have to make sure they're
in ink numbers, that's CMYK.

113
00:05:58.042 --> 00:06:03.079
And then making sure you have
enough pixels within a physical

114
00:06:03.079 --> 00:06:09.100
square inch that will print at a high
enough quality on a piece of a paper,

115
00:06:09.100 --> 00:06:12.590
or whatever device, not device-
>> Medium.

116
00:06:12.590 --> 00:06:13.530
>> Medium, thank you.

117
00:06:13.530 --> 00:06:15.990
Because you can print on plastic,

118
00:06:15.990 --> 00:06:19.730
they actually have synthetic paper
that's not made of paper at all.

119
00:06:19.730 --> 00:06:20.520
>> That's pretty cool.

120
00:06:20.520 --> 00:06:21.583
>> Yeah, it's pretty neat, actually.

121
00:06:21.583 --> 00:06:23.008
[LAUGH] But
that's because I'm a print nerd.

122
00:06:23.008 --> 00:06:26.281
[LAUGH] And then over on the web side,
it's honestly,

123
00:06:26.281 --> 00:06:31.390
if you're talking in realistic terms,
it's not really about the resolution.

124
00:06:31.390 --> 00:06:33.730
It's really about the image dimensions.

125
00:06:33.730 --> 00:06:35.180
How many pixels do you have width and

126
00:06:35.180 --> 00:06:38.380
height, because if you're putting
an image on a website and

127
00:06:38.380 --> 00:06:42.890
the space that you have to occupy
the image is 500 pixels over 300 pixels,

128
00:06:42.890 --> 00:06:47.750
that's the measurement that you're talking
already, that's what really matters.

129
00:06:47.750 --> 00:06:50.800
Because pixels per square inch, we're
not talking about inches on a screen.

130
00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:54.270
We're just talking about actual pixels,
pixel-to-pixels, so

131
00:06:54.270 --> 00:06:55.120
that's what really matters.

132
00:06:55.120 --> 00:06:58.960
So that's why I'm saying image
dimensions in width and height, and

133
00:06:58.960 --> 00:07:03.360
then also making sure you
have the right file type,

134
00:07:03.360 --> 00:07:07.400
because it all comes back to the file
size cuz you want that fast load time.

135
00:07:07.400 --> 00:07:10.400
You want pictures to come up
on your website like that, and

136

00:30:37.145 --> 00:30:41.001
Well, we'll go with 400 cuz that's the
height, but whichever one's is going to,

594
00:30:41.001 --> 00:30:44.300
like if I really wanted to be 500 height,
I would then change to 500.

595
00:30:44.300 --> 00:30:46.530
I would crop out the rest of the width.

596
00:30:46.530 --> 00:30:49.480
Then, you can crop it to the specific
dimensions that you want.

597
00:30:49.480 --> 00:30:52.179
But, if I go here,
this is a 300-by-400 file.

598
00:30:52.179 --> 00:30:55.631
Now, it's gonna be 350 K.

599
00:30:55.631 --> 00:30:57.811
>> Wow.
>> Yeah, that's where it is.

600
00:30:57.811 --> 00:30:58.627
>> Huge difference.

601
00:30:58.627 --> 00:31:02.836
>> That's what makes this, and this
resolution, this resolution can be 72,

602
00:31:02.836 --> 00:31:05.920
this resolution could be 150,
this could be 450.

603
00:31:05.920 --> 00:31:09.115
It doesn't matter if
you're going to screen.

604
00:31:09.115 --> 00:31:13.726
It's pixel to pixel,
it's gonna show up as 300-by-400.

605
00:31:13.726 --> 00:31:18.235
Regards the resolution,
in actuality, is a print thing,

606
00:31:18.235 --> 00:31:24.654
it's not necessarily a web thing, but
in the whole, this is a concept, it is 72.

607
00:31:24.654 --> 00:31:28.445
All right, so there we go and
then that's it.

608
00:31:28.445 --> 00:31:30.940
Now ooh, this is really small,
that's okay.

609
00:31:30.940 --> 00:31:33.257
It's already in RGB color modes for good.

610
00:31:33.257 --> 00:31:36.020
For this, for a website,
I would use a JPEG.

611
00:31:36.020 --> 00:31:39.320
I would not be changing this to a GIF or
a PNG.

612
00:31:39.320 --> 00:31:41.820
I guess I could do a PNG but
I would just still stick with JPEGs.

613
00:31:41.820 --> 00:31:43.110
>> PNG being?

614
00:31:43.110 --> 00:31:44.590
>> Portable network graphics sorry.

615
00:31:44.590 --> 00:31:47.540
>> Yep, yep.
>> Yes, PNG, they also refer to as pings.

616
00:31:47.540 --> 00:31:48.875
Sorry.
>> [LAUGH]

617
00:31:48.875 --> 00:31:51.200
>> And that's what we've got.

618
00:31:51.200 --> 00:31:55.710
That's, I think, everything you can
know about with image resolution and

619
00:31:55.710 --> 00:31:56.390
file formats.

620
00:31:56.390 --> 00:31:57.970
>> That's a great look at it.

621
00:31:57.970 --> 00:31:59.470
A lot of questions that I know I and

622
00:31:59.470 --> 00:32:02.060
maybe some of you out there,
have always wondered about.

623
00:32:02.060 --> 00:32:06.660
Especially when you go to work with one of
these images and you start changing these

624
00:32:06.660 --> 00:32:11.540
numbers and all of a sudden your image
gets crazy pixelated or gets really,

625
00:32:11.540 --> 00:32:14.170
really tiny, like it's now a thumbnail or
something like that.

626
00:32:14.170 --> 00:32:17.460
So we thank you for that, Vaughn,
hope everybody out their enjoyed watching.

627
00:32:17.460 --> 00:32:20.620
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your Mike Rodrick.

628
00:32:20.620 --> 00:32:21.340
>> And I'm Vaughn Smith.

629
00:32:21.340 --> 00:32:24.960
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Images in Illustrator
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.917 --> 00:00:12.549
Hello.

3
00:00:12.549 --> 00:00:16.708
Welcome to another exciting episode here
at ITProTV I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and

4
00:00:16.708 --> 00:00:19.261
today we're doing
Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

5
00:00:19.261 --> 00:00:21.590
And, specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:21.590 --> 00:00:25.730
we're gonna be looking at working
with images within Illustrator.

7
00:00:25.730 --> 00:00:30.420
We've had a couple episodes where we've
talked about file types of images and

8
00:00:30.420 --> 00:00:33.590
resolution for our images, for
both the web and for print.

9
00:00:33.590 --> 00:00:36.670
Now, we've got, now that we know
what we're doing with our images,

10
00:00:36.670 --> 00:00:39.030
need to get them into our
project in Illustrator.

11
00:00:39.030 --> 00:00:40.860
And here to help us with
that is Miss Von Smith.

12
00:00:40.860 --> 00:00:41.700
How you doing, Von?

13
00:00:41.700 --> 00:00:42.780
>> I'm good.

14
00:00:42.780 --> 00:00:45.411
I'm here to talk about images in
Illustrator, just like Mike said.

15
00:00:45.411 --> 00:00:46.271
[LAUGH] And

16
00:00:46.271 --> 00:00:50.670
the one thing you did forget was that
you also understand the color modes.

17
00:00:50.670 --> 00:00:51.270
>> Yes.
>> Yes,

18
00:00:51.270 --> 00:00:53.740
we had a lot of episodes about colors and

19
00:00:53.740 --> 00:00:55.900
the RGB versus
>> CMYK.

20
00:00:55.900 --> 00:00:57.560
JPEG versus a TIFF.

21
00:00:57.560 --> 00:01:01.460
That's the basics of images.

22
00:01:01.460 --> 00:01:07.350
So how do I make my images
get into my brochure or

23
00:01:07.350 --> 00:01:10.050
ad or logo or
whatever I'm doing in Illustrator?

24
00:01:10.050 --> 00:01:12.980
With a chair and
a whip like the old lion tamer.

25
00:01:12.980 --> 00:01:13.538
Get in there.

26
00:01:13.538 --> 00:01:14.543
No?

27
00:01:14.543 --> 00:01:19.310
>> Well no, but good visual.

28
00:01:19.310 --> 00:01:23.680
We will place the images into the cage.

29
00:01:23.680 --> 00:01:24.320
>> There you go-
>> So-

30
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:25.060
>> Okay.

31
00:01:25.060 --> 00:01:25.630
>> Whip and

32
00:01:25.630 --> 00:01:26.336
a chair, so.

33
00:01:26.336 --> 00:01:27.164
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

34
00:01:27.164 --> 00:01:30.780
>> All right, so I've got a file ready for

35
00:01:30.780 --> 00:01:34.300
us that has a little bit of an Overview so

36
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:38.090
we can get the kind of
basics of how do we do it.

37
00:01:38.090 --> 00:01:39.390
I already said place-
>> Mm-hm.

38
00:01:39.390 --> 00:01:41.310
>> We're gonna place images.

39
00:01:41.310 --> 00:01:42.900
And you do that by doing a file place.

40
00:01:42.900 --> 00:01:48.060
But, I'd like to start off also by
saying that this illustrator is not

41
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:56.100
a roster editing program, you don't take
an image and remove a spot off of a shirt.

42
00:01:56.100 --> 00:02:01.397
Or change the eye color of your cats or
what have you making me thinner.

43
00:02:01.397 --> 00:02:05.032
>> [LAUGH] Right, yes,
the nice [SOUND]- that's all in Photoshop.

44
00:02:05.032 --> 00:02:08.580
So photo editing is
done in other programs.

45
00:02:08.580 --> 00:02:12.490
This is where your end
image just goes into it.

46
00:02:12.490 --> 00:02:15.330
So there's a limited amount
of things that you can do

47
00:02:15.330 --> 00:02:19.860
with images in a sense of
editing it To look different.

48
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:25.240
>> So if we're talking about our workflow
then the images would already be prepared

49
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:28.760
for my project by the time
I get Illustrator open.

50
00:02:28.760 --> 00:02:30.310
>> Exactly.
>> Except for maybe some minor.

51
00:02:30.310 --> 00:02:31.150
>> Yeah, I can do some things.

52
00:02:31.150 --> 00:02:34.620
And that's what I'll demonstrate and
I'll show you guys what you can do.

53
00:02:34.620 --> 00:02:38.540
But I just want to show you
what you can't do, okay?

54
00:02:38.540 --> 00:02:41.280
You don't open an image in Illustrator and
start doing stuff.

55
00:02:41.280 --> 00:02:42.460
You can open it.

56
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:44.870
It will allow you to open up a jpeg or

57
00:02:44.870 --> 00:02:48.500
a tiff but that's not the purpose
of the program really.

58
00:02:48.500 --> 00:02:52.210
So what you do is you place it.

59
00:02:52.210 --> 00:02:56.970
And when you place an image It
will grab whatever image and

60
00:02:56.970 --> 00:02:59.120
it goes into your document.

61
00:02:59.120 --> 00:03:04.090
It is important to understand that by
default, when you place a document into

62
00:03:04.090 --> 00:03:08.470
Illustrator it will be
linked to the source file.

63
00:03:08.470 --> 00:03:12.720
Which means if I have my AI
file stored in one folder and

64
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:14.380
my images in another folder.

65
00:03:14.380 --> 00:03:16.680
And for some reason I'm cleaning house,

66
00:03:16.680 --> 00:03:19.850
and I move my pictures
to a different location.

67
00:03:19.850 --> 00:03:21.710
Well, when I go back to my
Illustrator document and

68
00:03:21.710 --> 00:03:22.650
open it up, it's gonna be like.

69
00:03:22.650 --> 00:03:26.330
I don't know where the picture
went because it creates a path

70
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:29.980
specifically to where you told
it where that picture is.

71
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:33.900
And if you move it,
it doesn't update itself by default.

72
00:03:33.900 --> 00:03:34.730
It doesn't understand.

73
00:03:34.730 --> 00:03:39.060
It's like a hard link if you
wanna say to wherever that is.

74
00:03:39.060 --> 00:03:43.710
So just know that that's gonna happen and
just be aware of it, and

75
00:03:43.710 --> 00:03:46.020
then just know how to fix it,
which I'll show.

76
00:03:46.020 --> 00:03:50.390
Because you can go back and relink images.

77
00:03:50.390 --> 00:03:51.790
You're like, I forgot I moved that.

78
00:03:51.790 --> 00:03:54.470
Okay, let me tell you Illustrator.

79
00:03:54.470 --> 00:04:00.150
Where that is right now and why would you
want to have the images linked because

80
00:04:00.150 --> 00:04:06.420
if I have a bunch of pictures that
I'm creating for an advertisement.

81
00:04:06.420 --> 00:04:09.920
If they lived inside of
the illustrator document,

82
00:04:09.920 --> 00:04:12.600
its going to be a really,
really big illustrator file.

83
00:04:12.600 --> 00:04:17.530
So there's a reason why you
might want to keep it linked.

84
00:04:17.530 --> 00:04:18.630
I've already set it.

85
00:04:18.630 --> 00:04:21.990
You can embed a picture into the file.

86
00:04:21.990 --> 00:04:25.920
So, it's like I don't want you to have any
connection, to where the source file is.

87
00:04:25.920 --> 00:04:30.540
I want you to live inside of
the Illustrator document.

88
00:04:30.540 --> 00:04:32.510
That is possible, okay?

89
00:04:32.510 --> 00:04:36.920
I think we've talked about that with
fonts, where if I'm sending you a file and

90
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:39.840
I have Fonts in there,
I don't send you the font files with it.

91
00:04:39.840 --> 00:04:42.970
Then if you don't have the fonts,
it doesn't work.

92
00:04:42.970 --> 00:04:44.430
>> That was going to be my next question.

93
00:04:44.430 --> 00:04:48.150
If I put an image here and
it's linked, and I send you that file,

94
00:04:48.150 --> 00:04:52.780
that means I've also got to send
you the photo itself, as well?

95
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:53.920
>> If it's linked, yes.

96
00:04:53.920 --> 00:04:57.550
>> And the path is not gonna move
depending on where you copy them to your

97
00:04:57.550 --> 00:05:01.180
machine the path might break anyway
even if you've got the picture.

98
00:05:01.180 --> 00:05:03.055
>> Yes, and
that's why they have packaging.

99
00:05:03.055 --> 00:05:04.130
[LAUGH]
>> Ahhh.

100
00:05:04.130 --> 00:05:07.860
>> So there is an actual
command that you can do that.

101
00:05:07.860 --> 00:05:11.470
>> Packs it all up in a nice little bow,
and it says all right,

102
00:05:11.470 --> 00:05:15.330
I'm not doing a link to wherever it is on
your computer, I'm linking within itself.

103
00:05:15.330 --> 00:05:17.700
It's like an internal link,
if you wanna say.

104
00:05:17.700 --> 00:05:18.280
>> Very good.
>> And

105
00:05:18.280 --> 00:05:21.590
that's where I would send you the entire
package, I would ZIP the folder and

106
00:05:21.590 --> 00:05:25.720
send you that, and that gives you
>> All the images, all the fonts, and

107
00:05:25.720 --> 00:05:28.250
everything ready to go for you.

108
00:05:28.250 --> 00:05:32.680
So that's a great point, and yep, and
it's in our little notes right here.

109
00:05:32.680 --> 00:05:35.570
So I have right here package to transport.

110
00:05:35.570 --> 00:05:36.510
>> Ah-ha.

111
00:05:36.510 --> 00:05:40.470
>> So that's what you could do to
keep everything together, okay?

112
00:05:40.470 --> 00:05:43.200
So, reasons why you want to embed,

113
00:05:43.200 --> 00:05:47.650
reasons why don't want to embed Knowing
that it's always linked by default.

114
00:05:47.650 --> 00:05:53.200
You can change that setting and
knowing that packages is there.

115
00:05:53.200 --> 00:05:57.870
I also through in here clipping masks and

116
00:05:57.870 --> 00:06:02.200
effects because those are things that you
can do to change the look and modify,

117
00:06:02.200 --> 00:06:06.010
if you want to say,
your images within Illustrator.

118
00:06:06.010 --> 00:06:09.240
So those are some kinds of fun
things that we'll go over.

119
00:06:09.240 --> 00:06:14.050
And just one other little note,
is when we talk about we know,

120
00:06:14.050 --> 00:06:18.580
we understand why you want to have a 300,
CMYK,

121
00:06:18.580 --> 00:06:25.830
Tiff image if you're doing a final
project for print, publication.

122
00:06:25.830 --> 00:06:29.000
So you know you need to get in that but
it also,

123
00:06:30.020 --> 00:06:34.280
when you export whatever said
project out of Illustrator.

124
00:06:34.280 --> 00:06:37.660
The end result determines
the resolution because if I take and

125
00:06:37.660 --> 00:06:39.250
make an ad for print.

126
00:06:39.250 --> 00:06:42.610
And then, I also want to take the same
version and put it on my website.

127
00:06:42.610 --> 00:06:45.000
Well in Illustrator,
as long as I just go ahead and

128
00:06:45.000 --> 00:06:49.530
export that out as a JPEG
at a 72 RGB resolution.

129
00:06:49.530 --> 00:06:53.880
Then that JPEG becomes
that end resolution, okay?

130
00:06:53.880 --> 00:06:59.350
So, but in reverse,
if I place an image in Illustrator

131
00:06:59.350 --> 00:07:04.640
at a 72 RGB and
it says at a small resolution, and

132
00:07:04.640 --> 00:07:10.880
then I export my Illustrator document
out as a high resolution PDF.

133
00:07:10.880 --> 00:07:15.050
It didn't start as a high resolution, so
it's just gonna do that up sampling and

134
00:07:15.050 --> 00:07:19.230
you could have issues with that way.

135
00:07:19.230 --> 00:07:21.000
So it is okay to go down.

136
00:07:21.000 --> 00:07:24.530
It's not always as good to go up,
if you wanna say.

137
00:07:24.530 --> 00:07:29.000
So that's why you always
wanna start up and go down.

138
00:07:29.000 --> 00:07:29.770
So there's my overview.

139
00:07:29.770 --> 00:07:34.930
I have a little picture of what we were
doing in the image resolution episode of

140
00:07:36.800 --> 00:07:39.560
my little kitties, so
I've got Fuego and Bishop here.

141
00:07:39.560 --> 00:07:41.930
They're the stars of the image shows.

142
00:07:41.930 --> 00:07:45.297
So right now this has
already been placed and

143
00:07:45.297 --> 00:07:48.941
you always wanna look at
your tool options bar.

144
00:07:48.941 --> 00:07:51.274
Just being always aware of your
environment that you're looking at in

145
00:07:51.274 --> 00:07:51.793
Illustrator.

146
00:07:51.793 --> 00:07:55.074
So you can see up here in the tool
options bar that they linked.

147
00:07:55.074 --> 00:07:59.982
File, it shows me the name of the file
that it's linked to, the color mode, and

148
00:07:59.982 --> 00:08:01.100
the resolution.

149
00:08:01.100 --> 00:08:05.510
So, you can see all of that
across the top of where this,

150
00:08:05.510 --> 00:08:09.060
it's just telling you that
this is what it's got.

151
00:08:09.060 --> 00:08:11.270
Okay?
And, now, this 36x369, what?

152
00:08:11.270 --> 00:08:14.350
We'll get more when I place other files,
so you can see the differentiation,

153
00:08:14.350 --> 00:08:16.010
because you're not.

154
00:08:17.410 --> 00:08:21.970
It's that whole concept of that image size
goes down, the resolution goes up and

155
00:08:21.970 --> 00:08:23.150
vice versa.

156
00:08:23.150 --> 00:08:26.400
It's not going to resample
your images in Illustrator.

157
00:08:26.400 --> 00:08:27.810
So that's the key point there.

158
00:08:27.810 --> 00:08:31.740
Okay, and it is a linked file,
now where is this?

159
00:08:31.740 --> 00:08:32.540
That hard link?

160
00:08:32.540 --> 00:08:37.360
If you click that linked
link if you want to say,

161
00:08:37.360 --> 00:08:39.280
in the tool option bar, it shows it.

162
00:08:39.280 --> 00:08:41.730
I actually made this bigger so that you
guys could see it a little bit better.

163
00:08:41.730 --> 00:08:47.820
It's showing me that the location Is
in that folder so it's letting me know.

164
00:08:47.820 --> 00:08:52.470
Okay it's in my images smaller folder,
and it's RGB, and here's the dimensions.

165
00:08:52.470 --> 00:08:56.950
And here's the ending resolution because I

166
00:08:56.950 --> 00:09:01.280
made it smaller within Illustrator, so
the resolution gets jacked up, okay?

167
00:09:01.280 --> 00:09:03.800
So I can do that,
there's also some buttons in here

168
00:09:03.800 --> 00:09:06.790
where if i did have a missing image,
I could relink it.

169
00:09:06.790 --> 00:09:11.460
Maybe I have it placed, but
I wanna link it to a newer version.

170
00:09:11.460 --> 00:09:13.850
Maybe I have a different
photo of Fuego and

171
00:09:13.850 --> 00:09:15.870
Bishop that I wanted to put in
there with a different name.

172
00:09:15.870 --> 00:09:18.300
I can re-link it to something else, okay?

173
00:09:18.300 --> 00:09:21.650
So there's a couple different options
to go to the link Update the link,

174
00:09:21.650 --> 00:09:22.660
edit the original.

175
00:09:22.660 --> 00:09:25.510
That's actually is gonna like
take you out into Photoshop.

176
00:09:25.510 --> 00:09:27.720
So you have some different items there.

177
00:09:27.720 --> 00:09:32.940
And that's like the end results so
how do i get the pictures in my file.

178
00:09:32.940 --> 00:09:35.930
Well, that's where you go to File>Place.

179
00:09:35.930 --> 00:09:39.800
I'm going to place
the images into Illustrator.

180
00:09:39.800 --> 00:09:44.060
I'm in that images smaller folder so
maybe I wanna pull up a couple more.

181
00:09:44.060 --> 00:09:48.450
So maybe I wanna get a picture
of a fellow lounging in the sun.

182
00:09:48.450 --> 00:09:53.190
Notice down here when I click on
the image It does have right there Link

183
00:09:53.190 --> 00:09:55.050
checked on by default.

184
00:09:55.050 --> 00:09:57.120
So that's where if you
didn't want it linked and

185
00:09:57.120 --> 00:09:59.920
embedded right from the get go,
uncheck that.

186
00:09:59.920 --> 00:10:02.920
But that's always on in the beginning,
okay.

187
00:10:02.920 --> 00:10:05.440
We'll come back to
the Show Import Options in a second.

188
00:10:05.440 --> 00:10:09.030
There isn't any import options on a JPG so
I just go to Place.

189
00:10:09.030 --> 00:10:12.490
It goes ahead and loads up my cursor
icon with the of saying okay,

190
00:10:12.490 --> 00:10:13.870
well where do you want to go?

191
00:10:13.870 --> 00:10:16.890
And if I want to go here,
there are to ways you can do this.

192
00:10:16.890 --> 00:10:21.410
You can just click, and
