this wonderful file.

654
00:34:07.360 --> 00:34:10.122
So, didn't wanna go away with that one.

655
00:34:10.122 --> 00:34:12.426
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, this is the file,

656
00:34:12.426 --> 00:34:17.220
let's just get little Fuego back in here
>> So this is my awesome file, I love it.

657
00:34:17.220 --> 00:34:20.070
I'm gonna send it to you,
cuz you wanna use this.

658
00:34:20.070 --> 00:34:21.305
>> I do, I love Fuego.

659
00:34:21.305 --> 00:34:23.820
>> All right, and
I don't wanna miss anything.

660
00:34:23.820 --> 00:34:25.000
I want the fonts.

661
00:34:25.000 --> 00:34:27.500
All I have to do is do a File > Package,
okay?

662
00:34:27.500 --> 00:34:28.930
It's a very quick command.

663
00:34:28.930 --> 00:34:33.870
I mean, it's the concept that takes longer
than actually showing you how to do it.

664
00:34:33.870 --> 00:34:35.232
>> Where am I gonna put this?

665
00:34:35.232 --> 00:34:37.680
It's gonna go on my desktop.

666
00:34:37.680 --> 00:34:43.130
And maybe just for making it quicker,
I'll just put it on the desktop, okay.

667
00:34:43.130 --> 00:34:46.270
And it's copying the links,
it's copying all the fonts,

668
00:34:46.270 --> 00:34:49.440
it's going to create me a report
just letting me know that, hey,

669
00:34:49.440 --> 00:34:55.710
you better have the right options for
your fonts and sending things to people.

670
00:34:55.710 --> 00:34:59.120
And then you click OK, and
it says it's been shown successfully.

671
00:34:59.120 --> 00:35:03.980
And if I show the package, you can
see that on my desktop I have this.

672
00:35:03.980 --> 00:35:06.410
This is what sends to you,
you get the Illustrator file.

673
00:35:06.410 --> 00:35:08.670
You get all the pictures in there.

674
00:35:08.670 --> 00:35:10.770
So all the linked, remember,
there was some embedded.

675
00:35:10.770 --> 00:35:12.250
So you're like,
those aren't all the pictures.

676
00:35:12.250 --> 00:35:13.020
Some I did embed.

677
00:35:13.020 --> 00:35:16.170
And then, all the fonts that
you would need for this file.

678
00:35:16.170 --> 00:35:19.830
You would get the package,
you would open this Illustrator item, and

679
00:35:19.830 --> 00:35:24.570
it would link directly to those
linked items in that folder.

680
00:35:24.570 --> 00:35:25.780
Very, very handy.

681
00:35:25.780 --> 00:35:29.685
I love packaging in Illustrator,
it wasn't always an option, so

682
00:35:29.685 --> 00:35:32.305
when they finally added that,
I was like, yes!

683
00:35:32.305 --> 00:35:32.995
Thank you!

684
00:35:32.995 --> 00:35:34.395
So I was very happy.

685
00:35:34.395 --> 00:35:35.075
>> Very good.

686
00:35:35.075 --> 00:35:37.575
All right, well, now,
another great episode.

687
00:35:37.575 --> 00:35:39.635
>> Yes.
>> And we threw in packaging in there.

688
00:35:39.635 --> 00:35:43.845
Obviously, a very important part of
the whole thing as we get our document or

689
00:35:43.845 --> 00:35:47.565
whatever it is we're working on, ready for
sending to somebody for web or for

690
00:35:47.565 --> 00:35:48.845
printer, what have you.

691
00:35:48.845 --> 00:35:49.785
So we thank you for that Vaughn.

692
00:35:49.785 --> 00:35:52.620
Lot a good look at what
we can do with images.

693
00:35:52.620 --> 00:35:54.640
Really, maybe a little bit limited but

694
00:35:54.640 --> 00:35:55.420
still-
>> A lot.

695
00:35:55.420 --> 00:35:56.290
>> Quite a bit of things, yeah,

696
00:35:56.290 --> 00:35:58.830
that we can do with those
images within Illustrator.

697
00:35:58.830 --> 00:35:59.880
So we appreciate that, Vaughan.

698
00:35:59.880 --> 00:36:01.810
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

699
00:36:01.810 --> 00:36:04.190
Signing off of IT Pro TV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

700
00:36:04.190 --> 00:36:06.753
>> And I'm Vaughan Smith.
>> And we'll see you next time.

701
00:36:06.753 --> 00:36:14.900
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Image Trace
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.567 --> 00:00:14.660
Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode here

3
00:00:14.660 --> 00:00:15.270
at IT ProTV.

4
00:00:15.270 --> 00:00:17.390
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and

5
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:21.120
today we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC
2015 and specifically in

6
00:00:21.120 --> 00:00:25.010
this episode we're actually going
to be going over image trace.

7
00:00:25.010 --> 00:00:29.730
I don't know about you guys out there,
when I was a kid Love to trace pictures,

8
00:00:29.730 --> 00:00:31.540
but I don't think that's
exactly what this means.

9
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:33.800
So, thankfully,
Vaughn is here to help us with that.

10
00:00:33.800 --> 00:00:35.870
Vaughn, you going to help us
out with image trace today?

11
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:38.670
>> I am.
And actually, you introduced it perfectly.

12
00:00:38.670 --> 00:00:39.380
>> Great.
>> That's

13
00:00:39.380 --> 00:00:40.755
exactly what we're going to be doing.

14
00:00:40.755 --> 00:00:43.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're going to be tracing images.

15
00:00:43.670 --> 00:00:48.390
And it's really, we're going to be
taking a raster image that we place

16
00:00:48.390 --> 00:00:52.640
in Illustrator, and
converting it into vector path.

17
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:53.610
>> So we are tracing.

18
00:00:53.610 --> 00:00:54.150
>> Just, remember.

19
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:57.010
We are! Yeah! >> With a little
tracing paper and all of that.

20
00:00:57.010 --> 00:00:57.524
Great.
>> Mm-hm.

21
00:00:57.524 --> 00:00:58.460
Yeah, well we're, you put it and

22
00:00:58.460 --> 00:01:01.890
you have to tape it on the sides so
it doesn't move and all that stuff.

23
00:01:01.890 --> 00:01:04.400
It's really the digital format.

24
00:01:04.400 --> 00:01:06.190
>> Fantastic, let's dive in.

25
00:01:06.190 --> 00:01:11.850
>> So, I've got my handy overview files
that we go over each one of our topics and

26
00:01:11.850 --> 00:01:12.736
it's like wow that's it?

27
00:01:12.736 --> 00:01:16.770
[LAUGH] There's not like a huge amount

28
00:01:16.770 --> 00:01:20.080
to go over in a sense of
the concept of what it means.

29
00:01:20.080 --> 00:01:21.505
It's raster to vector.

30
00:01:21.505 --> 00:01:23.550
>> Mm-hm.
>> You're tracing and making paths.

31
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:30.460
And there are some presets that you have
for how Illustrator finds the tracing.

32
00:01:30.460 --> 00:01:34.210
And where it's actually finding
the paths and making the paths.

33
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:37.360
So you do have those options
that you can modify.

34
00:01:37.360 --> 00:01:40.770
Talking about what it means
when you're done tracing and

35
00:01:40.770 --> 00:01:43.390
now you wanna do more with
it then you expand it.

36
00:01:43.390 --> 00:01:48.800
And I'd like to go over how you
can make swatches out of tracing

37
00:01:48.800 --> 00:01:50.230
images that are in color.

38
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:54.110
So you can kind of actually take
the colors out of the pictures and

39
00:01:54.110 --> 00:01:56.240
do some fun stuff with it, so-
>> Fantastic.

40
00:01:56.240 --> 00:01:56.830
>> That's what we got.

41
00:01:56.830 --> 00:01:58.500
So we're just gonna jump right in.

42
00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:01.690
And a little disclaimer If I
say live trace at any time

43
00:02:01.690 --> 00:02:05.790
throughout this episode that's because
it used to be called live trace.

44
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:07.840
Now they call it image trace so

45
00:02:07.840 --> 00:02:11.510
I'm kind of back of what I
always knew it from the start.

46
00:02:11.510 --> 00:02:15.360
>> Well that's good to know for those of
you who maybe have a little experience in

47
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:19.790
Illustrator, where basically this is what
we used to call Live Trace for the exam

48
00:02:19.790 --> 00:02:22.100
and things like that, though know we'll
need to know it's called Image Trace.

49
00:02:22.100 --> 00:02:22.860
>> All Image Trace.

50
00:02:22.860 --> 00:02:26.770
And it has its own panel that comes
up when you go to the options.

51
00:02:26.770 --> 00:02:28.530
So let me show you.

52
00:02:28.530 --> 00:02:32.660
I've got a couple of art boards here and
I've got a photograph.

53
00:02:32.660 --> 00:02:36.310
I drew these beautiful doodles.

54
00:02:36.310 --> 00:02:40.440
Right here to kinda show you that it's
just something I just took a picture

55
00:02:40.440 --> 00:02:45.370
of and
I wanted to make this into a vector image.

56
00:02:45.370 --> 00:02:47.580
I wanna do something with it all right?

57
00:02:47.580 --> 00:02:49.980
So I've already placed it,
I have it selected.

58
00:02:49.980 --> 00:02:53.610
Now wether it's linked or embedded it
doesn't really matter on that point

59
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:55.910
as long as long as they
rast your file some sort.

60
00:02:55.910 --> 00:02:58.930
And you can see right up at the top
it's got the button right there.

61
00:02:58.930 --> 00:03:04.200
Image trace, okay, so I take it and
you trace it, and poof, you're done.

62
00:03:04.200 --> 00:03:05.280
>> That was it?

63
00:03:05.280 --> 00:03:09.660
>> Yeah, and this one since I had really

64
00:03:09.660 --> 00:03:14.170
defined black lines on a very
solid colored background,

65
00:03:14.170 --> 00:03:18.910
I mean, the default tracing precept for
this was, boom, there you go.

66
00:03:18.910 --> 00:03:24.380
So this was just an example of, if it
works perfectly on the very first time.

67
00:03:24.380 --> 00:03:25.120
Doesn't mean, you know,

68
00:03:25.120 --> 00:03:29.360
that's a trace that you want is like
it's not exactly picking what you want.

69
00:03:29.360 --> 00:03:33.140
>> So like the ideal image
to do an image trace with.

70
00:03:33.140 --> 00:03:38.250
>> Yeah because in the simplest point
is place the file, trace it, expand it.

71
00:03:38.250 --> 00:03:41.510
>> But if I take a photograph it's not
gonna have those same contrasts and

72
00:03:41.510 --> 00:03:42.610
fine lines.

73
00:03:42.610 --> 00:03:45.660
>> Yes because the preset,
it's really just like a black and

74
00:03:45.660 --> 00:03:48.470
white just trace the image and
there you go, okay.

75
00:03:48.470 --> 00:03:51.690
So let's just go over those
presets right up here.

76
00:03:51.690 --> 00:03:55.620
Since we are in the tracing
of the image and

77
00:03:55.620 --> 00:03:57.320
we go into the Presets
that are right there.

78
00:03:57.320 --> 00:03:58.910
You drop it down,

79
00:03:58.910 --> 00:04:04.730
these are all of those options that
they've created for you as just let's go.

80
00:04:04.730 --> 00:04:06.900
If I went into,
now this is not a colored image,

81
00:04:06.900 --> 00:04:10.910
so I'm not going to choose the 13 and
16, I have other examples for that.

82
00:04:10.910 --> 00:04:12.290
Maybe black and white logo.

83
00:04:12.290 --> 00:04:15.480
And you're really just
looking at the traces,

84
00:04:15.480 --> 00:04:17.210
that didn't seem to do anything, did it?

85
00:04:17.210 --> 00:04:17.970
Sketched art.

86
00:04:17.970 --> 00:04:21.590
Okay, you can see that it actually kind of
shifted a little bit, if you're watching

87
00:04:21.590 --> 00:04:25.850
the lines of the hearts and
the doohickeys that are coming off of it.

88
00:04:25.850 --> 00:04:27.800
If I go to a silhouette.

89
00:04:27.800 --> 00:04:29.130
Now that's not gonna work, is it?

90
00:04:29.130 --> 00:04:32.370
The line art.

91
00:04:32.370 --> 00:04:34.210
Sorry my computer's gonna
start thinking of it.

92
00:04:34.210 --> 00:04:35.360
That's okay.

93
00:04:35.360 --> 00:04:37.940
>> A little bit thinner
on the vectors now.

94
00:04:37.940 --> 00:04:38.580
>> Yeah.

95
00:04:38.580 --> 00:04:42.400
It's going through those options that
I'll show you in some other parts, but

96
00:04:42.400 --> 00:04:48.450
these are just again the presets that,
I like the black and white logo.

97
00:04:48.450 --> 00:04:51.840
The shades of gray,
I really don't want the shades of gray.

98
00:04:51.840 --> 00:04:56.470
So that's actually picking up the color
of the paper that was taken the picture.

99
00:04:56.470 --> 00:04:59.740
So I'm just gonna go back to the default
and be like, that works for me.

100
00:04:59.740 --> 00:05:00.370
>> That works best.

101
00:05:00.370 --> 00:05:03.940
Now can you show us that those are truly
vectors and that we can manipulate those?

102
00:05:03.940 --> 00:05:05.330
>> Yes
>> Yeah.

103
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:07.170
>> If we expand, okay?

104
00:05:07.170 --> 00:05:10.400
It's still kind of in
that half limbo world.

105
00:05:10.400 --> 00:05:14.430
I'm still just looking at the and
giving in the tracing results.

106
00:05:14.430 --> 00:05:17.280
It's viewing the trace results.

107
00:05:17.280 --> 00:05:24.230
So, if I viewed the source image,
it's still there-ish.

108
00:05:24.230 --> 00:05:25.210
But it's kind of.

109
00:05:25.210 --> 00:05:27.600
>> It's like it hasn't been finalized yet.

110
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:28.649
You're not committed.

111
00:05:28.649 --> 00:05:32.020
>> That's actually a perfect
description of why I would say expand.

112
00:05:32.020 --> 00:05:36.060
I want to now become actual vector
pass that I can do stuff with.

113
00:05:36.060 --> 00:05:40.630
And the expand button's right there, so
I go ahead and expand and there it is.

114
00:05:40.630 --> 00:05:44.170
It does come in as a group so
it's all these grouped items.

115
00:05:44.170 --> 00:05:47.000
So if you wanted to either
double click to isolate it or

116
00:05:47.000 --> 00:05:49.320
in this case I'm just going
to go ahead and ungroup it.

117
00:05:49.320 --> 00:05:55.920
I'm going to click off it so you can
see that fact everything is now a path.

118
00:05:55.920 --> 00:05:58.810
Now this of course is a compound
path because the hole's knocked

119
00:05:58.810 --> 00:06:02.450
out of it which we talked
about is an advanced path.

120
00:06:02.450 --> 00:06:06.360
Outline or
the dimension of the photograph.

121
00:06:06.360 --> 00:06:09.780
That's something and
just to show you if I change this blue.

122
00:06:09.780 --> 00:06:11.310
Like okay perfect.

123
00:06:11.310 --> 00:06:14.290
And I could take each one of these guys,
maybe I wanna color

124
00:06:14.290 --> 00:06:18.160
these hearts in pink and I wanna make,
I think you get the idea.

125
00:06:18.160 --> 00:06:21.190
If I can just keep on going and
change this,

126
00:06:21.190 --> 00:06:24.950
I can make this different sizes so
and so forth.

127
00:06:24.950 --> 00:06:26.325
I'm getting carried away aren't I?

128
00:06:26.325 --> 00:06:27.400
[LAUGH] I need to stop.

129
00:06:27.400 --> 00:06:28.770
>> But you're having fun.

130
00:06:28.770 --> 00:06:31.780
>> Yes, so it's just like all right,
that's perfect.

131
00:06:31.780 --> 00:06:33.760
I've got this.

132
00:06:33.760 --> 00:06:35.520
I can do whatever I want with it.

133
00:06:35.520 --> 00:06:39.620
Just to kind of throw it into some other
lessons, maybe we'll take all of this.

134
00:06:39.620 --> 00:06:41.475
Remember making pattern swatches?

135
00:06:41.475 --> 00:06:42.430
>> Mm-hm.

136
00:06:42.430 --> 00:06:43.810
>> Back in some of our other lessons.

137
00:06:43.810 --> 00:06:45.190
So I could take this.

138
00:06:45.190 --> 00:06:47.270
Now I've got this little guy here.

139
00:06:47.270 --> 00:06:51.690
Take all that and throw it into the
swatches panel and now I've got a pattern.

140
00:06:51.690 --> 00:06:54.930
I've even just got a little demonstration
down here of this little guy.

141
00:06:54.930 --> 00:06:57.860
And then, ooh,
now I've got some really cool patterns.

142
00:06:57.860 --> 00:07:04.280
Anything you wanna do with paths,
you can do it because it's paths.

143
00:07:04.280 --> 00:07:11.030
Now, I wanted to go to some other
examples just to get into the options,

144
00:07:11.030 --> 00:07:16.290
so here's another drawn image that I
created with a good old permanent marker.

145
00:07:16.290 --> 00:07:17.220
>> I think we recognize that.

146
00:07:17.220 --> 00:07:19.550
We all know that hop along hills, right?

147
00:07:19.550 --> 00:07:22.310
>> It is, yes, you'll see this
demonstration some other places.

148
00:07:22.310 --> 00:07:26.160
It's the inspiration for it, yes.

149
00:07:26.160 --> 00:07:27.817
And, cuz I like bunnies, so.

150
00:07:27.817 --> 00:07:32.610
[LAUGH] So, if I go to the Image Trace,
cuz I had the photo selected and I clicked

151
00:07:32.610 --> 00:07:38.560
the button, the presets are great, but
then coming into the Image Trace panel.

152
00:07:38.560 --> 00:07:41.400
All the options that I can go to.

153
00:07:43.110 --> 00:07:46.630
Get even just more details
than the presets, okay?

154
00:07:48.180 --> 00:07:51.960
If I expand this advance right here
just to you show where the corners are.

155
00:07:51.960 --> 00:07:55.280
I'm not going to go through every
single option here cuz really it's just

156
00:07:55.280 --> 00:07:57.560
pull to the left, pull to the right,
see what it does.

157
00:07:57.560 --> 00:08:01.730
How does it change what you're
trying to get out of it?

158
00:08:01.730 --> 00:08:08.200
But I wanted to point out a few things
because in the default, remember the white

159
00:08:08.200 --> 00:08:13.550
background, it became a result
of our expanded trace.

160
00:08:13.550 --> 00:08:17.080
That's because it was creating fills and
it was doing the fills,

161
00:08:17.080 --> 00:08:19.910
but if you wanted to
take off the fills and

162
00:08:19.910 --> 00:08:24.830
only do the strokes,
in certain traces that might be good.

163
00:08:24.830 --> 00:08:31.920
I don't want the insides of the heart to
be a piece, I want just the outlines.

164
00:08:31.920 --> 00:08:32.680
The strokes.

165
00:08:32.680 --> 00:08:34.520
So you can change that.

166
00:08:34.520 --> 00:08:37.230
Now on this one it doesn't really
necessarily work the best.

167
00:08:37.230 --> 00:08:40.550
But then I can change the thickness.

168
00:08:40.550 --> 00:08:41.450
And now you can say,

169
00:08:41.450 --> 00:08:45.220
it's actually starting to come
around if I'm putting a stroke late.

170
00:08:45.220 --> 00:08:48.510
So it's going to export,
or not export, I'm sorry,

171
00:08:48.510 --> 00:08:53.630
expand out as a stroke,
not a compound path

172
00:08:53.630 --> 00:08:57.630
like the other result happened when we did
the trace of the hearts and everything.

173
00:08:57.630 --> 00:09:00.740
So that could be great if you wanted to.

174
00:09:00.740 --> 00:09:04.820
And how many corners it's gonna have and
if I start changing these options too much

175
00:09:04.820 --> 00:09:08.720
I will say that if you have a very
complex photo to start with,

176
00:09:08.720 --> 00:09:10.850
it will tax out your machine.

177
00:09:10.850 --> 00:09:14.420
And since this little
baby's a little older,

178
00:09:14.420 --> 00:09:16.330
I don't wanna stress her
out too much [LAUGH].

179
00:09:16.330 --> 00:09:20.400
Because then we'll just sit there
spinning with the wheel, okay.

180
00:09:20.400 --> 00:09:23.210
So you could go through all
of these different options,

181
00:09:23.210 --> 00:09:28.265
starting with some of the presets and
go from there to get the exact

182
00:09:28.265 --> 00:09:33.185
result that you want to
have from your image trace.

183
00:09:33.185 --> 00:09:36.185
And for demonstration purposes,
I'll just end with that.

184
00:09:36.185 --> 00:09:37.405
That sounds good.

185
00:09:37.405 --> 00:09:40.735
I'll close the panel cause that's there.

186
00:09:40.735 --> 00:09:44.815
And then I expand it,
to show you that now with this group,

187
00:09:44.815 --> 00:09:49.020
if I ungroup this,
you see how this is This is a stroke.

188
00:09:49.020 --> 00:09:54.350
It's not fill, like the compound
path that was in the other result.

189
00:09:54.350 --> 00:09:58.780
And then I can change it is a stroke,
rather than a closed path.

190
00:09:58.780 --> 00:09:59.830
This is an open path.

191
00:09:59.830 --> 00:10:01.290
The other ones were clothes paths.

192
00:10:01.290 --> 00:10:01.970
Okay, all right.

193
00:10:03.040 --> 00:10:07.670
So let's move on to a photograph
like a color photograph.

194
00:10:07.670 --> 00:10:10.390
They're the stars of the show,
aren't they?

195
00:10:10.390 --> 00:10:11.150
Yes.
Yes.

196
00:10:11.150 --> 00:10:12.210
Little guys.

197
00:10:12.210 --> 00:10:14.960
So, I got my pictures,
I'm going to image trace it.

198
00:10:16.600 --> 00:10:18.300
Well, if I was.

199
00:10:18.300 --> 00:10:22.220
Maybe some crazy pop art thing.

200
00:10:22.220 --> 00:10:25.950
That might be cute, but
I want it to actually have the colors and

201
00:10:25.950 --> 00:10:29.570
maybe look a little bit more like a photo.

202
00:10:29.570 --> 00:10:31.670
So you can go into some of your presets.

203
00:10:31.670 --> 00:10:35.460
If I choose high fidelity photo, we will
spin for a little bit because it's going

204
00:10:35.460 --> 00:10:40.500
to try to create as many colors and
small little paths as possible to

205
00:10:40.500 --> 00:10:45.870
make this as photo like but
yet still have paths going on.

206
00:10:45.870 --> 00:10:50.268
So, just for you know,
don't want to, you know.

207
00:10:50.268 --> 00:10:52.870
>> In our 30 minute episode, we might
not want to wait for it to render.

208
00:10:52.870 --> 00:10:57.005
>> Yeah, we'd have to do a lot of filler
talk in and we don't want to do that.

209
00:10:57.005 --> 00:10:59.760
[LAUGH] But I will go to see
that the six colored ones.

210
00:10:59.760 --> 00:11:03.520
It's looking at it and analyzing all
the picture colors and saying okay,

211
00:11:03.520 --> 00:11:08.610
now what can I make to make six
colors out of this photograph.

212
00:11:08.610 --> 00:11:09.440
There you go.

213
00:11:09.440 --> 00:11:12.800
So it just helps you see the oranges,
you can see the whites and everything.

214
00:11:14.350 --> 00:11:16.160
Maybe with 16 of course i'll make more.

215
00:11:16.160 --> 00:11:20.140
And you can go through the options
there as well, so, see.

216
00:11:20.140 --> 00:11:20.860
See, we gotta make some.

217
00:11:20.860 --> 00:11:21.730
>> Very cool, so yeah.

218
00:11:21.730 --> 00:11:22.320
>> Some filler space.

219
00:11:22.320 --> 00:11:24.860
>> While that's rendering then,
but once that's done,

220
00:11:24.860 --> 00:11:29.470
you could then manipulate those vectors
like we did in our other episodes.

221
00:11:29.470 --> 00:11:33.460
If I needed to tweak something within
that photo without taking over to say,

222
00:11:33.460 --> 00:11:39.075
Photoshop some raster based program and
using my Tools there.

223
00:11:39.075 --> 00:11:41.940
>> Mm-hm, yeah, and
these are now going to be vectors.

224
00:11:41.940 --> 00:11:43.790
It's not going to be raster information.

225
00:11:43.790 --> 00:11:45.180
So I got this-
>> Which also means,

226
00:11:45.180 --> 00:11:47.900
we've talked about scalability
on vector objects, right?

227
00:11:47.900 --> 00:11:50.950
Now if you had to blow
this up to poster size,

228
00:11:50.950 --> 00:11:53.310
you wouldn't lose that detail
like you would with a raster.

229
00:11:53.310 --> 00:11:56.360
Yeah, especially if you were doing
this as a really large format.

230
00:11:56.360 --> 00:11:59.250
Maybe you're putting this as an
advertisement on the side of a building,

231
00:11:59.250 --> 00:12:01.210
something to that effect.

232
00:12:01.210 --> 00:12:05.990
From far away, from the street view,
it probably looks like a photograph.

233
00:12:05.990 --> 00:12:09.390
But if you get up really close to it,
you can actually see the shapes.

234
00:12:09.390 --> 00:12:12.720
And so like here, if I expand it,
it's like, whoa, that's a lot of.

235
00:12:12.720 --> 00:12:18.490
If I zoom, zoom in like every single
little part of the colors has combined

236
00:12:18.490 --> 00:12:22.870
together to make individual little shapes,
they're all kind of put together.

237
00:12:22.870 --> 00:12:25.190
And it's a neat look,
you've seen this look.

238
00:12:25.190 --> 00:12:30.540
I've seen this on commercials and
different advertisements, this is a look.

239
00:12:30.540 --> 00:12:34.460
There's a reason why you probably want
to do that, so if I ungroup this and

240
00:12:34.460 --> 00:12:35.510
this is where.

241
00:12:35.510 --> 00:12:38.860
You know, I can then take this,
and remember from other episodes,

242
00:12:38.860 --> 00:12:43.030
we talked about how you can
select the same fill color and

243
00:12:43.030 --> 00:12:47.110
then I can go ahead and you know, make
this you know, red or something like that.

244
00:12:47.110 --> 00:12:52.200
So now it's just kind of,
that's a little scary, let's not do that.

245
00:12:52.200 --> 00:12:55.830
So I can take that and
manipulate the different colors like and

246
00:12:55.830 --> 00:12:59.770
this is where another thing,
talking about making swatches.

247
00:12:59.770 --> 00:13:02.610
If I have this color
photograph that's all trace,

248
00:13:02.610 --> 00:13:04.870
I got all these images,
or all these, sorry.

249
00:13:04.870 --> 00:13:06.190
It's not images, are they?

250
00:13:06.190 --> 00:13:07.382
They're vector paths.

251
00:13:07.382 --> 00:13:11.820
[LAUGH] So if I take here, select them
all, I can actually move this in.

252
00:13:11.820 --> 00:13:14.400
That's the wrong one I want to do,
that was not what you were supposed to do.

253
00:13:14.400 --> 00:13:15.320
I'm sorry.
You're supposed to make

254
00:13:15.320 --> 00:13:16.710
the color group right here.

255
00:13:16.710 --> 00:13:19.100
If I haven't,
I can make a new color group and

256
00:13:19.100 --> 00:13:24.160
I can actually take the selected art
work and create swatches out of it.

257
00:13:24.160 --> 00:13:28.000
And talking about global swatches,
remember we wanted to change the colors?

258
00:13:28.000 --> 00:13:32.140
That's the whole idea of it's
linked to whatever swatch is there.

259
00:13:32.140 --> 00:13:33.770
So I click OK.

260
00:13:33.770 --> 00:13:39.272
Now, I've got a whole group of
all the colors that are in this

261
00:13:39.272 --> 00:13:44.770
art board with these paths and so
if I wanted to change that color,

262
00:13:44.770 --> 00:13:48.360
if I just change the global swatch and
throw that in there like.

263
00:13:48.360 --> 00:13:53.370
So now everywhere where
that colors lives I can

264
00:13:53.370 --> 00:13:56.120
change from the source
from the global swatch.

265
00:13:56.120 --> 00:13:58.680
You can have a lot of fun.

266
00:13:58.680 --> 00:13:59.530
I love.

267
00:13:59.530 --> 00:14:03.600
I just think it's so much fun and
starting with images that are,

268
00:14:03.600 --> 00:14:07.480
you know line graphics with the black and
white and tracing that in.

269
00:14:07.480 --> 00:14:09.960
You can get some really great results and
then you can modify it.

270
00:14:09.960 --> 00:14:13.370
And then in the next episodes we're
going to talk about live paint.

271
00:14:13.370 --> 00:14:15.670
And that's almost like paint by numbers.

272
00:14:15.670 --> 00:14:16.290
Remember that?

273
00:14:16.290 --> 00:14:19.330
So you take a black and
white line image, you go ahead and

274
00:14:19.330 --> 00:14:20.870
bring it into Illustrator.

275
00:14:20.870 --> 00:14:22.840
You live, sorry, image trace it.

276
00:14:22.840 --> 00:14:23.840
I almost said live trace.

277
00:14:23.840 --> 00:14:26.540
You image trace it and then you go ahead
and throw it into a live paint group and

278
00:14:26.540 --> 00:14:29.060
you can paint it all up and
it's just like poof there you go.

279
00:14:29.060 --> 00:14:31.850
It's awesome
>> Very cool, looking forward to that.

280
00:14:31.850 --> 00:14:35.940
All right, Von, well a great look
at what we can do with image trace.

281
00:14:35.940 --> 00:14:38.900
Taking that raster based Photograph and

282
00:14:38.900 --> 00:14:43.370
then converting it into vectors with
as much or as little detail as we need.

283
00:14:43.370 --> 00:14:46.790
As well as, depending on how much
time you have to let that guy render.

284
00:14:46.790 --> 00:14:47.550
So thank you for that.

285
00:14:47.550 --> 00:14:48.730
Great demonstrations there.

286
00:14:48.730 --> 00:14:49.680
>> Thank you.
>> Hope everybody

287
00:14:49.680 --> 00:14:51.010
out there enjoyed watching.

288
00:14:51.010 --> 00:14:53.510
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm Mike Rodrick.

289
00:14:53.510 --> 00:14:54.825
>> And I'm Von Smith
>> And we'll see you next time.

290
00:14:54.825 --> 00:15:03.904
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Live Paint
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.165 --> 00:00:10.165
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.056 --> 00:00:15.365
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.365 --> 00:00:16.587
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.587 --> 00:00:20.153
Today, we're doing
Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

5
00:00:20.153 --> 00:00:24.820
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be looking at Live Paint.

6
00:00:24.820 --> 00:00:28.424
I don't think we're painting anything
that's alive, but we'll see.

7
00:00:28.424 --> 00:00:30.337
Here to help us with that is Ms.
Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:30.337 --> 00:00:31.206
How are you doing, Vonne?

9
00:00:31.206 --> 00:00:33.549
>> [LAUGH] I'm good,
we're not gonna be painting anything live.

10
00:00:33.549 --> 00:00:36.364
>> [LAUGH] Models come in please, no.

11
00:00:36.364 --> 00:00:38.337
>> No, not like that.

12
00:00:38.337 --> 00:00:39.422
>> Okay.
>> Actually it's gonna be

13
00:00:39.422 --> 00:00:40.299
more like the paint by number.

14
00:00:40.299 --> 00:00:41.043
Remember those?

15
00:00:41.043 --> 00:00:41.838
>> Yes, I do.

16
00:00:41.838 --> 00:00:42.711
>> Fun.
>> I love those.

17
00:00:42.711 --> 00:00:45.752
>> Yes, where all the little colors and
you want this and you want that,

18
00:00:45.752 --> 00:00:47.751
and you paint in a little box and
everything.

19
00:00:47.751 --> 00:00:48.796
>> All that is coming back.

20
00:00:48.796 --> 00:00:51.419
It's like an adult way of relaxation,
right?

21
00:00:51.419 --> 00:00:53.340
So here we go with the Illustrator.

22
00:00:53.340 --> 00:00:56.379
>> Yeah, so it's digital paint by number.

23
00:00:56.379 --> 00:00:57.075
>> All right.

24
00:00:57.075 --> 00:00:59.953
>> So it's just exactly what I said.

25
00:00:59.953 --> 00:01:03.853
These are the spaces I wanted then
just kind of fill them in and

26
00:01:03.853 --> 00:01:05.938
that's really it, honestly.

27
00:01:05.938 --> 00:01:11.136
[LAUGH] So let's get into the overview so
we can just jump right in.

28
00:01:11.136 --> 00:01:16.444
Live Paint,
anything can be a Live Paint group.

29
00:01:16.444 --> 00:01:18.752
And I already said Live Paint group,
right?

30
00:01:18.752 --> 00:01:24.044
It's grouping our paths to create that
skeleton, if you want to say that,

31
00:01:24.044 --> 00:01:29.260
framework, that outline,
we're gonna paint in the different places.

32
00:01:30.420 --> 00:01:35.290
And you know that you have something in a
Live Paint group, one by of course always

33
00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:38.170
looking at the Tool Options Bar,
that we always like to do for everything.

34
00:01:38.170 --> 00:01:40.574
But you'll see this little asterisks or

35
00:01:40.574 --> 00:01:44.755
these little stars in the squares of
the corners of the selected item.

36
00:01:44.755 --> 00:01:45.550
>> Okay.

37
00:01:45.550 --> 00:01:51.120
>> I'll show you guys, but
that's a big indication that you know that

38
00:01:51.120 --> 00:01:56.313
this is the paint group, and
how do you make a Live Paint group?

39
00:01:56.313 --> 00:02:00.454
Two ways, you select the items and you can
either click with a Live Paint bucket.

40
00:02:00.454 --> 00:02:04.093
Because that's where we're gonna be
filling in those little pieces or

41
00:02:04.093 --> 00:02:07.680
you can go to the Object menu, and
go into the make with the Live Paint.

42
00:02:09.960 --> 00:02:15.480
The terminology that we'll be using when
we're in a Live Paint groups is faces and

43
00:02:15.480 --> 00:02:16.044
edges.

44
00:02:16.044 --> 00:02:18.835
Again, that's kind of one of those,
that's a test question maybe.

45
00:02:18.835 --> 00:02:19.709
>> Right, yeah.

46
00:02:19.709 --> 00:02:24.316
>> So you have faces would be
the insides that fills and

47
00:02:24.316 --> 00:02:27.325
the edges would be the outsides.

48
00:02:27.325 --> 00:02:32.307
You can alternate between formatting
the face or the edge by holding either

49
00:02:32.307 --> 00:02:36.576
the alt or the option key when
you're in the Live Paint bucket and

50
00:02:36.576 --> 00:02:40.629
you'll see the indication change
by the mouse cursor icon.

51
00:02:40.629 --> 00:02:44.341
And just like we had in the live trace,
there are a lot of things to expand it,

52
00:02:44.341 --> 00:02:47.067
that's actually taking it
out of the Live Paint group,

53
00:02:47.067 --> 00:02:49.463
wanting to get into
the individual components.

54
00:02:49.463 --> 00:02:54.303
It will expand out the faces and
the edges as separate groups and

55
00:02:54.303 --> 00:02:58.700
there's something in Live Paint
known as Gap options.

56
00:02:58.700 --> 00:03:02.047
So that's the little overview,
let's go ahead and get into this.

57
00:03:02.047 --> 00:03:04.489
I have just a very simple what?

58
00:03:04.489 --> 00:03:05.921
We've got four squares here?

59
00:03:05.921 --> 00:03:09.756
So this is what I want to
become my Live Paint group and

60
00:03:09.756 --> 00:03:13.150
I'm going to pick all
the little pieces out.

61
00:03:13.150 --> 00:03:16.920
So I'm gonna select all of that and
you can see, just by selecting where

62
00:03:16.920 --> 00:03:22.200
the paths are by the blue
outlines of any selected objects.

63
00:03:22.200 --> 00:03:25.690
There's pieces right here that look
like I could fill those things in.

64
00:03:25.690 --> 00:03:28.440
Well there you go,
that's going to be our Live Paint group.

65
00:03:28.440 --> 00:03:33.270
So I've selected them, your Live Paint
bucket is hidden underneath your inside of

66
00:03:33.270 --> 00:03:34.794
the shape builder group.

67
00:03:34.794 --> 00:03:38.780
So there's our Live Paint bucket,
I'm gonna grab that guy.

68
00:03:38.780 --> 00:03:41.450
I'm gonna come over here and
you can see as soon as I hover over it,

69
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:45.860
there will be a little tool tip that says,
click to make a live paint group.

70
00:03:45.860 --> 00:03:46.750
So I'm gonna do that,

71
00:03:46.750 --> 00:03:50.800
I'm gonna go ahead and click, and
now I know this is a Live Paint.

72
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:54.552
And when I hover over it with the Live
Paint bucket, it's actually creating and

73
00:03:54.552 --> 00:03:57.240
highlighting if you wanna say,
it's showing me yep,

74
00:03:57.240 --> 00:04:00.376
I found that I had detected that this
is a place that I could fill in or

75
00:04:00.376 --> 00:04:02.630
I could fill in there or
there or there or there.

76
00:04:02.630 --> 00:04:07.153
So it's almost like the pathfinder where
it's actually finding the paths and

77
00:04:07.153 --> 00:04:10.950
now creating fillable faces
of a Live Paint group.

78
00:04:10.950 --> 00:04:13.710
To show you that asterisk thing I was
talking about, I'm gonna go back to

79
00:04:13.710 --> 00:04:17.450
the black arrow tool and it might be yeah,
I think you can probably see that.

80
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:22.020
You see how it's kinda got a little
asterisk in the square of the selected

81
00:04:22.020 --> 00:04:26.790
item and of course, up here it does
tell me that this is a Live Paint.

82
00:04:26.790 --> 00:04:30.245
So those are our two indications,
I'm gonna go back over to our Live Paint

83
00:04:30.245 --> 00:04:34.001
bucket because that's the tool that we
use to go ahead and fill in those pieces.

84
00:04:34.001 --> 00:04:36.638
And now it's just picking the color or

85
00:04:36.638 --> 00:04:41.205
swatch that you want to use to fill
in with that particular color.

86
00:04:41.205 --> 00:04:45.726
So I'll pick like a purple, and you see
if I start hovering over I want that,

87
00:04:45.726 --> 00:04:49.625
you just click, click, click,
see, paint by number, right?

88
00:04:49.625 --> 00:04:51.612
>> [LAUGH]
>> I want that, and I want that, and

89
00:04:51.612 --> 00:04:52.740
you can just keep on going.

90
00:04:52.740 --> 00:04:57.517
And now you can see that there's
a tiny strip on top of the Live Paint

91
00:04:57.517 --> 00:05:01.460
bucket that has like
three colors in there.

92
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:04.970
This is where if you didn't want to
go over to the Swatches panel, and

93
00:05:04.970 --> 00:05:06.460
pick the color from there.

94
00:05:06.460 --> 00:05:11.357
You can use your keyboard to cycle
through the different swatches that

95
00:05:11.357 --> 00:05:15.184
are on your Swatches panel
in that little indication.

96
00:05:15.184 --> 00:05:19.960
You see the middle one, the middle one
is going to be the one that shows you

97
00:05:19.960 --> 00:05:24.580
what color you will have ready in your
Live Paint bucket to get ahead and

98
00:05:24.580 --> 00:05:26.085
fill into that piece.

99
00:05:26.085 --> 00:05:28.564
>> Interesting and you can even see
it changing in the Swatch panel and

100
00:05:28.564 --> 00:05:29.543
you cycle through those.

101
00:05:29.543 --> 00:05:31.626
>> Yep, that's why I wanted
to bring up both of them.

102
00:05:31.626 --> 00:05:34.690
[LAUGH] And you can use the up and
down and left and right.

103
00:05:34.690 --> 00:05:37.460
And so you can see that it
goes through the down or

104
00:05:37.460 --> 00:05:40.880
up goes through the regular
swatches down into your groups.

105
00:05:40.880 --> 00:05:43.587
And then your left and right,
really just kinda watch.

106
00:05:43.587 --> 00:05:46.044
I don't know which way is faster,

107
00:05:46.044 --> 00:05:50.213
it really depends on how close
together the swatches are.

108
00:05:50.213 --> 00:05:54.968
Like if you're doing a very analogous
color or very monotone, you go ahead and

109
00:05:54.968 --> 00:05:57.777
just use the arrow keys
to maybe switch back and

110
00:05:57.777 --> 00:06:02.250
forth to the shades of blue or
the shades of purple that you want to use.

111
00:06:02.250 --> 00:06:05.396
But if you're going like big jumps
you might wanna just come over to

112
00:06:05.396 --> 00:06:06.417
the Swatches panel.

113
00:06:06.417 --> 00:06:11.572
And so this is a yeah,
don't look at the [LAUGH].

114
00:06:11.572 --> 00:06:14.070
Yeah, I'm just gonna go ahead and
finish this.

115
00:06:14.070 --> 00:06:19.484
So that was all the faces, but
the edges that we talked about,

116
00:06:19.484 --> 00:06:22.624
I want to change the color of those.

117
00:06:22.624 --> 00:06:25.873
So that's what equivilates?

118
00:06:25.873 --> 00:06:28.930
[LAUGH] Equates to what
we think of stroke.

119
00:06:28.930 --> 00:06:31.932
So if I change what I want
my stroke formatting to be,

120
00:06:31.932 --> 00:06:34.131
I'm just gonna go in a different way.

121
00:06:34.131 --> 00:06:39.002
Maybe I'll use this light blue,
maybe I'll make it 10 points to make

122
00:06:39.002 --> 00:06:43.802
it a little more, you can see it better,
that demonstrate it better?

123
00:06:43.802 --> 00:06:49.013
And I go there, if I hover over and
I hold my Shift key, I did the shift.

124
00:06:49.013 --> 00:06:51.176
You know what?
I just realized I did the wrong notes in

125
00:06:51.176 --> 00:06:52.439
our overview, didn't I?

126
00:06:52.439 --> 00:06:54.285
I did, okay.

127
00:06:54.285 --> 00:06:55.480
>> We said the Option Alt key, didn't we?

128
00:06:55.480 --> 00:06:58.211
>> I did,
I realized where I just did that.

129
00:06:58.211 --> 00:07:00.643
Okay, so don't go by the notes, okay?

130
00:07:00.643 --> 00:07:02.041
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

131
00:07:02.041 --> 00:07:03.920
>> I'll edit that in the final version,

132
00:07:03.920 --> 00:07:05.159
but it's the Shift key.

133
00:07:05.159 --> 00:07:07.957
Sorry, I realized I was clicking on it,
that's the wrong one, and

134
00:07:07.957 --> 00:07:11.420
I actually kind of muscle memory,
I went to the shift automatically.

135
00:07:11.420 --> 00:07:15.482
Anyways, you can see if I hold the Shift
key, when I'm using a Live Paint,

136
00:07:15.482 --> 00:07:17.752
it actually turns to a paint brush, see?

137
00:07:17.752 --> 00:07:23.125
Bucket, paintbrush, and
if I start hovering,

138
00:07:23.125 --> 00:07:29.640
now the hovers are pointing
out the found edges of it.

139
00:07:29.640 --> 00:07:33.750
And if I click it, now you could see
there's going to start formatting

140
00:07:33.750 --> 00:07:37.430
the edges of this Live Paint group.

141
00:07:37.430 --> 00:07:42.060
And if I change this stroke color,
maybe change the thickness,

142
00:07:42.060 --> 00:07:44.041
that's a lot, but there.

143
00:07:44.041 --> 00:07:49.009
Now you can really see the difference
there of holding your Shift key

144
00:07:49.009 --> 00:07:53.105
[LAUGH] to get to the formatting
of the edges of a Live Paint

145
00:07:53.105 --> 00:07:56.005
group versus the face with the bucket.

146
00:07:56.005 --> 00:07:57.927
So this is beautiful, isn't it?

147
00:07:57.927 --> 00:08:02.800
[LAUGH] So if I'm done with this, and
you can keep it in a Live Paint group.

148
00:08:02.800 --> 00:08:06.790
Nothing says you have to expand it out.

149
00:08:06.790 --> 00:08:10.901
I can keep it if I want to, but if I wanna
change it more, you can go back to here.

150
00:08:10.901 --> 00:08:14.557
Now there isn't an actual button
across the top in the tool options

151
00:08:14.557 --> 00:08:17.740
bar like you had in the Live Trays or
the image trays.

152
00:08:17.740 --> 00:08:22.300
So if I have here I can
go to the Object menu,

153
00:08:22.300 --> 00:08:26.210
and I can go to Expand and
then I can go there.

154
00:08:26.210 --> 00:08:29.880
Notice that it will expand the fill
in the strokes separately and

155
00:08:29.880 --> 00:08:32.090
this is where you could
change it if you wanted to.

156
00:08:32.090 --> 00:08:36.030
But I'm just gonna go with the defaults,
go to there, it does make it a group.

157
00:08:36.030 --> 00:08:41.002
I'm gonna ungroup this once and click
off to show you that this is one group.

158
00:08:41.002 --> 00:08:45.324
See, these are all the edges,
these are all the faces.

159
00:08:45.324 --> 00:08:49.996
So they're individual groups and then of
course you can ungroup each one of those

160
00:08:49.996 --> 00:08:52.757
from here and
then modify each path from there.

161
00:08:52.757 --> 00:08:56.627
And then that's some kind of crazy
art deco furniture pattern, right?

162
00:08:56.627 --> 00:08:57.544
>> That is, yes.

163
00:08:57.544 --> 00:08:58.402
>> Maybe that's how they do it.

164
00:08:58.402 --> 00:09:00.154
>> [LAUGH]
>> They just start just clicking around

165
00:09:00.154 --> 00:09:02.044
and experimenting and
there we go, we got patterns.

166
00:09:02.044 --> 00:09:04.743
[LAUGH] So that's-
>> We'll see it in a museum pretty

167
00:09:04.743 --> 00:09:05.408
soon, I'm sure.

168
00:09:05.408 --> 00:09:06.558
>> Right?
>> [LAUGH]

169
00:09:06.558 --> 00:09:09.206
>> Perfectly, so that's how you can go

170
00:09:09.206 --> 00:09:14.082
ahead and finished it with the expanding
getting out to the groups.

171
00:09:14.082 --> 00:09:17.640
Now I did mentioned that
we do have Gap options.

172
00:09:17.640 --> 00:09:18.320
Because these are all,

173
00:09:18.320 --> 00:09:21.540
I just made some squares, I made it in
a Live Paint group and that's fine.

174
00:09:21.540 --> 00:09:23.398
Well let me show you another option.

175
00:09:23.398 --> 00:09:29.170
So this was a doodle that I
made with my permanent marker,

176
00:09:29.170 --> 00:09:34.620
and then I took a picture, brought it in,
live image traced it, and expanded it.

177
00:09:34.620 --> 00:09:38.690
So these are actually expanded
regular compound paths that we've got.

178
00:09:38.690 --> 00:09:42.657
But I drew this specifically that
some of them are closed, and

179
00:09:42.657 --> 00:09:44.808
some of them have little spaces.

180
00:09:44.808 --> 00:09:50.910
Small gaps, and
I have like a perimeter of this too.

181
00:09:50.910 --> 00:09:55.085
So if I go ahead and select this,
let's go ahead and let's go the other way.

182
00:09:55.085 --> 00:09:57.090
Let's go to Live Paint, we'll go to Make.

183
00:09:58.550 --> 00:10:02.710
So now I've made this into a Live Paint
group, you can see the little asterisk.

184
00:10:02.710 --> 00:10:07.420
And I come over to my Live Paint bucket,
and maybe I'll go with the pink.

185
00:10:07.420 --> 00:10:13.775
And you can even see from the highlighting
like this one, this one, but if I go here.

186
00:10:13.775 --> 00:10:16.586
Well it's already closing because
I think I have the options on.

187
00:10:16.586 --> 00:10:21.900
But if I didn't have that detected,
it would actually go into the hearts.

188
00:10:21.900 --> 00:10:27.750
So let me show you what I mean,
if I go into the Object menu and

189
00:10:27.750 --> 00:10:31.700
I go into Live Paint,
there are these Gap options.

190
00:10:31.700 --> 00:10:33.460
What are the options that you want to use?

191
00:10:33.460 --> 00:10:35.161
See, I have the Gap Detection on.

192
00:10:35.161 --> 00:10:38.356
I actually forgot to turn
that off before we started.

193
00:10:38.356 --> 00:10:42.562
[LAUGH] But demonstration purposes,
this is all learning experience.

194
00:10:42.562 --> 00:10:45.907
[LAUGH] So if I take
the Gap Detection off and click OK,

195
00:10:45.907 --> 00:10:48.426
now if I go back to my Live Paint bucket.

196
00:10:48.426 --> 00:10:53.340
Now you can see, that's what I was trying
to show from the beginning is that

197
00:10:53.340 --> 00:10:57.474
it's actually filling in that area and
going into the heart and

198
00:10:57.474 --> 00:11:00.220
the circle that I actually want it to not.

199
00:11:00.220 --> 00:11:03.830
>> Because it's seeing that gap and
so that there's really no fill there.

200
00:11:03.830 --> 00:11:04.979
That's part of the background.
>> Yes.

201
00:11:04.979 --> 00:11:05.794
>> In its opinion.

202
00:11:05.794 --> 00:11:07.096
>> Yeah, it's all one compound path.

203
00:11:07.096 --> 00:11:09.745
>> Gotcha.
>> Okay, so that's where if I did,

204
00:11:09.745 --> 00:11:10.596
I just undo.

205
00:11:10.596 --> 00:11:14.344
If I wanted it to have the Gap options on,

206
00:11:14.344 --> 00:11:18.313
like I want you to stop and
make that close,

207
00:11:18.313 --> 00:11:23.962
you turn the Gap Detection on and
it's actually finding it.

208
00:11:23.962 --> 00:11:28.498
You can see right down here,
like it's showing you where it sees,

209
00:11:28.498 --> 00:11:31.160
where the gaps are located.

210
00:11:31.160 --> 00:11:34.300
And you can detect whether you
want small gaps, medium gaps,

211
00:11:35.780 --> 00:11:41.310
basically the space of what it shows as a
gap and where you want the paint to stop.

212
00:11:41.310 --> 00:11:43.620
You could also if you want,
you could close it with a path.

213
00:11:43.620 --> 00:11:45.470
Especially if you just had like lines and

214
00:11:45.470 --> 00:11:47.940
you wanted to close off with
an actual path you could do that.

215
00:11:47.940 --> 00:11:52.162
For this one, I don't really want
it to do that,so if I click OK.

216
00:11:52.162 --> 00:11:56.824
Now back to the Live Paint,
you can see that that closes,

217
00:11:56.824 --> 00:12:01.660
the Gap Detection is on and
then I can go on my merry way.

218
00:12:01.660 --> 00:12:07.010
And start painting all of my different
things because it has detected the spaces.

219
00:12:08.060 --> 00:12:12.962
And now I can do it, and I can expand,
go on, make swatches, modify,

220
00:12:12.962 --> 00:12:14.388
whatever you want.

221
00:12:14.388 --> 00:12:17.300
>> All right, great look Vonne,
at our Live Paint and

222
00:12:17.300 --> 00:12:20.970
taking us back to our childhood
days in the old color by numbers.

223
00:12:20.970 --> 00:12:22.020
We thank you for that.

224
00:12:22.020 --> 00:12:23.890
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

225
00:12:23.890 --> 00:12:26.202
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

226
00:12:26.202 --> 00:12:26.900
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

227
00:12:26.900 --> 00:12:28.863
>> And we'll see you next time.

228
00:12:28.863 --> 00:12:33.460
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Brushes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.979 --> 00:00:15.184
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.184 --> 00:00:16.497
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.497 --> 00:00:21.472
Today, we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC
2015, and specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:21.472 --> 00:00:23.768
we're gonna be taking a look at brushes.

6
00:00:23.768 --> 00:00:27.323
One of the important tools we have
to use within Illustrator and

7
00:00:27.323 --> 00:00:30.160
here to guide us through this is Ms.
Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:30.745
How you doing, Vonne?

9
00:00:30.745 --> 00:00:32.257
>> Great, hello.

10
00:00:32.257 --> 00:00:35.443
The most important thing about brushes,
brushes are fun.

11
00:00:35.443 --> 00:00:38.538
>> [LAUGH]
>> They're just a lot of fun to work with.

12
00:00:38.538 --> 00:00:42.484
And I think I've referred to
Illustrator as a box of crayons before,

13
00:00:42.484 --> 00:00:45.817
all the different colors and
you get the really big box with

14
00:00:45.817 --> 00:00:50.530
all the different flavors in it, flavors,
colors, cuz don't eat the crayons.

15
00:00:50.530 --> 00:00:55.550
But this is one of those crayon
type aspects of Illustrator.

16
00:00:55.550 --> 00:00:59.800
They're just fun and they have a lot of
ones that are already in there for you.

17
00:00:59.800 --> 00:01:02.915
But of course just like swatches or
anything that comes with all

18
00:01:02.915 --> 00:01:06.630
those fantastic libraries that we
talked about the swatch episode.

19
00:01:06.630 --> 00:01:11.588
You can make your own brushes as well and
you can modify the existing ones and

20
00:01:11.588 --> 00:01:12.539
go like that.

21
00:01:12.539 --> 00:01:14.898
Let's dive into some funness.

22
00:01:14.898 --> 00:01:16.299
[LAUGH]
>> Sounds good.

23
00:01:16.299 --> 00:01:17.146
>> Fun with brushes.

24
00:01:17.146 --> 00:01:19.557
>> [LAUGH]
>> [COUGH] So

25
00:01:19.557 --> 00:01:24.617
brushes only apply to
the strokes of any path.

26
00:01:24.617 --> 00:01:27.998
It's not a fill thing,
it's a stroke thing.

27
00:01:27.998 --> 00:01:33.100
And there are different types of brushe,
and it is a panel.

28
00:01:33.100 --> 00:01:35.900
So let's come over to our brushes panel.

29
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:39.846
And I'm actually gonna pull this out cuz
we're probably gonna be demonstrating from

30
00:01:39.846 --> 00:01:42.663
this a couple times, so
you can see this a little bit better.

31
00:01:42.663 --> 00:01:44.004
So with the brushes,

32
00:01:44.004 --> 00:01:48.997
now I have this file with brushes already
in here that I've created a whole bunch

33
00:01:48.997 --> 00:01:53.410
of them because as part of our notes
is that brushes are file specific.

34
00:01:53.410 --> 00:01:55.993
If I did a File > New,
just to do really quickly.

35
00:01:55.993 --> 00:01:59.530
I don't have the same brushes here,
because they are file specific.

36
00:01:59.530 --> 00:02:03.490
Just like we talked about how
swatches were file specific.

37
00:02:03.490 --> 00:02:09.170
So brushes go along that same idea and
of course you can create your own library,

38
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:11.560
and then move them over if you're on CRB,

39
00:02:11.560 --> 00:02:15.770
able to use them in file
to file just like swatches.

40
00:02:15.770 --> 00:02:18.210
Same thing here, and
you also have lots of libraries.

41
00:02:18.210 --> 00:02:22.140
So you have a lot of predetermined
ones that you can use, and

42
00:02:22.140 --> 00:02:26.910
we'll go into making our own and
editing the already existing brushes.

43
00:02:26.910 --> 00:02:30.670
And then going into the Paintbrush
tool because the Paintbrush tool works

44
00:02:30.670 --> 00:02:33.870
by whatever brush you have selected.

45
00:02:33.870 --> 00:02:37.740
Identifying the different types
of brushes that you have.

46
00:02:37.740 --> 00:02:41.324
You have Art, Pattern, Scatter,
Bristle, and Calligraphic.

47
00:02:41.324 --> 00:02:44.202
>> [LAUGH]
>> We were talking about this before

48
00:02:44.202 --> 00:02:45.420
the episode.

49
00:02:45.420 --> 00:02:46.526
That's a hard word to pronounce.

50
00:02:46.526 --> 00:02:51.357
>> It's a hard word to say, cuz you really
want to start it off with calligraphy, but

51
00:02:51.357 --> 00:02:52.839
it's not calligraphy.

52
00:02:52.839 --> 00:02:54.303
>> Yeah, calligraphic.

53
00:02:54.303 --> 00:02:55.120
>> Yeah, it is.

54
00:02:55.120 --> 00:02:56.215
>> We actually looked it up.

55
00:02:56.215 --> 00:02:57.519
>> Yeah, we did.

56
00:02:57.519 --> 00:02:58.221
>> [LAUGH]
>> We had

57
00:02:58.221 --> 00:03:00.468
a look at the pronunciation to make
sure that we were saying it proper.

58
00:03:00.468 --> 00:03:02.644
So we're gonna just go
with calligraphy brushes.

59
00:03:02.644 --> 00:03:04.316
>> There we go.
>> So yes, that's how they are.

60
00:03:04.316 --> 00:03:08.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> How you can identify each one of them.

61
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:10.274
>> Just from the Brushes panel.

62
00:03:10.274 --> 00:03:14.586
You see here in the Brushes, we have
some that are in squares, some of them

63
00:03:14.586 --> 00:03:18.847
that are in long strips, and some of
them that I call on railroad tracks.

64
00:03:18.847 --> 00:03:22.004
So that gives you a visual
indication in the Brushes panel,

65
00:03:22.004 --> 00:03:23.400
like which one is which.

66
00:03:23.400 --> 00:03:27.170
If you have the ones up at
the top that are in squares.

67
00:03:27.170 --> 00:03:32.490
They're either a scatter brush or
a calligraphy brush.

68
00:03:32.490 --> 00:03:35.711
[LAUGH]
>> And how do I know?

69
00:03:35.711 --> 00:03:39.982
Well they look like little pen strokes
like the actual calligraphy brushes,

70
00:03:39.982 --> 00:03:41.300
that's what it shows.

71
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:44.564
And if you actually hover over it,
it's gonna tell you that it's like

72
00:03:44.564 --> 00:03:50.720
the different versions and
types of calligraphy brushes.

73
00:03:50.720 --> 00:03:53.497
And then when we apply you can
really see the difference.

74
00:03:53.497 --> 00:03:58.300
And these right here, they just look like
little items that are going to scatter.

75
00:03:58.300 --> 00:04:00.850
So a scatter brush,
kinda what's you thinking?

76
00:04:00.850 --> 00:04:02.790
it's gonna scatter all the every
place with this calligraphy,

77
00:04:02.790 --> 00:04:06.040
it's gonna be like actual
pen that you're using.

78
00:04:06.040 --> 00:04:11.290
These long one, if you look at this one
here or that my zoom is actually too big.

79
00:04:11.290 --> 00:04:15.945
So those are going to be art brushes.

80
00:04:15.945 --> 00:04:18.140
Long strips, that's an art brush.

81
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:22.009
This guy with a little paintbrush
that is a bristle brush.

82
00:04:23.180 --> 00:04:25.410
And then the one's at the train
tracks down at the bottom,

83
00:04:25.410 --> 00:04:31.010
those are pattern brushes and I've got a
couple different ones to give you options.

84
00:04:31.010 --> 00:04:35.330
You see how in these ones you have
like the white hands versus the black

85
00:04:35.330 --> 00:04:36.410
hand in there?

86
00:04:36.410 --> 00:04:41.080
It's because it's showing how if it's
a closed path how the corners will look

87
00:04:41.080 --> 00:04:46.340
different than the straight path,
the in between parts.

88
00:04:46.340 --> 00:04:49.340
And you have one here where it
has a couple different ones and

89
00:04:49.340 --> 00:04:50.355
then you got this guy.

90
00:04:50.355 --> 00:04:55.400
That's what's it's going to look
like applied to an open path.

91
00:04:55.400 --> 00:04:59.660
So the different boxes on
the train track as I call

92
00:04:59.660 --> 00:05:02.390
it indicates what it's going to apply to.

93
00:05:03.950 --> 00:05:09.120
So this is a square that has a scatter
brush that's already applied,

94
00:05:09.120 --> 00:05:11.760
you can see that it's highlighting
right over here that yep,

95
00:05:11.760 --> 00:05:13.620
that's the brush that you're using.

96
00:05:13.620 --> 00:05:17.720
So if I wanted to take this circle and

97
00:05:17.720 --> 00:05:21.190
I wanted to apply a brush to it,
like change the stroke.

98
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:24.260
I can click over here and
I can start clicking through.

99
00:05:24.260 --> 00:05:30.748
See how these all scatter versus this art
brush that just kind of falls along that,

100
00:05:30.748 --> 00:05:34.619
that looks a little strange or
my bristle brush.

101
00:05:34.619 --> 00:05:36.593
So you can see the idea here,

102
00:05:36.593 --> 00:05:41.790
of it's just applying whatever type of
brush to that path and changing it.

103
00:05:41.790 --> 00:05:43.470
So there's no white hands in here,

104
00:05:43.470 --> 00:05:48.500
because there's no corners, and
it's just different variations.

105
00:05:48.500 --> 00:05:53.120
So let me just grab this, all of these
guys, and throw on this pattern brush.

106
00:05:53.120 --> 00:05:55.420
See, there's where you can really
I got a little square in there.

107
00:05:55.420 --> 00:05:56.780
Didn't realize it was there,
okay, there we go.

108
00:05:56.780 --> 00:05:57.677
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

109
00:05:57.677 --> 00:06:02.610
you can see that the Pattern
brush is really changing that and

110
00:06:02.610 --> 00:06:07.458
if I apply, say,
like an Art brush to this one right there.

111
00:06:07.458 --> 00:06:15.524
See, Art brushes they look different
on a closed path versus an open path.

112
00:06:15.524 --> 00:06:19.886
And the same with your
Pattern brushes you can see.

113
00:06:19.886 --> 00:06:22.330
Here, let me bump up the stroke
on this one a little bit.

114
00:06:22.330 --> 00:06:27.490
So you can see there's a corner, and
there's that end of that pattern.

115
00:06:27.490 --> 00:06:31.680
It's a lot of fun,
how you can go ahead and apply the brush.

116
00:06:31.680 --> 00:06:33.766
These are all very straight, but

117

if you have curves it's gonna change how

00:18:59.270 --> 00:19:00.169
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

342
00:19:00.169 --> 00:19:02.111
>> And we'll see you next time.

343
00:19:02.111 --> 00:19:06.910
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Symbols
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.075 --> 00:00:10.075
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.136 --> 00:00:15.456
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.456 --> 00:00:20.489
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:20.489 --> 00:00:24.450
And specifically in this episode
we're gonna be looking at symbols.

5
00:00:24.450 --> 00:00:27.880
Notice that symbols with an s,
not cymbals with a c.

6
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:30.880
I was getting excited,
thought we were breaking out the drum kit.

7
00:00:30.880 --> 00:00:31.700
I was wrong.

8
00:00:31.700 --> 00:00:34.858
So here to help us with symbols
with an s is Ms Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:34.858 --> 00:00:35.942
How you doing, Vonne?

10
00:00:35.942 --> 00:00:37.086
>> Crash!

11
00:00:37.086 --> 00:00:39.227
[LAUGHS] Don't let one fly out that way.

12
00:00:39.227 --> 00:00:40.067
>> That's right.

13
00:00:40.067 --> 00:00:44.294
>> So we're not gonna try to lose any
symbols in this episode we're gonna talk

14
00:00:44.294 --> 00:00:48.060
about actually adding symbols
into our Illustrator documents.

15
00:00:48.060 --> 00:00:50.740
So [LAUGH] thank you for
that fun little introduction.

16
00:00:50.740 --> 00:00:52.683
I was in band, so-
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I know, I know.

17
00:00:52.683 --> 00:00:54.308
That's why I thought we were
breaking out the crash cymbals.

18
00:00:54.308 --> 00:00:55.602
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

19
00:00:55.602 --> 00:00:57.862
[LAUGH] Yeah, I wasn't a cool drummer-
>> No?

20
00:00:57.862 --> 00:00:58.998
>> So I played flute.

21
00:00:58.998 --> 00:01:00.594
>> Okay.
>> Yeah, so.

22
00:01:00.594 --> 00:01:03.570
[LAUGH] But yes,
we're not going to be making music,

23
00:01:03.570 --> 00:01:05.200
we're going to be making graphics!

24
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:08.600
So symbols, what are they?

25
00:01:08.600 --> 00:01:13.930
Well, they're just instances, that's
the one thing that comes to my mind.

26
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:16.980
And back in the day when using Flash,

27
00:01:16.980 --> 00:01:18.705
do you remember when we would
teach Flash back in the day?

28
00:01:18.705 --> 00:01:20.160
>> Mm-hm.

29
00:01:20.160 --> 00:01:24.000
Flash was all about symbols, and
the different types of symbols.

30
00:01:24.000 --> 00:01:27.371
And you could have graphic symbols,
you could have movie clip symbols, and

31
00:01:27.371 --> 00:01:30.543
you could have another type of symbol
that I can't remember right now.

32
00:01:30.543 --> 00:01:32.730
But since we're not teaching Flash,
we're okay.

33
00:01:33.753 --> 00:01:35.205
But that carryover of,

34
00:01:35.205 --> 00:01:41.405
there are different types of symbols
as a symbol and how you make instances.

35
00:01:41.405 --> 00:01:43.655
You will see that when we
actually create our own symbols.

36
00:01:43.655 --> 00:01:46.930
It'll say, do you want it to be
a graphic symbol or a movie clip symbol?

37
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:51.210
That would only make a difference
if you were going over into Flash.

38
00:01:51.210 --> 00:01:55.667
So it's still there, but
since we won't be going in that direction,

39
00:01:55.667 --> 00:01:58.321
I just thought I'd throw that out there.

40
00:01:58.321 --> 00:02:04.070
And again that's where my brain goes to
when I talk about symbol instances, okay?

41
00:02:04.070 --> 00:02:07.490
And it's really just like clip-art,
kind of.

42
00:02:07.490 --> 00:02:12.690
It's created graphics,
like vector graphics, that you can

43
00:02:12.690 --> 00:02:17.800
drag out from the Symbols panel, and
when you place it into your document,

44
00:02:17.800 --> 00:02:22.535
it creates instances of that symbol that
are all linked to that source, okay?

45
00:02:22.535 --> 00:02:25.570
It's the same as global swatches or
stuff like that.

46
00:02:25.570 --> 00:02:30.400
You can go to the source of what the
symbol looks like, edit the symbol, and

47
00:02:30.400 --> 00:02:33.490
any instance of that symbol is going to
take on whatever formats that you do,

48
00:02:33.490 --> 00:02:35.850
whether you change colors, or
sizes or things like that.

49
00:02:37.540 --> 00:02:41.730
And if you didn't want that symbol
to be linked to its source,

50
00:02:41.730 --> 00:02:42.910
you can always break the link.

51
00:02:42.910 --> 00:02:45.050
It's kind of like nope,
I don't wanna be connected to you,

52
00:02:45.050 --> 00:02:47.130
mom, I wanna go out on my own.

53
00:02:47.130 --> 00:02:50.694
So you could do that, so
you could break your link and

54
00:02:50.694 --> 00:02:56.280
then it becomes its own entity,
its own vector graphic shape, path.

55
00:02:56.280 --> 00:03:00.090
And then you do have lots of
pre-made symbols that come with

56
00:03:00.090 --> 00:03:02.370
Illustrator in the symbols libraries.

57
00:03:02.370 --> 00:03:03.360
You can make your own.

58
00:03:03.360 --> 00:03:06.530
We'll talk about the 9-point scaling,
what that means.

59
00:03:06.530 --> 00:03:10.620
And then talk about the fun little tool
called the Symbol Sprayer, okay, and

60
00:03:10.620 --> 00:03:14.110
it basically sprays like spray paint,
right, like a spray painter.

61
00:03:14.110 --> 00:03:15.270
And whatever symbol you have, and

62
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:19.290
there's some really cool little editing
tools that you can do that's kind of fun.

63
00:03:19.290 --> 00:03:25.090
So let's get started because I do
have some examples right here.

64
00:03:25.090 --> 00:03:28.355
Some basic,
this is just a regular star, and

65
00:03:28.355 --> 00:03:31.635
this is actually this was,
[LAUGH] actually took this,

66
00:03:31.635 --> 00:03:34.785
if you're looking at the brushes episodes,
that looks familiar, doesn't it?

67
00:03:34.785 --> 00:03:37.585
>> Yes, it does.
>> I actually just took the brush out.

68
00:03:37.585 --> 00:03:40.967
I just took this and kinda dragged it
out there and it just becomes a path.

69
00:03:40.967 --> 00:03:43.715
You remember, because of how we
can make a brush, which you just,

70
00:03:43.715 --> 00:03:46.555
we made a star, I think, dragged into
the Brushes panel, the same thing.

71
00:03:46.555 --> 00:03:50.040
You can take the brush out and
it's just its thing.

72
00:03:50.040 --> 00:03:50.990
>> That can be handy.

73
00:03:50.990 --> 00:03:51.610
>> Yeah, it's neat.

74
00:03:51.610 --> 00:03:53.888
So that's what I did.
I took it out, and then I ungrouped it,

75
00:03:53.888 --> 00:03:55.596
and then changed the color, okay?

76
00:03:55.596 --> 00:03:59.190
[LAUGH] In case you were wondering and
picked up on that, all right.

77
00:03:59.190 --> 00:04:03.910
These are things that we're gonna use
to create or make our own symbols.

78
00:04:03.910 --> 00:04:09.800
I'd like to start with let's just apply or
add symbols into our document.

79
00:04:09.800 --> 00:04:15.390
So we do have a Symbols panel right here,
and I have a couple.

80
00:04:15.390 --> 00:04:20.188
And if I wanted to add that
cool little pink flower,

81
00:04:20.188 --> 00:04:24.326
gerba, gerbaba, I'm not even gonna try.

82
00:04:24.326 --> 00:04:27.840
All right, we're just gonna,
[LAUGH] let's move on.

83
00:04:27.840 --> 00:04:30.330
We're just gonna move on to taking this,
and

84
00:04:30.330 --> 00:04:36.820
you can see that I have added
this symbol to my document.

85
00:04:36.820 --> 00:04:41.460
And up here you can see that in the Tool
Options bar, because we always know to go

86
00:04:41.460 --> 00:04:47.360
there, you have your instance of,
you can see instance of our flower.

87
00:04:47.360 --> 00:04:49.680
And [LAUGH] it's telling us there,
see you can Edit,

88
00:04:49.680 --> 00:04:53.300
you can Break, you can Reset or
you can Replace, so different things.

89
00:04:53.300 --> 00:04:54.440
So if I wanted another one,

90
00:04:54.440 --> 00:04:58.820
I could just drag another instance
out of the Symbols panel or

91
00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:03.300
I could just Alt+drag and duplicate
it just like I would anything else.

92
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:07.386
And I can change, I can stretch
this one out, make this one bigger,

93
00:05:07.386 --> 00:05:08.832
make that one smaller.

94
00:05:08.832 --> 00:05:14.240
But they're all connected to
the same symbol source, okay?

95
00:05:14.240 --> 00:05:19.530
So if I ever wanted to change
some colors of the petals, right?

96
00:05:19.530 --> 00:05:22.679
I can double-click and it's actually
letting me know, because I'm kind of

97
00:05:22.679 --> 00:05:25.634
getting into isolation mode, like I
would with a group or a clippy mask or

98
00:05:25.634 --> 00:05:29.530
anything like that, it's telling us, hey,
you're editing the symbol definition.

99
00:05:29.530 --> 00:05:31.630
It's gonna apply for
everybody, you cool with that?

100
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:32.560
Yep, I'm good.

101
00:05:32.560 --> 00:05:36.140
So you click OK, and
now I come into here and

102
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:39.190
it's showing me that I am
in that isolation mode.

103
00:05:39.190 --> 00:05:43.555
I just zoomed in and I could go into,
I could either, I'm not gonna ungroup.

104
00:05:43.555 --> 00:05:45.730
I'm just gonna double-click one more time.

105
00:05:45.730 --> 00:05:51.570
And maybe I'll go ahead and
select the same fill color here and

106
00:05:51.570 --> 00:05:56.690
change these to purple or something,
something quick so you can see this.

107
00:05:56.690 --> 00:06:01.530
And if I now double-click out here
on the ethernet, if you wanna say,

108
00:06:01.530 --> 00:06:07.470
to go ahead and get out, or come up here,
back all the way out and zoom out, you can

109
00:06:07.470 --> 00:06:12.790
see that, yep, every single one of those
instances of that symbol has been changed.

110
00:06:12.790 --> 00:06:13.460
>> Sure enough.

111
00:06:13.460 --> 00:06:14.628
>> So connected to the source.

112
00:06:14.628 --> 00:06:19.878
And so it's got some great flexibility and
reasons why you'd want to keep

113
00:06:19.878 --> 00:06:25.818
them all linked, but maybe I didn't want
this guy to be the same as everybody else.

114
00:06:25.818 --> 00:06:29.929
I wanna break out on my own so
you could take that, any instance,

115
00:06:29.929 --> 00:06:33.770
and you can break the link,
and now it's just an object.

116
00:06:33.770 --> 00:06:37.410
It's just its own entity,
so if I go into here and

117
00:06:37.410 --> 00:06:41.390
start changing the different things there,
and I could go ahead and

118
00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:44.634
select the same fill color there,
change that.

119
00:06:45.730 --> 00:06:48.320
Okay, you can see that double-clicking,
get out.

120
00:06:48.320 --> 00:06:48.980
There we go, get out.

121
00:06:50.060 --> 00:06:54.820
No change, now maybe I want this to
become its own symbol, right, and

122
00:06:54.820 --> 00:06:57.330
make ones that are connected
to the blue ones.

123
00:06:57.330 --> 00:07:00.650
Just like anything else,
I can take this, for our brushes,

124
00:07:00.650 --> 00:07:04.375
our swatches, drag and
drop right into the symbols library.

125
00:07:04.375 --> 00:07:09.389
And this is where it will let me know
when I'm making my own symbol from

126
00:07:09.389 --> 00:07:16.270
from anything, do you want it to be, what
type of symbol, movie clip or graphic?

127
00:07:16.270 --> 00:07:18.593
Again, if you're not worried
about going to Flash,

128
00:07:18.593 --> 00:07:20.459
then I wouldn't worry about that either.

129
00:07:20.459 --> 00:07:22.562
There is something called
a 9-point scaling, but

130
00:07:22.562 --> 00:07:24.198
I'll show you that in another example.

131
00:07:24.198 --> 00:07:27.536
You can name it blue guy.

132
00:07:27.536 --> 00:07:34.730
[LAUGH] And you click OK and so now I
have my own version of that same symbol.

133
00:07:34.730 --> 00:07:37.130
And so then I can have

134
00:07:37.130 --> 00:07:41.660
a linked version of all these
instances of now with this as symbol.

135
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:43.537
>> Neat.
>> Yeah, and it's fun.

136
00:07:43.537 --> 00:07:47.033
So we can go through and find all
sorts of symbols already created for

137
00:07:47.033 --> 00:07:50.590
us in our symbols library,
bottom right, that's the other right,

138
00:07:50.590 --> 00:07:52.261
that's the left [LAUGH] corner.

139
00:07:52.261 --> 00:07:54.822
>> [LAUGH]
>> Of any panel that gets you into

140
00:07:54.822 --> 00:07:59.806
the different types There's some 3D
symbols that might be kinda fun, like,

141
00:07:59.806 --> 00:08:02.500
ooh, let's get this guy out there.

142
00:08:02.500 --> 00:08:05.275
Okay, that's a, yeah,
little keyboard symbol.

143
00:08:05.275 --> 00:08:09.700
[LAUGH] Which actually you don't
have a five on a percentage, but

144
00:08:09.700 --> 00:08:10.945
some weird version.

145
00:08:10.945 --> 00:08:15.610
[LAUGH] So I can go ahead and add any
of the symbols out here that I want.

146
00:08:15.610 --> 00:08:18.670
Notice that from the library it's
going into my symbols panel.

147
00:08:18.670 --> 00:08:20.650
And we can go in and

148
00:08:20.650 --> 00:08:25.960
do the same modifications of the instances
like we did with the flowers.

149
00:08:25.960 --> 00:08:29.340
Okay?
So I would like to maybe add a few more

150
00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:34.752
flowers for a specific reason,
just because I like flowers.

151
00:08:34.752 --> 00:08:39.132
Okay, [LAUGH] so I just wanted more cuz
I wanna get when we get into symbols

152
00:08:39.132 --> 00:08:43.658
sprayer, I just want, I want to use
the white one because I like the things

153
00:08:43.658 --> 00:08:47.270
that it can demonstrate with
the symbols sprayer,okay.

154
00:08:47.270 --> 00:08:50.290
So we know that we can make our,

155
00:08:50.290 --> 00:08:54.680
I can make a symbol out of anything
that I have on my document.

156
00:08:54.680 --> 00:08:56.840
So I can make the star symbol.

157
00:08:56.840 --> 00:08:58.370
I can even make images.

158
00:08:58.370 --> 00:09:02.930
Images can be created into a symbol but

159
00:09:02.930 --> 00:09:06.170
I will let you know that it's saying,
wait, what?

160
00:09:06.170 --> 00:09:07.720
No, it can't be linked, okay?

161
00:09:07.720 --> 00:09:11.100
I did that on purpose to show you that I
started to drag it into the symbols lib or

162
00:09:11.100 --> 00:09:12.400
the symbols panel.

163
00:09:12.400 --> 00:09:13.740
It's like, wait, nope.

164
00:09:13.740 --> 00:09:14.480
It cannot be linked.

165
00:09:14.480 --> 00:09:17.172
So you would have to embed any image.

166
00:09:17.172 --> 00:09:18.232
>> Okay.

167
00:09:18.232 --> 00:09:21.760
>> Before you make it into a symbol
in case you're wondering about that.

168
00:09:21.760 --> 00:09:23.860
But it did actually let us know that.

169
00:09:23.860 --> 00:09:28.480
All right, the one that I wanted to
show you here is the banner one to make

170
00:09:28.480 --> 00:09:35.640
a symbol out of, so we can show you
the 9-point scaling part, okay?

171
00:09:35.640 --> 00:09:39.680
So I'm going to, before we start,
I'm gonna make a duplicate of this.

172
00:09:39.680 --> 00:09:40.870
I just Alt+drag.

173
00:09:40.870 --> 00:09:42.120
So here's one.

174
00:09:42.120 --> 00:09:46.210
I'm going to take these mixed objects and
I'm going to make it into a symbol.

175
00:09:46.210 --> 00:09:48.010
And I'm not going to scale this one.

176
00:09:48.010 --> 00:09:50.965
And we'll say like, no scale.

177
00:09:50.965 --> 00:09:52.792
Let's spell that right.

178
00:09:52.792 --> 00:09:57.410
Okay so that is one that does
not have the 9-point scaling.

179
00:09:57.410 --> 00:10:01.790
I'll take this one, make it a symbol,
dragging it in there.

180
00:10:01.790 --> 00:10:05.540
And I will enable the 9-slice.

181
00:10:05.540 --> 00:10:07.076
I think it was saying points,
wasn't I saying, okay.

182
00:10:07.076 --> 00:10:08.192
Sorry it's slice.

183
00:10:08.192 --> 00:10:10.840
[LAUGH] 9-slice scaling.

184
00:10:10.840 --> 00:10:12.440
Okay, just remember the 9 in there.

185
00:10:12.440 --> 00:10:13.467
So we'll click OK.

186
00:10:13.467 --> 00:10:18.688
So two symbols with
different options on it.

187
00:10:18.688 --> 00:10:23.060
I'm gonna take this one
which is the no scale.

188
00:10:23.060 --> 00:10:24.780
I don't think I named the other one but
that's okay.

189
00:10:24.780 --> 00:10:28.720
No scale, and
I'm going to maybe squash this down here.

190
00:10:28.720 --> 00:10:30.250
I'm gonna stretch it out.

191
00:10:30.250 --> 00:10:34.830
And so everything is scaling the same way.

192
00:10:34.830 --> 00:10:38.020
The little, what do you call those,
little flags?

193
00:10:38.020 --> 00:10:38.678
>> Mm-hm
>> Yes,

194
00:10:38.678 --> 00:10:43.378
the little flags in the end of the banner,
they're all scaling all the same, okay.

195
00:10:43.378 --> 00:10:46.720
This one if I start changing it

196
00:10:46.720 --> 00:10:52.080
you see how the flags are not
scaling the same way right?

197
00:10:52.080 --> 00:10:53.250
>> Really didn't squish.

198
00:10:53.250 --> 00:10:59.250
>> Yeah, they didn't squish,
yeah, because of the segments or

199
00:10:59.250 --> 00:11:03.870
quadrants you might want to say
from that 9-slice scaling option.

200
00:11:03.870 --> 00:11:07.750
So let's go in to editing
that scaling symbol, okay.

201
00:11:07.750 --> 00:11:12.510
So you can see that right here It's
actually kinda divided it up into

202
00:11:12.510 --> 00:11:19.170
the different places that is allowing
things to not scale, and things to scale.

203
00:11:19.170 --> 00:11:22.480
So, anything in this rectangle right here,

204
00:11:22.480 --> 00:11:27.900
that will be allowed to scale and
everything outside it, it will not, okay?

205
00:11:27.900 --> 00:11:30.790
And so that's where, here let me,
let me get out of this window just to

206
00:11:30.790 --> 00:11:34.028
show you the difference of this one,
which is the no scale.

207
00:11:34.028 --> 00:11:37.483
You see that there's none,
there's no dotted lines.

208
00:11:37.483 --> 00:11:38.175
>> No guides.

209
00:11:38.175 --> 00:11:39.371
>> Exactly, and there's no quadrants.

210
00:11:39.371 --> 00:11:41.770
So it's saying everything is scaled.

211
00:11:42.960 --> 00:11:45.590
And by the way I am double
clicking from the symbols library,

212
00:11:45.590 --> 00:11:48.770
because that's the other way that
you can get into editing a symbol.

213
00:11:48.770 --> 00:11:53.270
It's just go by double clicking to
the icon and the symbols panel.

214
00:11:53.270 --> 00:11:57.800
Rather than the instance on the page,
document in illustrator.

215
00:11:57.800 --> 00:12:00.340
So just wanted to point that out in
case you are like wait how are you

216
00:12:00.340 --> 00:12:01.040
getting there.

217
00:12:01.040 --> 00:12:02.060
That's what I'm doing.

218
00:12:02.060 --> 00:12:06.860
So double clicking from here,
not in the new symbol.

219
00:12:06.860 --> 00:12:10.200
Here is my scaling and so
anything that I want to and

220
00:12:10.200 --> 00:12:15.940
it was already there but I just wanted to
kinda show you that you can designate.

221
00:12:15.940 --> 00:12:21.290
Don't scale inside here everything,
scale inside of here, sorry.

222
00:12:21.290 --> 00:12:24.017
Inside scale, outside of it,
don't scale, okay.

223
00:12:24.017 --> 00:12:24.660

00:15:49.215 --> 00:15:50.260
>> Mm-hm.

>> So if I take my square and

I backed it as just a straight

It's kinda like a clean slate,

00:16:24.490 --> 00:16:31.040
cuz I wanted to start over to show you

What happened is I had the fill selected,

00:16:46.432 --> 00:16:51.110
So [LAUGH] I had to kind of go back

00:16:51.110 --> 00:16:54.720

00:16:54.720 --> 00:16:58.770
So that's always just try to

All right, so I've got my square selected,

00:17:05.858 --> 00:17:07.726

00:17:07.726 --> 00:17:11.847
And it brings up the 3D Extrude and

00:17:11.847 --> 00:17:14.330

00:17:14.330 --> 00:17:19.250
And I'm going to turn on your preview so

00:17:19.250 --> 00:17:21.836
You have the Extruded Depth,

00:17:21.836 --> 00:17:28.280
how far back do I want to make this cube,

326
00:17:28.280 --> 00:17:33.871
So if I extend this, see, ooh,
I'm actually making a cube, right.

00:17:33.871 --> 00:17:35.054
Ooh, that's fun.

328
00:17:35.054 --> 00:17:40.035
All right, and I can go through and

00:17:40.035 --> 00:17:41.915
You see how it's see-through?

I have a cap versus no cap,

Keep that cap on.

How do you want it to bevel, the different

And it's really just start

334

I'm going to have none on this.

And it's oriented in this manner but
this guy right here,

this is where you're gonna

338
00:18:04.550 --> 00:18:06.660
Now you can change
the different angles and

339
00:18:06.660 --> 00:18:11.495
the perspective in the dialogue boxes but
I like to just kind of move it around.

340
00:18:11.495 --> 00:18:13.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so I take this and
