00:18:13.820 --> 00:18:18.372
you see how you hover,
you get different icons of

342
00:18:18.372 --> 00:18:23.367
being able to rotate it this way,
rotate it this way,

343
00:18:23.367 --> 00:18:27.824
okay, rotate there,
flip it around this way.

344
00:18:27.824 --> 00:18:32.507
So there's all sorts of ways that
you could go ahead and manuever and

345
00:18:32.507 --> 00:18:36.944
rotate this cube and this 3D effect
that you have going on here,

346
00:18:36.944 --> 00:18:41.570
cuz I want to kind of keep it like that,
and that looks pretty good.

347
00:18:41.570 --> 00:18:44.290
So I'm trying to move it around,
I realize that I'm in a dialogue box and

348
00:18:44.290 --> 00:18:45.465
it's not letting me do that.

349
00:18:45.465 --> 00:18:48.870
[LAUGH] All right, so
we've got that in your shading.

350

The other thing I wanted to

351

Like blocks, like building blocks,

352
00:18:57.344 --> 00:19:00.865
>> Letters on the different sides,
right, where a dice has numbers.

353
00:19:00.865 --> 00:19:05.640
>> Mm-hm, exactly, this is the place where
you could actually do this by mapping

354
00:19:05.640 --> 00:19:09.780
the artwork on the different sides,
and I have that preview still on.

355
00:19:09.780 --> 00:19:12.890
I'm starting to run out of

356
00:19:12.890 --> 00:19:17.590
You have the surfaces, and I probably
should not have had this as orange,

357
00:19:17.590 --> 00:19:18.440
this is the wrong color.

358
00:19:18.440 --> 00:19:24.585
But there's a red box that's
moving around that is showing me

359
00:19:24.585 --> 00:19:30.969
on my screen which side of this
six-sided cube that's actually

360
00:19:30.969 --> 00:19:36.422
letting me then add something
to that surface, okay.

361
00:19:36.422 --> 00:19:38.930
So I'm gonna pick this one of six.

362
00:19:38.930 --> 00:19:42.440
And again,
the red outlining will show you,

363
00:19:42.440 --> 00:19:44.980
not sure if you're
seeing it on the orange.

364
00:19:44.980 --> 00:19:46.400
It's connected to symbols.

365
00:19:46.400 --> 00:19:50.752
So going back to our symbols episode,
if you wanted specific things to

366
00:19:50.752 --> 00:19:55.619
map on those different sides of this cube
or this 3D artwork, you would have to

367
00:19:55.619 --> 00:19:59.930
create is a symbol first before you
went into the map artwork, okay.

368
00:19:59.930 --> 00:20:01.710
Now, I have some in here.

369
00:20:01.710 --> 00:20:04.355
Remember the flowers that we
had from our symbols episode.

370
00:20:04.355 --> 00:20:09.540
I went ahead and added these cuz I
wanted to make a cube of flowers.

371
00:20:09.540 --> 00:20:13.990
So if I choose the symbol, okay, and since
I got the preview on I could go ahead and

372
00:20:13.990 --> 00:20:16.270
change the size, I can move it around.

373
00:20:16.270 --> 00:20:20.150
The other neat thing is you can go ahead
and do Scale to Fit and it just scales

374
00:20:20.150 --> 00:20:25.470
the symbol to the size of that
surface of those 3D objects.

375
00:20:25.470 --> 00:20:26.010
>> Handy.

376
00:20:26.010 --> 00:20:27.940
>> It is, so then I kind of move around.

Let me go over to that one.

378

I know that's the left-hand side, and
then I go ahead and add another one and

scale to fit, okay.

380
00:20:36.290 --> 00:20:40.620
And then we can go to that one at the top,
and then I could go with the,

381
00:20:40.620 --> 00:20:41.540
which one do we have?

382
00:20:41.540 --> 00:20:42.230
There we go.

383
00:20:42.230 --> 00:20:47.396
And scale and so
you're actually creating a 3D surface with

384
00:20:47.396 --> 00:20:52.990
mapped artwork to the perspective
that it has in that 3D-ness.

385
00:20:52.990 --> 00:20:56.899
[LAUGH] I love this part too,
this invisible geometry.

386
00:20:56.899 --> 00:20:59.128
It's like don't even show
me the box around it.

387
00:20:59.128 --> 00:20:59.884
>> Wow.

388
00:20:59.884 --> 00:21:04.264
>> Yeah, so you can do some really neat

389
00:21:04.264 --> 00:21:09.374
things using 3D with this map artwork and

390
00:21:09.374 --> 00:21:14.365
this 3D effect, and it's just great.

391
00:21:14.365 --> 00:21:17.860
So I'm gonna take that off and
I'm gonna click OK,

392
00:21:17.860 --> 00:21:23.572
click OK again from mapping my artwork,
and look at that, a nice 3D looking cube.

393
00:21:23.572 --> 00:21:25.980
I just think it's a lot of fun.

394
00:21:25.980 --> 00:21:27.160
>> That is very cool.

395
00:21:27.160 --> 00:21:32.080
>> So 3D extrude and
bevel is just one of the effects you can

396
00:21:32.080 --> 00:21:37.326
apply to any of your vector shapes or
really, your images.

397
00:21:37.326 --> 00:21:40.926
Now, I wouldn't necessarily do 3D

398
00:21:40.926 --> 00:21:43.571
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz that would look a little strange,

399
00:21:43.571 --> 00:21:47.340
but it's really about just getting in,
and figuring it out and playing.

400
00:21:47.340 --> 00:21:48.960
Because we didn't go
through all the effects.

401
00:21:48.960 --> 00:21:51.430
There's a bunch of them in here, okay.

402
00:21:51.430 --> 00:21:54.220
I'm not gonna show you every single
one of them because that would take

403
00:21:54.220 --> 00:21:55.840
forever, okay.

404
00:21:55.840 --> 00:21:58.880
I do like drop shadows, so I will tell you
what a drop shadow is because I'm always

405
00:21:58.880 --> 00:21:59.780
looking for a drop shadow.

406
00:21:59.780 --> 00:22:02.820
That's in the stylized effect, but

407
00:22:02.820 --> 00:22:07.495
again, knowing the concept of
where this is coming from,

408
00:22:07.495 --> 00:22:11.220
what's an effect,
where does it go in the Appearance panel.

409
00:22:11.220 --> 00:22:13.330
What does the Appearance panel let me do?

410
00:22:13.330 --> 00:22:15.020
How can I modify things?

411
00:22:15.020 --> 00:22:16.955
How can I then take the appearances and

412
00:22:16.955 --> 00:22:19.387
make it into a style where
the style is library?

413
00:22:19.387 --> 00:22:22.380
It all kind of, it does blend together.

414
00:22:22.380 --> 00:22:27.750
Like I was saying in the beginning is that
there's separate places in Illustrator,

415
00:22:27.750 --> 00:22:29.860
but they all work together.

416
00:22:29.860 --> 00:22:34.310
So just get into those effects, just start
clicking on stuff, just modify it in

417
00:22:34.310 --> 00:22:40.270
the Appearance panel and you can just go
crazy with them and it's lots of fun.

418
00:22:40.270 --> 00:22:41.200
>> Fantastic.

419
00:22:41.200 --> 00:22:44.020
Love it, Vonne, great look at

420
00:22:44.020 --> 00:22:48.540
We can modify the appearance and
we can create those graphic styles and

421
00:22:48.540 --> 00:22:51.790
apply them to our objects
within our Illustrator project.

422
00:22:51.790 --> 00:22:52.900
So we thank you for that.

423
00:22:52.900 --> 00:22:54.750
We hope everybody out

episodes.title: Perspective Grid
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.105 --> 00:00:15.870
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.870 --> 00:00:19.430
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:19.430 --> 00:00:23.680
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be taking a look at

5
00:00:23.680 --> 00:00:28.310
perspective grid,
which is a grid that gives us perspective.

6
00:00:28.310 --> 00:00:32.320
Okay, there's a little bit more to it than
that and thankfully, Miss Vaughn is here

7
00:00:32.320 --> 00:00:35.030
to help us understand what its
gonna do and what it can do for us.

8
00:00:35.030 --> 00:00:35.860
So how you doing Vaughn?

9
00:00:35.860 --> 00:00:36.620
>> Great.

10
00:00:36.620 --> 00:00:39.270
I hope to explain it a little
bit better that that.

11
00:00:39.270 --> 00:00:41.420
But honestly you're not that far off.

12
00:00:41.420 --> 00:00:41.990
>> Alright.

13
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:44.525
>> It is a grid that gives us perspective.

14
00:00:44.525 --> 00:00:46.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that we draw on the grid.

15
00:00:46.600 --> 00:00:47.200
>> And wrap.

16
00:00:47.200 --> 00:00:48.330
That's the show.

17
00:00:48.330 --> 00:00:49.030
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

18
00:00:49.030 --> 00:00:50.001
End scene.

19
00:00:50.001 --> 00:00:52.160
[LAUGH] No we have a little bit more for
you there.

20
00:00:52.160 --> 00:00:56.300
I'll give you a few more details on
how to actually work the prospective

21
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:59.129
grade tool and
the perspective selection tool,

22
00:00:59.129 --> 00:01:02.030
why, how and
all the wonderful nuances about it.

23
00:01:02.030 --> 00:01:03.100
>> And tell me again,

24
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:06.680
perspective, what do we mean by
perspective when working with this stuff?

25
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:07.950
>> Exactly.
So, so

26
00:01:07.950 --> 00:01:14.250
far we've been creating things on a flat
surface, like anything that's just there.

27
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:16.024
That's a [CROSSTALK] descriptions right?

28
00:01:16.024 --> 00:01:20.091
>> More like your typical newspaper or
a flat brochure or something.

29
00:01:20.091 --> 00:01:21.278
>> Correct.
>> Not a lot of depth to it.

30
00:01:21.278 --> 00:01:24.980
>> Yes, and what you get with
a perspective is, there's something called

31
00:01:24.980 --> 00:01:29.048
a vanishing point to where you can see
something off in the distance and it's not

32
00:01:29.048 --> 00:01:32.890
just where it's flat and straight,
you actually see the perspective.

33
00:01:32.890 --> 00:01:36.151
It's 3D, it's a 3D depth perception,
if you want to say.

34
00:01:36.151 --> 00:01:38.200
>> I always think of the railroad tracks,
right?

35
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:41.760
If you're standing on railroad tracks and
you're looking down.

36
00:01:41.760 --> 00:01:44.199
It's not two lines that runs
on forever and ever, right?

37
00:01:44.199 --> 00:01:46.720
>> Mm-hm.
>> They kinda go together way out there

38
00:01:46.720 --> 00:01:47.795
in the distance.

39
00:01:47.795 --> 00:01:50.890
>> Mm-hm, they start like this,
and they come to a point and

40
00:01:50.890 --> 00:01:54.520
that's what they called the vanishing
point in 3D perspective.

41
00:01:54.520 --> 00:02:01.600
So you can create what looks like
3D-ness with certain shading.

42
00:02:01.600 --> 00:02:05.260
You could take a circle, and
if you use gradients the right way,

43
00:02:05.260 --> 00:02:08.930
you can make it look
like an actual sphere.

44
00:02:08.930 --> 00:02:12.510
Like there is actual body to it,
it's not just a flat surface.

45
00:02:12.510 --> 00:02:17.560
You can do that with just regular shapes,
and coloring with gradients, and

46
00:02:17.560 --> 00:02:18.250
so on and so forth.

47
00:02:18.250 --> 00:02:23.340
But this particular tool is where
you actually have a grid that is in

48
00:02:23.340 --> 00:02:27.940
a perspective and then you add things on
to it and it keeps it in that perspective.

49
00:02:27.940 --> 00:02:29.510
>> Yeah, it's pretty cool, so.

50
00:02:29.510 --> 00:02:35.020
Cuz we had done some 3D effects when
we were in the effects section, and we

51
00:02:35.020 --> 00:02:40.140
did some mapping where we put some artwork
on a cube, put some flowers on there.

52
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:43.920
So it can be similar to that,
but again, it's similar yet

53
00:02:43.920 --> 00:02:45.101
different, my favorite saying.

54
00:02:45.101 --> 00:02:46.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because it's a completely

55
00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:47.740
different tool.

56
00:02:47.740 --> 00:02:52.300
So let's go ahead and go into my
little notes section of this document.

57
00:02:52.300 --> 00:02:54.290
I just wanted to throw
some things in there.

58
00:02:54.290 --> 00:02:55.000
Which it says,

59
00:02:55.000 --> 00:03:00.070
well you have two main tools in your tool
panel that you're going to be using.

60
00:03:00.070 --> 00:03:02.370
You're going to use
the perspective grid tool,

61
00:03:02.370 --> 00:03:04.090
where it actually just puts it on there.

62
00:03:04.090 --> 00:03:06.770
And once you choose
a perspective grid tool.

63
00:03:06.770 --> 00:03:08.430
That's going to be a mouthful
throughout this episode.

64
00:03:08.430 --> 00:03:09.773
>> It is.
>> I can already feel it.

65
00:03:09.773 --> 00:03:11.261
>> PGT can we just call it that?

66
00:03:11.261 --> 00:03:13.601
>> We can do the PGT, okay.

67
00:03:13.601 --> 00:03:14.614
I'll probably mess that one up too.

68
00:03:14.614 --> 00:03:18.685
[LAUGH] So once you get the PGT tool,
it makes the grid.

69
00:03:18.685 --> 00:03:20.660
Like you don't have any like backtrack.

70
00:03:20.660 --> 00:03:23.800
There's no undo, and that's something
that would always throw me off.

71
00:03:23.800 --> 00:03:25.150
Can I make that go away?

72
00:03:25.150 --> 00:03:31.920
You can hide it and not adhere to the
grid, but you can't really undo adding it.

73
00:03:31.920 --> 00:03:34.700
It's kind of strange, but
again, hide it, don't use it,

74
00:03:34.700 --> 00:03:36.050
it's like it was never there anyways.

75
00:03:37.200 --> 00:03:41.770
And then making sure that once you start
adding things onto your perspective grid,

76
00:03:41.770 --> 00:03:45.690
you have to make sure you use
the perspective selection tool,

77
00:03:45.690 --> 00:03:46.560
the PS tool [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

78
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:48.820
>> Because that's where if you don't use

79
00:03:48.820 --> 00:03:54.080
that PS tool and you use the regular
selection tool, which I've kind of

80
00:03:54.080 --> 00:03:56.640
drilled into your brains like
always go back to that black arrow.

81
00:03:56.640 --> 00:03:58.330
It's where you have to
go back to the black.

82
00:03:58.330 --> 00:04:02.690
Well, that's where you actually
need to go to the perspective

83
00:04:02.690 --> 00:04:05.450
selection tool to make sure you're
keeping that because if you don't,

84
00:04:05.450 --> 00:04:07.980
it goes somewhere different
we're demonstrating.

85
00:04:07.980 --> 00:04:09.230
The other main points.

86
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:12.690
You go to the View menu because that's
where you can show and hide and

87
00:04:12.690 --> 00:04:17.780
change your presets for the actual
grids that are on your document.

88
00:04:18.920 --> 00:04:22.670
And then there's something, there's this
little box at the top once you start

89
00:04:22.670 --> 00:04:28.050
getting into the perspective grid
of which grid you want to be on or

90
00:04:28.050 --> 00:04:30.810
have active when you add items to it.

91
00:04:30.810 --> 00:04:34.140
So that's something that
you need to be aware of and

92
00:04:34.140 --> 00:04:38.330
understand that when you're editing or
moving from within the grid using

93
00:04:38.330 --> 00:04:43.180
the perspective grid tool, and how you can
use your hot keys to flip back and forth.

94
00:04:43.180 --> 00:04:46.480
And you can always drag
items that you've created

95
00:04:46.480 --> 00:04:51.830
off the grid to pull them into the grid
to make them come into perspective.

96
00:04:51.830 --> 00:04:58.250
And you cannot add images, or raster
images directly to a perspective grid.

97

00:15:52.234 --> 00:15:53.881
>> And again turn it back on.

325
00:15:53.881 --> 00:15:55.898
The snap to the grid is by default.

326
00:15:55.898 --> 00:16:00.275
I would like to go ahead and
point this lock station point.

327
00:16:00.275 --> 00:16:03.570
Okay, and
let me demonstrate it without it on first.

328
00:16:03.570 --> 00:16:07.410
Because if I come back over here and
I've drawn this and I think it's great,

329
00:16:07.410 --> 00:16:11.760
but now I realize I need to basically
change the angle of the building.

330
00:16:11.760 --> 00:16:12.415
I need to change.

331
00:16:12.415 --> 00:16:13.595
The vantage point.

332
00:16:15.045 --> 00:16:17.545
You do that with
the perspective grid tool.

333
00:16:17.545 --> 00:16:20.305
The perspective grid modifies the grid.

334
00:16:20.305 --> 00:16:22.995
So come back over here and
I'm just going to move this over, and

335
00:16:22.995 --> 00:16:27.350
you can see that the building that
is attached to it doesn't move.

336
00:16:27.350 --> 00:16:31.730
Okay, by default, because it just doesn't.

337
00:16:31.730 --> 00:16:35.220
You could come back and
draw one thing in one perspective.

338
00:16:35.220 --> 00:16:36.170
Say, okay, I'm done.

339
00:16:36.170 --> 00:16:39.010
Come back, go to the perspective grid,
put another perspective, so

340
00:16:39.010 --> 00:16:40.160
you can do some really cool things.

341
00:16:40.160 --> 00:16:42.000
>> You can do some Escher-like stuff and

342
00:16:42.000 --> 00:16:44.290
have different perspectives
on the same drawing.

343
00:16:44.290 --> 00:16:46.630
>> Exactly, yeah,
you can do some really neat stuff.

344
00:16:46.630 --> 00:16:48.088
So you might want to do that by default.

345
00:16:48.088 --> 00:16:50.340
You know by, on purpose.

346
00:16:50.340 --> 00:16:53.770
I want to move this and
not have anything stay with it, but

347
00:16:53.770 --> 00:16:58.180
in this example I do want to
the building to move with me.

348
00:16:59.200 --> 00:17:01.880
So that's where,
if you go to the view menu and

349
00:17:01.880 --> 00:17:03.780
you go to that lock station point.

350
00:17:03.780 --> 00:17:08.460
And this only changes the perspective,
sorry the vanishing point, my bad,

351
00:17:08.460 --> 00:17:13.100
it won't change, see if I swing
the gate open that's not gonna change.

352
00:17:13.100 --> 00:17:18.590
But if I change this guy,
do you see how now everything shifts?

353
00:17:18.590 --> 00:17:20.130
So, if you move the vanishing point.

354
00:17:20.130 --> 00:17:21.030
I keep saying that.

355
00:17:21.030 --> 00:17:22.630
Yes, I said it right, actually.

356
00:17:22.630 --> 00:17:24.520
>> Yeah.
>> If you move the vanishing point,

357
00:17:24.520 --> 00:17:30.990
it will move everything with you if
you have that lock point on, okay?

358
00:17:30.990 --> 00:17:32.990
Not the gates, but the vanishing point.

359
00:17:32.990 --> 00:17:34.550
And I know gates is not
the technical word, but,

360
00:17:34.550 --> 00:17:36.365
to me,
it's the easiest way to describe it, okay?

361
00:17:36.365 --> 00:17:38.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I think that's pretty neat.

362
00:17:38.860 --> 00:17:40.560
>> That is.
>> That can really help you.

363
00:17:40.560 --> 00:17:42.615
>> You could really get creative
with something like that.

364
00:17:42.615 --> 00:17:43.440
>> Mm-hm, yeah.

365
00:17:43.440 --> 00:17:46.380
Just draw a grid, move it over.

366
00:17:46.380 --> 00:17:50.690
I can see things in my brain,
like different advertisers or

367
00:17:50.690 --> 00:17:51.600
different art pieces.

368
00:17:51.600 --> 00:17:52.720
We're like, that's really cool.

369
00:17:52.720 --> 00:17:54.895
We could do that in illustrator.

370
00:17:54.895 --> 00:17:57.530
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's pretty neat, and

371
00:17:57.530 --> 00:18:01.600
I guess that the last thing
that I wanted to review.

372
00:18:01.600 --> 00:18:05.720
Since I put it in my notes,
was how to get that image in there.

373
00:18:05.720 --> 00:18:08.720
I wanna put a picture or
a poster off to the side.

374
00:18:08.720 --> 00:18:10.864
>> Normally, it does not go to the grid.

375
00:18:10.864 --> 00:18:11.940
>> Correct.
>> It's a raster.

376
00:18:11.940 --> 00:18:14.910
>> Yeah and actually that does
remind me that I missed one other

377
00:18:14.910 --> 00:18:18.370
point of dragging something into
the grid after it's not in there.

378
00:18:18.370 --> 00:18:21.505
So, let me give you two more points.

379
00:18:21.505 --> 00:18:23.210
[LAUGH] So the image part.

380
00:18:23.210 --> 00:18:25.585
Let me back up and
talk about drawing things or

381
00:18:25.585 --> 00:18:28.599
adding things into the grid
that's not in perspective.

382
00:18:28.599 --> 00:18:34.320
All right, so,
here I've got the little control guide.

383
00:18:34.320 --> 00:18:36.600
Oops, I need to go ahead and
get the right tool.

384
00:18:37.620 --> 00:18:38.275
There it is, sorry.

385
00:18:38.275 --> 00:18:40.910
[LAUGH] That is the blend tool,
where am I going?

386
00:18:40.910 --> 00:18:41.610
All right, here we go.

387
00:18:41.610 --> 00:18:46.220
All right, so I have decided that I
do not want anything in, on the grid,

388
00:18:46.220 --> 00:18:50.910
because I want to add maybe a cloud or
some text.

389
00:18:50.910 --> 00:18:54.160
Maybe I'll say hello.

390
00:18:54.160 --> 00:18:55.060
There we go.

391
00:18:55.060 --> 00:18:57.009
And then maybe I'll draw like a square.

392
00:18:58.200 --> 00:19:02.150
All right, because I chose that I did
not want that to be in perspective.

393
00:19:02.150 --> 00:19:04.310
I want it just flat, okay.

394
00:19:04.310 --> 00:19:09.300
But then, I realize that actually I really
do want to have that in perspective.

395
00:19:09.300 --> 00:19:10.820
Sorry, I'm just making this bigger so
you can see it.

396
00:19:12.130 --> 00:19:16.820
So that's where you take
the perspective selection tool.

397
00:19:16.820 --> 00:19:19.190
We grab any of these items and.

398
00:19:19.190 --> 00:19:23.400
I do have to indicate a plane, I just
realized that, that I need to go ahead and

399
00:19:23.400 --> 00:19:24.000
add that one.

400
00:19:24.000 --> 00:19:27.390
So I'm on the left plane cuz I want
to add the word hello on to the left.

401
00:19:27.390 --> 00:19:29.970
So I take this and I just drag it in.

402
00:19:29.970 --> 00:19:31.420
So you see how it actually kind of flips.

403
00:19:31.420 --> 00:19:33.385
>> You can almost see as soon as you
>> You selected it,

404
00:19:33.385 --> 00:19:35.605
the bounding box-
>> Mm-hm.

405
00:19:35.605 --> 00:19:37.095
>> Will actually already snap to the grid.

406
00:19:37.095 --> 00:19:37.615
>> Correct.

407
00:19:37.615 --> 00:19:39.665
Yeah, so it's like, okay, there we go.

408
00:19:39.665 --> 00:19:44.635
And now, here we go, I'm in perspective,
I've added it into that plane.

409
00:19:44.635 --> 00:19:47.730
Okay, so
that's where It's not in perspective,

410
00:19:47.730 --> 00:19:52.940
grab it in, select PS tool,
perspective selection tool, pick the grid.

411
00:19:52.940 --> 00:19:57.880
So if I wanted to take this guy I'll go
ahead and flip it onto the right grid,

412
00:19:57.880 --> 00:20:00.600
because I have to always go back and
indicate which grid I want

413
00:20:00.600 --> 00:20:04.910
to go with first, and
I just drag it in and I can go like so.

414
00:20:04.910 --> 00:20:10.110
So if you forget to put in
you can put it in later.

415
00:20:10.110 --> 00:20:14.100
And that's where in here if I
tried to take this image and drag.

416
00:20:14.100 --> 00:20:15.610
It saying it won't even let me.

417
00:20:15.610 --> 00:20:17.610
>> Yeah.
>> It's saying nope, you cannot do that.

418
00:20:17.610 --> 00:20:21.010
>> And before you get to that image one
more question for you, so we can drag

419
00:20:21.010 --> 00:20:25.665
things into the grid with that perspective
selection tool, if I got that right.

420
00:20:25.665 --> 00:20:28.475
>> Uh-huh.
>> What if I decide now that I dont want

421
00:20:28.475 --> 00:20:30.627
that in perspective anymore?

422
00:20:30.627 --> 00:20:36.300
Cuz you said one, two, three from my
number is four though outer ring or?

423
00:20:36.300 --> 00:20:41.430
>> Well yes, you can take it
out of the perspective grid.

424
00:20:41.430 --> 00:20:45.380
What it means, I can just take
it out on the block air tool.

425
00:20:45.380 --> 00:20:47.440
If I just add the block air tool and
move this.

426
00:20:47.440 --> 00:20:51.250
I mean, it's not gonna stay on
perspective and then I can go back and

427
00:20:51.250 --> 00:20:52.600
use like the anchor.

428
00:20:52.600 --> 00:20:58.340
>> The white arrow tool and now,
it just looks like a regular

429
00:20:58.340 --> 00:21:02.970
square and honestly, it might just be
easier to just to delete it cuz you might.

430
00:21:02.970 --> 00:21:06.790
When you go out of perspective,
you want it to stay flat again.

431
00:21:06.790 --> 00:21:09.800
You want it to go flat like
a regular square, but here it.

432
00:21:09.800 --> 00:21:12.750
>> It's not gonna magically lose
the perspective or that twist and

433
00:21:12.750 --> 00:21:14.870
shape that it got when we
put it in perspective, so

434
00:21:14.870 --> 00:21:16.990
you might as well just start
with a nice square again.

435
00:21:16.990 --> 00:21:18.080
>> Yeah, that's what I would say.

436
00:21:18.080 --> 00:21:18.950
I think it would be easier.

437
00:21:18.950 --> 00:21:22.480
So, I mean, you can do that or
you could, you could also,

438
00:21:22.480 --> 00:21:27.710
here let me back up a little bit, I mean,
you could take this and you could cut it.

439
00:21:27.710 --> 00:21:32.680
You could come over to your perspective
grid tool or perspective selection and

440
00:21:32.680 --> 00:21:34.540
say no grid and then paste it.

441
00:21:34.540 --> 00:21:36.950
So now, it's just in nowhere land.

442
00:21:36.950 --> 00:21:38.480
Whoops, I'm using the same tool.

443
00:21:38.480 --> 00:21:39.570
You know what?

444
00:21:39.570 --> 00:21:42.004
Just delete it and
just put it back in the regular world.

445
00:21:42.004 --> 00:21:42.610
>> I like that idea.
>> Yeah,

446
00:21:42.610 --> 00:21:44.250
I think that's really the easiest way.

447
00:21:44.250 --> 00:21:48.210
Because it really,
again it's just a shape that has certain

448
00:21:48.210 --> 00:21:51.690
points in a certain way that makes
it appear like it's in perspective.

449
00:21:51.690 --> 00:21:52.982
So I would say that.

450
00:21:52.982 --> 00:21:54.875
>> All right, so let's see what
we can do with that picture.

451
00:21:54.875 --> 00:21:55.690
>> All right.

452
00:21:55.690 --> 00:21:59.790
So we can go ahead and
we can try to drag this in,

453
00:21:59.790 --> 00:22:02.300
it's gonna, I'm back to the PS tool.

454
00:22:02.300 --> 00:22:03.230
Won't let me do it.

455
00:22:03.230 --> 00:22:06.200
It's like nope, you can not drag it,
like I dragged in the text or

456
00:22:06.200 --> 00:22:10.810
I dragged in that square, right?

457
00:22:10.810 --> 00:22:12.950
But you can do it in a weird way.

458
00:22:12.950 --> 00:22:16.390
Now one thing you have to do is you
have to have the image embedded,

459
00:22:16.390 --> 00:22:17.215
it can not be linked.

460
00:22:17.215 --> 00:22:18.302
Okay.

461
00:22:18.302 --> 00:22:23.644
And, you take your regular selection too,
not the perspective selection.

462
00:22:23.644 --> 00:22:25.628
And you take your regular selection,

463
00:22:25.628 --> 00:22:28.920
you make sure that the image is
behind the object that you want.

464
00:22:28.920 --> 00:22:30.440
It's basically like a clipping mask,
really.

465
00:22:30.440 --> 00:22:31.020
>> Mm.

466
00:22:31.020 --> 00:22:32.880
>> Remember doing
clipping masks in images?

467
00:22:32.880 --> 00:22:36.880
So you're making a clipping mask but
you don't use the clipping mask command.

468
00:22:36.880 --> 00:22:42.410
You have to use this envelope
distort make with top object.

469
00:22:42.410 --> 00:22:43.110
Okay, yeah.

470
00:22:43.110 --> 00:22:45.850
It's a weirder one, but it works.

471
00:22:45.850 --> 00:22:46.550
Okay.

472
00:22:46.550 --> 00:22:48.030
So I'm back in my black arrow tool.

473
00:22:48.030 --> 00:22:51.250
I'm gonna take this image and
I'm gonna put it right here.

474
00:22:51.250 --> 00:22:56.030
Now I know it's gonna be in the front
because I did it that way, so

475
00:22:56.030 --> 00:22:58.470
I'm going to go ahead and
arrange and sent to back.

476
00:22:58.470 --> 00:23:02.400
Just like it's all the way in the back,
but I still have it selected,

477
00:23:02.400 --> 00:23:03.400
I can see the frame.

478
00:23:03.400 --> 00:23:04.620
You know what I did?

479
00:23:04.620 --> 00:23:05.420
I forgot to embed it.

480
00:23:05.420 --> 00:23:06.950
Let me go ahead and
embed that really quickly.

481
00:23:06.950 --> 00:23:08.680
So, all right.

482
00:23:08.680 --> 00:23:10.065
Gotta embed first sorry.

483
00:23:10.065 --> 00:23:12.260
[LAUGH] Well that's a quick step so
there we go.

484
00:23:12.260 --> 00:23:13.700
So I have it selected it still.

485
00:23:13.700 --> 00:23:17.010
I'm gonna hold my shift key and
I'm gonna select that square right here.

486
00:23:17.010 --> 00:23:20.430
So I know I have those two items
selected that there's the image and

487
00:23:20.430 --> 00:23:22.600
the square that I want it to show through.

488
00:23:22.600 --> 00:23:24.260
And then,
I'm gonna go to that object menu.

489
00:23:24.260 --> 00:23:28.610
I'm gonna go to envelope distort,
and I'm gonna make with top object.

490
00:23:28.610 --> 00:23:30.000
And then, poof!

491
00:23:30.000 --> 00:23:30.740
There you go.

492
00:23:30.740 --> 00:23:33.980
So you can have the picture
in perspective.

493
00:23:33.980 --> 00:23:36.830
You just have to skirt along the edges.

494
00:23:36.830 --> 00:23:40.080
>> So the key there is you wanna make sure
it was embedded, put it out there and

495
00:23:40.080 --> 00:23:42.130
make sure it's behind everything.

496
00:23:42.130 --> 00:23:44.350
And then, with the picture still selected,

497
00:23:44.350 --> 00:23:48.015
select the shape that you
wanted to conform to as well.

498
00:23:48.015 --> 00:23:49.730
>> Uh-huh.
>> So you had them both selected when you

499
00:23:49.730 --> 00:23:50.530
did that last step.

500
00:23:50.530 --> 00:23:53.040
>> Yes, it's just like when
you create a clipping mask.

501
00:23:53.040 --> 00:23:57.930
You have the image underneath the frame
that you want to clip it into,

502
00:23:57.930 --> 00:24:01.410
so the stacking order and
then just make with envelope to store it.

503
00:24:01.410 --> 00:24:04.450
Now you can't really move it.

504
00:24:04.450 --> 00:24:08.462
If I try to use that perspective selection
tool, it's not gonna let me move it, so

505
00:24:08.462 --> 00:24:10.746
it's like it's kind of
fixated in its place.

506
00:24:10.746 --> 00:24:14.910
So if you don't like it,
you basically have to back up.

507
00:24:14.910 --> 00:24:16.270
You have to undo and keep going.

508
00:24:16.270 --> 00:24:21.120
Now you can go back to the black arrow
tool, the regular selection tool, and

509
00:24:21.120 --> 00:24:26.320
you can select that Item,
cuz it is showing up here in the control

510
00:24:26.320 --> 00:24:30.200
panel that it is an envelope top.

511
00:24:30.200 --> 00:24:33.740
So I can go back to envelope distort and

512
00:24:33.740 --> 00:24:38.890
release it, and then it's gonna release.

513
00:24:38.890 --> 00:24:42.470
It's going to say I'm not going to conform
to what you are telling me to do anymore,

514
00:24:42.470 --> 00:24:43.750
and then you can move on from there.

515
00:24:43.750 --> 00:24:46.490
So, yeah little trick,
and that's where it is.

516
00:24:46.490 --> 00:24:49.410
So you can drag things into perspective.

517
00:24:49.410 --> 00:24:53.580
You can kind of drag things out,
really just delete them.

518
00:24:53.580 --> 00:24:56.714
Hide or show the grid,
create the grid, and

519
00:24:56.714 --> 00:25:00.204
do some fun stuff with drawing and
perspective.

520
00:25:00.204 --> 00:25:02.710
So that is your 3D drawing.

521
00:25:02.710 --> 00:25:03.700
>> Fantastic, Vonne.

522
00:25:03.700 --> 00:25:05.390
Thank you for those great demonstrations.

523
00:25:05.390 --> 00:25:08.650
Really cool, look at what we can
do with that perspective grid.

524
00:25:08.650 --> 00:25:12.820
Be able to draw and
give it that perception of depth, right?

525
00:25:12.820 --> 00:25:15.310
And give it that look of 3D.

526
00:25:15.310 --> 00:25:16.290
I love it.

527
00:25:16.290 --> 00:25:17.070
Fantastic.

528
00:25:17.070 --> 00:25:21.580
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching,
signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

529
00:25:21.580 --> 00:25:22.450
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

530
00:25:22.450 --> 00:25:24.484
>> And we'll see you next time.

531
00:25:24.484 --> 00:25:32.700
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Export for Web and Print
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.329 --> 00:00:15.560
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.560 --> 00:00:20.630
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing Adobe Illustrator CC 2015.

4
00:00:20.630 --> 00:00:24.568
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna learn how to export for

5
00:00:24.568 --> 00:00:26.350
both web and print, all right?

6
00:00:26.350 --> 00:00:29.830
We've spent a lot of time getting our
document ready, we've learned all about

7
00:00:29.830 --> 00:00:34.230
fonts and colors, and swatches, and
gradients, and curves, and perspective

8
00:00:34.230 --> 00:00:38.920
grids and more things than I can even
remember but now what do we do, right?

9
00:00:38.920 --> 00:00:42.800
We're done, we've got to either
turn it in to our customer or

10
00:00:42.800 --> 00:00:44.340
send it off to the printer.

11
00:00:44.340 --> 00:00:45.350
How do we do that?

12
00:00:45.350 --> 00:00:47.830
Here, luckily for us,
Vonne is here to show us the way.

13
00:00:47.830 --> 00:00:50.030
How are you doing, Vonne?
>> Hi, I'm good.

14
00:00:50.030 --> 00:00:55.090
Ready to show you how to finalize
everything because you get all into,

15
00:00:55.090 --> 00:00:56.230
what am I going to create,

16
00:00:56.230 --> 00:01:01.050
but the final step is actually one
of the most important ones and

17
00:01:01.050 --> 00:01:06.340
it's really important that it goes
back to the basics of graphic design.

18
00:01:06.340 --> 00:01:10.500
I feel like it's Graphics 101,
what are your file types,

19
00:01:10.500 --> 00:01:14.380
what do they support, where am I going,
what do I need to have for

20
00:01:14.380 --> 00:01:18.910
my resolution, and my color mode, and
if you understand that at its core,

21
00:01:18.910 --> 00:01:23.850
then the steps to get it into
that is actually pretty simple.

22
00:01:23.850 --> 00:01:27.010
So I've given you,
I've got a little roadmap.

23
00:01:27.010 --> 00:01:30.510
Okay, my little matrix and schematics.

24
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:35.790
So we always start with our .AI file,
so if I'm going to

25
00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:41.090
create my logo in Illustrator,
